Producer Person Video Movie producer costume designer Pamela Norris  Cliff Chally aka name birth name birth date 'Paul Clay (I)' (qv) (June 1989 - November 2008) (divorced); 2 children Norris began her writing career in the series Saturday Night Live from 1980-84, receiving an Emmy nomination for her writing. She then moved on to write episodes for the series It's Your Move, Gimme A Break, and Remington Steele before co-writing the screenplay for Troop Beverly Hills. She then became producer and writer for the series Designing Women, for which she received three more Emmy nominations. She also produced episodes of the series Hearts Afire, Mad About You,The Huntress, Emeril, and The Simple Life (also creator). Norris returned to writing, penning a 2010 episode of Ghost Whisperer. Episode Series Cinematographer Writer actor writer Jack Wagner   Susan Wald name 'TV Guide' (USA), 18 July 2004, Vol. 52, Iss. 29, pg. 30-32, by: Margy Rochlin, 'Diane Clehane, Ron LaFranco, Cathy Piedmont' Attended University of Arizona, Tucson 'TV-Maailma' (Finland), 10 December 2004, Iss. 50, pg. 4, by: Minna Kontkanen, 'Laulava saippuaveteraani' (2000) TV commercial: Forever White Wagner, Peter John 3 October 1959 (2003) Joined the cast of _'The Bold and the Beautiful' (1987)_ (qv) as lost Sea Captain Dominick Payne Born in Washington, Missouri, the son of Peter Wagner, a car salesman who died in 1990, and his wife, Scotty, he took up golf at age 10 and spent his teen years planning on becoming a pro. Performing on stage was just an extracurricular activity for him at the local St. Gertrude School though he won raves. 'He has always been an entertainer', says his friend Jim Powers, a former teacher at St. Gertrude who is now his personal manager. 'He was really a leader of the school'. After attending the University of Missouri for a year and winning the state golf championship, he applied for a golf scholarship to the University of Arizona in 1980. 'Fifty young guys all thought they were going to be 'Jack Nicklaus' (qv)', he says. He lost out. In frustration, he auditioned for the drama program and won a full scholarship. From that point on, golf took second place. 'I decided that I have much more control over what I do on stage', says Jack, 'than whether or not my golf ball goes out-of-bounds when it hits a tree'. The day after graduating in 1982, Wagner drove to Los Angeles, where he found work as a tour guide at Universal Studios while auditioning for parts. After a brief stint in the short lived cable-TV soap _'A New Day in Eden' (1982)_ (qv), he won the role of 'Frisco Jones' on _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv). Jack Wagner 'TV Guide' (USA), 5 July 2003, Vol. 51, Iss. 27, pg. 34, by: Michael Logan, 'Wagner Unplugged' 'Soap Opera Digest' (USA), 26 March 1985, Vol. 10, Iss. 7 Jack P. Wagner Washington, Missouri, USA Male Susan Wald

'TV Guide' (USA), 31 May 2003, Vol. 51, Iss. 22, pg. 42, by: Michael Logan, 'Here Comes Trouble' King, Theodore William 1 October 1965 (April 2005) Has signed a new contract with _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv), ending rumors he was planning to leave the show. Ted King was raised in Maryland, California and New York. He attended the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University where he studied film direction. King co-founded the Portal Theatre Company in New York City and has been a strong presence in New York Theatre for several years. King worked as a film and video editor before landing his first leading acting role. Episode Series Cinematographer Writer actor writer   Susan Wald Maurice Benard gender trivia nick names spouse quotes birth notes aka name birth name where now mini biography magazine cover photo height Susan Wald 'Paula Smith (I)' (qv) (11 August 1990 - present); 4 children Enjoys Martial Arts and Boxing. 'I was told directors wouldn't hire me. They'd think I'd go crazy on the set. What's more important - directors or producers who might not cast me becuase they're ignorant, or helping people? So that's what I've been doing.' - speaking publicly about his bipolar disorder. Morales, Mauricio Jose Mo (November 2004) Recently signed on for 4 more years with General Hospital, so he will be there at least till 2008 Daytime Emmy Award winning Actor Maurice Benard joined the cast of General Hospital in the role of Sonny Corinthos in August 1993. He briefly left the show for a year-long hiatus in December 1998. For his portrayal, Mr. Benard received the Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in 2003. He was also nominated in 1996, 1997, 2004, 2006 and 2011.  Mr. Benard's multi-cultural upbringing began in San Francisco, where he was born to parents from Nicaragua and San Salvador. Uninspired by the traditional education route, he gleaned an education in the open job market after high school. He began modeling in his early twenties. Following that, Mr. Benard took up acting in numerous theatrical productions in the Bay area.  After auditioning for a role on the ABC drama All My Children, Mr. Benard was cast as Nico Kelly. Two years later, he struck out to find new challenges and moved to Los Angeles, where he was cast as the lead in the much-publicized TV movie, Lucy and Desi: Before the Laughter. He later added a pivotal role in the feature film Ruby to several other prominent film and television credits.  Mr. Benard has been a popular voice in the battle against bipolar disorder. He has been very open about his personal battle with the illness, appearing on television programs such as The View, Entertainment Tonight, and Oprah. He has been featured in People and LA Life Magazines. He also began working with the National Mental Health Association (NMHA) on the 'Bipolar Disorder: Do You Know It?' campaign to help educate Americans about the importance of recognizing the signs and symptoms of bipolar disorder. Maurice Benard 'Soap Opera Digest' (USA), 19 September 2000 Mauricio Jose Morales 5' 9' Martinez, California, USA Male

Series Character Writer actress writer Tina Fey   'The Independent Arts & Books' (UK), 19 March 2010, Iss. 7305, pg. 12 - 13, by: Gill Pringle, 'From spoofer to movie stardom' 'Jeff Richmond (II)' (qv) (3 June 2001 - present); 2 children Recipient of the 2010 Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, given annually by the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Mary Tyler Moore was a working woman whose story lines were not always about dating and men. They were about work friendships and relationships, which is what I feel my adult life has mostly been about. (2012) Print ads for Garnier's Nutrisse Nourishing Color Creme hair color. Fey, Elizabeth Stamatina Tina Fey. _Bossypants._ New York: Reagan Arthur Books, 2011. ISBN 0316056863 Elizabeth Stamatina Fey was born in Upper Darby, Pennsylvania, just west of Philadelphia, in 1970 to Donald and Jeannec Fey. Going by the name of Tina, Ms. Fey considered herself a 'supernerd' during her high school and college years. She studied drama at the University of Virginia, and after graduating in 1992, she headed to Chicago, the ancestral home of American comedy. While working at a YMCA to support herself, she started Second City's first set of courses. After about nine months, a teacher told her to just skip ahead and audition for the more selective Second City Training Center. She failed but about eight weeks later, she re-auditioned and got into the year-long program. She ended up spending many years at The Second City in Chicago where many SNL cast members first started out. Then in 1995, _'Saturday Night Live' (1975)_ (qv) came to The Second City's cast, including Fey's friend, 'Adam McKay (I)' (qv), as a writer, searching for new talent. What they found was Tina Fey. When Adam was made Head writer, he suggested Fey should send a submission packet over the summer with six sketches, 10 pages each. Tina took the advice and sent them. After 'Lorne Michaels' (qv) met her and saw her work she was offered a job a week later. She admitted that she was extremely nervous working in the legendary Studio 8H; being a foot shorter than everyone else, younger, and being one of the only female writers at the time. After a few years, Tina made history by becoming the first female head writer in the show's history. Tina also made her screen debut as a featured player during the 25th season by co-anchoring Weekend Update with 'Jimmy Fallon' (qv). Since Tina and Jimmy have taken over Weekend Update it has been considered the best ever. This year she made it to full fledged star by becoming a regular cast member, though she is hardly on the show, besides Update. And during the past two summers, Tina and 'Rachel Dratch' (qv) performed their two-woman show to critical acclaim in both Chicago (1999) and New York (2000) and made their Aspen Comedy Festival Debut. Tina is married to 'Jeff Richmond (II)' (qv), a Second City director and currently lives in New York City. Tina Fey 'The Orlando Sentinel' (USA), 2 December 2008, by: Newsday, 'Tina Fey and Husband Talk About Scar on Her Cheek' Black plastic-rimmed glasses 'Vogue' (USA), March 2010 Tina Faye 5' 4 1/2' Upper Darby, Pennsylvania, USA Female

Video Game Language Producer editor language    Joel Cox birth notes gender aka name trivia birth name mini biography birth date 2 April 1942 Joel Cox was born c. 1941 and his film career began at a very early age - appearing before the cameras, in fact - as a baby in the film 'Random Harvest'. Some twenty years later he began work as a mail-room boy with Warner Brothers, the company with whom he has worked ever since, and in 1969 moved into the cutting-room, as an uncredited assistant editor on 'Woodstock' and 'The Wild Bunch'. He was a credited assistant on 'The Outlaw Josey Wales', working for the first time with Clint Eastwood. A durable collaboration followed with Cox cutting all films made by Eastwood since. Joel Cox He credits 'Ferris Webster' (qv) and 'Walter Thompson (I)' (qv) as being his greatest mentors, followed by 'Sam O'Steen' (qv). Joel Edward Cox Los Angeles, California, USA Male Cox, Joel Edward

Video Game Production Designer Producer actor editor  David Leitch  Joel Cox birth notes gender aka name trivia birth name mini biography birth date David Leitch Dave Leitch 5' 11' Male 2 April 1942 Joel Cox was born c. 1941 and his film career began at a very early age - appearing before the cameras, in fact - as a baby in the film 'Random Harvest'. Some twenty years later he began work as a mail-room boy with Warner Brothers, the company with whom he has worked ever since, and in 1969 moved into the cutting-room, as an uncredited assistant editor on 'Woodstock' and 'The Wild Bunch'. He was a credited assistant on 'The Outlaw Josey Wales', working for the first time with Clint Eastwood. A durable collaboration followed with Cox cutting all films made by Eastwood since. Joel Cox He credits 'Ferris Webster' (qv) and 'Walter Thompson (I)' (qv) as being his greatest mentors, followed by 'Sam O'Steen' (qv). Joel Edward Cox Los Angeles, California, USA Male Cox, Joel Edward

Video Game TV Movie Actor Writer actor actress Paul Benjamin   Samantha Bond birth notes gender other works name trivia birth date spouse height quotes 1938 Born and raised for a time in Pelion, South Carolina, African-American actor Paul Benjamin is the youngest of twelve children born to a Baptist preacher, the Reverend Fair Benjamin, and his wife Rosa. Paul lost his mother while still a baby and his father as a child. He moved to Columbia, South Carolina, where he was taken in by one of his older brothers, David, and his wife and family. Suppressing his teenage desires of becoming an actor due to social pressures, he attended C.A. Johnson High and, upon graduation, enrolled at Benedict College for about a year before deciding to move to New York City and pursue his dream. Studying at the 'Herbert Berghof' (qv) Studio, he finally made his professional stage debut in the late 60s at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. His theater career quickly picked up steam with such classical and contemporary plays as 'Hamlet' (1967), 'Cities in Bezique (1969), 'The Owl Answers' (1969), 'No Place to Be Somebody' (1969), 'The Year Boston Won the Pennant' (1969), 'Camino Royal' 1970, 'Operation Sidewinder' (1970), Boesman and Lena (1970), 'The Black Terror' (1971), 'Assassination 1865' (1971), 'The Cherry Orchard' (1973) and 'The Old Glory' (1976).  Benjamin made his film debut inauspiciously as a bartender in _Midnight Cowboy (1969)_ (qv), which highlighted New York's seamier side. Following small roles in _The Anderson Tapes (1971)_ (qv) and _Born to Win (1971)_ (qv), he earned a top featured role and strong notices playing a robber-turned-killer in _Across 110th Street (1972)_ (qv) co-starring 'Anthony Quinn (I)' (qv) and 'Yaphet Kotto' (qv), which again took place on the gritty New York streets. He then gave incisive, strong-armed portrayals as part of a gang in _The Deadly Trackers (1973)_ (qv) and as a lieutenant alongside 'Tony Lo Bianco' (qv) and 'Hal Linden' (qv) in the above-average TV-movie _Mr. Inside/Mr. Outside (1973) (TV)_ (qv). His film and TV career, which peaked in the 1970s, included the 'blaxploitation' scene -- he appeared with 'Mary Alice (I)' (qv) as the parents of the titular character in _The Education of Sonny Carson (1974)_ (qv) and as a senator in the 'Pam Grier' (qv) vehicle _Friday Foster (1975)_ (qv).  Throughout the decades he has worked with prestigious actors in prestigious projects yet never attained the public attention he merited. Neverthless he added solid authenticity to the musical bio _Leadbelly (1976)_ (qv); 'Clint Eastwood' (qv)'s _Escape from Alcatraz (1979)_ (qv); the 'Richard Pryor' (qv) comedy-drama _Some Kind of Hero (1982)_ (qv); 'Barbra Streisand' (qv)'s courtroom vehicle _Nuts (1987)_ (qv); 'Spike Lee' (qv)'s lacerating, one-two punch on urban black life in _Do the Right Thing (1989)_ (qv); the Temptations-like story of _The Five Heartbeats (1991)_ (qv); and the excellent, fact-based drama in _Rosewood (1997)_ (qv) with racism at its core. On the mini-movie circuit he appeared in good company as 'LeVar Burton' (qv)'s father in the baseball story _One in a Million: The Ron LeFlore Story (1977) (TV)_ (qv), and was a noticeable factor in _Gideon's Trumpet (1980) (TV)_ (qv) starring 'Henry Fonda' (qv); 'Maya Angelou' (qv)'s _I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings (1979) (TV)_ (qv); the hard-hitting _'The Atlanta Child Murders' (1985)_ (qv)_ (TV) and, perhaps most notably, the chain-gang story _The Man Who Broke 1,000 Chains (1987) (TV)_ (qv) in which he portrayed Big Sam.  Paul the actor has added to his success as an award-winning playwright as well and, broaching age 70, continues to write as well as perform. His play 'Carrier', in which he appeared with 'Roscoe Lee Browne' (qv) and 'Paula Kelly (I)' (qv), received special citations for its writing and performances. Paul Benjamin Mayor Tom Bradley presented Paul with a Commendation from the City of Los Angeles for Paul's play, 'Carrier,' for which 'Paula Kelly (I)' (qv) won the 1982 NAACP Image Awards for Best Actress. She, along with Paul and actor/poet Roscoe Lee Browne, received Certificates of Recognition from Sen. Diane Watson for their performances in the same play. 6' 1 1/2' Pelion, South Carolina, USA Male 27 November 1961 'Alexander Hanson' (qv) (? - present); 2 children Samantha Bond Sister of 'Abigail Bond' (qv) 5' 6 1/2' 'As for 'Daniel Craig (I)' (qv) as Bond, I think it is an absolutely brilliant choice. He is butch, male, attractive and a bloody good actor. He was by far the most plausible choice' [on _Casino Royale (2006)_ (qv)]. London, England, UK Female (August 1988) She acted in 'William Shakespeare (I)' (qv)'s play, 'Much Ado About Nothing', in a Renaissance Theatre Company production during the Renaissance Shakespeare Festival at the Phoenix Theatre in London, England with 'Kenneth Branagh' (qv), Samantha Bond, 'Richard Easton (II)' (qv), 'Edward Jewesbury' (qv), 'David Lloyd Meredith' (qv), 'Dearbhla Molloy' (qv), 'David Parfitt' (qv), 'Shaun Prendergast' (qv), 'Sophie Thompson (I)' (qv), 'Jay Villiers' (qv) and 'Jimmy Yuill' (qv) in the cast. 'Judi Dench' (qv) was the director. 1966 'Ruth' (1997 - present); 1 child Ewan Bailey was born in 1966 in Brighton, Sussex,as Ewan Thomson, the son of Dr. Bruce Thomson, a noted Rugby Union player who represented Scotland at international level. He attended Brighton College and read Modern History at Keble College, Oxford, before studying drama at the Central School of Speech and Drama in London. In 2001 he was one of the actor presenters of the BBC radio satirical show 'The Sunday Format', mocking Sunday newspaper contents, and has provided the narration for numerous television documentaries on Channel 4 and the Discovery Channel. He is also the founder of Rubbaball, a small comedy theater company. Ewan Bailey Graduated from Oxford University with a degree in Modern History. Has a Black Belt (Second Dan) in Shotokan Karate. Marrow, Tracy Lauren 16 February 1958 Ice Ice-T and Douglas Century. _Ice: A Memoir of Gangster Life and Redemption-from South Central to Hollywood._ New York: One World/Ballantine, 2011. ISBN 0345523288 The legendary gangsta hip-hop emcee Ice-T was born Tracy Marrow on February 16, 1958, in Newark, New Jersey. He moved to Los Angeles, California, to live with his paternal aunt after the death of his father while he was in the sixth grade; his mother had died earlier when he was in the third grade. His aunt lived in the South Los Angeles district of Crenshaw, colloquially referred to as South Central. He became immersed in the street life of the inner-city and eventually became a member of the West Side Rollin 30s Original Harlem Crips.  In 1979, Marrow joined the Army after leaving Crenshaw High School, but his 4-year hitch was enough for him, as he was a leader, not a follower. 'I didn't like total submission to a leader other than myself,' he said. After ETSing from the Army in 1983, he returned to South Central with the intention of becoming a hip-hop musician. More than music, his life got caught up in street life as as a jewel thief and as a pimp. (His nomme de guerre, Ice T, is an homage to the fabled pimp and raconteur Iceberg Slim ('Robert Beck (III)' (qv)). He committed himself totally to his music after a 1985 car crash.  As a musician, Ice-T played a major role in the creation of the gangsta incarnation of hip-hop music and was a colossus of the West Coast hip-hop scene, despite his East Coast, greater New York, origins. Though his music displays a political consciousness, like the indictments of racism that were a hallmark of seminal hip-hop group 'Public Enemy' (qv), it also is nihilistic as befits a chronicler of street life. His most infamous song, the heavy metal 'Cop Killer,' was one of the major battle in the cultural wars of the 1990s, in which cultural conservatives enlisted the Moses of the right wing, 'Charlton Heston' (qv), to get Ice-T dropped from his then-label, Sire/Warner Bros.  The charismatic Ice-T has also achieved success as an actor in movies and on TV. He plays Detective Odafin Tutuola on the TV series _'Law & Order: Special Victims Unit' (1999)_ (qv), which is ironic for someone famous for 'Cop Killer' and his feud with the L.A.P.D. Ice-T currently resides in North Bergen, New Jersey, with his wife, 'Coco Austin' (qv). Ice-T 'Spin' (USA), May 1991, Vol. 7, Iss. 2, pg. 58-59, by: Scott Cohen, 'Cool Career Move: Ice-T' His instantly recognizable nasal voice 'Oor' (Netherlands), 22 August 1992, Iss. 17 Tracy Marrow 5' 11' Newark, New Jersey, USA Male
Video Game TV Movie Actor Writer actor actress Morris Chestnut  Samantha Bond   'Chicago Tribune' (USA), 9 January 2009, by: Lauren Viera, 'Morris Chestnut: An Actor Not Easily Broken' 'Pam Byse' (1995 - present); 2 children Has worked with 'Steven Seagal' (qv) twice. He was both Seagal's character's partner and main enemy. In _Under Siege 2: Dark Territory (1995)_ (qv), Chestnut is Seagal's character's reluctant partner. In _Half Past Dead (2002)_ (qv), he co-starred as the main villain. 'Razor magazine' (USA), August/September 2001, Vol. 1, Iss. 9, pg. 81, by: none, 'night vision' Music video for Jamie Foxx: 'Blame It' Chestnut, Morris L. 1 January 1969 A tall, handsome, and versatile black actor, Morris Chestnut first came to be recognized by moviegoers starring as Ricky in _Boyz n the Hood (1991)_ (qv), a role where he played a high school running back using his football skills to escape the violent surroundings of his South Central Los Angeles neighborhood. His half brother was played by 'Ice Cube' (qv) who in the movie did not have the same motivation. Two years later, he landed a lead role in Civil Rights Drama _The Ernest Green Story (1993) (TV)_ (qv), showing courage and perseverance as one of the Arkansas Nine high school students. He later starred in action films like _Under Siege 2: Dark Territory (1995)_ (qv), _G.I. Jane (1997)_ (qv) and _Half Past Dead (2002)_ (qv) as well as the romantic comedies _The Best Man (1999)_ (qv), _The Brothers (2001)_ (qv), _Two Can Play That Game (2001)_ (qv), and _Breakin' All the Rules (2004)_ (qv). In 2004, he appeared in _Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)_ (qv) and _Ladder 49 (2004)_ (qv). Morris Chestnut Morris L. Video Game Series Production Designer Genre actor genre   David Leitch   David Leitch Dave Leitch 5' 11' Male
Video Game Series Production Designer Genre actor genre  Paul Benjamin    1938 Born and raised for a time in Pelion, South Carolina, African-American actor Paul Benjamin is the youngest of twelve children born to a Baptist preacher, the Reverend Fair Benjamin, and his wife Rosa. Paul lost his mother while still a baby and his father as a child. He moved to Columbia, South Carolina, where he was taken in by one of his older brothers, David, and his wife and family. Suppressing his teenage desires of becoming an actor due to social pressures, he attended C.A. Johnson High and, upon graduation, enrolled at Benedict College for about a year before deciding to move to New York City and pursue his dream. Studying at the 'Herbert Berghof' (qv) Studio, he finally made his professional stage debut in the late 60s at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. His theater career quickly picked up steam with such classical and contemporary plays as 'Hamlet' (1967), 'Cities in Bezique (1969), 'The Owl Answers' (1969), 'No Place to Be Somebody' (1969), 'The Year Boston Won the Pennant' (1969), 'Camino Royal' 1970, 'Operation Sidewinder' (1970), Boesman and Lena (1970), 'The Black Terror' (1971), 'Assassination 1865' (1971), 'The Cherry Orchard' (1973) and 'The Old Glory' (1976).  Benjamin made his film debut inauspiciously as a bartender in _Midnight Cowboy (1969)_ (qv), which highlighted New York's seamier side. Following small roles in _The Anderson Tapes (1971)_ (qv) and _Born to Win (1971)_ (qv), he earned a top featured role and strong notices playing a robber-turned-killer in _Across 110th Street (1972)_ (qv) co-starring 'Anthony Quinn (I)' (qv) and 'Yaphet Kotto' (qv), which again took place on the gritty New York streets. He then gave incisive, strong-armed portrayals as part of a gang in _The Deadly Trackers (1973)_ (qv) and as a lieutenant alongside 'Tony Lo Bianco' (qv) and 'Hal Linden' (qv) in the above-average TV-movie _Mr. Inside/Mr. Outside (1973) (TV)_ (qv). His film and TV career, which peaked in the 1970s, included the 'blaxploitation' scene -- he appeared with 'Mary Alice (I)' (qv) as the parents of the titular character in _The Education of Sonny Carson (1974)_ (qv) and as a senator in the 'Pam Grier' (qv) vehicle _Friday Foster (1975)_ (qv).  Throughout the decades he has worked with prestigious actors in prestigious projects yet never attained the public attention he merited. Neverthless he added solid authenticity to the musical bio _Leadbelly (1976)_ (qv); 'Clint Eastwood' (qv)'s _Escape from Alcatraz (1979)_ (qv); the 'Richard Pryor' (qv) comedy-drama _Some Kind of Hero (1982)_ (qv); 'Barbra Streisand' (qv)'s courtroom vehicle _Nuts (1987)_ (qv); 'Spike Lee' (qv)'s lacerating, one-two punch on urban black life in _Do the Right Thing (1989)_ (qv); the Temptations-like story of _The Five Heartbeats (1991)_ (qv); and the excellent, fact-based drama in _Rosewood (1997)_ (qv) with racism at its core. On the mini-movie circuit he appeared in good company as 'LeVar Burton' (qv)'s father in the baseball story _One in a Million: The Ron LeFlore Story (1977) (TV)_ (qv), and was a noticeable factor in _Gideon's Trumpet (1980) (TV)_ (qv) starring 'Henry Fonda' (qv); 'Maya Angelou' (qv)'s _I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings (1979) (TV)_ (qv); the hard-hitting _'The Atlanta Child Murders' (1985)_ (qv)_ (TV) and, perhaps most notably, the chain-gang story _The Man Who Broke 1,000 Chains (1987) (TV)_ (qv) in which he portrayed Big Sam.  Paul the actor has added to his success as an award-winning playwright as well and, broaching age 70, continues to write as well as perform. His play 'Carrier', in which he appeared with 'Roscoe Lee Browne' (qv) and 'Paula Kelly (I)' (qv), received special citations for its writing and performances. Paul Benjamin Mayor Tom Bradley presented Paul with a Commendation from the City of Los Angeles for Paul's play, 'Carrier,' for which 'Paula Kelly (I)' (qv) won the 1982 NAACP Image Awards for Best Actress. She, along with Paul and actor/poet Roscoe Lee Browne, received Certificates of Recognition from Sen. Diane Watson for their performances in the same play. 6' 1 1/2' Pelion, South Carolina, USA Male
Video Game Series Production Designer Genre actor genre  Evan Seinfeld    29 December 1967 Spyder Jones 'Club' (USA), February 2003, Vol. 29, Iss. 1, pg. 50-55, by: Anneli Adolfsson, 'Rock Hard! 1 Rock Superstar + 6 Gorgeous Girls = Sex'n'Rock'n'Roll Galore!' 'Tera Patrick' (qv) (9 January 2004 - 2009) (divorced) Evan Seinfeld Previously played bass guitar for Damnocracy. Currently plays for the Brooklyn based hardcore/metal band Biohazard, the Spyders, and joined Tattooed Millionaires in October 2008. Spyder Jonez 5' 9 1/2' Brooklyn, New York, USA Male Vocalist and bassist for Hardcore Metal band, Biohazard.

Video Game Series Production Designer Genre actor genre    Ewan Bailey birth notes gender aka name trivia mini biography birth date spouse height 1966 'Ruth' (1997 - present); 1 child Ewan Bailey was born in 1966 in Brighton, Sussex,as Ewan Thomson, the son of Dr. Bruce Thomson, a noted Rugby Union player who represented Scotland at international level. He attended Brighton College and read Modern History at Keble College, Oxford, before studying drama at the Central School of Speech and Drama in London. In 2001 he was one of the actor presenters of the BBC radio satirical show 'The Sunday Format', mocking Sunday newspaper contents, and has provided the narration for numerous television documentaries on Channel 4 and the Discovery Channel. He is also the founder of Rubbaball, a small comedy theater company. Ewan Bailey Graduated from Oxford University with a degree in Modern History. Has a Black Belt (Second Dan) in Shotokan Karate. Ewan Bailley 191 cm Brighton, Sussex, England, UK Male
Video Game Series Production Designer Genre actor genre    Ice-T gender other works trivia nick names spouse article quotes interviews birth notes books aka name trade mark birth name mini biography birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial 'NME' (UK), 22 March 1997, pg. 12+57, by: Sylvia Patterson, 'For Your Demise Only' 'Coco Austin' (qv) (31 December 2005 - present) His feud with former LAPD chief 'Daryl Gates' (qv) was widely reported by the American press. 'Veronica' (Netherlands), 23 February 2008, Iss. 8, by: Sunshine, 'Tupperware T' (On the controversy created by 'Cop Killer): 'When the President (of the United States) mentions your name in anger, you KNOW the s--t has hit the fan!' (1998) Album: 'Below Utopia: The Lost Score,' Noo Trybe/Virgin/EMI Records V2-45854. Marrow, Tracy Lauren 16 February 1958 Ice Ice-T and Douglas Century. _Ice: A Memoir of Gangster Life and Redemption-from South Central to Hollywood._ New York: One World/Ballantine, 2011. ISBN 0345523288 The legendary gangsta hip-hop emcee Ice-T was born Tracy Marrow on February 16, 1958, in Newark, New Jersey. He moved to Los Angeles, California, to live with his paternal aunt after the death of his father while he was in the sixth grade; his mother had died earlier when he was in the third grade. His aunt lived in the South Los Angeles district of Crenshaw, colloquially referred to as South Central. He became immersed in the street life of the inner-city and eventually became a member of the West Side Rollin 30s Original Harlem Crips.  In 1979, Marrow joined the Army after leaving Crenshaw High School, but his 4-year hitch was enough for him, as he was a leader, not a follower. 'I didn't like total submission to a leader other than myself,' he said. After ETSing from the Army in 1983, he returned to South Central with the intention of becoming a hip-hop musician. More than music, his life got caught up in street life as as a jewel thief and as a pimp. (His nomme de guerre, Ice T, is an homage to the fabled pimp and raconteur Iceberg Slim ('Robert Beck (III)' (qv)). He committed himself totally to his music after a 1985 car crash.  As a musician, Ice-T played a major role in the creation of the gangsta incarnation of hip-hop music and was a colossus of the West Coast hip-hop scene, despite his East Coast, greater New York, origins. Though his music displays a political consciousness, like the indictments of racism that were a hallmark of seminal hip-hop group 'Public Enemy' (qv), it also is nihilistic as befits a chronicler of street life. His most infamous song, the heavy metal 'Cop Killer,' was one of the major battle in the cultural wars of the 1990s, in which cultural conservatives enlisted the Moses of the right wing, 'Charlton Heston' (qv), to get Ice-T dropped from his then-label, Sire/Warner Bros.  The charismatic Ice-T has also achieved success as an actor in movies and on TV. He plays Detective Odafin Tutuola on the TV series _'Law & Order: Special Victims Unit' (1999)_ (qv), which is ironic for someone famous for 'Cop Killer' and his feud with the L.A.P.D. Ice-T currently resides in North Bergen, New Jersey, with his wife, 'Coco Austin' (qv). Ice-T 'Spin' (USA), May 1991, Vol. 7, Iss. 2, pg. 58-59, by: Scott Cohen, 'Cool Career Move: Ice-T' His instantly recognizable nasal voice 'Oor' (Netherlands), 22 August 1992, Iss. 17 Tracy Marrow 5' 11' Newark, New Jersey, USA Male
Video Game Series Production Designer Genre actor genre    Michael Sottile gender name magazine cover photo Michael Sottile 'Modus Operandi' (USA), 4 April 2012 Male
Video Game Series Production Designer Genre actor genre  Steve Covino    Steve Covino Male

?instanceObjectNumber2 a <http://www.imdb.com/Miscellaneous_Crew>.
?instanceObjectNumber1 a <http://www.imdb.com/Person>.


Crew Member Person Video Movie editor cinematographer Robert Draper Martin Nicholson   'Fangoria Horror Spectacular' (USA), 1991, Iss. 4, pg. 10-13, by: Mark Cerulli, 'Lighting the Crypt' With more than 35 years experience in Film and Television, Rob has worked on everything from Regional TV News to Hollywood Feature Films.  Known as a technical innovator and creative risk taker in the industry he has pioneered many new techniques and worked on development of motion picture products for SONY, Panasonic, Fuji Film, Arri and Zeiss. Rob was also the first to run a full scale Hi Definition shoot in Hollywood on the then 'new gen' camera's.  Rob set the style for what has become known as Reality TV in a groundbreaking series he shot for Universal called 'The Street'...after which the New York Times declared 'the show practically creates a new visual language'. Rob also worked on some of the first Music Videos used to promote feature Films and developed a visual style for using promotional music videos for retailing in a 5 minute Hollywood extravaganza for Coca Cola.  Rob's photography on the Sundance Audience award winner, The Spitfire Grill, drew accolades worldwide.  Rob draws inspiration from the classic painters and his skilled and delicate use of light and shade as integral elements of composition sets his work apart. Over the past 20 years he has inspired thousand of cinematographers worldwide as a dynamic instructor at workshops, and as a consultant, on the art of film lighting  More recently he has been on the cutting edge of digital technology on the web with his groundbreaking IPTV channel Singlemalt TV. Launched in 2006 it immediately drew attention and a long relationship with major media players in UK.  Rob has worked worldwide on TV movies,Feature Films,Mini Series,TV series documentaries, TV Commercials and Music Videos. He has worked for every major Hollywood studio and US TV Network claiming multiple Awards in both Australia and the United States. Robert Draper 'Imagine News' (USA), June 2002, by: 'Eric Harper (I)' (qv), 'Rob Draper: New England Cinematography on the Cutting Edge' 'Imagine News' (USA), June 2002 Male Martin Nicholson Marty Nicholson
Crew Member Person Video Movie editor cinematographer  Timothy Galfas Stan Cole gender name Timothy Galfas Stan Cole Female
Crew Member Person Video Movie editor cinematographer Larry McConkey  Brent Carpenter gender name mini biography Larry McConkey Larry McKonkey Brent directed a wide range of productions over the last several years including the darkly humorous _'Greg the Bunny' (2002)_ (qv), _'Caroline in the City' (1995)_ (qv), 'The Hollywood Bowl Hall of Fame', _'America's Greatest Pets' (1998)_ (qv), _'Union Square' (1997)_ (qv) and 'How To Lose Friends and Irritate People'. Brent also directed a special '50th Birthday Film' for Billy Crystal's birthday party, starring Rob Reiner, Martin Short and Christopher Guest among many others.  Brent was Emmy and Grammy nominated in 1998 as co-producer on the Robert Altman film _'Great Performances' (1970) {Robert Altman's Jazz '34 (#25.13)}_ (qv). He also oversaw the editing of this jazz spectacular, featuring a number of current jazz greats portraying jazz stars of the 1930s. In addition he produced and directed the short films 'Extras', _Chantmania: The Benzedrine Monks of Santo Damonica (1994) (V)_ (qv), _The Fan (1995) (V)_ (qv) starring Judy Tenuta and 'Exceeding Expectations' with Harry Anderson. Brent was a featured director on 'The Dog & Pony Show' broadcast. He worked as sketch director on the 'Stephanie Miller Show', and he served as co-producer on Harry Anderson's CBS special 'Tricks Of His Trade'. Brent served as co-producer and editor on the first season of _'The Larry Sanders Show' (1992)_ (qv) helping to create the backstage look that served the show so well. He was one of a number of producers and the editor on the CBS comedy _'Dave's World' (1993)_ (qv), and has long been involved in the world of comedy. He also served in that capacity on the critically acclaimed HBO series _'Sessions' (1991)_ (qv) created by 'Billy Crystal' (qv).  Brent is also heavily involved in the world of music, directing and producing music videos for a number of alternative country and folk acts, including Dale Watson and Chuck E. Weiss.  Brent started in television as a news photographer in Phoenix and Minneapolis. Before becoming involved with television, he was a roustabout in the Tulsa oil fields and cooked hamburgers. He prefers television. Brent Carpenter Male
Crew Member Person Video Movie editor cinematographer  Mark A. Catalena aka name Mark A. Catalena Mark Catalena
Crew Member Person Video Movie editor cinematographer Randall P. Dark Shane Marr   In 1986, Randall Dark was given the opportunity to view High Definition for the first time and knew it was the future of images. A few short years later, he founded HD Vision in New York City. The company later moved its headquarters to Dallas, then to Los Angeles. Its mandate was to specialize in the growth of High Definition, launching Dark into the position of a technological and creative visionary. An undisputed pioneer in the emerging industry, today, Randall is the creative and marketing force behind Randall Dark Productions, Inc. He received one of the International Electronic Cinema Festival's top honors: The Pioneer Award, bestowed in recognition of extraordinary contributions to the success of High Definition. He is a member of the Television Arts and Sciences Academy and is one of a select few members of the Consumer Electronics Association's Academy of Digital Pioneers, a group recognized for their efforts implementing Digital Television in the United States.  Recognized globally as an expert in emerging technologies, Randall has spoken to audiences at events including: MIPCOM, Tokyo International Film Festival, CASBAA Hong Kong, Banff World Television Festival, National Association of Broadcaster's Convention, International Electronic Cinema Festival, Infocomm, Consumer Electronic Show, HDExpo, World Television Forum, creaTVty Zurich, Canadian Association of Broadcasters Convention, Hollywood Post Alliance, New York State Bar Association, Bear Stearns Media Conference, NATPE and Playback Forum (Toronto) where he served as the Keynote Speaker.  Dark and his companies have been involved in over 2000 HD projects including feature films, documentaries, commercials, music videos, corporate presentations, product launches and live events.  In 2007, the Maxell Corporation presented Dark its Independent Filmmaker Award for Achievement made during the making of 'Closing Escrow'. HD Programs directed by Dark have also received awards from CEA, Telly, IECF, Communicator, Aurora, Axiem, WorldFest Houston International Film Festival, Videographer, The American Corporate Video Awards and Cinema Chicago. Randall P. Dark 'TV Technology' (USA), 26 July 2010, by: John Merli, 'A 3D Ode to the Smokies' Shane Marr

Episode Work Cinematographer edited into cinematographer Gordon Willis    28 May 1931 The Prince of Darkness 'Below the Line' (USA), 10 July 2004, Vol. 19, pg. 35, by: April MacIntyre, ''Gordon Willis: The Prince of Darkness' Gordon Willis 'New York Times' (United States), 1 August 1983 Member of the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC) since 1975. Known in the industry as 'The Prince of Darkness', due to his lighting technique of using shadows and often not allowing a character's eyes to be seen clearly (_The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), _The Parallax View (1974)_ (qv)). The Prince of Darkness [on 'ruining' footage to create the look of time-ravaged 1920s newsreels] 'The lack of perfection, that's the hardest quality of all, because you're fighting your instincts. You're trained to want to do things perfectly.' Queens, New York City, New York, USA Male
Episode Work Cinematographer edited into cinematographer  Gordon Willis   28 May 1931 The Prince of Darkness 'Below the Line' (USA), 10 July 2004, Vol. 19, pg. 35, by: April MacIntyre, ''Gordon Willis: The Prince of Darkness' Gordon Willis 'New York Times' (United States), 1 August 1983 Member of the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC) since 1975. Known in the industry as 'The Prince of Darkness', due to his lighting technique of using shadows and often not allowing a character's eyes to be seen clearly (_The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), _The Parallax View (1974)_ (qv)). Episode Series Producer Cinematographer writer cinematographer Roy H. Wagner   Susan Wald name Buddy Born in a very small community in the mid west Roy had no other contact to his dream of becoming a cinematographer than through the local theater and the Los Angeles phone directory. He would recall the names of cinematographers as they appeared on their films and call them blindly to talk with them about their work. Many of them were so suprised by this young man's ambition and interest that they took him under their wing, mentoring him. When he arrived in Los Angeles he spent every moment with them on their sets and homes learning as much about them and their work as he could. Because of this he was able to meet and befriend many of the greatest cinematographers in Hollywood. His key mentor was Harry Stradling Sr. Through him he developed friendships with Joseph Ruttenberg, George Folsey, James Wong Howe, Leon Shamroy, Frank Phillipd, Leonard South, and many many others. In the late 70s he began a life long process of interviewing cinematographers on video tape or film. A deep reverence for all that is old Hollywood remains a great part of his life and the memory of the behind the scene stories told him as a young man is an important basis for his life and work. Roy H. Wagner 'International Photographer' (USA), January 1996, pg. 22-27, 'It's A Party' Esteemed and longtime member of the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC). Roy Henry Wagner III Male III, Roy Henry Wagner Susan Wald
Episode Series Producer Cinematographer writer cinematographer   Susan Wald Steven Fierberg birth notes gender aka name trivia Susan Wald Steven Fierberg Member of the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC). Steve Fierberg Detroit, Michigan, USA Male

Composer Episode Work edited into writer Francis Ford Coppola    'The Independent Arts & Books' (UK), 11 June 2010, Iss. 7383, pg. 10 - 11, by: Kaleem Aftab, 'It's all about the family business' 'Eleanor Coppola' (qv) (2 February 1963 - present); 3 children 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) said that he based the 'Han Solo' character from the Star Wars trilogy on Coppola. 'New York Times Magazine' (USA), 19 May 2002, pg. 26+28, by: Frank Bruni, 'In the Name of the Father' On 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv): Most directors have one masterpiece by which they are known, or possibly two. Kurosawa has at least eight or nine. Print ad for Robert Mondavi Wines. (2000) 7 April 1939 (September 2005) Visiting Istanbul for vacation. Rodney F. Hill. _Francis Ford Coppola: Interviews._ 2004. He was born in 1939 in Detroit, USA, but he grew up in a New York suburb in a creative, supportive Italian-American family. His father, 'Carmine Coppola' (qv), was a composer and musician. His mother, 'Italia Coppola' (qv), had been an actress. Francis Ford Coppola graduated with a degree in drama from Hofstra University, and did graduate work at UCLA in filmmaking. He was training as assistant with filmmaker 'Roger Corman' (qv), working in such capacities as sound-man, dialogue director, associate producer and, eventually, director of _Dementia 13 (1963)_ (qv), Coppola's first feature film. During the next four years, Coppola was involved in a variety of script collaborations, including writing an adaptation of 'This Property is Condemned' by 'Tennessee Williams' (qv) (with 'Fred Coe' (qv) and 'Edith Sommer' (qv)), and screenplays for _Paris br?le-t-il? (1966)_ (qv) and _Patton (1970)_ (qv), the film for which Coppola won a Best Original Screenplay Academy Award. In 1966, Coppola's 2nd film brought him critical acclaim and a Master of Fine Arts degree. In 1969, Coppola and 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) established American Zoetrope, an independent film production company based in San Francisco. The company's first project was _THX 1138 (1971)_ (qv), produced by Coppola and directed by Lucas. Coppola also produced the second film that Lucas directed, _American Graffiti (1973)_ (qv), in 1973. This movie got five Academy Award nominations, including one for Best Picture. In 1971, Coppola's film _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv) became one of the highest-grossing movies in history and brought him an Oscar for writing the screenplay with 'Mario Puzo' (qv) The film was a Best Picture Academy Award-winner, and also brought Coppola a Best Director Oscar nomination. Following his work on the screenplay for _The Great Gatsby (1974)_ (qv), Coppola's next film was _The Conversation (1974)_ (qv), which was honored with the Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and brought Coppola Best Picture and Best Original Screenplay Oscar nominations. Also released that year, _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), rivaled the success of _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), and won six Academy Awards, bringing Coppola Oscars as a producer, director and writer. Coppola then began work on his most ambitious film, _Apocalypse Now (1979)_ (qv), a Vietnam War epic that was inspired by 'Joseph Conrad (I)' (qv)'s _Heart of Darkness (1993) (TV)_ (qv). Released in 1979, the acclaimed film won a Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and two Academy Awards. Also that year, Coppola executive produced the hit _The Black Stallion (1979)_ (qv). With 'George Lucas (I)' (qv), Coppola executive produced _Kagemusha (1980)_ (qv), directed by 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv), and _Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)_ (qv), directed by 'Paul Schrader (I)' (qv) and based on the life and writings of 'Yukio Mishima' (qv). Coppola also executive produced such films as _The Escape Artist (1982)_ (qv), _Hammett (1982)_ (qv) _The Black Stallion Returns (1983)_ (qv), _Barfly (1987)_ (qv), _Wind (1992)_ (qv), _The Secret Garden (1993)_ (qv), etc.  He helped to make a star of his nephew, 'Nicolas Cage' (qv). Personal tragedy hit in 1986 when his son Gio died in a boating accident. Francis Ford Coppola is one of America's most erratic, energetic and controversial filmmakers. Francis Ford Coppola 'Cinema' (Greece), March 1998, Iss. 88, pg. 45, by: Yorgos Krassakopoulos, 'Skinothetis kai alla polla...' _Brando Unauthorized (2011)_ (qv) Often works with cinematographer 'Gordon Willis (I)' (qv) and producers 'Fred Roos' (qv) and 'Gray Frederickson' (qv). 'The Independent Arts & Books Review' (UK), 16 November 2007 Thomas Colchart 5' 11 1/2' Detroit, Michigan, USA Male
Composer Episode Work edited into writer Mario Puzo    'Playboy' (USA), July 1991, Vol. 38, Iss. 7, pg. 18, by: Joan Goodman, 'Guest Shot: Mario Puzo' 'Erika Lina Broske' (1946 - 9 November 1978) (her death); 5 children Bay Shore, Long Island, New York, USA (heart failure) Was writing a story outline for a fourth 'Godfather' film before he died. The best way to launch an Italian restaurant is to have it raided because the Mafia eats there. Everybody knows they eat well. Novel: 'The Family' Puzo, Mario Gianluigi 15 October 1920 Mario Puzo was born October 15, 1920, in 'Hell's Kitchen' on Manhattan's (NY) West Side and, following military service in World War II, attended New York's New School for Social Research and Columbia University. His best-known novel, 'The Godfather,' was preceded by two critically acclaimed novels, 'The Dark Arena' and 'The Fortunate Pilgrim.' In 1978, he published 'Fools Die,' followed by 'The Sicilian' (1984) and 'The Fourth K' (1991). Mario Puzo has also written several screenplays, including _Earthquake (1974)_ (qv), _Superman (1978)_ (qv), and all three 'Godfather' movies, for which he received two Academy Awards. Mario's latest novel, 1996's 'The Last Don,' was made into a CBS television miniseries in May 1997, starring 'Danny Aiello' (qv), 'Kirstie Alley' (qv) and 'Joe Mantegna' (qv). In 1997, Part II was aired. Also in 1997, Mario's 'The Fortunate Pilgrim' was re-released by Random House. Mario passed away July 2, 1999, at his home in Bay Shore, Long Island. His last novel, 'Omerta,' will be published July, 2000. He is survived by his companion of 20 years, Carol Gino, and five children. Mario Puzo 'Di?rio de Not?cias' (Portugal), 4 July 1999, pg. 58, by: Abel Coelho de Morais, 'Morreu o autor de ?O Padrinho?' 2 July 1999 'Time' (USA), 28 August 1978 Mario Gianluigi Puzo New York City, New York, USA Male
Composer Episode Work edited into writer  Francis Ford Coppola   'The Independent Arts & Books' (UK), 11 June 2010, Iss. 7383, pg. 10 - 11, by: Kaleem Aftab, 'It's all about the family business' 'Eleanor Coppola' (qv) (2 February 1963 - present); 3 children 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) said that he based the 'Han Solo' character from the Star Wars trilogy on Coppola. 'New York Times Magazine' (USA), 19 May 2002, pg. 26+28, by: Frank Bruni, 'In the Name of the Father' On 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv): Most directors have one masterpiece by which they are known, or possibly two. Kurosawa has at least eight or nine. Print ad for Robert Mondavi Wines. (2000) 7 April 1939 (September 2005) Visiting Istanbul for vacation. Rodney F. Hill. _Francis Ford Coppola: Interviews._ 2004. He was born in 1939 in Detroit, USA, but he grew up in a New York suburb in a creative, supportive Italian-American family. His father, 'Carmine Coppola' (qv), was a composer and musician. His mother, 'Italia Coppola' (qv), had been an actress. Francis Ford Coppola graduated with a degree in drama from Hofstra University, and did graduate work at UCLA in filmmaking. He was training as assistant with filmmaker 'Roger Corman' (qv), working in such capacities as sound-man, dialogue director, associate producer and, eventually, director of _Dementia 13 (1963)_ (qv), Coppola's first feature film. During the next four years, Coppola was involved in a variety of script collaborations, including writing an adaptation of 'This Property is Condemned' by 'Tennessee Williams' (qv) (with 'Fred Coe' (qv) and 'Edith Sommer' (qv)), and screenplays for _Paris br?le-t-il? (1966)_ (qv) and _Patton (1970)_ (qv), the film for which Coppola won a Best Original Screenplay Academy Award. In 1966, Coppola's 2nd film brought him critical acclaim and a Master of Fine Arts degree. In 1969, Coppola and 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) established American Zoetrope, an independent film production company based in San Francisco. The company's first project was _THX 1138 (1971)_ (qv), produced by Coppola and directed by Lucas. Coppola also produced the second film that Lucas directed, _American Graffiti (1973)_ (qv), in 1973. This movie got five Academy Award nominations, including one for Best Picture. In 1971, Coppola's film _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv) became one of the highest-grossing movies in history and brought him an Oscar for writing the screenplay with 'Mario Puzo' (qv) The film was a Best Picture Academy Award-winner, and also brought Coppola a Best Director Oscar nomination. Following his work on the screenplay for _The Great Gatsby (1974)_ (qv), Coppola's next film was _The Conversation (1974)_ (qv), which was honored with the Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and brought Coppola Best Picture and Best Original Screenplay Oscar nominations. Also released that year, _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), rivaled the success of _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), and won six Academy Awards, bringing Coppola Oscars as a producer, director and writer. Coppola then began work on his most ambitious film, _Apocalypse Now (1979)_ (qv), a Vietnam War epic that was inspired by 'Joseph Conrad (I)' (qv)'s _Heart of Darkness (1993) (TV)_ (qv). Released in 1979, the acclaimed film won a Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and two Academy Awards. Also that year, Coppola executive produced the hit _The Black Stallion (1979)_ (qv). With 'George Lucas (I)' (qv), Coppola executive produced _Kagemusha (1980)_ (qv), directed by 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv), and _Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)_ (qv), directed by 'Paul Schrader (I)' (qv) and based on the life and writings of 'Yukio Mishima' (qv). Coppola also executive produced such films as _The Escape Artist (1982)_ (qv), _Hammett (1982)_ (qv) _The Black Stallion Returns (1983)_ (qv), _Barfly (1987)_ (qv), _Wind (1992)_ (qv), _The Secret Garden (1993)_ (qv), etc.  He helped to make a star of his nephew, 'Nicolas Cage' (qv). Personal tragedy hit in 1986 when his son Gio died in a boating accident. Francis Ford Coppola is one of America's most erratic, energetic and controversial filmmakers. Francis Ford Coppola 'Cinema' (Greece), March 1998, Iss. 88, pg. 45, by: Yorgos Krassakopoulos, 'Skinothetis kai alla polla...' _Brando Unauthorized (2011)_ (qv) Often works with cinematographer 'Gordon Willis (I)' (qv) and producers 'Fred Roos' (qv) and 'Gray Frederickson' (qv). 'The Independent Arts & Books Review' (UK), 16 November 2007 Thomas Colchart 5' 11 1/2' Detroit, Michigan, USA Male

Cinematographer  Andrew Irvin birth notes gender name mini biography birth date magazine cover photo 5 October 1986 Andrew Irvin was born and raised throughout Central Ohio, living and attending school in Newark, Granville, and all around Columbus. He attended college in Gambier, Ohio. While there, he pursued his interests in music, film, and dance by organizing, recording, and participating in a wide number of concerts, shooting his first feature film, Work It Out, in the moments between shows and parties.  Avid about documenting media, he also constructed and operated Kenyon's radio station recording studio, recording for various student and outside musicians. After working on various student films at Northwestern University in 2008 and a stint as a video store clerk at Chicago's Odd Obsession Movies, he works and resides in Los Angeles, California. Andrew Irvin 'Kenyon College Alumni Bulletin' (USA), May 2006, Vol. 28, Iss. 4 Granville, Ohio, USA Male

Cinematographer  Jack Venturo birth notes gender aka name trivia mini biography birth date article height 9 January 1981 Jack Venturo was born in Lima, Peru on January 9, 1981. He came to the United States in March 1990 and spent two months in New York before settling in Miami, Florida where he developed his love of movies.  After Hurricane Andrew struck in August 1992, Jack headed to St. Petersburg, Florida. There, he attended Gibbs High School and The Pinellas County Center for the Arts (P.C.C.A) in 1996.  While in P.C.C.A. he pursued a wide range of visual arts including photography, oil painting, welding, rendering, sketching, design, sculpture art history and film history. Jack held an art exhibition in March of 2000, entitled 'Fear', which dealt with horror and its portrayal in motion pictures.  An interest in puppeteering led him to create his puppet, Stanley who quickly became very popular with cult audiences, making cameo appearances in some short films. The success of these shorts inspired Jack to write a full three-part screenplay about Stanley and create his first feature length film, 'Natural Born Stanley' which was released on December 19, 1997.  With the success of 'Natural Born Stanley' and intent on maintaining creative control over his future films, Jack channeled all of his efforts into creating his own production company.  The foundation of the company was set with his first film. Moviegod Productions was formed and with it came the much-anticipated sequel 'Stanley 2 - The Legacy', released on February 13, 1999. Along with the release of his second feature length film the 'M' logo for Moviegod Productions was created.  After 'Stanley 2 - The Legacy' he wrote and directed 'Lost in the Wilderness - Quest For Episode I' which opened on June 22, 2000 at the Film Paradiso Beach Theatre in St. Pete Beach, Florida. The premiere was an undisputed success, with lines forming around the theatre. The premiere with young and old moviegoers alike was almost sold out opening night.  The premiere included a display of behind the scenes photos, complimentary gifts for pre-purchase ticket holders, autographed pictures of the cast, movie-based merchandise and a live performance by 'Kill Theory', who played live music from the original motion picture soundtrack.  On December 24, 2000 Jack moved to Los Angeles, California after a seven-day cross country road trip, taking the newly restored and re-titled Moviegod Productions Entertainment with him.  In 2001 Jack created The MPE Network a networking website where actors can post their headshots and resumes.  In July of 2003, Jack started working on his 4th film, entitled 'The Shortest Day'. The film was released on Friday, September 5, 2003 to critical acclaim. It was the most nominated and most awarded movie at The 2003 Circle of Excellence Film Festival Archie Awards. The awards ceremony included both Los Angeles and Ventura Counties and was held at the Colony Theatre in Burbank, California. 'The Shortest Day' was nominated for four Archie Awards, of which it won three.  In 2005 Jack took a much needed two year break from filmmaking, writing and web building. He spent his personal time off mountain climbing, sight seeing, reading, soul searching, meditating, hiking, resting and learning about what ever he could get his hand on.  On February 16, 2007 Jack was ordained by Rose Ministries and became a Reverend capable of performing Weddings, Baptisms, Funerals and other spiritual and religious ceremonies.  In March of 2007 Jack became a Set Intern for Shadow Machine Films building miniature sets and props for 'Robot Chicken' & 'Morel Orel' on Cartoon Network's [adult swim].  On June 3rd 2007 Moviegod Productions Entertainment joined forces with YouTube where Jack uploaded his personal collection of videos and created 'MPE TV' a variety show with segments like 'A Month A Minute'.  On August 17, 2007 Jack became a Citizen of The States of America, He was sworn in at the Staples Center in Downtown Los Angeles. Jack Venturo 'MovieMaker Magazine' (USA), 1 June 2005, Vol. 12, Iss. 58, pg. 72, 'L.A Stories' After Hurricane Andrew struck in August 1992, he headed to St. Petersburg, Florida. There, he attended Gibbs High School and The Pinellas County Center for the Arts (P.C.C.A) in 1996. Jacky 6' 1' Lima, Peru Male

Cinematographer  Jonathan Hensleigh birth notes gender other works aka name trivia birth name where now mini biography spouse height interviews 'Starlog' (USA), July 1998, Iss. 252, by: Marc Shapiro, 'Doom Sayer' (August 2003) He is now filming his new movie _The Punisher (2004)_ (qv) for Marvel which he is writing and directing and is due for release in Summer 2004. 'Gale Anne Hurd' (qv) (19 June 1995 - present); 1 stepdaughter One of the most prolific screenwriters in the action/adventure genre, Jonathan started his career writing episodes of _'The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles' (1992)_ (qv) for 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) and ABC. He wrote _Die Hard: With a Vengeance (1995)_ (qv), re-conceived from his original spec script 'Simon Says'. He followed that with _Jumanji (1995)_ (qv). His script for the _The Saint (1997)_ (qv) was completely re-written by others. After this frustration, he enjoyed a long working friendship with producer 'Jerry Bruckheimer' (qv) with whom he collaborated on many projects since 1996. He re-wrote the whole script for _The Rock (1996)_ (qv) without credit, which he tried desperately to achieve via WGA arbitration.  He did uncredited re-writes on _Con Air (1997)_ (qv) and the remake of _Gone in Sixty Seconds (2000)_ (qv) and received executive producer credits on both. _Armageddon (1998)_ (qv), from Jonathan's original idea, was the second time Jonathan had the highest grossing film, worldwide, at the box office. The other was _Die Hard: With a Vengeance (1995)_ (qv).  Jonathan's next projects are _Gemini Man (????)_ (qv) for Disney and _The Punisher (2004)_ (qv) for Artisan/Marvel, which he will also direct in late 2002. Jonathan Hensleigh Is a fan of the London-based football team, Arsenal. Video Game Production Designer Producer actor actress Constantine Gregory  Samantha Bond birth notes gender other works name trivia birth date spouse height quotes 16 September 1942 Actor and dialect coach, Constantine Gregory was born Constantine Liebert, or Leebaert to a Dutch father and Russian mother. As the son of a journalist/broadcaster father and an actress mother, Constantine attended school in England after moving there with his mother in 1950. After attending Dartington Hall School, Constantine went to Trinity College, Dublin from 1961-1965, studying Economics and Political Science. During his college years, he was President of the Trinity College Players and found huge success while at the Edinburgh Festival, performing at the still-newly opened Traverse Theatre. Constantine continued his stage work with performances across the London front. He began screen work in 1967 and cultivated a vast amount television credits. Constantine's film work ties itself to high-profile movies including the action-adventure spy thriller GoldenEye (1995) starring Pierce Brosnan, the Ancient Roman drama Titus (1999) starring Anthony Hopkins and into the early 2000s, appeared in the adventure comedy Shanghai Knights (2003) starring Jackie Chan and Owen Wilson. Wilson  Samantha Bond birth notes gender other works name trivia birth date spouse height quotes 21 January 1943 'Starlog' (USA), September 1989, Iss. 146, pg. 64-66, by: Lee Goldberg, 'James Bond's Final Mission?' (December 2007) A film producer and photographic collector in London W1J, England Michael G. Wilson Due to the Writers' Guild of America strike in 1989, long-time James Bond scriptwriter 'Richard Maibaum' (qv) was unable to continue working on the screenplay during production of _Licence to Kill (1989)_ (qv). A long time member of the Guild, Maibaum felt he could not betray his membership and ghost-write the script. Wilson had to complete the screenplay on his own. This was to be the fifth and final pairing for the Maibaum-Wilson writing team which had started with _For Your Eyes Only (1981)_ (qv). Michael Gregg Wilson At the end of the day, what's really important - not just for the audience but ourselves - is that we are doing stuff that we believe in, that makes us enthusiastic... whether _Casino Royale (2006)_ (qv) will make more or less money (than _Die Another Day (2002)_ (qv)), I don't know. But, because we needed to re-energize ourselves, it's going to be a better film -- Interview with 'David Giammarco (II)' (qv), The Globe & Mail, March 27, 2006. Video Game Production Designer Producer actor actress Michael Kitchen  Samantha Bond birth notes gender other works name trivia birth date spouse height quotes 31 October 1948 'Rowena Miller' (1988 - present); 2 children Michael Kitchen He is an Associate Member of the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art. 5' 7' On _'Foyle's War' (2002)_ (qv): When the series first went out in the States, for example, at the front of each episode a rather eminent historian spent a couple of minutes on camera explaining how that episode related to the period of war it's set in, what actual incidents have inspired it along with various things to look out for during the course of the programme. I think it's a great shame something similar doesn't happen when the series is screened in the UK. It undeniably adds another level and depth to the programme, not to mention the success this sort of prologue or introduction has had in the past - the Alfred Hitchcock series for example. Leicester, Leicestershire, England, UK Male (January, April, June-December 1980) He acted in the British National Theatre Season Repertoire of Athol Fugard's play, 'A Lesson From Aloes,' Peter Shaffer's play, 'Amadeus,' William Shakespeare's plays, 'As You Like It,' 'Othello,' and Richard III;' Arthur Miller's plays, 'Death of a Salesman and 'The Crucible;' David Storey's play, 'Early Days,' Terence Rattigan's plays, 'Harlequinade' and 'The Browning Version;' Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's play, 'Hiawatha,' Eugene O'Neill's plays, 'Hughie,' 'The Iceman Cometh,' and 'The Long Voyage Home;' Nigel Williams's play, 'Line 'Em,' Alan Ayckbourn's play, 'Sisterly Feelings,' Henrik Ibsen's play, 'The Wild Duck,' Bernard Pomerance's play, 'The Elephant Man,' Howard Brenton's play, 'The Romans in Britain,' Bertolt Brecht's play, 'The Life of Galileo,' John Vanbrugh's play, 'The Provok'd Wife,' religious plays, 'The Passion' and 'The Nativity;' Harold Pinter's play, 'The Caretaker,' play, 'Thee and Me,' Tom Stoppard's play, 'Undiscovered Country,' Lillian Helman's play, 'Watch on the Rhine,' and J.B. Video Game Production Designer Producer actor actress Sean Bean  Samantha Bond birth notes gender other works name trivia birth date spouse height quotes 'Radio Times' (UK), 22 April 2006, Vol. 329, Iss. 4281, pg. 8-10, by: Anna Hunt, 'Sharpe focus' 'Abigail Cruttenden' (qv) (22 November 1997 - July 2000) (divorced); 1 child His father, Brian, owned a fabric shop and his mother, Rita, worked as a secretary. All the videos were so good, they always seem fresh and new, though the lyrics are quite melancholy. (On 'Madness' (qv)) Played Tybalt in Shakespeare's 'Romeo and Juliet' - Watermill Theatre, Newbury. Bean, Shaun Mark 17 April 1959 (May 2003) Filming _Troy (2004)_ (qv). Laura Jackson. _Sean Bean - The Biography._ London: Judy Piatkus Limited, 2000. ISBN 0749922362 Sean Bean, England's most versatile actor, holds a stellar career spanning every medium for approximately 20 years, in theater, radio, television and movies. This soulful, green-eyed blonde's roles are so varied that his magnetic persona convincing plays angst-ridden villians, as in 'Clarissa,' passionate lovers like Mellors in 'Lady Chatterley's Lover,' rough-and-ready soldiers such as Richard Sharpe, heartwrenching warriors as the emotionally torn Boromir in 'The Lord of the Rings,' and noble Greeks, like Odysseus in 'Troy,' where his very presence in the film adds grace and validity to the rest of the movie.  Recently, he did a turn in Shakespeare's 'Macbeth,' where as the principal lead, he so transfixed the audience that the show was extended in London and critically acclaimed.  Bean, however, remains himself, a man's man, and in the glizty world of movies this is a rare thing indeed. Bean currently resides in London where he enjoys raising his beautiful daughters, his beloved football, and the occasional pint. In his home country of England, he was recently voted the second sexiest man in the UK, and seemed to enjoy this notoriety, stating, 'I don't have any problems with women seeing me as their ideal bit of 'rough'. Why would I?' Well, good to know, because his legions of fans do not have a problem with it either. Sean Bean 'Premiere' (USA), May 2006, Vol. 19, Iss. 8, pg. 20, by: Jason Matloff, 'Scene Stealer' Often plays men who start off as heroes and, sometime during the course of the film, takes a dark turn and become villainous ('006' in _GoldenEye (1995)_ (qv), 'Boromir' in _The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of The Ring (2001)_, 'Ian Howe' in _National Treasure (2004)_ (qv) ). Shaun Mark Bean 5' 10 1/2' Sheffield, South Yorkshire, England, UK Male 27 November 1961 'Alexander Hanson' (qv) (? - present); 2 children Samantha Bond Sister of 'Abigail Bond' (qv) 5' 6 1/2' 'As for 'Daniel Craig (I)' (qv) as Bond, I think it is an absolutely brilliant choice. He is butch, male, attractive and a bloody good actor. He was by far the most plausible choice' [on _Casino Royale (2006)_ (qv)]. London, England, UK Female (August 1988) She acted in 'William Shakespeare (I)' (qv)'s play, 'Much Ado About Nothing', in a Renaissance Theatre Company production during the Renaissance Shakespeare Festival at the Phoenix Theatre in London, England with 'Kenneth Branagh' (qv), Samantha Bond, 'Richard Easton (II)' (qv), 'Edward Jewesbury' (qv), 'David Lloyd Meredith' (qv), 'Dearbhla Molloy' (qv), 'David Parfitt' (qv), 'Shaun Prendergast' (qv), 'Sophie Thompson (I)' (qv), 'Jay Villiers' (qv) and 'Jimmy Yuill' (qv) in the cast. Episode Work Writer edited into director  Francis Ford Coppola   'The Independent Arts & Books' (UK), 11 June 2010, Iss. 7383, pg. 10 - 11, by: Kaleem Aftab, 'It's all about the family business' 'Eleanor Coppola' (qv) (2 February 1963 - present); 3 children 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) said that he based the 'Han Solo' character from the Star Wars trilogy on Coppola. 'New York Times Magazine' (USA), 19 May 2002, pg. 26+28, by: Frank Bruni, 'In the Name of the Father' On 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv): Most directors have one masterpiece by which they are known, or possibly two. Kurosawa has at least eight or nine. Print ad for Robert Mondavi Wines. (2000) 7 April 1939 (September 2005) Visiting Istanbul for vacation. Rodney F. Hill. _Francis Ford Coppola: Interviews._ 2004. He was born in 1939 in Detroit, USA, but he grew up in a New York suburb in a creative, supportive Italian-American family. His father, 'Carmine Coppola' (qv), was a composer and musician. His mother, 'Italia Coppola' (qv), had been an actress. Francis Ford Coppola graduated with a degree in drama from Hofstra University, and did graduate work at UCLA in filmmaking. He was training as assistant with filmmaker 'Roger Corman' (qv), working in such capacities as sound-man, dialogue director, associate producer and, eventually, director of _Dementia 13 (1963)_ (qv), Coppola's first feature film. During the next four years, Coppola was involved in a variety of script collaborations, including writing an adaptation of 'This Property is Condemned' by 'Tennessee Williams' (qv) (with 'Fred Coe' (qv) and 'Edith Sommer' (qv)), and screenplays for _Paris br?le-t-il? (1966)_ (qv) and _Patton (1970)_ (qv), the film for which Coppola won a Best Original Screenplay Academy Award. In 1966, Coppola's 2nd film brought him critical acclaim and a Master of Fine Arts degree. In 1969, Coppola and 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) established American Zoetrope, an independent film production company based in San Francisco. The company's first project was _THX 1138 (1971)_ (qv), produced by Coppola and directed by Lucas. Coppola also produced the second film that Lucas directed, _American Graffiti (1973)_ (qv), in 1973. This movie got five Academy Award nominations, including one for Best Picture. In 1971, Coppola's film _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv) became one of the highest-grossing movies in history and brought him an Oscar for writing the screenplay with 'Mario Puzo' (qv) The film was a Best Picture Academy Award-winner, and also brought Coppola a Best Director Oscar nomination. Following his work on the screenplay for _The Great Gatsby (1974)_ (qv), Coppola's next film was _The Conversation (1974)_ (qv), which was honored with the Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and brought Coppola Best Picture and Best Original Screenplay Oscar nominations. Also released that year, _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), rivaled the success of _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), and won six Academy Awards, bringing Coppola Oscars as a producer, director and writer. Coppola then began work on his most ambitious film, _Apocalypse Now (1979)_ (qv), a Vietnam War epic that was inspired by 'Joseph Conrad (I)' (qv)'s _Heart of Darkness (1993) (TV)_ (qv). Released in 1979, the acclaimed film won a Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and two Academy Awards. Also that year, Coppola executive produced the hit _The Black Stallion (1979)_ (qv). With 'George Lucas (I)' (qv), Coppola executive produced _Kagemusha (1980)_ (qv), directed by 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv), and _Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)_ (qv), directed by 'Paul Schrader (I)' (qv) and based on the life and writings of 'Yukio Mishima' (qv). Coppola also executive produced such films as _The Escape Artist (1982)_ (qv), _Hammett (1982)_ (qv) _The Black Stallion Returns (1983)_ (qv), _Barfly (1987)_ (qv), _Wind (1992)_ (qv), _The Secret Garden (1993)_ (qv), etc.  He helped to make a star of his nephew, 'Nicolas Cage' (qv). Personal tragedy hit in 1986 when his son Gio died in a boating accident. Francis Ford Coppola is one of America's most erratic, energetic and controversial filmmakers. Francis Ford Coppola 'Cinema' (Greece), March 1998, Iss. 88, pg. 45, by: Yorgos Krassakopoulos, 'Skinothetis kai alla polla...' _Brando Unauthorized (2011)_ (qv) Often works with cinematographer 'Gordon Willis (I)' (qv) and producers 'Fred Roos' (qv) and 'Gray Frederickson' (qv). 'The Independent Arts & Books Review' (UK), 16 November 2007 Thomas Colchart 5' 11 1/2' Detroit, Michigan, USA Male
Episode Work Writer edited into director Francis Ford Coppola    'The Independent Arts & Books' (UK), 11 June 2010, Iss. 7383, pg. 10 - 11, by: Kaleem Aftab, 'It's all about the family business' 'Eleanor Coppola' (qv) (2 February 1963 - present); 3 children 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) said that he based the 'Han Solo' character from the Star Wars trilogy on Coppola. 'New York Times Magazine' (USA), 19 May 2002, pg. 26+28, by: Frank Bruni, 'In the Name of the Father' On 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv): Most directors have one masterpiece by which they are known, or possibly two. Kurosawa has at least eight or nine. Print ad for Robert Mondavi Wines. (2000) 7 April 1939 (September 2005) Visiting Istanbul for vacation. Rodney F. Hill. _Francis Ford Coppola: Interviews._ 2004. He was born in 1939 in Detroit, USA, but he grew up in a New York suburb in a creative, supportive Italian-American family. His father, 'Carmine Coppola' (qv), was a composer and musician. His mother, 'Italia Coppola' (qv), had been an actress. Francis Ford Coppola graduated with a degree in drama from Hofstra University, and did graduate work at UCLA in filmmaking. He was training as assistant with filmmaker 'Roger Corman' (qv), working in such capacities as sound-man, dialogue director, associate producer and, eventually, director of _Dementia 13 (1963)_ (qv), Coppola's first feature film. During the next four years, Coppola was involved in a variety of script collaborations, including writing an adaptation of 'This Property is Condemned' by 'Tennessee Williams' (qv) (with 'Fred Coe' (qv) and 'Edith Sommer' (qv)), and screenplays for _Paris br?le-t-il? (1966)_ (qv) and _Patton (1970)_ (qv), the film for which Coppola won a Best Original Screenplay Academy Award. In 1966, Coppola's 2nd film brought him critical acclaim and a Master of Fine Arts degree. In 1969, Coppola and 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) established American Zoetrope, an independent film production company based in San Francisco. The company's first project was _THX 1138 (1971)_ (qv), produced by Coppola and directed by Lucas. Coppola also produced the second film that Lucas directed, _American Graffiti (1973)_ (qv), in 1973. This movie got five Academy Award nominations, including one for Best Picture. In 1971, Coppola's film _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv) became one of the highest-grossing movies in history and brought him an Oscar for writing the screenplay with 'Mario Puzo' (qv) The film was a Best Picture Academy Award-winner, and also brought Coppola a Best Director Oscar nomination. Following his work on the screenplay for _The Great Gatsby (1974)_ (qv), Coppola's next film was _The Conversation (1974)_ (qv), which was honored with the Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and brought Coppola Best Picture and Best Original Screenplay Oscar nominations. Also released that year, _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), rivaled the success of _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), and won six Academy Awards, bringing Coppola Oscars as a producer, director and writer. Coppola then began work on his most ambitious film, _Apocalypse Now (1979)_ (qv), a Vietnam War epic that was inspired by 'Joseph Conrad (I)' (qv)'s _Heart of Darkness (1993) (TV)_ (qv). Released in 1979, the acclaimed film won a Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and two Academy Awards. Also that year, Coppola executive produced the hit _The Black Stallion (1979)_ (qv). With 'George Lucas (I)' (qv), Coppola executive produced _Kagemusha (1980)_ (qv), directed by 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv), and _Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)_ (qv), directed by 'Paul Schrader (I)' (qv) and based on the life and writings of 'Yukio Mishima' (qv). Coppola also executive produced such films as _The Escape Artist (1982)_ (qv), _Hammett (1982)_ (qv) _The Black Stallion Returns (1983)_ (qv), _Barfly (1987)_ (qv), _Wind (1992)_ (qv), _The Secret Garden (1993)_ (qv), etc.  He helped to make a star of his nephew, 'Nicolas Cage' (qv). Personal tragedy hit in 1986 when his son Gio died in a boating accident. Francis Ford Coppola is one of America's most erratic, energetic and controversial filmmakers. Francis Ford Coppola 'Cinema' (Greece), March 1998, Iss. 88, pg. 45, by: Yorgos Krassakopoulos, 'Skinothetis kai alla polla...' _Brando Unauthorized (2011)_ (qv) Often works with cinematographer 'Gordon Willis (I)' (qv) and producers 'Fred Roos' (qv) and 'Gray Frederickson' (qv).
