Video Game Composer Language TV Movie actress language Kelly McGillis     'Parade Magazine' (USA), November 1997, pg. 22, by: James Brady, 'In Step With: Kelly McGillis' 'Boyd Black' (14 April 1979 - 1981) (divorced) Wanted to play the role of 'Kathryn Murphy', the district attorney in _The Accused (1988)_ (qv), because she and her roommate were assaulted and raped by two men in their apartment in 1982. 'Celebrity Sleuth' (USA), 1991, Vol. 5, Iss. 1, pg. 58-59, by: staff, 'Not To Be Myth'd: Kelly McGillis' For a long time I thought I could deal with my anger and hostility on my own. But I couldn't. I denied that it had affected me, and yet I was so frantic on the inside with other people: I needed to be constantly reassured. It wasn't until I started seeing myself self-destructing that I realized I needed help. To realize how angry I was and to ask for help -- those were the stepping stones. There's a part of me that wants to be stoic and very strong. I had to realize that the attack wasn't directed at me, as Kelly. It was random. I was at the wrong place at the wrong time. That was the first step toward getting rid of all those hostile feelings I had about it. Still, when you're a victim of a violent crime -- when somebody has taken control over your life, if only for a moment -- I don't think you ever fully recover. - Speaking about her reactions to being raped. Appeared in production of John Webber's play 'The Duchess of Malfi' at the Shakespeare Theatre, Washington, DC. (2002) McGillis, Kelly Ann 9 July 1957 (March 2004) Performing on stage as 'Mrs. Robinson' in the national touring company of the play 'The Graduate.' Kelly McGillis was born in Newport Beach, California, to Joan, a homemaker, and Donald McGillis, a general practitioner of medicine. She decided to drop out of high school to pursue a career as an actress and eventually attended Juilliard in Manhattan and Pacific Conservatory of Performing Art in Santa Monica, CA.  She held a variety of jobs while pursuing her career, such as waitressing, and snagged a few stage roles before landing a supporting part in the Academy Award-nominated _Reuben, Reuben (1983)_ (qv). This led to a lot of TV work and a lead role opposite 'Harrison Ford (I)' (qv) in the highly acclaimed thriller _Witness (1985)_ (qv). This box office hit, directed by 'Peter Weir (I)' (qv), got her noticed around Hollywood and producers took note of her. One of them was 'Jerry Bruckheimer' (qv), who cast her as Charlie Blackwood in the mega-hit _Top Gun (1986)_ (qv) which became the highest-grossing film of the year and gave her some major name recognition.  Ironically, that breakthrough role didn't help her career in terms of high-profile work. She played prosecutor Kathryn Murphy in _The Accused (1988)_ (qv) with 'Jodie Foster' (qv) who won an Academy Award for her role, but unfortunately for McGillis she was overlooked for any major nomination. Never interested in being box-office gold, she remained loyal to the theater, even after being established as a major star during the mid to late 1980s, taking such various stage roles in such 'William Shakespeare (I)' (qv) plays as 'The Merchant of Venice', 'Don Juan', 'Twelfth Night', 'The Merry Wives of Windsor', 'Mourning Becomes Electra' and 'A Midsummer Night's Dream'. In 1994 she scored the title role in the Broadway production of 'Hedda Gabler' but unfortunately it only played for 33 performances before closing.  She had two daughters in the early 1990s, and worked more sporadically on TV and film so she could spend time with her family and owned her business, a restaurant in Florida. She worked on _Winter People (1989)_ (qv), _Cat Chaser (1989)_ (qv), _The Babe (1992)_ (qv), _North (1994)_ (qv), _At First Sight (1999)_ (qv) and _The Monkey's Mask (2000)_ (qv) as well as a string of made-for-TV films.  She has completed a national stage tour of 'The Graduate', playing the infamous Mrs. Robinson, and continues to act as she begins study on Addiction Studies and raising her children in Pennsylvania. Kelly McGillis 'Prevue' (USA), June 1990, Vol. 2, Iss. 39, pg. 48-49, by: Lowell Goldman, 'Chasing Kelly McGillis' 'Kino' (Germany), December 1986 Kelly Ann McGillis 5' 10' Newport Beach, California, USA Female

Video Game Composer Language TV Movie actress language    Christine Hewett birth notes gender death date name mini biography birth date death notes 11 August 1943 A tall, fair-haired model since the late sixties, Christine Hewitt appeared in the cantina sequence of _Star Wars (1977)_ (qv) together with another 'Space Girl', Angela Staines. Although the casting call asked for blonde girls, both of them were fitted with black beehive style wigs for the occasion. Even though she was on screen for less than 5 seconds in the finished film, her character received a name and a back-story through Star Wars games and merchandising, and is listed as such on this database. Nowadays, Christine Hewitt still works as a 'mature model' in commercials and in uncredited roles in films such as _Four Weddings and a Funeral (1994)_ (qv) and _Bridget Jones's Diary (2001)_ (qv). Work Person Writer director producer  Thom Oliphant name mini biography Thom has spent a decade as a producer, executive producer, and show runner for major network and cable series. He began his career as a music video director. He has worked with who's who list of music superstars from BB King to Faith Hill, Bruce Springsteen to Shania Twain and the Dixie Chicks to Metallica. As a director, he has won awards for excellence, like the Country Music Association Video of the Year, a Clio, a Canadian Country Music Association Award, multiple Addys, and several Billboard Awards. After over 200 music videos and 100 commercial campaigns, he segued into TV. He has worked on big formats and music competition series (CMT's Can You Duet and Fox's Next Great American Band) and lately he has turned his focus has been on telling stories (CMT's Posse). Thom Oliphant

Work Person Writer director producer Jimmy Holcomb Steven Goldmann   Jimmy Holcomb James Terry Holcomb Jr. In 1998-1999, Steven Goldmann won the triple crown of the Country music video industry. His innovative direction of Faith Hill's 'This Kiss' took top prize with the Country Music Association, Academy of Country Music, and TNN Music City News Best Video of the Year. In addition, he was awarded Video of the Year by Country Music Television (CMT) and Nashville Music Awards for 'This Kiss.' The 1998 Music Row Awards Best Video of the Year and a Telly Award (Kathy Mattea's 'I'm On Your Side'), the 1998 MVPA (Music Video Production Association) Award for Country Video Of The Year (Mary Chapin Carpenter's 'Better To Dream Of You'), It was by all measurements a year to remember and a year that brought Goldmann to national prominence. It capped off a run of recognition in the music video world that started with consecutive (1996 and 1997) CMT Director of the Year Awards.  With almost 200 videos to his credit, Goldmann's reputation as a storyteller with distinct visual style has attracted such major stars as Bruce Springsteen, Alan Jackson, Faith Hill, Martina McBride, Brooks and Dunn, and Shania Twain. It was Goldmann's four videos for Shania's 'The Woman in Me' album that helped propel her album to the thirteen million unit selling mark. In 1996, he was recognized by the Canadian Country Music Association for his direction of Shania's ('If You're Not In It For Love') I'm Outta Here' with Video of the Year honors, a Clio (a prestigious acknowledgment from the US Advertising industry) and a Telly Award (a national television broadcast award for creative excellence). Rolling Stone Magazine sighted Shania and Goldmann's video for 'You Win My Love' as the 5th most import/influential video of the 90's.  It was inevitable, that after all this acclamation, Goldmann would turn his sights beyond the music video industry. In 2000 Goldmann began principle photography on a fantasy musical 'Our Country' an IMAX film for Gaylord Entertainment. Featuring Lyle Lovett, The Dixie Chicks, Dwight Yoakum, Alan Jackson, Martina McBride, Dolly Parton, and over thirty other stars, the film was released in 2003 coinciding with yet another honor by the Academy of Country Music -- Video of the Year for the Alan Jackson video, 'Drive.'  With a script by Writer's Guild Of Canada winner for Best Feature Screenplay (Stardom, directed by Denys Arcand), J. Jacob Potashnik, Goldmann directed, '50 Odd Dollars,' a film noir inspired by Razor & Tie recording Artist, singer/songwriter Fred Eaglesmith's recording of the same name. The film has had a long and well-received broadcast run on CMT CANADA and has won Gold Awards at the Houston World Film Festival and the Alabama/UNA Television and Film Festival. 2004 found Goldmann directing episodes of 'Missing' starring Vivica Fox for Lifetime and Lions Gate Entertainment, while still finding time to win Best Video and Best Director honors at the Canadian Country Music Awards as well as being nominated for the CMT Awards Breakthrough Video of the Year for Universal recording artist Julie Roberts  Goldmann most recently brought his style and story telling ability to his debut feature film 'Broken Bridges,' starring Toby Keith, Kelly Preston, Tess Harper, and Burt Reynolds for CMT FILMS/Paramount. In its inaugural showings its garnered more than 20 million viewers to make it the most-watched original telecast in CMT history. Additionally, the video for the film's centerpiece song 'Broken' was named the winner of the CMT.com Loaded Award for the 'Number One Streamed Video From A New Artist (Rookie of the Year). In 2007 he completed work on the horror film 'Trailer Park Of Terror' with Producer Jonathan Bogner . Based on the Imperium comic book of the same name, this will be Goldmann's first foray into a genre he has always loved. White Trash horror films will never be the same again! Steven Goldmann

Episode Producer Language actor language Paul Benjamin    1938 Born and raised for a time in Pelion, South Carolina, African-American actor Paul Benjamin is the youngest of twelve children born to a Baptist preacher, the Reverend Fair Benjamin, and his wife Rosa. Paul lost his mother while still a baby and his father as a child. He moved to Columbia, South Carolina, where he was taken in by one of his older brothers, David, and his wife and family. Suppressing his teenage desires of becoming an actor due to social pressures, he attended C.A. Johnson High and, upon graduation, enrolled at Benedict College for about a year before deciding to move to New York City and pursue his dream. Studying at the 'Herbert Berghof' (qv) Studio, he finally made his professional stage debut in the late 60s at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. His theater career quickly picked up steam with such classical and contemporary plays as 'Hamlet' (1967), 'Cities in Bezique (1969), 'The Owl Answers' (1969), 'No Place to Be Somebody' (1969), 'The Year Boston Won the Pennant' (1969), 'Camino Royal' 1970, 'Operation Sidewinder' (1970), Boesman and Lena (1970), 'The Black Terror' (1971), 'Assassination 1865' (1971), 'The Cherry Orchard' (1973) and 'The Old Glory' (1976).  Benjamin made his film debut inauspiciously as a bartender in _Midnight Cowboy (1969)_ (qv), which highlighted New York's seamier side. Following small roles in _The Anderson Tapes (1971)_ (qv) and _Born to Win (1971)_ (qv), he earned a top featured role and strong notices playing a robber-turned-killer in _Across 110th Street (1972)_ (qv) co-starring 'Anthony Quinn (I)' (qv) and 'Yaphet Kotto' (qv), which again took place on the gritty New York streets. He then gave incisive, strong-armed portrayals as part of a gang in _The Deadly Trackers (1973)_ (qv) and as a lieutenant alongside 'Tony Lo Bianco' (qv) and 'Hal Linden' (qv) in the above-average TV-movie _Mr. Inside/Mr. Outside (1973) (TV)_ (qv). His film and TV career, which peaked in the 1970s, included the 'blaxploitation' scene -- he appeared with 'Mary Alice (I)' (qv) as the parents of the titular character in _The Education of Sonny Carson (1974)_ (qv) and as a senator in the 'Pam Grier' (qv) vehicle _Friday Foster (1975)_ (qv).  Throughout the decades he has worked with prestigious actors in prestigious projects yet never attained the public attention he merited. Neverthless he added solid authenticity to the musical bio _Leadbelly (1976)_ (qv); 'Clint Eastwood' (qv)'s _Escape from Alcatraz (1979)_ (qv); the 'Richard Pryor' (qv) comedy-drama _Some Kind of Hero (1982)_ (qv); 'Barbra Streisand' (qv)'s courtroom vehicle _Nuts (1987)_ (qv); 'Spike Lee' (qv)'s lacerating, one-two punch on urban black life in _Do the Right Thing (1989)_ (qv); the Temptations-like story of _The Five Heartbeats (1991)_ (qv); and the excellent, fact-based drama in _Rosewood (1997)_ (qv) with racism at its core. On the mini-movie circuit he appeared in good company as 'LeVar Burton' (qv)'s father in the baseball story _One in a Million: The Ron LeFlore Story (1977) (TV)_ (qv), and was a noticeable factor in _Gideon's Trumpet (1980) (TV)_ (qv) starring 'Henry Fonda' (qv); 'Maya Angelou' (qv)'s _I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings (1979) (TV)_ (qv); the hard-hitting _'The Atlanta Child Murders' (1985)_ (qv)_ (TV) and, perhaps most notably, the chain-gang story _The Man Who Broke 1,000 Chains (1987) (TV)_ (qv) in which he portrayed Big Sam.  Paul the actor has added to his success as an award-winning playwright as well and, broaching age 70, continues to write as well as perform. His play 'Carrier', in which he appeared with 'Roscoe Lee Browne' (qv) and 'Paula Kelly (I)' (qv), received special citations for its writing and performances. Paul Benjamin Mayor Tom Bradley presented Paul with a Commendation from the City of Los Angeles for Paul's play, 'Carrier,' for which 'Paula Kelly (I)' (qv) won the 1982 NAACP Image Awards for Best Actress. She, along with Paul and actor/poet Roscoe Lee Browne, received Certificates of Recognition from Sen. Diane Watson for their performances in the same play. 6' 1 1/2' Pelion, South Carolina, USA Male
Episode Producer Language actor language   Michael Sottile gender name magazine cover photo Michael Sottile 'Modus Operandi' (USA), 4 April 2012 Male
Episode Producer Language actor language Morris Chestnut    'Chicago Tribune' (USA), 9 January 2009, by: Lauren Viera, 'Morris Chestnut: An Actor Not Easily Broken' 'Pam Byse' (1995 - present); 2 children Has worked with 'Steven Seagal' (qv) twice. He was both Seagal's character's partner and main enemy. In _Under Siege 2: Dark Territory (1995)_ (qv), Chestnut is Seagal's character's reluctant partner. In _Half Past Dead (2002)_ (qv), he co-starred as the main villain. 'Razor magazine' (USA), August/September 2001, Vol. 1, Iss. 9, pg. 81, by: none, 'night vision' Music video for Jamie Foxx: 'Blame It' Chestnut, Morris L. 1 January 1969 A tall, handsome, and versatile black actor, Morris Chestnut first came to be recognized by moviegoers starring as Ricky in _Boyz n the Hood (1991)_ (qv), a role where he played a high school running back using his football skills to escape the violent surroundings of his South Central Los Angeles neighborhood. His half brother was played by 'Ice Cube' (qv) who in the movie did not have the same motivation. Two years later, he landed a lead role in Civil Rights Drama _The Ernest Green Story (1993) (TV)_ (qv), showing courage and perseverance as one of the Arkansas Nine high school students. He later starred in action films like _Under Siege 2: Dark Territory (1995)_ (qv), _G.I. Jane (1997)_ (qv) and _Half Past Dead (2002)_ (qv) as well as the romantic comedies _The Best Man (1999)_ (qv), _The Brothers (2001)_ (qv), _Two Can Play That Game (2001)_ (qv), and _Breakin' All the Rules (2004)_ (qv). In 2004, he appeared in _Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)_ (qv) and _Ladder 49 (2004)_ (qv). Morris Chestnut Morris L. Chestnut 6' Cerritos, California, USA Male
Episode Producer Language actor language Evan Seinfeld    29 December 1967 Spyder Jones 'Club' (USA), February 2003, Vol. 29, Iss. 1, pg. 50-55, by: Anneli Adolfsson, 'Rock Hard! 1 Rock Superstar + 6 Gorgeous Girls = Sex'n'Rock'n'Roll Galore!' 'Tera Patrick' (qv) (9 January 2004 - 2009) (divorced) Evan Seinfeld Previously played bass guitar for Damnocracy. Currently plays for the Brooklyn based hardcore/metal band Biohazard, the Spyders, and joined Tattooed Millionaires in October 2008. Spyder Jonez 5' 9 1/2' Brooklyn, New York, USA Male Vocalist and bassist for Hardcore Metal band, Biohazard.
Episode Producer Language actor language   Ewan Bailey birth notes gender aka name trivia mini biography birth date spouse height 1966 'Ruth' (1997 - present); 1 child Ewan Bailey was born in 1966 in Brighton, Sussex,as Ewan Thomson, the son of Dr. Bruce Thomson, a noted Rugby Union player who represented Scotland at international level. He attended Brighton College and read Modern History at Keble College, Oxford, before studying drama at the Central School of Speech and Drama in London. In 2001 he was one of the actor presenters of the BBC radio satirical show 'The Sunday Format', mocking Sunday newspaper contents, and has provided the narration for numerous television documentaries on Channel 4 and the Discovery Channel. He is also the founder of Rubbaball, a small comedy theater company. Ewan Bailey Graduated from Oxford University with a degree in Modern History. Has a Black Belt (Second Dan) in Shotokan Karate. Ewan Bailley 191 cm Brighton, Sussex, England, UK Male
Episode Producer Language actor language  David Leitch   David Leitch Dave Leitch 5' 11' Male
Episode Producer Language actor language  Paul Benjamin   1938 Born and raised for a time in Pelion, South Carolina, African-American actor Paul Benjamin is the youngest of twelve children born to a Baptist preacher, the Reverend Fair Benjamin, and his wife Rosa. Paul lost his mother while still a baby and his father as a child. He moved to Columbia, South Carolina, where he was taken in by one of his older brothers, David, and his wife and family. Suppressing his teenage desires of becoming an actor due to social pressures, he attended C.A. Johnson High and, upon graduation, enrolled at Benedict College for about a year before deciding to move to New York City and pursue his dream. Studying at the 'Herbert Berghof' (qv) Studio, he finally made his professional stage debut in the late 60s at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. His theater career quickly picked up steam with such classical and contemporary plays as 'Hamlet' (1967), 'Cities in Bezique (1969), 'The Owl Answers' (1969), 'No Place to Be Somebody' (1969), 'The Year Boston Won the Pennant' (1969), 'Camino Royal' 1970, 'Operation Sidewinder' (1970), Boesman and Lena (1970), 'The Black Terror' (1971), 'Assassination 1865' (1971), 'The Cherry Orchard' (1973) and 'The Old Glory' (1976).  Benjamin made his film debut inauspiciously as a bartender in _Midnight Cowboy (1969)_ (qv), which highlighted New York's seamier side. Following small roles in _The Anderson Tapes (1971)_ (qv) and _Born to Win (1971)_ (qv), he earned a top featured role and strong notices playing a robber-turned-killer in _Across 110th Street (1972)_ (qv) co-starring 'Anthony Quinn (I)' (qv) and 'Yaphet Kotto' (qv), which again took place on the gritty New York streets. He then gave incisive, strong-armed portrayals as part of a gang in _The Deadly Trackers (1973)_ (qv) and as a lieutenant alongside 'Tony Lo Bianco' (qv) and 'Hal Linden' (qv) in the above-average TV-movie _Mr. Inside/Mr. Outside (1973) (TV)_ (qv). His film and TV career, which peaked in the 1970s, included the 'blaxploitation' scene -- he appeared with 'Mary Alice (I)' (qv) as the parents of the titular character in _The Education of Sonny Carson (1974)_ (qv) and as a senator in the 'Pam Grier' (qv) vehicle _Friday Foster (1975)_ (qv). Neverthless he added solid authenticity to the musical bio _Leadbelly (1976)_ (qv); 'Clint Eastwood' (qv)'s _Escape from Alcatraz (1979)_ (qv); the 'Richard Pryor' (qv) comedy-drama _Some Kind of Hero (1982)_ (qv); 'Barbra Streisand' (qv)'s courtroom vehicle _Nuts (1987)_ (qv); 'Spike Lee' (qv)'s lacerating, one-two punch on urban black life in _Do the Right Thing (1989)_ (qv); the Temptations-like story of _The Five Heartbeats (1991)_ (qv); and the excellent, fact-based drama in _Rosewood (1997)_ (qv) with racism at its core. Episode Movie Director writer spoofed in Mario Puzo    'Playboy' (USA), July 1991, Vol. 38, Iss. 7, pg. 18, by: Joan Goodman, 'Guest Shot: Mario Puzo' 'Erika Lina Broske' (1946 - 9 November 1978) (her death); 5 children Bay Shore, Long Island, New York, USA (heart failure) Was writing a story outline for a fourth 'Godfather' film before he died. The best way to launch an Italian restaurant is to have it raided because the Mafia eats there. Everybody knows they eat well. Novel: 'The Family' Puzo, Mario Gianluigi 15 October 1920 Mario Puzo was born October 15, 1920, in 'Hell's Kitchen' on Manhattan's (NY) West Side and, following military service in World War II, attended New York's New School for Social Research and Columbia University. His best-known novel, 'The Godfather,' was preceded by two critically acclaimed novels, 'The Dark Arena' and 'The Fortunate Pilgrim.' In 1978, he published 'Fools Die,' followed by 'The Sicilian' (1984) and 'The Fourth K' (1991). Mario Puzo has also written several screenplays, including _Earthquake (1974)_ (qv), _Superman (1978)_ (qv), and all three 'Godfather' movies, for which he received two Academy Awards. Mario's latest novel, 1996's 'The Last Don,' was made into a CBS television miniseries in May 1997, starring 'Danny Aiello' (qv), 'Kirstie Alley' (qv) and 'Joe Mantegna' (qv). In 1997, Part II was aired. Also in 1997, Mario's 'The Fortunate Pilgrim' was re-released by Random House. Mario passed away July 2, 1999, at his home in Bay Shore, Long Island. His last novel, 'Omerta,' will be published July, 2000. He is survived by his companion of 20 years, Carol Gino, and five children. Mario Puzo 'Di?rio de Not?cias' (Portugal), 4 July 1999, pg. 58, by: Abel Coelho de Morais, 'Morreu o autor de ?O Padrinho?' 2 July 1999 'Time' (USA), 28 August 1978 Mario Gianluigi Puzo New York City, New York, USA Male
Episode Movie Director writer spoofed in Francis Ford Coppola    'The Independent Arts & Books' (UK), 11 June 2010, Iss. 7383, pg. 10 - 11, by: Kaleem Aftab, 'It's all about the family business' 'Eleanor Coppola' (qv) (2 February 1963 - present); 3 children 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) said that he based the 'Han Solo' character from the Star Wars trilogy on Coppola. 'New York Times Magazine' (USA), 19 May 2002, pg. 26+28, by: Frank Bruni, 'In the Name of the Father' On 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv): Most directors have one masterpiece by which they are known, or possibly two. Kurosawa has at least eight or nine. Print ad for Robert Mondavi Wines. (2000) 7 April 1939 (September 2005) Visiting Istanbul for vacation. Rodney F. Hill. _Francis Ford Coppola: Interviews._ 2004. He was born in 1939 in Detroit, USA, but he grew up in a New York suburb in a creative, supportive Italian-American family. His father, 'Carmine Coppola' (qv), was a composer and musician. His mother, 'Italia Coppola' (qv), had been an actress. Francis Ford Coppola graduated with a degree in drama from Hofstra University, and did graduate work at UCLA in filmmaking. He was training as assistant with filmmaker 'Roger Corman' (qv), working in such capacities as sound-man, dialogue director, associate producer and, eventually, director of _Dementia 13 (1963)_ (qv), Coppola's first feature film. During the next four years, Coppola was involved in a variety of script collaborations, including writing an adaptation of 'This Property is Condemned' by 'Tennessee Williams' (qv) (with 'Fred Coe' (qv) and 'Edith Sommer' (qv)), and screenplays for _Paris br?le-t-il? (1966)_ (qv) and _Patton (1970)_ (qv), the film for which Coppola won a Best Original Screenplay Academy Award. In 1966, Coppola's 2nd film brought him critical acclaim and a Master of Fine Arts degree. In 1969, Coppola and 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) established American Zoetrope, an independent film production company based in San Francisco. The company's first project was _THX 1138 (1971)_ (qv), produced by Coppola and directed by Lucas. Coppola also produced the second film that Lucas directed, _American Graffiti (1973)_ (qv), in 1973. This movie got five Academy Award nominations, including one for Best Picture. In 1971, Coppola's film _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv) became one of the highest-grossing movies in history and brought him an Oscar for writing the screenplay with 'Mario Puzo' (qv) The film was a Best Picture Academy Award-winner, and also brought Coppola a Best Director Oscar nomination. Following his work on the screenplay for _The Great Gatsby (1974)_ (qv), Coppola's next film was _The Conversation (1974)_ (qv), which was honored with the Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and brought Coppola Best Picture and Best Original Screenplay Oscar nominations. Also released that year, _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), rivaled the success of _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), and won six Academy Awards, bringing Coppola Oscars as a producer, director and writer. Coppola then began work on his most ambitious film, _Apocalypse Now (1979)_ (qv), a Vietnam War epic that was inspired by 'Joseph Conrad (I)' (qv)'s _Heart of Darkness (1993) (TV)_ (qv). Released in 1979, the acclaimed film won a Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and two Academy Awards. Also that year, Coppola executive produced the hit _The Black Stallion (1979)_ (qv). With 'George Lucas (I)' (qv), Coppola executive produced _Kagemusha (1980)_ (qv), directed by 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv), and _Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)_ (qv), directed by 'Paul Schrader (I)' (qv) and based on the life and writings of 'Yukio Mishima' (qv). Coppola also executive produced such films as _The Escape Artist (1982)_ (qv), _Hammett (1982)_ (qv) _The Black Stallion Returns (1983)_ (qv), _Barfly (1987)_ (qv), _Wind (1992)_ (qv), _The Secret Garden (1993)_ (qv), etc.  He helped to make a star of his nephew, 'Nicolas Cage' (qv). Personal tragedy hit in 1986 when his son Gio died in a boating accident. Francis Ford Coppola is one of America's most erratic, energetic and controversial filmmakers. Francis Ford Coppola 'Cinema' (Greece), March 1998, Iss. 88, pg. 45, by: Yorgos Krassakopoulos, 'Skinothetis kai alla polla...' _Brando Unauthorized (2011)_ (qv) Often works with cinematographer 'Gordon Willis (I)' (qv) and producers 'Fred Roos' (qv) and 'Gray Frederickson' (qv). 'The Independent Arts & Books Review' (UK), 16 November 2007 Thomas Colchart 5' 11 1/2' Detroit, Michigan, USA Male
Episode Movie Director writer spoofed in  Francis Ford Coppola   'The Independent Arts & Books' (UK), 11 June 2010, Iss. 7383, pg. 10 - 11, by: Kaleem Aftab, 'It's all about the family business' 'Eleanor Coppola' (qv) (2 February 1963 - present); 3 children 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) said that he based the 'Han Solo' character from the Star Wars trilogy on Coppola. 'New York Times Magazine' (USA), 19 May 2002, pg. 26+28, by: Frank Bruni, 'In the Name of the Father' On 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv): Most directors have one masterpiece by which they are known, or possibly two. Kurosawa has at least eight or nine. Print ad for Robert Mondavi Wines. (2000) 7 April 1939 (September 2005) Visiting Istanbul for vacation. Rodney F. Hill. _Francis Ford Coppola: Interviews._ 2004. He was born in 1939 in Detroit, USA, but he grew up in a New York suburb in a creative, supportive Italian-American family. His father, 'Carmine Coppola' (qv), was a composer and musician. His mother, 'Italia Coppola' (qv), had been an actress. Francis Ford Coppola graduated with a degree in drama from Hofstra University, and did graduate work at UCLA in filmmaking. He was training as assistant with filmmaker 'Roger Corman' (qv), working in such capacities as sound-man, dialogue director, associate producer and, eventually, director of _Dementia 13 (1963)_ (qv), Coppola's first feature film. During the next four years, Coppola was involved in a variety of script collaborations, including writing an adaptation of 'This Property is Condemned' by 'Tennessee Williams' (qv) (with 'Fred Coe' (qv) and 'Edith Sommer' (qv)), and screenplays for _Paris br?le-t-il? (1966)_ (qv) and _Patton (1970)_ (qv), the film for which Coppola won a Best Original Screenplay Academy Award. In 1966, Coppola's 2nd film brought him critical acclaim and a Master of Fine Arts degree. In 1969, Coppola and 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) established American Zoetrope, an independent film production company based in San Francisco. The company's first project was _THX 1138 (1971)_ (qv), produced by Coppola and directed by Lucas. Coppola also produced the second film that Lucas directed, _American Graffiti (1973)_ (qv), in 1973. This movie got five Academy Award nominations, including one for Best Picture. In 1971, Coppola's film _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv) became one of the highest-grossing movies in history and brought him an Oscar for writing the screenplay with 'Mario Puzo' (qv) The film was a Best Picture Academy Award-winner, and also brought Coppola a Best Director Oscar nomination. Following his work on the screenplay for _The Great Gatsby (1974)_ (qv), Coppola's next film was _The Conversation (1974)_ (qv), which was honored with the Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and brought Coppola Best Picture and Best Original Screenplay Oscar nominations. Also released that year, _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), rivaled the success of _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), and won six Academy Awards, bringing Coppola Oscars as a producer, director and writer. Coppola then began work on his most ambitious film, _Apocalypse Now (1979)_ (qv), a Vietnam War epic that was inspired by 'Joseph Conrad (I)' (qv)'s _Heart of Darkness (1993) (TV)_ (qv). Released in 1979, the acclaimed film won a Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and two Academy Awards. Also that year, Coppola executive produced the hit _The Black Stallion (1979)_ (qv). With 'George Lucas (I)' (qv), Coppola executive produced _Kagemusha (1980)_ (qv), directed by 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv), and _Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)_ (qv), directed by 'Paul Schrader (I)' (qv) and based on the life and writings of 'Yukio Mishima' (qv). Coppola also executive produced such films as _The Escape Artist (1982)_ (qv), _Hammett (1982)_ (qv) _The Black Stallion Returns (1983)_ (qv), _Barfly (1987)_ (qv), _Wind (1992)_ (qv), _The Secret Garden (1993)_ (qv), etc.  He helped to make a star of his nephew, 'Nicolas Cage' (qv). Personal tragedy hit in 1986 when his son Gio died in a boating accident. Francis Ford Coppola is one of America's most erratic, energetic and controversial filmmakers. Francis Ford Coppola 'Cinema' (Greece), March 1998, Iss. 88, pg. 45, by: Yorgos Krassakopoulos, 'Skinothetis kai alla polla...' _Brando Unauthorized (2011)_ (qv) Often works with cinematographer 'Gordon Willis (I)' (qv) and producers 'Fred Roos' (qv) and 'Gray Frederickson' (qv). 'The Independent Arts & Books Review' (UK), 16 November 2007 Thomas Colchart 5' 11 1/2' Detroit, Michigan, USA Male
Episode Movie Director writer spoofed in  Mario Puzo   'Playboy' (USA), July 1991, Vol. 38, Iss. 7, pg. 18, by: Joan Goodman, 'Guest Shot: Mario Puzo' 'Erika Lina Broske' (1946 - 9 November 1978) (her death); 5 children Bay Shore, Long Island, New York, USA (heart failure) Was writing a story outline for a fourth 'Godfather' film before he died. The best way to launch an Italian restaurant is to have it raided because the Mafia eats there. Everybody knows they eat well. Novel: 'The Family' Puzo, Mario Gianluigi 15 October 1920 Mario Puzo was born October 15, 1920, in 'Hell's Kitchen' on Manhattan's (NY) West Side and, following military service in World War II, attended New York's New School for Social Research and Columbia University. His best-known novel, 'The Godfather,' was preceded by two critically acclaimed novels, 'The Dark Arena' and 'The Fortunate Pilgrim.' In 1978, he published 'Fools Die,' followed by 'The Sicilian' (1984) and 'The Fourth K' (1991). Mario Puzo has also written several screenplays, including _Earthquake (1974)_ (qv), _Superman (1978)_ (qv), and all three 'Godfather' movies, for which he received two Academy Awards. Mario's latest novel, 1996's 'The Last Don,' was made into a CBS television miniseries in May 1997, starring 'Danny Aiello' (qv), 'Kirstie Alley' (qv) and 'Joe Mantegna' (qv). In 1997, Part II was aired. Also in 1997, Mario's 'The Fortunate Pilgrim' was re-released by Random House. Mario passed away July 2, 1999, at his home in Bay Shore, Long Island. His last novel, 'Omerta,' will be published July, 2000. He is survived by his companion of 20 years, Carol Gino, and five children. Mario Puzo 'Di?rio de Not?cias' (Portugal), 4 July 1999, pg. 58, by: Abel Coelho de Morais, 'Morreu o autor de ?O Padrinho?' 2 July 1999 'Time' (USA), 28 August 1978 Mario Gianluigi Puzo New York City, New York, USA Male

Video Game Company TV Movie Actor actor distributors   Cinema International Corporation (CIC) [FI] Ice-T gender other works trivia nick names spouse article quotes interviews birth notes books aka name trade mark birth name mini biography birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial Cinema International Corporation (CIC) [FI] 'NME' (UK), 22 March 1997, pg. 12+57, by: Sylvia Patterson, 'For Your Demise Only' 'Coco Austin' (qv) (31 December 2005 - present) His feud with former LAPD chief 'Daryl Gates' (qv) was widely reported by the American press. 'Veronica' (Netherlands), 23 February 2008, Iss. 8, by: Sunshine, 'Tupperware T' (On the controversy created by 'Cop Killer): 'When the President (of the United States) mentions your name in anger, you KNOW the s--t has hit the fan!' (1998) Album: 'Below Utopia: The Lost Score,' Noo Trybe/Virgin/EMI Records V2-45854. Marrow, Tracy Lauren 16 February 1958 Ice Ice-T and Douglas Century. _Ice: A Memoir of Gangster Life and Redemption-from South Central to Hollywood._ New York: One World/Ballantine, 2011. ISBN 0345523288 The legendary gangsta hip-hop emcee Ice-T was born Tracy Marrow on February 16, 1958, in Newark, New Jersey. He moved to Los Angeles, California, to live with his paternal aunt after the death of his father while he was in the sixth grade; his mother had died earlier when he was in the third grade. His aunt lived in the South Los Angeles district of Crenshaw, colloquially referred to as South Central. He became immersed in the street life of the inner-city and eventually became a member of the West Side Rollin 30s Original Harlem Crips.  In 1979, Marrow joined the Army after leaving Crenshaw High School, but his 4-year hitch was enough for him, as he was a leader, not a follower. 'I didn't like total submission to a leader other than myself,' he said. After ETSing from the Army in 1983, he returned to South Central with the intention of becoming a hip-hop musician. More than music, his life got caught up in street life as as a jewel thief and as a pimp. (His nomme de guerre, Ice T, is an homage to the fabled pimp and raconteur Iceberg Slim ('Robert Beck (III)' (qv)). He committed himself totally to his music after a 1985 car crash.  As a musician, Ice-T played a major role in the creation of the gangsta incarnation of hip-hop music and was a colossus of the West Coast hip-hop scene, despite his East Coast, greater New York, origins. Though his music displays a political consciousness, like the indictments of racism that were a hallmark of seminal hip-hop group 'Public Enemy' (qv), it also is nihilistic as befits a chronicler of street life. His most infamous song, the heavy metal 'Cop Killer,' was one of the major battle in the cultural wars of the 1990s, in which cultural conservatives enlisted the Moses of the right wing, 'Charlton Heston' (qv), to get Ice-T dropped from his then-label, Sire/Warner Bros.  The charismatic Ice-T has also achieved success as an actor in movies and on TV. He plays Detective Odafin Tutuola on the TV series _'Law & Order: Special Victims Unit' (1999)_ (qv), which is ironic for someone famous for 'Cop Killer' and his feud with the L.A.P.D. Ice-T currently resides in North Bergen, New Jersey, with his wife, 'Coco Austin' (qv). Ice-T 'Spin' (USA), May 1991, Vol. 7, Iss. 2, pg. 58-59, by: Scott Cohen, 'Cool Career Move: Ice-T' His instantly recognizable nasal voice 'Oor' (Netherlands), 22 August 1992, Iss. 17 Tracy Marrow 5' 11' Newark, New Jersey, USA Male
Video Game Company TV Movie Actor actor distributors  David Leitch Cinema International Corporation (CIC) [FI]   David Leitch Dave Leitch 5' 11' Male Cinema International Corporation (CIC) [FI]

He was both Seagal's character's partner and main enemy. In _Under Siege 2: Dark Territory (1995)_ (qv), Chestnut is Seagal's character's reluctant partner. In _Half Past Dead (2002)_ (qv), he co-starred as the main villain. 'Razor magazine' (USA), August/September 2001, Vol. 1, Iss. 9, pg. 81, by: none, 'night vision' Music video for Jamie Foxx: 'Blame It' Chestnut, Morris L. 1 January 1969 A tall, handsome, and versatile black actor, Morris Chestnut first came to be recognized by moviegoers starring as Ricky in _Boyz n the Hood (1991)_ (qv), a role where he played a high school running back using his football skills to escape the violent surroundings of his South Central Los Angeles neighborhood. His half brother was played by 'Ice Cube' (qv) who in the movie did not have the same motivation. Two years later, he landed a lead role in Civil Rights Drama _The Ernest Green Story (1993) (TV)_ (qv), showing courage and perseverance as one of the Arkansas Nine high school students. He later starred in action films like _Under Siege 2: Dark Territory (1995)_ (qv), _G.I. Jane (1997)_ (qv) and _Half Past Dead (2002)_ (qv) as well as the romantic comedies _The Best Man (1999)_ (qv), _The Brothers (2001)_ (qv), _Two Can Play That Game (2001)_ (qv), and _Breakin' All the Rules (2004)_ (qv). In 2004, he appeared in _Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)_ (qv) and _Ladder 49 (2004)_ (qv). Morris Chestnut Morris L. Chestnut 6' Cerritos, California, USA Male Cinema International Corporation (CIC) [FI]
Video Game Company TV Movie Actor actor distributors  Paul Benjamin  Cinema International Corporation (CIC) [FI] name 1938 Born and raised for a time in Pelion, South Carolina, African-American actor Paul Benjamin is the youngest of twelve children born to a Baptist preacher, the Reverend Fair Benjamin, and his wife Rosa. Paul lost his mother while still a baby and his father as a child. He moved to Columbia, South Carolina, where he was taken in by one of his older brothers, David, and his wife and family. Suppressing his teenage desires of becoming an actor due to social pressures, he attended C.A. Johnson High and, upon graduation, enrolled at Benedict College for about a year before deciding to move to New York City and pursue his dream. Studying at the 'Herbert Berghof' (qv) Studio, he finally made his professional stage debut in the late 60s at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. His theater career quickly picked up steam with such classical and contemporary plays as 'Hamlet' (1967), 'Cities in Bezique (1969), 'The Owl Answers' (1969), 'No Place to Be Somebody' (1969), 'The Year Boston Won the Pennant' (1969), 'Camino Royal' 1970, 'Operation Sidewinder' (1970), Boesman and Lena (1970), 'The Black Terror' (1971), 'Assassination 1865' (1971), 'The Cherry Orchard' (1973) and 'The Old Glory' (1976).  Benjamin made his film debut inauspiciously as a bartender in _Midnight Cowboy (1969)_ (qv), which highlighted New York's seamier side. Following small roles in _The Anderson Tapes (1971)_ (qv) and _Born to Win (1971)_ (qv), he earned a top featured role and strong notices playing a robber-turned-killer in _Across 110th Street (1972)_ (qv) co-starring 'Anthony Quinn (I)' (qv) and 'Yaphet Kotto' (qv), which again took place on the gritty New York streets. He then gave incisive, strong-armed portrayals as part of a gang in _The Deadly Trackers (1973)_ (qv) and as a lieutenant alongside 'Tony Lo Bianco' (qv) and 'Hal Linden' (qv) in the above-average TV-movie _Mr. Inside/Mr. Outside (1973) (TV)_ (qv). His film and TV career, which peaked in the 1970s, included the 'blaxploitation' scene -- he appeared with 'Mary Alice (I)' (qv) as the parents of the titular character in _The Education of Sonny Carson (1974)_ (qv) and as a senator in the 'Pam Grier' (qv) vehicle _Friday Foster (1975)_ (qv).  Throughout the decades he has worked with prestigious actors in prestigious projects yet never attained the public attention he merited. Neverthless he added solid authenticity to the musical bio _Leadbelly (1976)_ (qv); 'Clint Eastwood' (qv)'s _Escape from Alcatraz (1979)_ (qv); the 'Richard Pryor' (qv) comedy-drama _Some Kind of Hero (1982)_ (qv); 'Barbra Streisand' (qv)'s courtroom vehicle _Nuts (1987)_ (qv); 'Spike Lee' (qv)'s lacerating, one-two punch on urban black life in _Do the Right Thing (1989)_ (qv); the Temptations-like story of _The Five Heartbeats (1991)_ (qv); and the excellent, fact-based drama in _Rosewood (1997)_ (qv) with racism at its core. On the mini-movie circuit he appeared in good company as 'LeVar Burton' (qv)'s father in the baseball story _One in a Million: The Ron LeFlore Story (1977) (TV)_ (qv), and was a noticeable factor in _Gideon's Trumpet (1980) (TV)_ (qv) starring 'Henry Fonda' (qv); 'Maya Angelou' (qv)'s _I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings (1979) (TV)_ (qv); the hard-hitting _'The Atlanta Child Murders' (1985)_ (qv)_ (TV) and, perhaps most notably, the chain-gang story _The Man Who Broke 1,000 Chains (1987) (TV)_ (qv) in which he portrayed Big Sam.  Paul the actor has added to his success as an award-winning playwright as well and, broaching age 70, continues to write as well as perform. His play 'Carrier', in which he appeared with 'Roscoe Lee Browne' (qv) and 'Paula Kelly (I)' (qv), received special citations for its writing and performances. Paul Benjamin Mayor Tom Bradley presented Paul with a Commendation from the City of Los Angeles for Paul's play, 'Carrier,' for which 'Paula Kelly (I)' (qv) won the 1982 NAACP Image Awards for Best Actress. She, along with Paul and actor/poet Roscoe Lee Browne, received Certificates of Recognition from Sen. Diane Watson for their performances in the same play. 6' 1 1/2' Pelion, South Carolina, USA Male Cinema International Corporation (CIC) [FI]

Video Game Company TV Movie Actor actor distributors   Cinema International Corporation (CIC) [FI] Ewan Bailey birth notes gender aka name trivia mini biography birth date spouse height Cinema International Corporation (CIC) [FI] 1966 'Ruth' (1997 - present); 1 child Ewan Bailey was born in 1966 in Brighton, Sussex,as Ewan Thomson, the son of Dr. Bruce Thomson, a noted Rugby Union player who represented Scotland at international level. He attended Brighton College and read Modern History at Keble College, Oxford, before studying drama at the Central School of Speech and Drama in London. In 2001 he was one of the actor presenters of the BBC radio satirical show 'The Sunday Format', mocking Sunday newspaper contents, and has provided the narration for numerous television documentaries on Channel 4 and the Discovery Channel. He is also the founder of Rubbaball, a small comedy theater company. Ewan Bailey Graduated from Oxford University with a degree in Modern History. Has a Black Belt (Second Dan) in Shotokan Karate. Video Game Movie Production Designer Actress production designer writer  Simon Moore Jack Martin Smith   1958 Simon Moore (1987) His play, 'Up On The Roof', was performed at the Apollo Theatre in London, England with 'Beverly Hills (I)' (qv), 'Felicity Montagu' (qv), 'Michael M?ller (I)' (qv), 'Mark McGann (I)' (qv) and 'Gary Olsen (I)' (qv) in the cast. 2 January 1911 Jack Martin Smith graduated with a degree in architecture from the University of Southern California. He joined MGM as a sketch artist and designer in 1938 (among others, creating drawings for the Emerald City in _The Wizard of Oz (1939)_ (qv)) and the following year was promoted to full art director. He worked for the studio until 1954, chiefly associated with creating the lavish, mythical backgrounds for the big budget musicals produced by the 'Arthur Freed' (qv) unit, foremost among them _Meet Me in St. Louis (1944)_ (qv), _Ziegfeld Follies (1945)_ (qv) and _Easter Parade (1948)_ (qv).  In 1954, Smith joined 20th Century Fox, collaborating with 'Lyle R. Wheeler' (qv) on creating the sumptuous look of _An Affair to Remember (1957)_ (qv) and _Peyton Place (1957)_ (qv). He eventually succeeded Wheeler as supervising art director, putting his stamp on some of the most spectacular blockbusters of the era, including _Cleopatra (1963)_ (qv) and _Hello, Dolly! (1969)_ (qv). From the early 60's, he also worked extensively in television. In addition to his work in Hollywood, Smith was an accomplished painter of seascapes and river scenes. Jack Martin Smith Santa Barbara, California, USA Jack M. Smith Los Angeles, California, USA

He and Zimbalist both had died while the movie was still being filmed. Crew Member Series Producer actress producer Natalia Livingston  Jill Farren-Phelps birth notes gender aka name trivia birth name mini biography birth date spouse 26 March 1976 Natty (2008) Appeared in an infomercial, hosted by 'Vanessa Williams (VII)' (qv), for 'Proactiv Solution' acne medication. Natalia Livingston 'Soap Opera Digest' (USA), 11 November 2003, Vol. 28, Iss. 45, pg. 112, 'Take Five' studied ballet for 12 years Natty 5' 5' Honestly, and you're not going to believe this, the last time I really got angry was when I was 15-1/2 years old. My dad had told me six months before that when I was 15-1/2, he was going to let me start dating. Then, I turned 15-1/2, this guy asked me out, but my dad wouldn't let me go. That's when I got angry. - Soap Opera Weekly, July 27, 2004 Johnstown, Pennsylvania, USA Female In 2001, she appeared in the short film Hired Help (www.poshfilms.net) as a Translator. She speaks all Spanish in this. It was written and directed by Aundre Johnson. 7 July 1952 'Robert Phelps (I)' (qv) (? - present); 1 child Phelps studied at Carnegie Mellon University, where she received a BFA in directing. She stage-managed at New Jersey's McCarter Theater before becoming a production assistant for various New York stage productions, including shows directed by 'Mike Nichols (I)' (qv) and 'Bob Fosse' (qv). She began her television career in 1974 as a production assistant on _'The Guiding Light' (1952)_ (qv). From 1977-84 Phelps became an Emmy Award-winning music director on the ABC Daytime drama _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv). In 1984 she joined _'Santa Barbara' (1984)_ (qv) where she ultimately rose to the position of executive producer. During her tenure the show garnered three consecutive Emmy Awards for Outstanding Drama Series. From 1991-95 Phelps returned to her first stomping grounds, taking the helm of the longest-running Daytime soap _'The Guiding Light' (1952)_ (qv). Then, she served as executive producer of _'Another World' (1964)_ (qv) where she split viewers opinions but along with the creation of a dynamic new opening and innovative new sets she managed to achieve a sharp ratings increase. Afterwards Phelps returned to ABC Daytime serving as executive producer of _'One Life to Live' (1968)_ (qv) from December 1997 through December 2000 before switching to _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) in the same capacity. So far the show received numerous Emmy awards under her tenure. Jill Farren-Phelps Mother of Courtney Phelps. Jill Farren Phelps New York City, New York, USA Female Farren, Jill

Crew Member Series Producer actress producer  Vanessa Marcil Robert Guza Jr. gender aka name spouse 'Stuff' (USA), October 2003, Iss. 47, pg. 114-118, by: Bill Schulz, 'Sin City Pretty' 'Corey Feldman' (qv) (6 August 1989 - 1993) (divorced) Auditioned for the part of Nancy in _I Still Know What You Did Last Summer (1998)_ (qv) however, the part was eventually given to 'Jennifer Esposito' (qv), since the director felt her beauty would give less attention to the lead actors of the film. 'FHM' (USA), September 2000, pg. 106-110, by: Carlo Dalla Chiesa, 'Cheeky!' 'Because of my crazy work schedule, I have become something of a master at changing my clothes while driving. The men driving next to me love it.' - on driving to work while changing clothes. 1999 - Print ads for Head and Shoulders shampoo. (1999) 15 October 1968 (2010) Hostess of an infomercial for the DDF (Doctor's Dermatologic Formula) skin care system. Also appearing is 'Cynthia Sass' (qv). Vanessa Marcil was born on October 15, 1968, in Indio, California, to Peter Ortiz, a contractor, and Patricia Marcil Ortiz, an herbalist. She grew up in Palm Desert with her parents and her two older sisters Tina and Sherry and her older brother Sam. When Vanessa was 8 she started acting in plays and even performed her own song at a sixth-grade talent show, which she won. Soon afterward she began pursuing an acting career and starred in several theatre productions before landing the role of Brenda Barrett on the ABC daytime soap opera _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) in 1992.  She made her feature film debut in _The Rock (1996)_ (qv) opposite 'Nicolas Cage' (qv) and starred in a made-for-television movie, _To Love, Honor and Deceive (1996) (TV)_ (qv), in 1996. She stayed with _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) until 1998 and then left to join the cast of _'Beverly Hills, 90210' (1990)_ (qv) as Gina Kincaid, a former ice skater replacing 'Tiffani Thiessen' (qv) as the show's vixen. She met 'Brian Austin Green' (qv) on the show and the two had a baby together named Kassius Lijah Marcil-Green born on March 30, 2002.  In the fall of 2002 she made her long-awaited return to _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) reprising her role as Brenda Barrett, garnering her a Daytime Emmy Award for 'Outstanding Supporting Actress' in 2003. Vanessa later joined the cast of the NBC drama _'Las Vegas' (2003)_ (qv) as Sam Marquez, a casino host. She resides in Los Angeles, California with her son Kassius. Vanessa Marcil 'TV Guide' (USA), 1 February 2003, Vol. 51, Iss. 5, pg. 42, by: Michael Logan, 'On Soaps: Mom Knows Best' Uses her most recent, married name for on-screen credit 'ABC Soaps In Depth' (USA), 3 September 2002, Vol. 6, Iss. 36 Sally Vanessa Ortiz Indio, California, USA Female 'Meg Bennett' (qv) (25 May 2004 - present) Robert Guza Jr. Robert O. Guza Jr. Male

Video Game TV Movie Cinematographer Person crew member cinematographer  Alpha Barry Steven Soderbergh   Alpha Barry 'Humo' (Belgium), 6 November 2001, Iss. 3192, pg. 128, 'De zwarte periode' 'Jules Asner' (qv) (10 May 2003 - present) At one point, was interested in directing _Fantastic Four (2005)_ (qv). [on if he feels he understands what audiences want] No. I've tried to get better about weighing what I think the accessibility of an idea is against the cost of executing it. I've tried to be smarter about that, because if you're not smart about that, you're going to be unemployed. But I'm still mystified about what works for people. And I'm not talking about my movies, I'm talking in general. I'm mystified by the stuff that doesn't work. I'm mystified by what's going on in the critical side, too. Stuff I like is getting trashed and stuff that is being praised I think is terrible. I don't really feel in sync with what's happening, but at the same time, what I think keeps me afloat is that I try not to be, and don't want to be, very indulgent. I try to make the films as lean as possible, and to not spend a lot of time crawling up my own ass creatively. Directed stage play, 'Geniuses', for Swine Palace Productions, Baton Rouge, LA. (1996) Soderbergh, Steven A. 14 January 1963 Steven Soderbergh was born on January 14, 1963, in Atlanta, Georgia, USA, the second of six children and, while still at a very young age, his family moved to Baton Rouge, Louisiana, where his father, 'Peter Soderbergh' (qv), was a professor and the dean of the College of Education at Louisiana State University. While still in high school, around the age of 15, Soderbergh enrolled in the university's film animation class and began making short 16-millimeter films with second-hand equipment, one of which was the short film 'Janitor'. After graduating high school, he went to Hollywood, where he worked as a freelance editor. His time there was brief and, shortly after, he returned home and continued making short films and writing scripts.  His first major break was in 1986 when the rock group 'Yes' (qv) assigned him to shoot a full-length concert film for the band, which eventually earned him a Grammy nomination for the video, _Yes: 9012 Live (1985) (V)_ (qv). Following this achievement, Soderbergh filmed _Winston (1987)_ (qv), the short-subject film that he would later expand into _Sex, Lies, and Videotape (1989)_ (qv), a film that earned him the Cannes Film Festival's Palme d'Or Award, the Independent Spirit Award for Best Director, and an Oscar nomination for Best Original Screenplay. Over the next six years, he was married to actress 'Betsy Brantley' (qv) and had a daughter named Sarah Soderbergh, who was born in 1990.  Also during this time, he made such films as _Kafka (1991)_ (qv), _King of the Hill (1993)_ (qv), _Underneath (1995)_ (qv) and _Gray's Anatomy (1996)_ (qv), which many believed to be disappointments. In 1998, Soderbergh made _Out of Sight (1998)_ (qv), his most critically and commercially successful film since _Sex, Lies, and Videotape (1989)_ (qv). Then, in 2000, Soderbergh directed two major motion pictures that are now his most successful films to date: _Erin Brockovich (2000)_ (qv) and _Traffic (2000)_ (qv). These films were both nominated for Best Picture Oscars at the 2001 Academy Awards and gave him the first twin director Oscar nomination in almost 60 years and the first ever win. He won the Oscar for Best Director for _Traffic (2000)_ (qv) at the 2001 Oscars. Steven Soderbergh 'The New York Times' (USA), 23 May 2008, Vol. 157, Iss. 54,319, pg. E1 & E8, by: A.O. Scott, 'Soderbergh and Che, Provocateurs' Frequently uses jump-cuts 'M Le Magazine du Monde' (France), 11 August 2012, Iss. 47 Steve Soderbergh 6' Atlanta, Georgia, USA Male

Series Language Writer language writer  John Zurhellen   John Zurhellen Male
Series Language Writer language writer   Navid Khonsari gender name mini biography Raised in Iran and Canada, Khonsari was first introduced to filmmaking through his grandfather's super 8mm films. He developed an appreciation for storytelling from his grandmother, who would recite stories (both fictional and historical) from memory. Khonsari fell in love with video games after playing Pitfall on Atari.  He graduated from the University of British Columbia, and also studied at the Vancouver Film School. His first short film was entitled 'Arcade Angels', which focused on video game burnouts who robbed a video rental store and then opened an arcade. He wrote and produced The Contract, his first film with Billy Dee Williams. Khonsari broke out on to the gaming scene with Grand Theft Auto III and Max Payne.  He met his wife Vassiliki, while working on Pindemonium. They own and operate iNK Stories, a studio based out of New York and Toronto. Navid Khonsari Male

Episode Actor Work featured in writer  Francis Ford Coppola   'The Independent Arts & Books' (UK), 11 June 2010, Iss. 7383, pg. 10 - 11, by: Kaleem Aftab, 'It's all about the family business' 'Eleanor Coppola' (qv) (2 February 1963 - present); 3 children 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) said that he based the 'Han Solo' character from the Star Wars trilogy on Coppola. 'New York Times Magazine' (USA), 19 May 2002, pg. 26+28, by: Frank Bruni, 'In the Name of the Father' On 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv): Most directors have one masterpiece by which they are known, or possibly two. Kurosawa has at least eight or nine. Print ad for Robert Mondavi Wines. (2000) 7 April 1939 (September 2005) Visiting Istanbul for vacation. Rodney F. Hill. _Francis Ford Coppola: Interviews._ 2004. He was born in 1939 in Detroit, USA, but he grew up in a New York suburb in a creative, supportive Italian-American family. His father, 'Carmine Coppola' (qv), was a composer and musician. His mother, 'Italia Coppola' (qv), had been an actress. Francis Ford Coppola graduated with a degree in drama from Hofstra University, and did graduate work at UCLA in filmmaking. He was training as assistant with filmmaker 'Roger Corman' (qv), working in such capacities as sound-man, dialogue director, associate producer and, eventually, director of _Dementia 13 (1963)_ (qv), Coppola's first feature film. During the next four years, Coppola was involved in a variety of script collaborations, including writing an adaptation of 'This Property is Condemned' by 'Tennessee Williams' (qv) (with 'Fred Coe' (qv) and 'Edith Sommer' (qv)), and screenplays for _Paris br?le-t-il? (1966)_ (qv) and _Patton (1970)_ (qv), the film for which Coppola won a Best Original Screenplay Academy Award. In 1966, Coppola's 2nd film brought him critical acclaim and a Master of Fine Arts degree. In 1969, Coppola and 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) established American Zoetrope, an independent film production company based in San Francisco. The company's first project was _THX 1138 (1971)_ (qv), produced by Coppola and directed by Lucas. Coppola also produced the second film that Lucas directed, _American Graffiti (1973)_ (qv), in 1973. This movie got five Academy Award nominations, including one for Best Picture. In 1971, Coppola's film _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv) became one of the highest-grossing movies in history and brought him an Oscar for writing the screenplay with 'Mario Puzo' (qv) The film was a Best Picture Academy Award-winner, and also brought Coppola a Best Director Oscar nomination. Following his work on the screenplay for _The Great Gatsby (1974)_ (qv), Coppola's next film was _The Conversation (1974)_ (qv), which was honored with the Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and brought Coppola Best Picture and Best Original Screenplay Oscar nominations. Also released that year, _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), rivaled the success of _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), and won six Academy Awards, bringing Coppola Oscars as a producer, director and writer. Coppola then began work on his most ambitious film, _Apocalypse Now (1979)_ (qv), a Vietnam War epic that was inspired by 'Joseph Conrad (I)' (qv)'s _Heart of Darkness (1993) (TV)_ (qv). Released in 1979, the acclaimed film won a Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and two Academy Awards. Also that year, Coppola executive produced the hit _The Black Stallion (1979)_ (qv). With 'George Lucas (I)' (qv), Coppola executive produced _Kagemusha (1980)_ (qv), directed by 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv), and _Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)_ (qv), directed by 'Paul Schrader (I)' (qv) and based on the life and writings of 'Yukio Mishima' (qv). Coppola also executive produced such films as _The Escape Artist (1982)_ (qv), _Hammett (1982)_ (qv) _The Black Stallion Returns (1983)_ (qv), _Barfly (1987)_ (qv), _Wind (1992)_ (qv), _The Secret Garden (1993)_ (qv), etc.  He helped to make a star of his nephew, 'Nicolas Cage' (qv). Personal tragedy hit in 1986 when his son Gio died in a boating accident. Francis Ford Coppola is one of America's most erratic, energetic and controversial filmmakers. Francis Ford Coppola 'Cinema' (Greece), March 1998, Iss. 88, pg. 45, by: Yorgos Krassakopoulos, 'Skinothetis kai alla polla...' _Brando Unauthorized (2011)_ (qv) Often works with cinematographer 'Gordon Willis (I)' (qv) and producers 'Fred Roos' (qv) and 'Gray Frederickson' (qv). 'The Independent Arts & Books Review' (UK), 16 November 2007 Thomas Colchart 5' 11 1/2' Detroit, Michigan, USA Male
Episode Actor Work featured in writer Mario Puzo    'Playboy' (USA), July 1991, Vol. 38, Iss. 7, pg. 18, by: Joan Goodman, 'Guest Shot: Mario Puzo' 'Erika Lina Broske' (1946 - 9 November 1978) (her death); 5 children Bay Shore, Long Island, New York, USA (heart failure) Was writing a story outline for a fourth 'Godfather' film before he died. The best way to launch an Italian restaurant is to have it raided because the Mafia eats there. Everybody knows they eat well. Novel: 'The Family' Puzo, Mario Gianluigi 15 October 1920 Mario Puzo was born October 15, 1920, in 'Hell's Kitchen' on Manhattan's (NY) West Side and, following military service in World War II, attended New York's New School for Social Research and Columbia University. His best-known novel, 'The Godfather,' was preceded by two critically acclaimed novels, 'The Dark Arena' and 'The Fortunate Pilgrim.' In 1978, he published 'Fools Die,' followed by 'The Sicilian' (1984) and 'The Fourth K' (1991). Mario Puzo has also written several screenplays, including _Earthquake (1974)_ (qv), _Superman (1978)_ (qv), and all three 'Godfather' movies, for which he received two Academy Awards. Mario's latest novel, 1996's 'The Last Don,' was made into a CBS television miniseries in May 1997, starring 'Danny Aiello' (qv), 'Kirstie Alley' (qv) and 'Joe Mantegna' (qv). In 1997, Part II was aired. Also in 1997, Mario's 'The Fortunate Pilgrim' was re-released by Random House. Mario passed away July 2, 1999, at his home in Bay Shore, Long Island. His last novel, 'Omerta,' will be published July, 2000. He is survived by his companion of 20 years, Carol Gino, and five children. Mario Puzo 'Di?rio de Not?cias' (Portugal), 4 July 1999, pg. 58, by: Abel Coelho de Morais, 'Morreu o autor de ?O Padrinho?' 2 July 1999 'Time' (USA), 28 August 1978 Mario Gianluigi Puzo New York City, New York, USA Male

TV Movie Genre Person genre writer   Jane Wagner birth notes other works aka name trivia birth name birth date 26 February 1935 Jane Wagner Companion of comedienne 'Lily Tomlin' (qv) since 1971. Jane Ann Wagner Morristown, Tennessee, USA In 1973, she wrote the teleplay for an unsold sitcom pilot for ABC called 'J.T.' The plot concerned a typical 12-year-old African-American boy living in Harlem who befriends a 12-year-old white boy recently arrived from the rural South. Wagner, Jane Ann
TV Movie Genre Person genre writer Jack Thompson    10 September 1931 Jack Thompson 28 October 2008 Beaufort, South Carolina, USA Fox Lake, Illinois, USA
TV Movie Genre Person genre writer Kenny Solms    Kenny Solms began his professional career in New York, teamed with New York University classmate Gail Parent to write revue material for Leonard Sillman's Broadway revue New Faces of 1968 and for New York's famed Upstairs at the Downstairs. His association with Ms. Parent subsequently became one of the most successful collaborations in American comedy. Following the runway success of three comedy albums (including Our Wedding Album, a hilarious spoof of the Luci Baines Johnson wedding) and a season on Steve Allen's Comedy Hour, Solms created and wrote the first four seasons of the Emmy Award-winning Carol Burnett Show for which he received an award from the Writers Guild of America. He wrote numerous television specials for such stars as Julie Andrews, Ann-Margret, Mary Tyler Moore, Bing Crosby, Dick Van Dyke, Anne Bancroft, and Bill Cosby. His writing of Sills and Burnett at the Met earned him a Peabody Award. Solms wrote and produced The Smothers Brothers Show, Three Girls Three and two HBO specials starring Carol Burnett and Martin Mull. Solms wrote the book for the Jule Styne/Comden & Green musical Lorelei, which starred Carol Channing. He was reunited with Gail Parent when they adapted her novel Sheila Levine is Dead and Living in New York into a motion picture starring Roy Scheider and Jeannie Berlin. Solms has been head writer and producer for numerous television variety specials including Disneyland's 30th Anniversary Celebration and Neil Diamond's Hello Again. Solms also wrote and produced the HBO special The Return of Bruno, Burnett 'Discovers' Domingo for CBS, This Is Your Life, Kelsey Grammer Salutes Jack Benny, and is a frequent contributor to Touched by an Angel. He has recently finished writing a new musical for Broadway, Ain't That a Kick in the Head, based on the songs of Sammy Cahn. Kenny Solms Kenneth Solms Male 'Perfectly Frank: A celebration of the genius of Frank Loesser' (1980) (Broadway) conceived and written by Kenny Solms http://www.ibdb.com/production.asp?id=4081

Series Company Producer Video Movie actress production company Sonya Eddy   Black Marble Productions  name 17 June 1967 Sonya Eddy, a native of Concord, California, graduated from UC Davis. During her intense studies she began her acting career in the West Coast premiere of 'Zora, Is My Name!' (written by the award-winning actress Ruby Dee). Sonya performed several roles in 'Zora' including Big Sweet - a bawdy blues singer (Ruby Dee's personal favorite). Sonya continued forth to perform the role of the Courtesan in 'Comedy of Errors' as well as performances in productions of 'The Crucible', 'Pericles', and the Witch in 'Into The Woods'. Ms. Eddy won an Arty Award for her powerful portrayal of Bloody Mary in 'South Pacific'.  Sonya's professional acting career in Los Angeles has spanned over a dozen years. Her roles include recurrings on 'ER', 'Joan of Arcadia', 'Seinfeld', 'The Drew Carey Show' and others. Having appeared in the Hallmark Movie of the Week 'The Reading Room' opposite James Earl Jones, Ms. Eddy was also a series regular on Martin Short's 'Primetime Glick' and has also appeared professionally in 'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof' with John Goodman and Brenda Fricker at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles. Most recently, Ms. Eddy can be seen in her recurring role on 'General Hospital' as Epiphany Johnson - a no-nonsense head nurse. She will also bring Epiphany to SOAPnet's first serialized drama for primetime 'General Hospital: Night Shift', which premieres in July, 2007. Ms. Eddy can also be seen as a guest star on 'CSI: Crime Scene Investigation'.  Sonya's many guest appearances in other primetime shows include 'In Case of Emergency', 'Everybody Hates Chris', 'Daybreak', 'Malcolm In the Middle','Reba',and many others. Her guest star performances include 'Strong Medicine', 'Still Standing', and 'The Hughleys'.  In addition to her career successes, Ms. Eddy has recently become the only actor to have been cast twice on 'ER'. Her work can also be seen in over a dozen National commercials yearly.  Not to be omitted, her versatility as an all around performer can be seen in her most recent feature film roles in 'Coach Carter' starring Samuel L. Jackson, 'Bad News Bears' with Billy Bob Thornton, 'Barbershop', 'Daddy Daycare', 'Matchstick Men', and 'Surviving Christmas'. Recently, Sonya completed filming 'Year of the Dog' with Molly Shannon and Peter Sarsgaard.  Among Sonya's many special skills and talents she is also an accomplished Improv\Sketch artist, vocalist (2nd Soprano to 1st Tenor) and voice-over artist. Sonya Eddy Her home town is Concord, California. Sonya Jean Eddy 5' 4' Concord, California, USA Female Eddy, Sonya Jean Black Marble Productions 
Series Company Producer Video Movie actress production company Sonya Eddy Partizan [GB]    17 June 1967 Sonya Eddy, a native of Concord, California, graduated from UC Davis. During her intense studies she began her acting career in the West Coast premiere of 'Zora, Is My Name!' (written by the award-winning actress Ruby Dee). Sonya performed several roles in 'Zora' including Big Sweet - a bawdy blues singer (Ruby Dee's personal favorite). Sonya continued forth to perform the role of the Courtesan in 'Comedy of Errors' as well as performances in productions of 'The Crucible', 'Pericles', and the Witch in 'Into The Woods'. Ms. Eddy won an Arty Award for her powerful portrayal of Bloody Mary in 'South Pacific'.  Sonya's professional acting career in Los Angeles has spanned over a dozen years. Her roles include recurrings on 'ER', 'Joan of Arcadia', 'Seinfeld', 'The Drew Carey Show' and others. Having appeared in the Hallmark Movie of the Week 'The Reading Room' opposite James Earl Jones, Ms. Eddy was also a series regular on Martin Short's 'Primetime Glick' and has also appeared professionally in 'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof' with John Goodman and Brenda Fricker at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles. Most recently, Ms. Eddy can be seen in her recurring role on 'General Hospital' as Epiphany Johnson - a no-nonsense head nurse. She will also bring Epiphany to SOAPnet's first serialized drama for primetime 'General Hospital: Night Shift', which premieres in July, 2007. Ms. Eddy can also be seen as a guest star on 'CSI: Crime Scene Investigation'.  Sonya's many guest appearances in other primetime shows include 'In Case of Emergency', 'Everybody Hates Chris', 'Daybreak', 'Malcolm In the Middle','Reba',and many others. Her guest star performances include 'Strong Medicine', 'Still Standing', and 'The Hughleys'.  In addition to her career successes, Ms. Eddy has recently become the only actor to have been cast twice on 'ER'. Her work can also be seen in over a dozen National commercials yearly.  Not to be omitted, her versatility as an all around performer can be seen in her most recent feature film roles in 'Coach Carter' starring Samuel L. Jackson, 'Bad News Bears' with Billy Bob Thornton, 'Barbershop', 'Daddy Daycare', 'Matchstick Men', and 'Surviving Christmas'. Recently, Sonya completed filming 'Year of the Dog' with Molly Shannon and Peter Sarsgaard.  Among Sonya's many special skills and talents she is also an accomplished Improv\Sketch artist, vocalist (2nd Soprano to 1st Tenor) and voice-over artist. Sonya Eddy Her home town is Concord, California. Sonya Jean Eddy 5' 4' Concord, California, USA Female Eddy, Sonya Jean Partizan [GB]
Series Company Producer Video Movie actress production company Sonya Eddy ABC Films     17 June 1967 Sonya Eddy, a native of Concord, California, graduated from UC Davis. During her intense studies she began her acting career in the West Coast premiere of 'Zora, Is My Name!' (written by the award-winning actress Ruby Dee). Sonya performed several roles in 'Zora' including Big Sweet - a bawdy blues singer (Ruby Dee's personal favorite). Sonya continued forth to perform the role of the Courtesan in 'Comedy of Errors' as well as performances in productions of 'The Crucible', 'Pericles', and the Witch in 'Into The Woods'. Ms. Eddy won an Arty Award for her powerful portrayal of Bloody Mary in 'South Pacific'.  Sonya's professional acting career in Los Angeles has spanned over a dozen years. Her roles include recurrings on 'ER', 'Joan of Arcadia', 'Seinfeld', 'The Drew Carey Show' and others. Crew Member TV Movie Country editor country  Joel Cox   2 April 1942 Joel Cox was born c. 1941 and his film career began at a very early age - appearing before the cameras, in fact - as a baby in the film 'Random Harvest'. Some twenty years later he began work as a mail-room boy with Warner Brothers, the company with whom he has worked ever since, and in 1969 moved into the cutting-room, as an uncredited assistant editor on 'Woodstock' and 'The Wild Bunch'. He was a credited assistant on 'The Outlaw Josey Wales', working for the first time with Clint Eastwood. A durable collaboration followed with Cox cutting all films made by Eastwood since. Joel Cox He credits 'Ferris Webster' (qv) and 'Walter Thompson (I)' (qv) as being his greatest mentors, followed by 'Sam O'Steen' (qv). Joel Edward Cox Los Angeles, California, USA Male Cox, Joel Edward

PATTERN:
?instanceSubjectNumber1 <http://www.imdb.com/spoofed_in> ?instanceObjectNumber1.
?instanceSubjectNumber1 <http://www.imdb.com/composer> ?instanceObjectNumber2.
?instanceObjectNumber2 a <http://www.imdb.com/Composer>.
?instanceObjectNumber1 a <http://www.imdb.com/Episode>.
?instanceSubjectNumber1 a <http://www.imdb.com/Movie>.


Composer Episode Movie composer spoofed in   Nino Rota birth notes gender death date aka biographical movies name birth name mini biography birth date death notes article 3 December 1911 Born in Milan in 1911 into a family of musicians, Nino Rota was first a student of Orefice and Pizzetti. Then, still a child, he moved to Rome where he completed his studies at the Conservatory of Santa Cecilia in 1929 with Alfredo Casella. In the meantime, he had become an 'enfant prodige', famous both as a composer and as an orchestra conductor. His first oratorio, 'L'infanzia di San Giovanni Battista,' was performed in Milan and Paris as early as 1923 and his lyrical comedy, 'Il Principe Porcaro,' was composed in 1926. From 1930 to 1932, Nino Rota lived in the USA. He won a scholarship to the Curtis Institute of Philadelphia where he attended classes in composition taught by Rosario Scalero and classes in orchestra taught by 'Fritz Reiner' (qv). He returned to Italy and earned a degree in literature from the University of Milan. In 1937, he began a teaching career that led to the directorship of the Bari Conservatory, a title he held from 1950 until his death in 1979. After his 'childhood' compositions, Nino Rota wrote the following operas: Ariodante (Parma 1942), Torquemada (1943), Il cappello di paglia di Firenze (Palermo 1955), I due timidi (RAI 1950, London 1953), La notte di un neurastenico (Premio Italia 1959, La Scala 1960), Lo scoiattolo in gamba (Venezia 1959), Aladino e la lampada magica (Naples 1968), La visita meravigliosa (Palermo 1970), Napoli milionaria (Spoleto Festival 1977). He also wrote the following ballets: La rappresentazione di Adamo ed Eva (Perugia 1957), La Strada (La Scala 1965), Aci e Galatea (Rome 1971), Le Moli?re imaginaire (Paris and Brussels 1976) and Amor di poeta (Brussels 1978) for Maurice B?jart. In addition, there are countless works for orchestra that have been performed since before World War II and are still performed by orchestras in every part of the world. His work in film dates back to the early forties. His filmography includes the names of virtually all of the noted directors of his time. First among these is 'Federico Fellini' (qv). He wrote all of the movie scores for Fellini's films from _Lo sceicco bianco (1952)_ (qv) in 1952 to _Prova d'orchestra (1978)_ (qv) in 1978. Other directors include 'Renato Castellani' (qv), 'Luchino Visconti' (qv), 'Franco Zeffirelli' (qv), 'Mario Monicelli' (qv), 'Francis Ford Coppola' (qv) (Oscar for best original score for _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv)), 'King Vidor' (qv), 'Ren? Cl?ment' (qv), 'Edward Dmytryk' (qv), and 'Eduardo de Filippo'. He also composed the music for many theatre productions by Visconti, Zefirelli, and de Filippo. In February of 1995, the Nino Rota Foundation was established at Fondazione Cini of Venice, Italy. Cini specializes in the works of 20th century Italian composers and includes the estate of Casella. Nino Rota 'Difono' (Greece), January 2000, Iss. 52, pg. 105-109, by: Yorgos Notaras, '20 hronia apo to thanato tou Nino Rota' 10 April 1979 Rome, Lazio, Italy (coronary thrombosis) Giovanni Rota Rinaldi Milan, Lombardy, Italy Male _Un amico magico: il maestro Nino Rota (1999)_ (qv) Rinaldi, Giovanni Rota
Composer Episode Movie composer spoofed in  Nino Rota   3 December 1911 Born in Milan in 1911 into a family of musicians, Nino Rota was first a student of Orefice and Pizzetti. Then, still a child, he moved to Rome where he completed his studies at the Conservatory of Santa Cecilia in 1929 with Alfredo Casella. In the meantime, he had become an 'enfant prodige', famous both as a composer and as an orchestra conductor. His first oratorio, 'L'infanzia di San Giovanni Battista,' was performed in Milan and Paris as early as 1923 and his lyrical comedy, 'Il Principe Porcaro,' was composed in 1926. From 1930 to 1932, Nino Rota lived in the USA. He won a scholarship to the Curtis Institute of Philadelphia where he attended classes in composition taught by Rosario Scalero and classes in orchestra taught by 'Fritz Reiner' (qv). He returned to Italy and earned a degree in literature from the University of Milan. In 1937, he began a teaching career that led to the directorship of the Bari Conservatory, a title he held from 1950 until his death in 1979. After his 'childhood' compositions, Nino Rota wrote the following operas: Ariodante (Parma 1942), Torquemada (1943), Il cappello di paglia di Firenze (Palermo 1955), I due timidi (RAI 1950, London 1953), La notte di un neurastenico (Premio Italia 1959, La Scala 1960), Lo scoiattolo in gamba (Venezia 1959), Aladino e la lampada magica (Naples 1968), La visita meravigliosa (Palermo 1970), Napoli milionaria (Spoleto Festival 1977). He also wrote the following ballets: La rappresentazione di Adamo ed Eva (Perugia 1957), La Strada (La Scala 1965), Aci e Galatea (Rome 1971), Le Moli?re imaginaire (Paris and Brussels 1976) and Amor di poeta (Brussels 1978) for Maurice B?jart. In addition, there are countless works for orchestra that have been performed since before World War II and are still performed by orchestras in every part of the world. His work in film dates back to the early forties. His filmography includes the names of virtually all of the noted directors of his time. First among these is 'Federico Fellini' (qv). He wrote all of the movie scores for Fellini's films from _Lo sceicco bianco (1952)_ (qv) in 1952 to _Prova d'orchestra (1978)_ (qv) in 1978. Other directors include 'Renato Castellani' (qv), 'Luchino Visconti' (qv), 'Franco Zeffirelli' (qv), 'Mario Monicelli' (qv), 'Francis Ford Coppola' (qv) (Oscar for best original score for _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv)), 'King Vidor' (qv), 'Ren? Cl?ment' (qv), 'Edward Dmytryk' (qv), and 'Eduardo de Filippo'. He also composed the music for many theatre productions by Visconti, Zefirelli, and de Filippo. In February of 1995, the Nino Rota Foundation was established at Fondazione Cini of Venice, Italy. Cini specializes in the works of 20th century Italian composers and includes the estate of Casella. Nino Rota 'Difono' (Greece), January 2000, Iss. 52, pg. 105-109, by: Yorgos Notaras, '20 hronia apo to thanato tou Nino Rota' 10 April 1979 Rome, Lazio, Italy (coronary thrombosis) Giovanni Rota Rinaldi Milan, Lombardy, Italy Male _Un amico magico: il maestro Nino Rota (1999)_ (qv) Rinaldi, Giovanni Rota
