Series Production Designer Character actor null James Hong    'TV Guide' (USA), 6 August 2007, Vol. 55, Iss. 32, pg. 65, by: G. J. Donnelly, 'Q&A with James Hong' 'Susan Hong (I)' (qv) (20 October 1977 - present); 1 child Was a contestant on 'Groucho Marx' (qv)'s _'You Bet Your Life' (1950)_ (qv). (2008) TV Commercial: Burger King, voice-over Cees Geel. 22 February 1929 Jimmy James Hong was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA. He studied civil engineering at the University of Minnesota, but at some point along the way became interested in acting. He graduated from the University of Southern California and practiced for 1? years as a road engineer with the County of Los Angeles. He took sick leaves and vacation time to do films. He finally quit engineering to focus on acting full time.  He is one of the founders of the East-West Players, the oldest Asian American theater in Los Angeles. He served as president and charter member of the Association of Asian Pacific American Artists.  Hong is one of the most prolific and well-recognized Asian-American character actors of movies and television. He currently lives in Los Angeles and is planning to produce and direct his own films. Series Production Designer Character actor null  Shaun Cassidy   'Teen Beat' (USA), February 1979, pg. 46-47, by: 46-47, 'Shaun to Marry Model? The Whole Truth...' 'Tracey Lynne Turner' (qv) (28 August 2004 - present); 4 children 3rd child with wife Tracey Turner Cassidy, a daughter named Lila Tracey, born December 2008. (1990) Stage: Appeared in 'Bus Stop', West End, London, England. Also in cast: 'Jerry Hall (I)' (qv). Cassidy, Shaun Paul 27 September 1958 Connie Berman. _The Shaun Cassidy Scrapbook._ New York: Tempo Books, 1978. ISBN 0-448-14738-6 Shaun was born on September 27, 1958, and traveled with his parents when he was only six months old while they were doing shows. His parents were stage and screen actors 'Shirley Jones (I)' (qv) and 'Jack Cassidy (I)' (qv) who were both heavily involved in the business. When he was a pre-teen, he started a band called 'Every Mothers Dream' and when his mother and half-brother, 'David Cassidy (I)' (qv), were both starring in a musical TV sitcom called _'The Partridge Family' (1970)_ (qv), he asked his mom to put him in some episodes. However, she refused as she wanted to encourage him to concentrate on his schooling. He did appear as part of the chorus in many musical theatre productions. In 1972, he then sang in a punk rock band called 'The Longfellow,' which was short-lived, as his parents transferred him to a private school in Beverly Hills.  He had a chance to star with his mother as James Preston in a summer stock stage musical production of 'On A Clear Day You Can See Forever' to get a taste of acting. During his grad year, he decided to make some records in Germany and had a hit there called 'Morning Girl' and appeared in TV shows with his hit there as well as in Australia. Then, in late 1976, he signed up with agent Ruth Aarons and played Christopher Wentworth Hewlitt in a short independent film called _Born of Water (1976)_ (qv) and successfully auditioned for the role of Joe Hardy in _'The Hardy Boys/Nancy Drew Mysteries' (1977)_ (qv). Also, he had a dream of becoming a writer and re-wrote some of the scripts of the series to make it more suitable for him, which angered the producers of the show. On an episode of the show, he sang some numbers as his character in a local disco, which led to a number of hit 45s and albums.  In the 1980s, he made acting a primarily focus after his role in the movie of the week titled _Like Normal People (1979) (TV)_ (qv) which he was well credited in as the mentally challenged Roger Meyers as well as playing Dave Stohler in the short-lived series 'Breaking Away' (1980)_ based on the popular motion picture, which only 8 episodes were produced due to a writers strike. He then decided to learn the true craft of acting and pursued it on stage by starring in such productions like 'Mass Appeal,' 'The Subject Was Roses,' 'Diary of a Hunger Strike,' 'Dangerous Music,' 'Pass/Fail,' and 'Blood Brothers' with 'Petula Clark (I)' (qv) and his half-brother 'David Cassidy (I)' (qv) -- in their first show together. After a few more TV guest roles, movies of the week as well as acting on stage, he pursued his dreams as was mentioned and retired from acting to produce and write TV shows and films, including the short-lived but well-acclaimed _'American Gothic' (1995)_ (qv) as well as the other TV series _'The Agency' (2001)_ (qv) and _'Invasion' (2005)_ (qv). He also write the sequel to the hit motion picture _Midnight Run (1988)_ (qv) titled _Midnight Run for Your Life (1994) (TV)_ (qv), which became a noted TV movie. Writing and producing became Cassidy's most successful career in the industry today like for many other celebrities like former actor 'Ron Howard (I)' (qv). He admitted to this day he was only half good as a singer and admitted he had some limitations as an actor and felt he didn't enjoy it enough to pursue for the rest of his life. Shaun Cassidy 'Tiger Beat Star' (USA), August 1978, Vol. 2, Iss. 11, pg. 2, 'Little Known (Personal And Private!) Facts!' 'TV Superstar' (USA), December 1977, Vol. 2, Iss. 2 Shaun Paul Cassidy 5' 11' Los Angeles, California, USA Male
Series Production Designer Character actor null Jim Fitzpatrick    'St. Petersburg Times' (USA), 25 December 2005, Vol. http://www.stpetetimes.com/2005/12/25/Neighborhoodtimes/Sacred_scenery.shtml, Iss. Neighborhood Times, pg. 3, by: Waveney Ann Moore, 'Sacred Scnery' 'Jodi Knotts' (qv) (4 July 1990 - present); 2 children In 1986, he and his best friend, director/producer 'Corbin Timbrook (I)' (qv), met at an audition for a feature film titled 'Money Can't Buy Me Love,' vying for the role of the same character. He and Corbin have since worked together over 20 times in feature films, TV series episodes, and theatrical plays for the stage in Los Angeles. 'BABM (Bay Area Business Magazine)' (USA), 1 June 2008, Vol. 1, Iss. 13, pg. 24-27, by: Karen Conkel, 'The Show Must Go On' In my findings, our physical, psychological and emotional characteristics called instincts, are nothing more than stored genetic memory, handed-down from every generation of ancestry that came before us. He was seen in approximately 27 national commercials for Taco Bell, spanning 5 years, from 1989-1995. 28 August 1959 (November 2005) Living in Florida where he has launched a Feature Film Production Co. called PacAtlantic Pictures. His first Picture out of the box will be, 'National Lampoon's, The Last Guy on Earth,' which he is Producing and Directing. Jim Fitzpatrick was born in Omaha, Nebraska, on Offutt Air Force Base, better known as SAC (Strategic Air Command) headquarters. He eventually returned to Florida where his parents (Jim Sr. and Cookie) are from and began his acting career on the stage at the tender age of 13 when he appeared in his first school play, 'A Thousand Clowns', at Seminole (Florida) High School. Jim accepted a football scholarship to Illinois State University as a theater major where he became involved with the Steppenwolf Theatre Company founded by 'Gary Sinise' (qv) and 'John Malkovich' (qv). He put aside an acting career to play professional football, however, starting in 1981 with the Hamilton Tiger Cats in the CFL (Canadian Football league) followed by short stints with the Chicago Bears ('81) and the Baltimore Colts ('82). His football career ended when he retired in 1985, after spending three seasons with the Tampa Bay Bandits in the USFL ('83-'85). However, playing for the Bandits was a blessing in disguise. One of the owners of the Bandits was 'Burt Reynolds', who was instrumental in setting Jim's career in Los Angeles in motion. Jim began auditioning for productions during the off-seasons. Before moving to L.A., he landed parts in _'Miami Vice' (1984)_ (qv), _Cocoon (1985)_ (qv) and _D.A.R.Y.L. (1985)_ (qv). Since then, Jim has appeared in over 30 plays for the stage (six of which he has written, produced and directed in Los Angeles). He has also starred and guest-starred in over 50 roles in films and television such as U.S. Seals, Operation Delta Force 3: Clear Target, Armageddon (1998), Star Trek: _'Enterprise' (2001)_ (qv), _'JAG' (1995)_ (qv) and _'All My Children' (1970)_ (qv).  Besides acting, James has written, produced and directed a poignant romantic dramedy entitled _An American Reunion (2003)_ (qv), one of 33 screenplays he has written and produced. James filmed a pilot for a TV series called _Supernatural (2005) (TV)_ (qv), which he executive-produced and directed. Jim, his actress wife, 'Jodi Knotts' (qv), and their two sons, 'J.J. Fitzpatrick' (qv) and 'Jadon Fitzpatrick' (qv), have recently moved from Los Angeles to Seminole, Florida, where he is directing the fifth film, after completing the first a series of three called _The Adventure Scouts (2010)_ (qv). Jim Fitzpatrick 'BABM (Bay Area Business Magazine' (USA), 1 June 2008, Vol. 1, Iss. 13, pg. 24-28, by: Karen Conkel, 'That's Entertainment/'The Show Must Go On'' 'Soap Opera Magazine' (USA), 12 September 1995 James Alt Fitzpatrick Omaha, Nebraska, USA Male
Series Production Designer Character actor null Adolph Caesar    5 December 1933 'Diane' (? - 6 March 1986) (his death); 3 children Born in the Harlem section of New York City, joined the Navy, then studied drama at New York University; was an announcer for then joined the Negro Ensemble Co. in 1970 for such productions as 'The River Niger', 'Square Root of the Soul' and 'The Brownsville Raid'; worked with repertory groups such as the Minnesota Theater Co., Inner City Repertory Co., and the American Shakespeare Co.; first appeared on the screen in CHE (1969), then returned to stage until the late 1970s when he did low-budget films (_The Hitter (1979)_ (qv), _Fist of Fear, Touch of Death (1980)_ (qv)) before achieving his greatest success in _A Soldier's Story (1984)_ (qv) (from the stage play for which he collected two awards), which earned him an Oscar nomination; appeared in _The Color Purple (1985)_ (qv) and was working on 'Tough Guys' with 'Burt Lancaster' (qv) and 'Kirk Douglas (I)' (qv) when he collapsed on the set of a heart attack and died a short time later. He was only 52. Glory fades away. It's fickle. It comes and goes. TV Movie Actor Person actor director LL Cool J Trevor Lawrence Jr.   'Reader's Digest' (USA), February 2003, pg. 61-63, by: Laura Hilgers, 'Do It Well or Not at All' 'Simone Johnson (I)' (qv) (7 August 1995 - present); 4 children He has been on Def Jam Records longer than any other artists from its start in 1985 to the present. 'Playboy' (USA), December 1987, Vol. 34, Iss. 12, pg. 220, by: Paul Natkin, 'Grapevine: The Ninja of Rap' [on _Halloween H20: 20 Years Later (1998)_ (qv)] - 'Jamie Lee Curtis' (qv) taught me a lot about being classy on set. Me and my guys would be there, and she would be leaving and say, 'Oh, take my trailer!' I played the security guard who everybody thought was going to die, but I didn't. That brother lived! That was wonderful. I shocked the world! Then I shocked the world a year later in _Deep Blue Sea (1999)_ (qv) and lived again. Album, 'All World,' Def Jam/PolyGram Records 534 125, 1996. Smith, James Todd 14 January 1968 G.O.A.T. (Greatest Of All Time) LL Cool J (James Todd Smith), with Karen Hunter. _I Make My Own Rules._ New York: Ilion Books, 1997. ISBN 0-312-17110-2, L.L. Cool J was born James Todd Smith on January 14, 1968, in Bay Shore, Long Island, New York, to James and Ondrea Smith. Todd, as he was called, did not have a very happy childhood. At the age of four, he saw his mother and grandfather shot by his own father. After they recovered from their injuries, his mother began to date a young physical therapist she met while in the hospital. The therapist treated Ondrea kindly, but for years he abused Todd physically and verbally, which resulted in Todd becoming a bully himself. It was during this period that he started wearing hats all the time (one of L.L. Cool J's trademarks is the fact that people never see him without a hat on--until recently). Fortunately, Ondrea finally discovered what this man was doing to her son and left him.  As he grew older, Todd found a way to escape the effects of his abuse and his bullying attitude: hip-hop music. He fell in love with it at the age of nine, and by 11 he was writing lyrics and making his own songs with some DJ equipment his grandfather gave him. At 15, he and one of his best friends came up with his present stage name, L.L. Cool J, which means 'Ladies Love Cool James.'  In 1984, when L.L. was 16, he met 'Rick Rubin' (qv), a student at NYU, who gave him his big break in music. Rick really liked L.L.'s music and decided to try to get him a record deal. Together, they made the single 'I Need a Beat' and sent it to an artist manager named 'Russell Simmons' (qv). Simmons loved the single, and, in the same year, Rick and Russell co-founded the famous Def Jam Recordings; L.L.'s debut album, 'Radio,' released in 1985, after securing a distribution deal for Def Jam with Columbia/CBS Records, was the label's first long-playing release. Even today, L.L. is considered one of Def Jam's most prized possessions.  1985 was also the year L.L. started his acting career. He first appeared in _Krush Groove (1985)_ (qv), which is a semi-biographical account of the early days of Def Jam Recordings. L.L. had a cameo appearance in the film. In 1986, L.L. also had a cameo appearance in the movie _Wildcats (1986)_ (qv) and also wrote that movie's theme song. After that, L.L. took a break from film and concentrated more on his first love: music. His career took off, and after every one of his albums hit platinum-selling status, he was (and still is) regarded as one of the greatest hip-hop artists of all time. After a few years, he had small roles in a few other films, but was still better known for his music.  All this changed in 1995. By this time he was a happily married 27-year-old with three children. His first starring film, _Out-of-Sync (1995)_ (qv), had also been released. It didn't do very well at the box office, but it got him noticed by executives at NBC-TV, who wanted to give him a part in a sitcom they were going to air. This sitcom was _'In the House' (1995)_ (qv), which showed L.L.'s acting ability; the show stayed on the air until 1999. He had been offered several films roles during the run of the show and decided to accept a part in _Halloween H20: 20 Years Later (1998)_ (qv). Its success resulted in L.L. being cast in bigger and better film roles, and he has acted alongside actors such stars 'Whoopi Goldberg' (qv), 'Samuel L. Jackson' (qv), 'Jamie Lee Curtis' (qv), 'James Woods (I)' (qv), 'Al Pacino' (qv), 'Omar Epps' (qv), 'Pam Grier' (qv), 'Stanley Tucci (I)' (qv), and 'Dennis Quaid' (qv), to name a few.  In 2000, he was finally rewarded for his acting talent. That year he won a Blockbuster Entertainment Award for the best supporting actor in the action film _Deep Blue Sea (1999)_ (qv). Even though his film career has taken off, he hasn't forgotten his love of hip-hop music. In 1998, he was planning to retire from hip-hop and just concentrate on his film career, but he later decided to keep dividing his time between both fields. L.L. is not only known as one of the greatest MCs of all time, but he is also known as a great actor. LL Cool J 'Movieline's Hollywood Life' (USA), December 2003, Vol. XIV, Iss. 11, pg. 80-81+124, by: Martha Frankel, 'Cool As L' Always wears a hat when off-camera 'Men's Fitness' (USA), July 2003 James Todd Smith 6' 1 1/2' Bay Shore, Long Island, New York, USA Male Trevor Lawrence Jr. Trevor 'Trevbeats' Lawrence Male

TV Movie Actor Person actor director Adam Levine Trevor Lawrence Jr.   The 222 on his forearm represents door number of the very first studio that Maroon 5 ever recorded in. 'Cosmopolitan' (UK), February 2011, 'Cosmo Centrefold: Adam Levine' I don't know if it's possible to live the rock'n'roll lifestyle and still be romantic. (2010) Song featuring 'Slash' (qv): 'Gotten'. Levine, Adam Noah 18 March 1979 Sharky GRAMMY-winning band 'Maroon 5' (qv)'s frontman Adam Levine was born and raised in Los Angeles, California. He began playing music with his junior-high friends guitarist, rather than the keyboardist (for which he is known in the band 'Maroon 5' (qv)) 'Jesse Carmichael' (qv) and bassist 'Mickey Madden' (qv). Their first gig was at a school dance and Levine was terribly shy so he played with his back to the audience. 'Ryan Dusick' (qv) joined the band as drummer and the alternative rock band Kara's Flowers were born (1994). They released an album called 'The Fourth World' (1997). Then, he headed to New York City with Carmichael to study music at Five Towns College on Long Island. While they were there, he was surrounded by new music scenes and influences which give him whole new perspective on songwriting and singing. He dropped out of school after a semester and headed back to California with Carmichael to reunite with their pals and develop their band. He began writing a bunch of songs that were inspired by his recently failed relationship. After adding in new guitarist 'James Valentine (IV)' (qv) (moving Carmichael over to keyboards) Maroon 5 was officially born. The band released their debut album 'Songs About Jane' which is including international hits 'This Love', 'Sunday Morning' and 'She Will Be Loved' (2002). I first heard it and really liked the way they ['Lynyrd Skynyrd' (qv)] played their guitars. Then I heard my own name in it and thought, 'Now this is pretty great'. Since the 1970s often on tour with Crazy Horse ('Frank 'Pancho' Sampedro' (qv), 'Billy Talbot' (qv) and 'Ralph Molina' (qv)). Young, Neil Percival Kenneth Robert Ragland 12 November 1945 Don Grungio (April 2002) After recently coming back on tour with 'Crosby Stills Nash & Young' (qv), he has released his solo album, 'Are you Passionate', and is soon going on tour to promote it. Neil and Me Neil Young is one of the most respected and prolific rock/folk guitarists of the late 20th century. Raised in Canada, he first became well-known as a guitarist and occasional vocalist for the band 'Buffalo Springfield' (qv). After the band's breakup, Young became a solo performer. However, he also has spent more than 30 years performing with the super-group 'Crosby Stills Nash & Young' (qv), as well as with the band Crazy Horse. He also recorded an album with the grunge band 'Pearl Jam' (qv) in 1995. Besides his work as a musician, he has also been active in film. Young has produced and/or performed in such concert films as _Rust Never Sleeps (1979)_ (qv), _Year of the Horse (1997)_ (qv) and many more. He has also been involved with non-musical films, including _Human Highway (1982)_ (qv) and _Made in Heaven (1987)_ (qv). Neil Young 'The Washington Post' (USA), 3 May 2006, pg. C1, by: J. Freedom du Lac, 'Neil Young's Antiwar Howl' Songs about personal and political themes 'Oor' (Netherlands), 2 May 1979, Iss. 9 Neil Percival Kenneth Robert Ragland Young Toronto, Ontario, Canada Male

Composer Series Person actress writer  Michael Barrie Dolly Parton gender other works biographical movies trivia nick names spouse article quotes interviews portrayed in birth notes books aka name trade mark birth name where now mini biography birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial Michael Barrie Mike Barrie Male 'A&U: Art and Understanding' (USA), July 2003, Vol. 12, Iss. 7, pg. 16-17, by: Plant, B. Andrew, 'Dolly Parton: Red, Hot & Bluegrass' 'Carl Dean' (qv) (30 May 1966 - present) During the 40th Annual Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle Awards in 2009, Parton won for Best Musical Score for '9 To 5: The Musical' which played the Ahmanson Theatre in Los Angeles during in the fall of 2008. 'People Weekly' (USA), 9 February 1998, Vol. 49, Iss. 5, pg. 98, 'Brush With Fame - Roddy McDowall' (alluding to her famous bust) If I build another park, it will probably be in Silicon Valley. (2003) Music video: 'I'm Gone' _'E! True Hollywood Story' (1996) {Dolly Parton}_ (qv) Parton, Dolly Rebecca 19 January 1946 The Smoky Mountain Songbird (2006) Currently writing the score for the Broadway version of _Nine to Five (1980)_ (qv) as well as a children's book currently titled 'I Am A Rainbow'. As of October/November 2006, Parton is playing limited concerts at various venues in the USA and Canada and is currently working on a new country music CD currently titled 'Country Is As Country Does'. The new CD and children's book are expected to be released in 2007. Connie Berman (foreword by Dolly Parton). _The Official Dolly Parton Scrapbook._ New York: Grosset & Dunlap, 1978. ISBN 0- 44816176-1 Dolly Rebecca Parton was born on January 19, 1946, one of 12 children of Robert Lee Parton, a tobacco farmer, and Avie Lee Parton (n?e Owens). Dolly grew up on a run-down farm in Locust Ridge, Tennessee. At 12, she was appearing on Knoxville TV and, at 13, she was already recording on a small label and appearing at the Grand Ole Opry. After graduating from high school in Sevier County, Tennessee, in 1964, she moved to Nashville to launch her career as a country singer. She fell in love with 'Carl Dean' (qv), who ran an asphalt-paving business; they got married on May 30, 1966 (and they are still together). The next year, Dolly's singing caught the attention of 'Porter Wagoner' (qv). He hired Dolly to appear on his program, _'The Porter Wagoner Show' (1961)_ (qv). Dolly stayed with the show for 7 years, their duets became famous, and she appeared with his group at the Grand Ole Opry; she also toured and sold records. By the time her hit 'Joshua' reached #1 in 1970, her fame had overshadowed Porter's, and she struck out on her own, though still recording duets with him. She left him for good to become a solo artist in 1974. Dolly gained immense popularity as a singer/songwriter. Dolly won numerous Country Music Association awards (1968, 1970, 1971, 1975, 1976). This petite (5'0') beauty was a natural for television and, by the mid-1970s, Dolly was appearing frequently on TV specials and talk shows. Dolly then got her own show, aptly titled _'Dolly' (1976)_ (qv). In 1977, Dolly got her first Grammy award: Best Female Country Vocal Performance, for her song 'Here You Come Again'. Dolly's movie debut was in _Nine to Five (1980)_ (qv), where she got an Oscar nomination for writing the title tune, and also Grammy awards 2 and 3, Best Country Song, and Best Female Country Vocal Performance for the song 'Nine to Five'. Dolly got more fame for appearing in _The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas (1982)_ (qv), and in _Rhinestone (1984)_ (qv) with the song 'Tennessee Homesick Blues'. She is the head of Dolly Parton Enterprises, a $100 million media empire, and, in 1986, she founded Dollywood, a theme park in Pigeon Forge, Tennessee, celebrating her Smokey Mountain upbringing. She appeared as herself in the _'Dolly' (1987)_ (qv) TV series. In 1988, she won another Grammy award: Best Country Performance Duo or Group with Vocals, for 'Trio'. Dolly was in the acclaimed picture _Steel Magnolias (1989)_ (qv) with 'Julia Roberts (I)' (qv), and went on to appear in 15 movies and TV-movies for the 1990s, and of course garnered more Country Music Association awards. In 2000, Dolly received her 5th Grammy award: Best Country Collaboration with Vocals. She also released a Bluegrass Album. Dolly is known for beautiful songs such as 'Coat of Many Colors' and 'Jolene' and 'I Will Always Love You'. Dolly said in an interview, 'My music is what took me everywhere I've been and everywhere I will go. It's my greatest love. I can't abandon it. I'll always keep making records'. Dolly Parton 'Wide Open Magazine' (UK), 9 June 2006, Iss. 2, by: Staff Writer, 'Jill Jackson of Country Duo 'Jackson and Cassidy' on Why She Loves Dolly Parton' _'Blue Collar TV' (2004)_ (qv) Always uses butterflies as her logos, since she feels they represent beauty and freedom. 'TV Quick' (Spain), 6 July 1991 Dolly Rebecca Parton 4' 11' Sevierville, Tennessee, USA Female
Composer Series Person actress writer  Michael Barrie Rebecca Lobo birth notes gender other works name trivia birth date spouse height Michael Barrie Mike Barrie Male 6 October 1973 'Steve Rushin' (12 April 2003 - present); 4 children Rebecca Lobo A street named 'Rebecca Lobo Way' in Southwick, Massachusetts, where she attended high school, was named after her. 6' 4' Hartford, Connecticut, USA Female Since retiring from professional basketball, is a commentator for ESPN.
Composer Series Person actress writer Crystal Gayle  Morgan Neville birth notes other works name birth date 'Vassilios Gatzimos' (3 June 1971 - present); 2 children ACM award winner for Top Female Vocalist in 1976, 1978 and 1979. Album: 'In My Arms', 2001. Webb, Brenda Gail 9 January 1951 Born on January 9, 1951 in Paintsville, Kentucky, Crystal Gayle's family moved to Wabash, Indiana, when she was still quite young. Her music career was given a big boost by her older sister, country superstar 'Loretta Lynn' (qv). Loretta thought that Crystal's real name of Brenda Gail Webb was not quite 'classy' enough, and after noticing a sign for the Krystal restaurant chain, she changed the 'K' to a 'C' and her sister became Crystal Gayle. She recorded her first hit song, 'I've Cried the Blue (Right Out of My Eyes)', in 1970, which peaked at #23. In 1974, she signed up with United Artists Records and producer 'Allen Reynolds' (qv). Over the next two years, she released three albums and had several hit songs, including 'This Is My Year for Mexico', 'I'll Do It All Over Again', 'Wrong Road Again' and 'I'll Get Over You', her first #1. The next year, 1977, would prove to be a landmark year for Crystal with the release of her album 'We Must Believe in Magic' and the worldwide smash hit, 'Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue', which--along with her almost floor-length hair--made her a household name. She had many more hits throughout the rest of the 1970s, including 'Talking in Your Sleep', 'Ready for the Times to Get Better' and 'Half the Way'. She continued into the 1980s with such hits as 'If You Ever Change Your Mind', 'Too Many Lovers', 'The Woman in Me', 'Til I Gain Control Again' and 'The Sound of Goodbye'. In 1982, she recorded a duet with 'Eddie Rabbitt' (qv), the acclaimed 'You and I', which has become one of the most popular wedding songs ever. In 1985, she teamed up with 'Gary Morris (I)' (qv) to record the love theme for the prime-time soap opera _'Dallas' (1978)_ (qv), called 'Makin' Up For Lost Time', which turned into yet another #1 hit. Her other 1980s hits included 'A Long and Lasting Love', 'Nobody Wants to Be Alone', 'Straight to the Heart', 'Cry' and 'Nobody's Angel'. In 1987, she guest-starred on the daytime soap opera _'Another World' (1964)_ (qv) for a week. She teamed up again with Gary Morris and turned out the hit 'Another World', which was also used as the new theme song for the soap opera. Her career took somewhat of a downturn in the late 1980s and she released her last major single, 'Never Ending Song of Love', which peaked at #72, in 1990. Since then, she has released several more acclaimed albums and many hit compilations. Crystal Gayle 'Playboy' (USA), November 1981, Vol. 28, Iss. 11, pg. 130-132+156+202-209, by: Chet Flippo, 'The Trouble With Crystal' Floor-length brown hair Brenda Gail Webb 5' 2' Paintsville, Kentucky, USA Female 10 October 1967 Morgan Neville Los Angeles, California, USA Produced, directed 90-min documentary 'Hitmakers: The Teens Who Stole Pop Music' (2001), premiered May 3, 2001 at Museum of TV and Radio documentary festival in New York City.

Composer Series Person actress writer Martie Maguire  Morgan Neville birth notes other works name birth date 'Redbook' (USA), October 2002, Vol. 199, Iss. 4, pg. 154-156+158+160, by: Claire Connors, 'Dishing with the Dixie Chicks' 'Ted Seidel' (17 June 1995 - November 1999) (divorced) Was the sister-in-law of country singer 'Charlie Robison (I)' (qv). TV commercial, McDonalds' McRib. Erwin, Martha Elenor 12 October 1969 Martie Seidel, born Martha Elenor Erwin in York, Pennsylvania on October 12th 1969, began her musical career before the 'Dixie Chicks' (qv) were formed in 1989. She began playing classical violin at age 5. As teens, Martie & her sister, 'Emily Robison' (qv), were in a Bluegrass band named 'Blue Night Express'. She has 2 sisters - older sister Julia Erwin and younger sister 'Emily Robison' (qv) (who's married to singer-songwriter 'Charlie Robison (I)' (qv)). Martie and Emily began the 'Dixie Chicks' (qv), along with former members Robin Lynn Macy (vocals, guitar) & Laura Lynch (vocals, bass) before current singer 'Natalie Maines' (qv) joined in 1995. The current 'Dixie Chicks' (qv) lineup were recently featured in a TV movie, _Dixie Chicks on the Fly (2000) (TV)_ (qv). It was mainly a concert show showcasing Martie, Emily & Natalie's incredible vocal & instrumental talents. Martie and the other 'Dixie Chicks' have 2 songs featured in the 1999 'Julia Roberts (I)' (qv)/'Richard Gere' (qv) film _Runaway Bride (1999)_ (qv). One of the tunes, 'Ready To Run', was co-written by Martie. Her hobbies include shopping, golfing and bowling. Composer Series Person actress writer Wanda Jackson  Morgan Neville birth notes other works name birth date 'Mojo' (UK), November 2000, Iss. 84, pg. 19, by: Lois Wilson, ''Phone Home': Wanda Jackson- Queen of rockabilly enters Hall of Fame' 'Wendell Goodman' (1961 - present) Was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as an Early Influence on April 4, 2009. (observation, 2012) When you're going on seventy-five, you better do it now. It's been exciting for me. I always think, 'I wish this crowd could have seen me do these songs when I was younger. Album: 'I Remember Elvis' (2006) Jackson, Wanda Jean 20 October 1937 Queen of Rockabilly Bob Garbutt. _Hillbilly Queens: The Careers & Recordings of Wanda Jackson, Janis Martin and Brenda Lee._ Toronto, Canada: R. Garbutt Productions, 1979. Singer/songwriter Wanda Jean Jackson has enjoyed a long and successful music career which encompasses such diverse genres as country, gospel, and rockabilly. Wanda was born on October 20, 1937 in Maud, Oklahoma. Her father Tom was a former country singer who had to quit music because of the Depression. Jackson got her first guitar from her dad while living in California from 1941 to 1947. At age 12 Wanda and her family moved back to Oklahoma City. She won a local talent show contest in 1952 and got her own radio show on KLPR, which she hosted while attending high school. Jackson recorded several songs with the country group the Brazos Valley Boys in the 50's; her duet 'You Can't Have My Love' with band leader Billy Gray was a #8 country hit in 1954. Wanda met Elvis Presley while touring the country in 1956; Presley encouraged her to start recording rockabilly songs. Jackson's rousing 'Fujiyama Mama' was a huge smash in Japan; it remained at #1 on the charts for six weeks. The equally stirring 'Let's Have a Party' likewise did well; it peaked at #37 on the US pop charts in 1960. The touching ballads 'Right or Wrong' and 'In the Middle of a Heartache' were top 10 country hits in the early 60's. Wanda's other country hits include 'Tears Will Be the Chaser for Your Wine,' 'Both Sides of the Line,' 'A Girl Don't Have to Drink to Have Fun,' 'A Woman Lives for Love,' and 'Fancy Satin Pillows.' In 1966 Jackson had a #1 hit in Germany with 'Santo Domingo,' which she sang entirely in German. In 1971 Wanda and her manager husband Wendell Goodman became borne-again Christians; Jackson subsequently has recorded several gospel albums and has performed gospel songs at churches. In 1995 Jackson sang two duets with alternative country singer Rosie Flores on Flores' album 'Rockabilly Filly.' She has been twice nominated for Grammy Awards and was awarded the Oklahoma Native Daughter Award. Moreover, Wanda has been inducted into the Oklahoma Country Music Hall of Fame, the Rockabilly Hall of Fame, the International Gospel Music Hall of Fame, the Oklahoma Music Hall of Fame, and the German Country Music Hall of Fame. Now in her early 70's, Wanda Jackson still continues to tour and perform all over the world. Wanda Jackson Queen of Rockabilly Maud, Oklahoma, USA Female 10 October 1967 Morgan Neville Los Angeles, California, USA Produced, directed 90-min documentary 'Hitmakers: The Teens Who Stole Pop Music' (2001), premiered May 3, 2001 at Museum of TV and Radio documentary festival in New York City.

'Playboy' (USA), January 2003, Vol. 50, Iss. 1, pg. 196, by: Paul Natkin, 'Grapevine: Mountain Mama's High Harmony' 'Country Music' (USA), May/June 1997 Patty Lee Ramey 5' 6' Pikeville, Kentucky, USA Female Released album 'Only What I Feel' on April 20, 1993. Ramey, Patty Lee 10 October 1967 Morgan Neville Los Angeles, California, USA Produced, directed 90-min documentary 'Hitmakers: The Teens Who Stole Pop Music' (2001), premiered May 3, 2001 at Museum of TV and Radio documentary festival in New York City.

Movie Episode Cinematographer references cinematographer Gordon Willis    28 May 1931 The Prince of Darkness 'Below the Line' (USA), 10 July 2004, Vol. 19, pg. 35, by: April MacIntyre, ''Gordon Willis: The Prince of Darkness' Gordon Willis 'New York Times' (United States), 1 August 1983 Member of the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC) since 1975. Known in the industry as 'The Prince of Darkness', due to his lighting technique of using shadows and often not allowing a character's eyes to be seen clearly (_The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), _The Parallax View (1974)_ (qv)). The Prince of Darkness [on 'ruining' footage to create the look of time-ravaged 1920s newsreels] 'The lack of perfection, that's the hardest quality of all, because you're fighting your instincts. You're trained to want to do things perfectly.' Queens, New York City, New York, USA Male
Movie Episode Cinematographer references cinematographer  Gordon Willis   28 May 1931 The Prince of Darkness 'Below the Line' (USA), 10 July 2004, Vol. 19, pg. 35, by: April MacIntyre, ''Gordon Willis: The Prince of Darkness' Gordon Willis 'New York Times' (United States), 1 August 1983 Member of the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC) since 1975. Known in the industry as 'The Prince of Darkness', due to his lighting technique of using shadows and often not allowing a character's eyes to be seen clearly (_The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), _The Parallax View (1974)_ (qv)). Work Person Writer composer costume designer Ronald Leamon  Velton Ray Bunch birth notes aka name spouse 16 April 1954 Ronald Leamon Ron Leamon Streator, Illinois, USA Male 'Tina Bockrath' (qv) (27 April 2007 - present) Velton Ray Bunch Ray Velton Bunch Goldsboro, North Carolina, USA
Work Person Writer composer costume designer Julie Weiss  Georges Delerue birth notes gender death date other works aka biographical movies name trivia birth date death notes Julie Weiss Was nominated for Broadway's 1979 Tony Award as Best Costume Designer for 'The Elephant Man,' designs that can be seen in the television version with the same title, _The Elephant Man (1982) (TV)_ (qv). Juliellen Weiss Female 12 March 1925 Georges Delerue 20 March 1992 Los Angeles, California, USA Prolific French film composer and pianist. He won a scholarship to the Paris Conservatoire, where he studied under Henri Busser and Darius Milhaud and was encouraged to write music for the cinema. While studying, he supported himself financially by playing jazz in Parisian piano bars. His screen contributions began in the early 1950's, when he conducted the Club d'Essai orchestra for French National Radio and Television. He also wrote music for the stage, including the Opera Comique, and for short films. As the decade progressed, he collaborated with most of the top French film directors (on several occasions with Truffaut). As his reputation grew, he became much in demand by American and British film makers. The French Government awarded him the highly meritorious Commandeur des Arts et Lettres. Georges DeLerue Roubaix, Nord, France Male Unused score: _Something Wicked This Way Comes (1983)_ (qv) _'Sunday Night' (1965) {Don't Shoot the Composer}_ (qv)
Work Person Writer composer costume designer  Marc Shaiman Cliff Chally aka name birth name birth date 22 October 1959 'The Advocate' (USA), 26 April 1996, Iss. 704, pg. 56+58, by: Alan Frutkin, 'The Oscars '96: Marc Shaiman' (August 2006) Playing himself and a few other characters in 'Martin Short: Fame Becomes Me', at the 'Bernard B. Work Person Writer composer costume designer Patrick Williams Theadora Van Runkle   23 April 1939 Patrick Williams is one of the most versatile composers in the music industry. Having composed well over 150 scores for theatrical features and television films, as well as records and concert works, Williams is a man of diverse talents. He has received twenty-one Emmy nominations, twelve Grammy nominations, been nominated for both the Academy Award and the Pulitzer Prize in music and has received four Emmys, two Grammys, and a CableACE Award. In addition, he is a recipient of the prestigious Richard Kirk Lifetime Achievement Award from B.M.I. Williams is also an accomplished recording artist and arranger with extensive credits. He was chosen by 'Frank Sinatra' (qv) to act as Musical Director/Arranger for his final studio recordings, Duets and Duets II. Additionally, he has arranged for 'Vince Gill (I)' (qv), 'Amy Grant (I)' (qv), 'Gloria Estefan' (qv), 'Billy Joel' (qv), 'Brian Setzer' (qv) and 'Barbra Streisand' (qv). He attended Brighton College and read Modern History at Keble College, Oxford, before studying drama at the Central School of Speech and Drama in London. His half brother was played by 'Ice Cube' (qv) who in the movie did not have the same motivation. Two years later, he landed a lead role in Civil Rights Drama _The Ernest Green Story (1993) (TV)_ (qv), showing courage and perseverance as one of the Arkansas Nine high school students. He later starred in action films like _Under Siege 2: Dark Territory (1995)_ (qv), _G.I. Jane (1997)_ (qv) and _Half Past Dead (2002)_ (qv) as well as the romantic comedies _The Best Man (1999)_ (qv), _The Brothers (2001)_ (qv), _Two Can Play That Game (2001)_ (qv), and _Breakin' All the Rules (2004)_ (qv). In 2004, he appeared in _Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)_ (qv) and _Ladder 49 (2004)_ (qv). Morris Chestnut Morris L. Video Game Series Production Designer Actor actor writer  Simon Moore Paul Benjamin   1958 Simon Moore (1987) His play, 'Up On The Roof', was performed at the Apollo Theatre in London, England with 'Beverly Hills (I)' (qv), 'Felicity Montagu' (qv), 'Michael M?ller (I)' (qv), 'Mark McGann (I)' (qv) and 'Gary Olsen (I)' (qv) in the cast. 1938 Born and raised for a time in Pelion, South Carolina, African-American actor Paul Benjamin is the youngest of twelve children born to a Baptist preacher, the Reverend Fair Benjamin, and his wife Rosa. Paul lost his mother while still a baby and his father as a child. He moved to Columbia, South Carolina, where he was taken in by one of his older brothers, David, and his wife and family. Suppressing his teenage desires of becoming an actor due to social pressures, he attended C.A. Johnson High and, upon graduation, enrolled at Benedict College for about a year before deciding to move to New York City and pursue his dream. Studying at the 'Herbert Berghof' (qv) Studio, he finally made his professional stage debut in the late 60s at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. His theater career quickly picked up steam with such classical and contemporary plays as 'Hamlet' (1967), 'Cities in Bezique (1969), 'The Owl Answers' (1969), 'No Place to Be Somebody' (1969), 'The Year Boston Won the Pennant' (1969), 'Camino Royal' 1970, 'Operation Sidewinder' (1970), Boesman and Lena (1970), 'The Black Terror' (1971), 'Assassination 1865' (1971), 'The Cherry Orchard' (1973) and 'The Old Glory' (1976).  Benjamin made his film debut inauspiciously as a bartender in _Midnight Cowboy (1969)_ (qv), which highlighted New York's seamier side. Following small roles in _The Anderson Tapes (1971)_ (qv) and _Born to Win (1971)_ (qv), he earned a top featured role and strong notices playing a robber-turned-killer in _Across 110th Street (1972)_ (qv) co-starring 'Anthony Quinn (I)' (qv) and 'Yaphet Kotto' (qv), which again took place on the gritty New York streets. He then gave incisive, strong-armed portrayals as part of a gang in _The Deadly Trackers (1973)_ (qv) and as a lieutenant alongside 'Tony Lo Bianco' (qv) and 'Hal Linden' (qv) in the above-average TV-movie _Mr. Inside/Mr. Outside (1973) (TV)_ (qv). His film and TV career, which peaked in the 1970s, included the 'blaxploitation' scene -- he appeared with 'Mary Alice (I)' (qv) as the parents of the titular character in _The Education of Sonny Carson (1974)_ (qv) and as a senator in the 'Pam Grier' (qv) vehicle _Friday Foster (1975)_ (qv).  Throughout the decades he has worked with prestigious actors in prestigious projects yet never attained the public attention he merited. Neverthless he added solid authenticity to the musical bio _Leadbelly (1976)_ (qv); 'Clint Eastwood' (qv)'s _Escape from Alcatraz (1979)_ (qv); the 'Richard Pryor' (qv) comedy-drama _Some Kind of Hero (1982)_ (qv); 'Barbra Streisand' (qv)'s courtroom vehicle _Nuts (1987)_ (qv); 'Spike Lee' (qv)'s lacerating, one-two punch on urban black life in _Do the Right Thing (1989)_ (qv); the Temptations-like story of _The Five Heartbeats (1991)_ (qv); and the excellent, fact-based drama in _Rosewood (1997)_ (qv) with racism at its core. On the mini-movie circuit he appeared in good company as 'LeVar Burton' (qv)'s father in the baseball story _One in a Million: The Ron LeFlore Story (1977) (TV)_ (qv), and was a noticeable factor in _Gideon's Trumpet (1980) (TV)_ (qv) starring 'Henry Fonda' (qv); 'Maya Angelou' (qv)'s _I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings (1979) (TV)_ (qv); the hard-hitting _'The Atlanta Child Murders' (1985)_ (qv)_ (TV) and, perhaps most notably, the chain-gang story _The Man Who Broke 1,000 Chains (1987) (TV)_ (qv) in which he portrayed Big Sam.  Paul the actor has added to his success as an award-winning playwright as well and, broaching age 70, continues to write as well as perform. His play 'Carrier', in which he appeared with 'Roscoe Lee Browne' (qv) and 'Paula Kelly (I)' (qv), received special citations for its writing and performances. Paul Benjamin Mayor Tom Bradley presented Paul with a Commendation from the City of Los Angeles for Paul's play, 'Carrier,' for which 'Paula Kelly (I)' (qv) won the 1982 NAACP Image Awards for Best Actress. She, along with Paul and actor/poet Roscoe Lee Browne, received Certificates of Recognition from Sen. Diane Watson for their performances in the same play. 6' 1 1/2' Pelion, South Carolina, USA Male
Video Game Series Production Designer Actor actor writer  Simon Moore  Ice-T gender other works trivia nick names spouse article quotes interviews birth notes books aka name trade mark birth name mini biography birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial 1958 Simon Moore (1987) His play, 'Up On The Roof', was performed at the Apollo Theatre in London, England with 'Beverly Hills (I)' (qv), 'Felicity Montagu' (qv), 'Michael M?ller (I)' (qv), 'Mark McGann (I)' (qv) and 'Gary Olsen (I)' (qv) in the cast. 'NME' (UK), 22 March 1997, pg. 12+57, by: Sylvia Patterson, 'For Your Demise Only' 'Coco Austin' (qv) (31 December 2005 - present) His feud with former LAPD chief 'Daryl Gates' (qv) was widely reported by the American press. 'Veronica' (Netherlands), 23 February 2008, Iss. 8, by: Sunshine, 'Tupperware T' (On the controversy created by 'Cop Killer): 'When the President (of the United States) mentions your name in anger, you KNOW the s--t has hit the fan!' (1998) Album: 'Below Utopia: The Lost Score,' Noo Trybe/Virgin/EMI Records V2-45854. Marrow, Tracy Lauren 16 February 1958 Ice Ice-T and Douglas Century. _Ice: A Memoir of Gangster Life and Redemption-from South Central to Hollywood._ New York: One World/Ballantine, 2011. ISBN 0345523288 The legendary gangsta hip-hop emcee Ice-T was born Tracy Marrow on February 16, 1958, in Newark, New Jersey. He moved to Los Angeles, California, to live with his paternal aunt after the death of his father while he was in the sixth grade; his mother had died earlier when he was in the third grade. His aunt lived in the South Los Angeles district of Crenshaw, colloquially referred to as South Central. He became immersed in the street life of the inner-city and eventually became a member of the West Side Rollin 30s Original Harlem Crips.  In 1979, Marrow joined the Army after leaving Crenshaw High School, but his 4-year hitch was enough for him, as he was a leader, not a follower. 'I didn't like total submission to a leader other than myself,' he said. After ETSing from the Army in 1983, he returned to South Central with the intention of becoming a hip-hop musician. More than music, his life got caught up in street life as as a jewel thief and as a pimp. (His nomme de guerre, Ice T, is an homage to the fabled pimp and raconteur Iceberg Slim ('Robert Beck (III)' (qv)). He committed himself totally to his music after a 1985 car crash.  As a musician, Ice-T played a major role in the creation of the gangsta incarnation of hip-hop music and was a colossus of the West Coast hip-hop scene, despite his East Coast, greater New York, origins. Though his music displays a political consciousness, like the indictments of racism that were a hallmark of seminal hip-hop group 'Public Enemy' (qv), it also is nihilistic as befits a chronicler of street life. His most infamous song, the heavy metal 'Cop Killer,' was one of the major battle in the cultural wars of the 1990s, in which cultural conservatives enlisted the Moses of the right wing, 'Charlton Heston' (qv), to get Ice-T dropped from his then-label, Sire/Warner Bros.  The charismatic Ice-T has also achieved success as an actor in movies and on TV. He plays Detective Odafin Tutuola on the TV series _'Law & Order: Special Victims Unit' (1999)_ (qv), which is ironic for someone famous for 'Cop Killer' and his feud with the L.A.P.D. Ice-T currently resides in North Bergen, New Jersey, with his wife, 'Coco Austin' (qv). Ice-T 'Spin' (USA), May 1991, Vol. 7, Iss. 2, pg. 58-59, by: Scott Cohen, 'Cool Career Move: Ice-T' His instantly recognizable nasal voice 'Oor' (Netherlands), 22 August 1992, Iss. 17 Tracy Marrow 5' 11' Newark, New Jersey, USA Male

Scott Mark McKinsey California, USA McKinsey, Scott Mark 'Stuff' (USA), October 2003, Iss. 47, pg. 114-118, by: Bill Schulz, 'Sin City Pretty' 'Corey Feldman' (qv) (6 August 1989 - 1993) (divorced) Auditioned for the part of Nancy in _I Still Know What You Did Last Summer (1998)_ (qv) however, the part was eventually given to 'Jennifer Esposito' (qv), since the director felt her beauty would give less attention to the lead actors of the film. 'FHM' (USA), September 2000, pg. 106-110, by: Carlo Dalla Chiesa, 'Cheeky!' 'Because of my crazy work schedule, I have become something of a master at changing my clothes while driving. The men driving next to me love it.' - on driving to work while changing clothes. 1999 - Print ads for Head and Shoulders shampoo. (1999) 15 October 1968 (2010) Hostess of an infomercial for the DDF (Doctor's Dermatologic Formula) skin care system. Also appearing is 'Cynthia Sass' (qv). Vanessa Marcil was born on October 15, 1968, in Indio, California, to Peter Ortiz, a contractor, and Patricia Marcil Ortiz, an herbalist. She grew up in Palm Desert with her parents and her two older sisters Tina and Sherry and her older brother Sam. When Vanessa was 8 she started acting in plays and even performed her own song at a sixth-grade talent show, which she won. Soon afterward she began pursuing an acting career and starred in several theatre productions before landing the role of Brenda Barrett on the ABC daytime soap opera _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) in 1992.  She made her feature film debut in _The Rock (1996)_ (qv) opposite 'Nicolas Cage' (qv) and starred in a made-for-television movie, _To Love, Honor and Deceive (1996) (TV)_ (qv), in 1996. She stayed with _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) until 1998 and then left to join the cast of _'Beverly Hills, 90210' (1990)_ (qv) as Gina Kincaid, a former ice skater replacing 'Tiffani Thiessen' (qv) as the show's vixen. She met 'Brian Austin Green' (qv) on the show and the two had a baby together named Kassius Lijah Marcil-Green born on March 30, 2002.  In the fall of 2002 she made her long-awaited return to _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) reprising her role as Brenda Barrett, garnering her a Daytime Emmy Award for 'Outstanding Supporting Actress' in 2003. Vanessa later joined the cast of the NBC drama _'Las Vegas' (2003)_ (qv) as Sam Marquez, a casino host. She resides in Los Angeles, California with her son Kassius. Vanessa Marcil 'TV Guide' (USA), 1 February 2003, Vol. 51, Iss. 5, pg. 42, by: Michael Logan, 'On Soaps: Mom Knows Best' Uses her most recent, married name for on-screen credit 'ABC Soaps In Depth' (USA), 3 September 2002, Vol. 6, Iss. 36 Sally Vanessa Ortiz Indio, California, USA Female

Composer Series Actress actress director  Vanessa Marcil Alan Pultz birth notes death date aka name birth date death notes 'Stuff' (USA), October 2003, Iss. 47, pg. 114-118, by: Bill Schulz, 'Sin City Pretty' 'Corey Feldman' (qv) (6 August 1989 - 1993) (divorced) Auditioned for the part of Nancy in _I Still Know What You Did Last Summer (1998)_ (qv) however, the part was eventually given to 'Jennifer Esposito' (qv), since the director felt her beauty would give less attention to the lead actors of the film. (1999) 15 October 1968 (2010) Hostess of an infomercial for the DDF (Doctor's Dermatologic Formula) skin care system. Also appearing is 'Cynthia Sass' (qv). Vanessa Marcil was born on October 15, 1968, in Indio, California, to Peter Ortiz, a contractor, and Patricia Marcil Ortiz, an herbalist. She grew up in Palm Desert with her parents and her two older sisters Tina and Sherry and her older brother Sam. When Vanessa was 8 she started acting in plays and even performed her own song at a sixth-grade talent show, which she won. Soon afterward she began pursuing an acting career and starred in several theatre productions before landing the role of Brenda Barrett on the ABC daytime soap opera _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) in 1992.  She made her feature film debut in _The Rock (1996)_ (qv) opposite 'Nicolas Cage' (qv) and starred in a made-for-television movie, _To Love, Honor and Deceive (1996) (TV)_ (qv), in 1996. She stayed with _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) until 1998 and then left to join the cast of _'Beverly Hills, 90210' (1990)_ (qv) as Gina Kincaid, a former ice skater replacing 'Tiffani Thiessen' (qv) as the show's vixen. She met 'Brian Austin Green' (qv) on the show and the two had a baby together named Kassius Lijah Marcil-Green born on March 30, 2002.  In the fall of 2002 she made her long-awaited return to _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) reprising her role as Brenda Barrett, garnering her a Daytime Emmy Award for 'Outstanding Supporting Actress' in 2003. Vanessa later joined the cast of the NBC drama _'Las Vegas' (2003)_ (qv) as Sam Marquez, a casino host. She resides in Los Angeles, California with her son Kassius. Video Game Crew Member Series Editor crew member director Alpha Barry  Steven Soderbergh   Alpha Barry 'Humo' (Belgium), 6 November 2001, Iss. 3192, pg. 128, 'De zwarte periode' 'Jules Asner' (qv) (10 May 2003 - present) At one point, was interested in directing _Fantastic Four (2005)_ (qv). [on if he feels he understands what audiences want] No. I've tried to get better about weighing what I think the accessibility of an idea is against the cost of executing it. I've tried to be smarter about that, because if you're not smart about that, you're going to be unemployed. But I'm still mystified about what works for people. And I'm not talking about my movies, I'm talking in general. I'm mystified by the stuff that doesn't work. I'm mystified by what's going on in the critical side, too. Stuff I like is getting trashed and stuff that is being praised I think is terrible. I don't really feel in sync with what's happening, but at the same time, what I think keeps me afloat is that I try not to be, and don't want to be, very indulgent. I try to make the films as lean as possible, and to not spend a lot of time crawling up my own ass creatively. Directed stage play, 'Geniuses', for Swine Palace Productions, Baton Rouge, LA. (1996) Soderbergh, Steven A. 14 January 1963 Steven Soderbergh was born on January 14, 1963, in Atlanta, Georgia, USA, the second of six children and, while still at a very young age, his family moved to Baton Rouge, Louisiana, where his father, 'Peter Soderbergh' (qv), was a professor and the dean of the College of Education at Louisiana State University. While still in high school, around the age of 15, Soderbergh enrolled in the university's film animation class and began making short 16-millimeter films with second-hand equipment, one of which was the short film 'Janitor'. After graduating high school, he went to Hollywood, where he worked as a freelance editor. His time there was brief and, shortly after, he returned home and continued making short films and writing scripts.  His first major break was in 1986 when the rock group 'Yes' (qv) assigned him to shoot a full-length concert film for the band, which eventually earned him a Grammy nomination for the video, _Yes: 9012 Live (1985) (V)_ (qv). Following this achievement, Soderbergh filmed _Winston (1987)_ (qv), the short-subject film that he would later expand into _Sex, Lies, and Videotape (1989)_ (qv), a film that earned him the Cannes Film Festival's Palme d'Or Award, the Independent Spirit Award for Best Director, and an Oscar nomination for Best Original Screenplay. Over the next six years, he was married to actress 'Betsy Brantley' (qv) and had a daughter named Sarah Soderbergh, who was born in 1990.  Also during this time, he made such films as _Kafka (1991)_ (qv), _King of the Hill (1993)_ (qv), _Underneath (1995)_ (qv) and _Gray's Anatomy (1996)_ (qv), which many believed to be disappointments. In 1998, Soderbergh made _Out of Sight (1998)_ (qv), his most critically and commercially successful film since _Sex, Lies, and Videotape (1989)_ (qv). Then, in 2000, Soderbergh directed two major motion pictures that are now his most successful films to date: _Erin Brockovich (2000)_ (qv) and _Traffic (2000)_ (qv). These films were both nominated for Best Picture Oscars at the 2001 Academy Awards and gave him the first twin director Oscar nomination in almost 60 years and the first ever win. He won the Oscar for Best Director for _Traffic (2000)_ (qv) at the 2001 Oscars. Steven Soderbergh 'The New York Times' (USA), 23 May 2008, Vol. 157, Iss. 54,319, pg. E1 & E8, by: A.O. Scott, 'Soderbergh and Che, Provocateurs' Frequently uses jump-cuts 'M Le Magazine du Monde' (France), 11 August 2012, Iss. 47 Steve Soderbergh 6' Atlanta, Georgia, USA Male

Movie Editor Person production designer editor Jim Mullen Steve Bass   Jim Mullen James Multi-Emmy Award winner Steve Bass has designed many of the most prestigious live and televised shows produced, including the Oscars, Grammys, Emmys and Tony Awards. His talents were tapped for the Opening and Closing Ceremonies of the Atlanta Olympics, Salt Lake Olympics Medals Plaza, The Democratic Convention, Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus, and the Inaugural Celebration at the Lincoln Memorial for President Obama.  Live show design includes mega hits from Disney: the Lion King Celebration and a theatrical production of The Little Mermaid which to date has been seen by over 25 million guests, as well as the national tour of Disney's Symphonic Fantasy and Sesame Street Live. Recent live productions include DreamWorks Madagascar Live!, Disney's Mad T Party: an innovative experiential nightclub, and the award-winning Starlight Parade for Universal Studios Japan.  Steve has a long-standing history designing for iconic entertainment programs such as Great Performances, Nickelodeon's Kids Choice, Christmas in Washington, TV Land, and Entertainment Tonight, as well as corporate events for auto giants Lexus and Toyota. Steve Bass

I grew up as a farm boy in Fresno, which is an agricultural town plunked in the middle of California--thousands of miles mentally from Hollywood. I'd watch the Academy Awards and it was such a magical event. I really wanted to be part of that world, like everyone does. Movie Editor Person production designer editor  Roy Christopher Jon Bloom gender other works aka name trivia mini biography Roy Christopher Attended California State University, Fresno. I grew up as a farm boy in Fresno, which is an agricultural town plunked in the middle of California--thousands of miles mentally from Hollywood. I'd watch the Academy Awards and it was such a magical event. I really wanted to be part of that world, like everyone does. Male Stage: Designed sets for 'Oscar and Felix: A New Look at The Odd Couple' by 'Neil Simon (I)' (qv), Geffen Playhouse, Westwood, CA; 6/02. _A Conversation with Art Director Roy Christopher (2004) (V)_ (qv) Jon Bloom is an Oscar and Emmy nominated filmmaker with broad experience as a director, producer, writer, cinematographer and editor. With almost four decades in the motion picture industry, Bloom is a renowned specialist in entertainment marketing.  A multi award-winning filmmaker, Jon Bloom counts among his kudos six Emmy nominations, a Clio Award plus six Clio nominations, numerous Hollywood Reporter Key Art Trailer Awards and many film festival honors including an Academy Award nomination as producer/director of the live-action short 'Overnight Sensation,' based upon the Somerset Maugham short story 'The Colonel's Lady' and starring Robert Loggia, Louise Fletcher and Shari Belafonte. In addition to the Oscar nomination, the film won first place awards at the Houston, Aspen and American Film Festivals and is currently available at the Apple iTunes music store on the net.  A four-term Governor at the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences, Bloom also is Chair of the Short Films and Feature Animation Branch. Earlier, Bloom was elected by the AMPAS Board to serve as an Academy Officer. Additionally, he has created and produced for the Academy its annual theatrical trailer promoting the Oscar telecast several times and created many special montages and tributes for the Academy Awards ceremony, as well as for the Emmys, SAG Awards and other event telecasts.  His production company BloomFilm, founded in 1987, provides the entertainment industry with audio/visual marketing materials for promotion and advertising. It specializes in creative development and production of theatrical trailers and teaser trailers for movie theatres, television and radio spots for broadcast, special concept shooting, main title sequences, special graphics, documentaries, music videos, montages and product reels for special sales purposes.  BloomFilm continues to build upon Bloom's long term reputation as a top trailer-maker, compiling an impressive list of feature campaigns, including the hits Dances With Wolves, Sleeping With The Enemy, Far And Away, The Fast and The Furious, Chocolat, Flirting With Disaster, and Sling Blade, as well as Music Of The Heart, Mansfield Park, Runaway Bride, Prince Of Egypt, Diabolique, Wild America, Uncle Buck, The River Wild, Mountains Of The Moon, The Abyss, Say Anything, Working Girl, Bright Lights, Big City, Moon Over Parador, Murder In The First, Final Analysis, Toys, The Santa Clause, Sneakers and Chicago.  With his impressive credentials as a director, it is understandable that Bloom enjoys a solid reputation for his expertise in special shooting; from live-action shoots with major stars to table-top cinematography, special effects, computer graphics and trick photography. Jon has directed many top performers including Jack Lemmon, Jane Fonda, Bruce Willis, Kim Basinger, Darryl Hannah, Dudley Moore, Joseph Bologna, Danny Glover, James Garner, Mary Tyler Moore, and Tom Hanks.  Jon Bloom's early work experience includes stints as an assistant director to Robert Wise and Robert Altman, and an assistant editor to Francis Ford Coppola on Godfather II. His early years in motion picture advertising encompass his time as a principal and founder of both Seiniger/Bloom Productions and Intralink, and as a producer of trailers and director of behind-the-scenes documentaries for Kaleidoscope Films. During this period, his work included campaigns for such hit films as Return Of The Jedi, About Last Night, E.T., An American Tail, Throw Momma From The Train, Broadcast News, The Last Emperor, Little Shop Of Horrors, The Verdict, Twilight Zone: The Movie, Missing, The Morning After, Bladerunner, Shogun, 10 and Victor/Victoria. Jon Bloom Member of the Board of Governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (Short Films and Feature Animation Branch) [2000-] Jon N. Bloom Male Has created and produced many feature advertising campaigns, among them 'The Fast And The Furious', 'Dances With Wolves', 'Sleeping With The Enemy', 'The Last Emperor', 'Throw Momma From The Train', and 'Far And Away' which have won a Clio award, 6 Clio nominations and 8 Hollywood Reporter Key Art Awards.

Series Producer Director editor cinematographer Finian Shea Johnson  Andre Martinez aka name nick names article height Finian Shea Johnson Dre' Andre Martinez 'New York Times' (USA), 21 July 2008, by: GINIA BELLAFANTE, 'On Reality Shows, Love's Retreads Need Dates, Too' Dre' Martinez 5' 7 1/2'
Series Producer Director editor cinematographer Fredric Steinkamp  Owen Roizman birth notes gender name trivia mini biography birth date spouse article quotes 22 August 1928 Fredric Steinkamp 20 February 2002 Santa Monica, California, USA (heart failure) Father of film editor 'William Steinkamp (I)' (qv). Fredric 'Fritz' Steinkamp 22 September 1936 'Mona Lindholm' (6 December 1964 - present); 1 child Ace cinematographer Owen Roizman was born September 22, 1936, in Brooklyn, New York. His father Sol was a cinematographer for Fox Movietone News and his uncle 'Morrie Roizman' (qv) was a film editor. Owen studied math and physics at Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania. He began his career shooting TV commercials, and made his feature debut as a director of photography with the obscure and little seen 1970 movie _Stop (1970)_ (qv). Owen brought a strong and compelling sense of raw, gritty, documentary-style realism to 'William Friedkin' (qv)'s harsh and hard-hitting police action thriller classic _The French Connection (1971)_ (qv). Roizman received a well-deserved Academy Award nomination for his outstanding visual contributions to this picture; he went on to garner four additional Oscar nominations, for _The Exorcist (1973)_ (qv), _Tootsie (1982)_ (qv), _Network (1976)_ (qv) and _Wyatt Earp (1994)_ (qv). Owen gave a similar rough and grainy look to the edgy urban thrillers _The Taking of Pelham One Two Three (1974)_ (qv) and _Straight Time (1978)_ (qv). His other films encompass an impressively diverse array of different genres which include horror ('The Exorcist'), science fiction (_The Stepford Wives (1975)_ (qv)), comedy (_The Heartbreak Kid (1972)_ (qv) 'Tootsie'), musicals (_Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band (1978)_ (qv)), drama (_True Confessions (1981)_ (qv), _Absence of Malice (1981)_ (qv)) and even Westerns (_The Return of a Man Called Horse (1976)_ (qv), 'Wyatt Earp'). His last feature to date was _French Kiss (1995)_ (qv). In the early 1980s Owen took a hiatus from shooting films and formed the commercial production company Roizman and Associates. He has directed and/or photographed hundreds of TV commercials. In 1997 he was the recipient of a Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Society of Cinematographers. Owen Roizman 'American Cinematographer' (USA), February 1997, Vol. 78, Iss. 2, pg. 40-47, by: David E. Williams, 'Chasing Greatness: The ASC fetes Owen Roizman for his diverse career of groundbreaking work with the 1997 Lifetime Achievement Award.' Member of the Board of Governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (Cinematographers Branch) [2002-] When I was nominated for an Oscar for _The French Connection (1971)_ (qv), I couldn't believe it. I thought I was fooling everyone. You know, I still feel that way. In fact, when I was nominated for the fifth time for _Wyatt Earp (1994)_ (qv), the first thing my wife said was, 'Well, you fooled them again'. Brooklyn, New York City, New York, USA Male

TV Movie Person actor crew member Willie Nelson Shiran Stotland   'Playboy' (USA), November 2002, Vol. 49, Iss. 11, pg. 63-64+66-68+70+161, by: David Sheff, 'Playboy Interview: Willie Nelson' 'Constance Jean 'Connie' Koepke' (30 April 1972 - 1988) (divorced); 2 children He was the subject of the 'Toby Keith' (qv) song 'I'll Never Smoke Weed with Willie Again'. 'Der Spiegel' (Germany), 17 May 2010, Iss. 20, pg. 180 Waylon Jennings once said that if everybody got up in the morning and masturbated, there wouldn't be no wars. I am not in favor of that as much as I am of pot. They should start off every morning summit with a puff or maybe just pump a little into the air conditioner. In the future, I would like to be able to push a switch and have pot released into every household all over the world. (1975) Album: 'Red Headed Stranger' Nelson, Willie Hugh 30 April 1933 Red Headed Stranger (January 2006) Release of the book, 'Willie Nelson: The Outlaw' by Graeme Thomson. Willie Nelson, with Bud Shrake. _Willie._ Cooper Square Press, 2000. ISBN 0815410808 This versatile, eclectic, rather wanderlust country crossover star known for his classic ballads ('Always On My Mind'), autobiographical road songs ('On the Road Again') and catchy rhythms ('Mammas Don't Let Your Babies Grow Up to Be Cowboys') started out life as Willie Hugh Nelson on April 30, 1933, in Depression-era Abbot, Texas. After his mother abandoned the family and his father died, he and sister Bobbie Lee were raised by gospel-singing grandparents. Working in the cotton fields, Willie was handed his first guitar at age six and within a short time was writing woeful country songs and playing in polka bands. During his teenage years he played at high school dances and honky-tonks. He also worked for a local radio station and by graduation time he had become a DJ with his own radio show. Briefly serving a stint with the Air Force (discharged because of a bad back, which would plague him throughout his life), he sold his first song called 'No Place For Me' while getting by with menial jobs as a janitor and door-to-door Bible salesman. Married in 1952 to a full-blooded Cherokee, he and first wife Martha had two children. He initially came to be known in Nashville for selling his songs to well-established country artists such as 'Patsy Cline' (qv) ('Crazy'), 'Faron Young' (qv) ('Hello Walls') and 'Ray Price (III)' (qv) ('Night Life'). In 1962 he recorded a successful duet with singer Shirley Collie, whom he would later take as his second wife, but his career didn't progress despite joining the Grand 'Ol Opry. In the early 1970s, after extensive touring with his band (which included sister Bobbie on the piano) and experiencing a number of career downswings, he started performing and recording his own songs instead of selling them to others. Two of his albums, 'Shotgun Willie' and 'Phases and Stages', helped him gain some stature. In 1975 it all came together with the album 'Red-Headed Stranger', which would become the top-selling country music album in history and propel him into the country music stratosphere. His offbeat phrasing, distinctive nasal tones and leathery, bewhiskered hippie-styled looks set a new standard for 'outlaw' country music. Around 1978 Willie showed himself to be a loose and natural presence in front of the camera, thus launching a film career. He had roles in several movies, his first opposite 'Robert Redford (I)' (qv) and 'Jane Fonda' (qv) in _The Electric Horseman (1979)_ (qv). His took to leading roles as a country music star in _Honeysuckle Rose (1980)_ (qv), which would include a number of his songs on the soundtrack. He played opposite 'James Caan (I)' (qv) and 'Tuesday Weld' (qv) in _Thief (1981)_ (qv) and a legendary outlaw in the western _Barbarosa (1982)_ (qv). In the movie _Red Headed Stranger (1986)_ (qv), which was adapted from his hit 1975 album, he played a preacher, and he teamed up with pal 'Kris Kristofferson (I)' (qv) as a pair of country singers in _Songwriter (1984)_ (qv). He and pal Kristofferson went on to form The Highwaymen with the late 'Johnny Cash (I)' (qv) and 'Waylon Jennings' (qv) and he successfully recorded and toured with the group for a number of years. They also teamed up to remake the classic western _Stagecoach (1939)_ (qv) as a TV movie (_Stagecoach (1986) (TV)_ (qv)). As a unique song stylist, the bearded, braided-haired, bandanna-wearing non-conformist took a number of non-country standards and made them his own, including 'Elvis Presley' (qv)'s 'You Were Always on My Mind' and 'Ray Charles (I)' (qv)' 'Georgia on My Mind.' He happily married fourth wife Ann-Marie in 1991 and has survived more hard times in recent years, including a $16.7-million debt to the IRS and the suicide of one of his sons, Billy. Inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 1993, Nelson received the Kennedy Center Honors in 1998. Willie Nelson 'TV Guide' (USA), 28 September 2002, Vol. 50, Iss. 39, pg. 5, by: Joe Nick Patoski, 'The full Nelson' Often wears a Cowboy hat or a Bandana 'Parade' (USA), 27 June 2010 The Ambassador to Weedville 5' 6' Abbott, Texas, USA Male Shiran Stotland Shiran Stoland

TV Movie Person actor crew member Shawn Parr Shiran Stotland   14 February 1964 'Yahoo News' (USA), 18 May 2006, by: Joe Buscaino, 'Los Angeles Police-Celebrity Golf Tournament' (January 2007) KKGO 105.1 FM Los Angeles, from 5 AM to 10 PM weekdays and Satruday night from 7 PM to 10 PM. Referred to as the 'Ambassador of Country Music,' Shawn Parr has spent 20 plus years on the Los Angeles country music scene. His involvement in country music spans from his current radio shows to television and the Academy of country music.  In August of 2006 thousands of fans rallied to get Country Music back on their local airwaves when the defunct KZLA-FM flipped formats in August of that year. Shawn Parr was the on-air talent when the KZLA flipped. Within less than three months from the loss, Southern California had a new country station on the air. Five months later Shawn Parr was back on the air anchoring the new station.  You can find Shawn Parr as KKGO's wake-up voice on his morning show entitled 'Shawn Parr with Ashley Paige'(Ashley Paige was formerly a part of the KZLA morning show). You can tune in Monday through Friday 10 AM to 2 PM and on Saturday nights from 7 PM - 10 AM you can hear him again on 'Shawn Parr's Number 1 Show.' GoCountry 105, became the first affiliate and flagship station for Shawn Parr's 'The Number 1 Show,' produced by his good friend Rick Dees.  The show features 3 hours packed full of number 1 hits and the stories behind them, with the largest variety of number ones,interviews with those artists, and how those artists made it to number 1. Or in other words it has the biggest stories on the biggest songs. GoCountry 105.1 FM radio covers San Diego, Orange Country, Los Angeles to Santa Barbara, California. His show can also be heard world wide streaming on 'gocountry.am'.  Parr has a passion and a long-term involvement with country music. He is heavily involved with the Academy of Country Music and hosted the Academy's Bash in Irvine, California in 2006.  Shawn Parr is a Southern Californian native. He grew up in Norwalk, California and attended John Glenn High School, spending a lot of his youth in the 'O.C.' (Orange County).  He began his career at local dance venues and launched into his current career by becoming the warm-up personality for the TV show 'Hot Country Nights.' As the Announcer for the Academy of Country Music Awards, KZLA brought him on board at the helm of the KZLA Morning Show and later to the mid-day shift.  His career also includes acting with roles in such films as 'Lucky You' and 'Waist Deep.' Parr is also the voice of many awards shows such as the Golden Globes, the California Speedway, numerous commercials voice-overs, and the American Music Awards for the 16th year in a row.  In addition he does numerous public appearances at such locations as Cowboy Country, Montana's and most KKGO events. Parr is also on the Board of Directors for the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation and has hosted his own annual golf tournament benefiting the John Tracy Clinic. Shawn is an avid golfer and has been a part of the Bob Hope Classic for a number of years. Shawn Parr 'The Signal' (USA), 30 July 2002, by: Diana Sevanian, 'Spirit of American Charity and Fun' California, USA Male Shiran Stotland Shiran Stoland

(On 'Hillary Rodham Clinton' (qv)) (1972 Album: 'Honky Chateau' (Uni) _'South Park' (1997) {Chef Aid (#2.14)}_ (qv) Dwight, Reginald Kenneth 25 March 1947 Sharon (given to him by Rod Stewart) (February 2004) Along with long-time lyricist 'Bernie Taupin' (qv), he is currently working on the stage adaptation of 'Anne Rice (I)' (qv)'s novel, 'The Vampire Lestat'. 'Philip Norman (I)' (qv). _Elton John._ Sir Elton John is one of pop music's great survivors. Born 25 March, 1947, as Reginald Kenneth Dwight, he started to play the piano at the early age of four. At the age of 11, he won a scholarship to the Royal Academy of Music. His first band was called Bluesology. He later auditioned (unsuccessfully) as lead singer for the progressive rock bands 'King Crimson' (qv) and Gentle Giant. Dwight teamed up with lyricist 'Bernie Taupin' (qv) and changed his name to Elton John (merging the names of saxophonist 'Elton Dean' (qv) and 'Long John Baldry' (qv)). The duo wrote songs for 'Lulu (I)' (qv) and 'Roger Cook (II)' (qv). In the early 1970s, he recorded the concept album 'Tumbleweed Connection.' He became the most successful pop artist of the 1970s, and he has survived many different pop fads including punk, the New Romantics and Britpop to remain one of Britain's most internationally acclaimed musicians.  Elton John announced he was a bisexual in 1976, and in 1984, he married Renate Blauel. The marriage lasted four years before he finally came to terms with the fact that he was actually homosexual. In the 1970s and 1980s, he suffered from drug and alcohol addiction and bulimia but came through it. He is well known as a campaigner for AIDS research and he keeps his finger on the pulse of modern music, enjoying artists such as 'Eminem' (qv), 'Radiohead' (qv), 'Coldplay' (qv) and 'Robbie Williams (I)' (qv). He was knighted in 1997. Elton John 'The Washington Post' (USA), 22 December 2005, Vol. 129, Iss. 17, pg. C1+C7, by: Mary Jordan, 'Elton John, 'Single Man' No More: Pop Star and Partner Join in Civil Union' Outrageous costumes and spectacles 'Entertainment Weekly' (USA), 5 November 2004, Vol. 1, Iss. 791 Sir Elton John CBE 172 cm Pinner, Harrow, Middlesex, England, UK [now Pinner, Harrow, Greater London, England, UK] Male Shiran Stotland Shiran Stoland

Series Producer Cinematographer cinematographer Roy H. Wagner   Buddy Born in a very small community in the mid west Roy had no other contact to his dream of becoming a cinematographer than through the local theater and the Los Angeles phone directory. He would recall the names of cinematographers as they appeared on their films and call them blindly to talk with them about their work. Many of them were so suprised by this young man's ambition and interest that they took him under their wing, mentoring him. When he arrived in Los Angeles he spent every moment with them on their sets and homes learning as much about them and their work as he could. Because of this he was able to meet and befriend many of the greatest cinematographers in Hollywood. His key mentor was Harry Stradling Sr. Through him he developed friendships with Joseph Ruttenberg, George Folsey, James Wong Howe, Leon Shamroy, Frank Phillipd, Leonard South, and many many others. In the late 70s he began a life long process of interviewing cinematographers on video tape or film. A deep reverence for all that is old Hollywood remains a great part of his life and the memory of the behind the scene stories told him as a young man is an important basis for his life and work. Roy H. Wagner 'International Photographer' (USA), January 1996, pg. 22-27, 'It's A Party' Esteemed and longtime member of the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC). Roy Henry Wagner III Male III, Roy Henry Wagner
