Composer Episode Work actor featured in   Burt Richards birth notes books gender other works aka name where now mini biography nick names birth date article height 29 May 1939 Boca Burt (July 2003) completing his new book, 'Stars In My Eyes'. Burt Richards. _Stars In My Eyes Then & Now._ Bloomingto , I'll: Authorhouse, 2004. ISBN 1-4184-2298-3 Burt Richards' career as a professional actor started in 1964 with many appearances and leading roles on the Off-Broadway stage, films and TV commercials in New York. His move to Florida in 1972, gave him the outlet to be more active with many stage appearances, films, and television commercial & series work seen the world over, plus being sought after as being one of South Florida's busiest actors for over 35 years. He created a Travel & Theatre review column called 'Theatre Happenings, Adventures In Entertainment & Quips From the Stars'. A syndicated column published in South Florida for the past 22 Years, seen in many local newspapers and magazines. His special Celebrity Features appear in the Boomer & Senior times on a monthly basis, published in Bioca Raton, Florida.  He now devotes time towards his writing and reviewing theatre in his column and the celebrities he encounters on a personal level, and lends his theatrical articles and comments for readers to enjoy. Richards has an extensive collection on Presidents, Politicians and stories to go with each photo he has received, from Margaret Thatcher, Tony Blair, to Prince Rainier. Plus a huge collection of autographed photos of the world famous celebrities and letters from Julie Harris, Ed Asner, Lee Meriwether, Burt Lancaster, Leona Helmsly, Jimmy Stewart, Stacy Keach and many others.  Richards is a Carbonell award-winning producer presenting some wonderful shows, Hit Tunes From Flop Shows, Dam Yankees, 110 In The Shade and Nite Club Confidential, Broadway's Best Musical Hits From Forgotten Shows and The Sinatra Song Book. Since retirement from the stage as an actor, he spends more time with print and commercials, special musical shows and he established a radio show on W.D.B.F. and W.I.N.N. featuring Theatre Happenings for the weekend. He is also listed in Who's Who In Entertainment. He has featured celebrities with his stories on their lives that include the late great Bob Hope, Jane Russell, Don Rickles, Ed Asner, Jayne Meadows, Carroll Baker, Judge Judy, Wayne Newton, Irving R. Levine, Karl Malden, Dionne Warwick, Eli Wallach, Anne Jackson, Julie Ann Harris, Rona Barrett Stacy Keach. Burt Richards 'Boomer And Senior Times' (USA), 1 January 2003, Vol. 14, Iss. 1, pg. 2, by: Anita Finley, 'Renaissance & Family Man' Boca Burt 5' 10' New York City, New York, USA Male TV commercials for Harolds Jewelers - Atlantis Resort (2001)

Video Game Crew Member TV Movie Director editor composer   Tim Jones Joel Cox birth notes gender aka name trivia birth name mini biography birth date 1971 'Evelyn Jones' (1996 - present); 2 children Tim Jones Timothy Jones 6' 4' Mission Viejo, California, USA 2 April 1942 Joel Cox was born c. 1941 and his film career began at a very early age - appearing before the cameras, in fact - as a baby in the film 'Random Harvest'. Some twenty years later he began work as a mail-room boy with Warner Brothers, the company with whom he has worked ever since, and in 1969 moved into the cutting-room, as an uncredited assistant editor on 'Woodstock' and 'The Wild Bunch'. He was a credited assistant on 'The Outlaw Josey Wales', working for the first time with Clint Eastwood. A durable collaboration followed with Cox cutting all films made by Eastwood since. Joel Cox He credits 'Ferris Webster' (qv) and 'Walter Thompson (I)' (qv) as being his greatest mentors, followed by 'Sam O'Steen' (qv). Joel Edward Cox Los Angeles, California, USA Male Cox, Joel Edward

Sexuality in that way and women using it has been around for forever, but it seems now with Britney Spears and Paris Hilton, it seems that now in order to be successful you need to look like you want to have sex with every guy. I don't get it. She moved to Los Angeles at the age of eighteen and shortly landed roles in such television shows as _'Life Goes On' (1989)_ (qv), _'Class of '96' (1993)_ (qv) (recurring), _'Law & Order' (1990)_ (qv), HBO's _'Dream On' (1990)_ (qv) and the ABC mini-series _J.F.K.: Reckless Youth (1993) (TV)_ (qv), in which she played 'Kit Kennedy'. _The Craft (1996)_ (qv) was Tunney's first film lead though she has appeared in many supporting roles. Smith Tim Jones birth notes aka name birth date spouse height 'Emmy Magazine' (USA), October 2000, Vol. XXIII, Iss. 5, pg. 16, by: Daniel Guss, 'Shooting Stars' 'Lynn Dickinson' (July 1997 - present); 1 child Born and raised in Marshall, Missouri. He received his BA from Colorado College and MFA from CalArts. He shot several music videos, including 'Weird Al' Yankovic's 'All About the Pentiums,' 'The Saga Begins,' 'Amish Paradise,' 'Headline News,' 'Bob,' 'Bedrock Anthem,' and 'Gump,' Ben Folds, 'Rockin' The Suburbs,' The Jon Spencer Blues Explosion, 'Wail,' and Jeff Foxworthy's 'Redneck Stomp' and 'Party All Night.' Clyde is the son of former Missouri State Representative, James L. Smith and the brother of actress 'Jamie Smith-Jackson' (qv). Clyde W. Smith 'American Cinematographer' (USA), June 2000, Vol. 81, Iss. 6, pg. 26-32, by: Rachael K. Bosley, 'Comic Trip' Brother-in-law of actor 'Michael Ontkean' (qv) (of The Rookies, Twin Peaks, and Slapshot fame). Video Game Movie Cinematographer Person composer cinematographer   Steven Soderbergh Tim Jones birth notes aka name birth date spouse height 'Humo' (Belgium), 6 November 2001, Iss. 3192, pg. 128, 'De zwarte periode' 'Jules Asner' (qv) (10 May 2003 - present) At one point, was interested in directing _Fantastic Four (2005)_ (qv). [on if he feels he understands what audiences want] No. I've tried to get better about weighing what I think the accessibility of an idea is against the cost of executing it. I've tried to be smarter about that, because if you're not smart about that, you're going to be unemployed. But I'm still mystified about what works for people. And I'm not talking about my movies, I'm talking in general. I'm mystified by the stuff that doesn't work. I'm mystified by what's going on in the critical side, too. Stuff I like is getting trashed and stuff that is being praised I think is terrible. I don't really feel in sync with what's happening, but at the same time, what I think keeps me afloat is that I try not to be, and don't want to be, very indulgent. I try to make the films as lean as possible, and to not spend a lot of time crawling up my own ass creatively. Directed stage play, 'Geniuses', for Swine Palace Productions, Baton Rouge, LA. (1996) Soderbergh, Steven A. 14 January 1963 Steven Soderbergh was born on January 14, 1963, in Atlanta, Georgia, USA, the second of six children and, while still at a very young age, his family moved to Baton Rouge, Louisiana, where his father, 'Peter Soderbergh' (qv), was a professor and the dean of the College of Education at Louisiana State University. While still in high school, around the age of 15, Soderbergh enrolled in the university's film animation class and began making short 16-millimeter films with second-hand equipment, one of which was the short film 'Janitor'. After graduating high school, he went to Hollywood, where he worked as a freelance editor. His time there was brief and, shortly after, he returned home and continued making short films and writing scripts.  His first major break was in 1986 when the rock group 'Yes' (qv) assigned him to shoot a full-length concert film for the band, which eventually earned him a Grammy nomination for the video, _Yes: 9012 Live (1985) (V)_ (qv). Following this achievement, Soderbergh filmed _Winston (1987)_ (qv), the short-subject film that he would later expand into _Sex, Lies, and Videotape (1989)_ (qv), a film that earned him the Cannes Film Festival's Palme d'Or Award, the Independent Spirit Award for Best Director, and an Oscar nomination for Best Original Screenplay. Over the next six years, he was married to actress 'Betsy Brantley' (qv) and had a daughter named Sarah Soderbergh, who was born in 1990.  Also during this time, he made such films as _Kafka (1991)_ (qv), _King of the Hill (1993)_ (qv), _Underneath (1995)_ (qv) and _Gray's Anatomy (1996)_ (qv), which many believed to be disappointments. In 1998, Soderbergh made _Out of Sight (1998)_ (qv), his most critically and commercially successful film since _Sex, Lies, and Videotape (1989)_ (qv). Then, in 2000, Soderbergh directed two major motion pictures that are now his most successful films to date: _Erin Brockovich (2000)_ (qv) and _Traffic (2000)_ (qv). These films were both nominated for Best Picture Oscars at the 2001 Academy Awards and gave him the first twin director Oscar nomination in almost 60 years and the first ever win. He won the Oscar for Best Director for _Traffic (2000)_ (qv) at the 2001 Oscars. Steven Soderbergh 'The New York Times' (USA), 23 May 2008, Vol. 157, Iss. 54,319, pg. E1 & E8, by: A.O. Scott, 'Soderbergh and Che, Provocateurs' Frequently uses jump-cuts 'M Le Magazine du Monde' (France), 11 August 2012, Iss. 47 Steve Soderbergh 6' Atlanta, Georgia, USA Male 1971 'Evelyn Jones' (1996 - present); 2 children Tim Jones Timothy Jones 6' 4' Mission Viejo, California, USA

Production Designer Language TV Movie production designer language   John Barry birth notes gender death date aka name mini biography birth date death notes 1935 John Barry was a British production designer. Started his career in the art department of the movie Cleopatra (1963). He is known chiefly for his imaginative design work on 'Star Wars' and 'Superman: The Movie'. Barry got the opportunity to direct the sci-fi movie 'Saturn 3' but was replaced during filming. However, he returned to the Star Wars universe on 'The Empire Strikes Back' as a second unit director. On May 31st 1979, (two weeks into filming) he collapsed on-set and was hospitalized as his temperature rose to 104 degrees. He died at 2am on June 1st, a victim of meningitis. John Barry 1 June 1979 London, England, UK (infectious meningitis) Jonathan Barry London, England, UK Male
Production Designer Language TV Movie production designer language   Boris Leven birth notes death date aka name mini biography birth date death notes 13 August 1908 Boris Leven was born in Moscow, where he first studied painting and design. He emigrated to the U.S. in 1927 and attended the University of Southern California, graduating with a Bachelor of Architecture in 1932. He went on to complete his education at the Beaux Arts Institute of Design in New York and, the following year, was signed by Paramount to work as a sketch artist and illustrator under the tutelage of the experienced art director 'Hans Dreier' (qv). After a three-year apprenticeship, Leven went on to work for independent producer 'Samuel Goldwyn' (qv). His big break came in 1937, when he was signed under contract at 20th Century Fox as fully-qualified art director and production designer. For his first major assignment, _Alexander's Ragtime Band (1938)_ (qv), he utilised more than 85 period sets. Proficient not only with historical detail, but also instinctive about the mood or thematic requirement of a picture, he brought imagination to the look of _The Shanghai Gesture (1941)_ (qv), _Tales of Manhattan (1942)_ (qv) and varied other assignments.  Leven remained at Fox until 1947, then joined Universal (1947-48), free-lanced, had another spell with Fox (1951-52), then worked for United Artists (1953) and Warner Brothers (1954-55). In-between, he worked privately on oil and watercolour paintings, some of which found their way into private collections, or were exhibited at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Leven became best known in the 1950's for his work on the production design of _Giant (1956)_ (qv), for which he set the scene with the indelible image of an opulent Victorian mansion, contrasting like a monolith against the broad expanse of harsh Texan prairie - providing allegorical imagery of copious human materialism vis-?-vis raw nature. In 1962, Leven won an Academy Award for Best Art Direction and Set Decoration for _West Side Story (1961)_ (qv), a mixture of deliberately stylised theatrically-based sets and realistic New York locations. His other notable films during this period were _The Sound of Music (1965)_ (qv) and _The Sand Pebbles (1966)_ (qv), his work being greatly facilitated by picturesque on-location shooting, respectively, in the Austrian Alps and Salzburg, and in Taiwan and Hong Kong. Boris Leven was inducted into the Art Director's Hall of Fame in 2004. Boris Leven 11 October 1986 Los Angeles, California, USA Boris Levin Moscow, Russian Empire [now Russia]

Dante Feretti Macerata, Marche, Italy

Video Game Language Producer TV Movie language writer Ian Fleming     'Anne Geraldine Charteris' (24 March 1952 - 12 August 1964) (his death); 1 child Canterbury, Kent, England, UK (heart attack) His wife, Anne Geraldine Charteris, was the granddaughter of the 9th Earl of Wemyss, and had been previously married to Shane O'Neill, 3rd Lord O'Neill (she was his widow) and then to Esmond Cecil Harmsworth, 2nd Viscount Rothermere, whom she divorced to marry Ian. Anne and Ian had one son, Casper Robert Fleming, born 12th of August 1952. I wanted the simplest, dullest, plainest-sounding name I could find, James Bond was much better than something more interesting like 'Peregrine Maltravers.' Exotic things would happen to and around him but he would be a neutral figure - an anonymous blunt instrument wielded by a Government Department. (1965) Novel (published posthumously): 'The Man With The Golden Gun' (filmed as _The Man with the Golden Gun (1974)_ (qv)) _'Explorations' (1956) {Ian Fleming: The Brain Behind Bond}_ (qv) 28 May 1908 'John Pearson (III)' (qv). _The Life of Ian Fleming._ London, England: Jonathon Cape Ltd., 1966. Born into a wealthy and influential English family, Ian Fleming spent his early years attending top British schools such as Eton and Sandhurst military academy. He took to writing while schooling in Kitzbuhel, Austria, and upon failing the entrance requirements for Foreign Service joined the news agency Reuters as a journalist -- winning the respect of his peers for his coverage of a 'show trial' in Russia of several Royal Engineers on espionage charges. Fleming briefly worked in the financial sector for the family bank, but just prior to the Second World War, was recruited into British Naval Intelligence where he excelled, shortly achieving the rank of Commander. When the war ended, Fleming retired to Jamaica where he built a house called 'Goldeneye,' took up writing full-time and created the character that would make him famous -- British Secret Service agent James Bond, in a novel called 'Casino Royale.' Fleming spent the rest of his life writing and traveling the world, but as his Bond character reached new heights of popularity on movie screens, Fleming was in ailing health. He died of a heart attack (his second) in England in August 1964 at the age of 56. Ian Fleming 'The New York Times' (USA), 19 May 2008, Vol. 157, Iss. 54,315, pg. E1 & E6, by: John F. Burns, 'Remembering Fleming, Ian Fleming' 12 August 1964 _Goldeneye (1989) (TV)_ (qv) Cigarette (in holder) perched between fingers of his right hand 'The Times Magazine' (UK), 5 April 2008 Ian Lancaster Fleming 6' Mayfair, London, England, UK Male

Series Producer Language language cinematographer   James Carman aka name James Carman Saintjc
Series Producer Language language cinematographer Roy H. Wagner    Buddy Born in a very small community in the mid west Roy had no other contact to his dream of becoming a cinematographer than through the local theater and the Los Angeles phone directory. He would recall the names of cinematographers as they appeared on their films and call them blindly to talk with them about their work. Many of them were so suprised by this young man's ambition and interest that they took him under their wing, mentoring him. When he arrived in Los Angeles he spent every moment with them on their sets and homes learning as much about them and their work as he could. Because of this he was able to meet and befriend many of the greatest cinematographers in Hollywood. His key mentor was Harry Stradling Sr. Through him he developed friendships with Joseph Ruttenberg, George Folsey, James Wong Howe, Leon Shamroy, Frank Phillipd, Leonard South, and many many others. In the late 70s he began a life long process of interviewing cinematographers on video tape or film. A deep reverence for all that is old Hollywood remains a great part of his life and the memory of the behind the scene stories told him as a young man is an important basis for his life and work. Roy H. Wagner 'International Photographer' (USA), January 1996, pg. 22-27, 'It's A Party' Esteemed and longtime member of the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC). Roy Henry Wagner III Male III, Roy Henry Wagner

Episode Actress Writer editor producer Billy Weber Don Simpson   Billy Weber William Weber Los Angeles, California, USA Male Played the Priest in 'The Shopping Cart Bandit' (2003) short Los Angeles, California, USA Had a talent for deciphering key on-screen moments in a script. Moments in a wide-release picture known as 'The Hollywood Moment'. We have no obligation to make history. We have no obligation to make art. We have no obligation to make a statement. Our obligation is to make money. Simpson, Donald Clarence 29 October 1943 'High Concept: Don Simpson and The Hollywood Culture Of Excess' by Charles Fleming (Doubleday, 1998) Don Simpson, one of the most highly regarded creative forces in the entertainment industry and one of the most successful producers of all time, was a filmmaker who loved movies. In the 1980s, he was responsible for some of entertainment's most popular and enduring motion pictures. In the 1990s, this exceptional and unique producer continued that tradition, bringing audiences worldwide films that thrill, excite and delight. His tremendous contributions to the entertainment industry are dearly missed and there will always be an empty seat at the theatre.  A look back at the films that begin with the dual lightning bolt. With worldwide revenues of over $10 billion in box office, video and recording receipts, Simpson earned not only the acclaim and respect of the entertainment industry but the devotion of moviegoers worldwide.  Simpson was a native of Anchorage, Alaska, and spent several years as a senior executive at Paramount Pictures before becoming President of Worldwide Production at Paramount. As president, Simpson was instrumental in the making of such films as _American Gigolo (1980)_ (qv), _Urban Cowboy (1980)_ (qv), _Little Darlings (1980)_ (qv), _An Officer and a Gentleman (1982)_ (qv) and _48 Hrs. (1982)_ (qv). The years at Paramount fueled Simpson's creativity, provided him with invaluable experience and inspired him to take on his own projects. The first was the 1983 smash hit _Flashdance (1983)_ (qv), which grossed $100 million in the U.S. alone and made an instant star of 'Jennifer Beals' (qv). It also paired Simpson with an old acquaintance, 'Jerry Bruckheimer' (qv), who would be his partner for the next 14 years.  One of the most prolific partnerships in motion picture history, Simpson and Bruckheimer produced films that were honored with 15 Academy Award nominations, two Oscars for Best Song, four Grammys, three Golden Globes, two People's Choice Awards for Best Picture, and the MTV award for Best Picture of the Decade. Equally important to Simpson, creatively, was the fact that the films were turning the stars into box office giants. _Beverly Hills Cop (1984)_ (qv) launched 'Eddie Murphy (I)' (qv)'s career and _Top Gun (1986)_ (qv) made 'Tom Cruise' (qv) an international superstar.  Industry acclaim followed the box office success. In both 1985 and 1988, the National Association of Theatre Owners (NATO) named Simpson Producer of the Year. And in 1988, along with his partner, Simpson was chosen as the Motion Picture Showman of the Year by the Publicists Guild of America.  Simpson and Bruckheimer were one of the most distinguished producing teams in motion picture history. Throughout the Eighties, they connected with such smash hits as _Flashdance (1983)_ (qv) with 'Jennifer Beals' (qv), _Beverly Hills Cop (1984)_ (qv) starring 'Eddie Murphy (I)' (qv), _Top Gun (1986)_ (qv) with 'Tom Cruise' (qv), _Beverly Hills Cop II (1987)_ (qv) with 'Eddie Murphy (I)' (qv) and _Days of Thunder (1990)_ (qv) with 'Tom Cruise' (qv) as 'Cole Trickle'.  By 1995, the team was producing one hit after another. In that year alone, Simpson was responsible for _Bad Boys (1995)_ (qv), the 'Will Smith (I)' (qv)/'Martin Lawrence (I)' (qv) film that was Columbia Pictures' highest grossing movie of the year; 'Michelle Pfeiffer' (qv)'s acclaimed _Dangerous Minds (1995)_ (qv); and _Crimson Tide (1995)_ (qv), the 'Denzel Washington' (qv)/'Gene Hackman' (qv) adventure thriller.  In 1996, Simpson produced _The Rock (1996)_ (qv) starring 'Sean Connery' (qv) and 'Nicolas Cage' (qv). The film brought in nearly $350 million worldwide at the box office, and set the video rental market record as the most-ordered film in history. _The Rock (1996)_ (qv), named Favorite Movie of the Year by the National Association of Theater Owners (NATO), was Simpson's last movie. Don Simpson died in 1996. Don Simpson 'Cinema' (Hungary), March 1999, Iss. 88, pg. 94-95, by: Heiko Rosner, 'A f?rfi, akit Caligul?nak h?vtak' 19 January 1996 Donald C. Simpson Seattle, Washington, USA Male

Edited every one of 'Quentin Tarantino' (qv)'s films until her death in 2010 Sally Jo Menke Mineola, New York, USA Female Menke, Sally JoAnne 17 October 1957 Lawrence Bender 'Playboy' (USA), January 1998, Vol. 45, Iss. 1, pg. 20, by: Bruce Wiliamson, 'Off Camera: Lawrence Bender' In addition to his feature film and television work, Bender has enjoyed success in producing commercials and music videos with his production company, A Band Apart. The company has produced commercial spots for such directors as 'Tim Burton (I)' (qv), 'John Woo (I)' (qv) and 'McG' (qv). A Band Apart Music Videos represents top directors, including 'Nigel Dick' (qv), 'McG' (qv), and 'Wayne Isham' (qv). In 2001, the company shot 75 commercials and music videos and garnered 13 MTV Music Video Award nominations. Episode Actress Writer editor producer Chris Lebenzon Don Simpson   29 October 1953 Chris Lebenzon Christopher Lebenzon Redwood City, California, USA Male Lebenzon, Christopher John Los Angeles, California, USA Had a talent for deciphering key on-screen moments in a script. Moments in a wide-release picture known as 'The Hollywood Moment'. We have no obligation to make history. We have no obligation to make art. We have no obligation to make a statement. Our obligation is to make money. Simpson, Donald Clarence 29 October 1943 'High Concept: Don Simpson and The Hollywood Culture Of Excess' by Charles Fleming (Doubleday, 1998) Don Simpson, one of the most highly regarded creative forces in the entertainment industry and one of the most successful producers of all time, was a filmmaker who loved movies. In the 1980s, he was responsible for some of entertainment's most popular and enduring motion pictures. In the 1990s, this exceptional and unique producer continued that tradition, bringing audiences worldwide films that thrill, excite and delight. His tremendous contributions to the entertainment industry are dearly missed and there will always be an empty seat at the theatre.  A look back at the films that begin with the dual lightning bolt. With worldwide revenues of over $10 billion in box office, video and recording receipts, Simpson earned not only the acclaim and respect of the entertainment industry but the devotion of moviegoers worldwide.  Simpson was a native of Anchorage, Alaska, and spent several years as a senior executive at Paramount Pictures before becoming President of Worldwide Production at Paramount. As president, Simpson was instrumental in the making of such films as _American Gigolo (1980)_ (qv), _Urban Cowboy (1980)_ (qv), _Little Darlings (1980)_ (qv), _An Officer and a Gentleman (1982)_ (qv) and _48 Hrs. (1982)_ (qv). The years at Paramount fueled Simpson's creativity, provided him with invaluable experience and inspired him to take on his own projects. The first was the 1983 smash hit _Flashdance (1983)_ (qv), which grossed $100 million in the U.S. alone and made an instant star of 'Jennifer Beals' (qv). It also paired Simpson with an old acquaintance, 'Jerry Bruckheimer' (qv), who would be his partner for the next 14 years.  One of the most prolific partnerships in motion picture history, Simpson and Bruckheimer produced films that were honored with 15 Academy Award nominations, two Oscars for Best Song, four Grammys, three Golden Globes, two People's Choice Awards for Best Picture, and the MTV award for Best Picture of the Decade. And in 1988, along with his partner, Simpson was chosen as the Motion Picture Showman of the Year by the Publicists Guild of America. Crew Member Series Genre crew member genre  Navid Khonsari   Raised in Iran and Canada, Khonsari was first introduced to filmmaking through his grandfather's super 8mm films. He developed an appreciation for storytelling from his grandmother, who would recite stories (both fictional and historical) from memory. Khonsari fell in love with video games after playing Pitfall on Atari.  He graduated from the University of British Columbia, and also studied at the Vancouver Film School. His first short film was entitled 'Arcade Angels', which focused on video game burnouts who robbed a video rental store and then opened an arcade. He wrote and produced The Contract, his first film with Billy Dee Williams. Khonsari broke out on to the gaming scene with Grand Theft Auto III and Max Payne.  He met his wife Vassiliki, while working on Pindemonium. They own and operate iNK Stories, a studio based out of New York and Toronto. Navid Khonsari Male

Production Designer Producer TV Movie production designer costume designer Richard Bruno  Boris Leven birth notes death date aka name mini biography birth date death notes 21 August 1924 Richard Bruno 11 January 2012 Port Townsend, Washington, USA (kidney failure) Member of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences [Designers Branch]. Richard S. Bruno 13 August 1908 Boris Leven was born in Moscow, where he first studied painting and design. He emigrated to the U.S. in 1927 and attended the University of Southern California, graduating with a Bachelor of Architecture in 1932. He went on to complete his education at the Beaux Arts Institute of Design in New York and, the following year, was signed by Paramount to work as a sketch artist and illustrator under the tutelage of the experienced art director 'Hans Dreier' (qv). After a three-year apprenticeship, Leven went on to work for independent producer 'Samuel Goldwyn' (qv). His big break came in 1937, when he was signed under contract at 20th Century Fox as fully-qualified art director and production designer. For his first major assignment, _Alexander's Ragtime Band (1938)_ (qv), he utilised more than 85 period sets. Proficient not only with historical detail, but also instinctive about the mood or thematic requirement of a picture, he brought imagination to the look of _The Shanghai Gesture (1941)_ (qv), _Tales of Manhattan (1942)_ (qv) and varied other assignments.  Leven remained at Fox until 1947, then joined Universal (1947-48), free-lanced, had another spell with Fox (1951-52), then worked for United Artists (1953) and Warner Brothers (1954-55). In-between, he worked privately on oil and watercolour paintings, some of which found their way into private collections, or were exhibited at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Leven became best known in the 1950's for his work on the production design of _Giant (1956)_ (qv), for which he set the scene with the indelible image of an opulent Victorian mansion, contrasting like a monolith against the broad expanse of harsh Texan prairie - providing allegorical imagery of copious human materialism vis-?-vis raw nature. In 1962, Leven won an Academy Award for Best Art Direction and Set Decoration for _West Side Story (1961)_ (qv), a mixture of deliberately stylised theatrically-based sets and realistic New York locations. His other notable films during this period were _The Sound of Music (1965)_ (qv) and _The Sand Pebbles (1966)_ (qv), his work being greatly facilitated by picturesque on-location shooting, respectively, in the Austrian Alps and Salzburg, and in Taiwan and Hong Kong. Boris Leven was inducted into the Art Director's Hall of Fame in 2004. Boris Leven 11 October 1986 Los Angeles, California, USA Boris Levin Moscow, Russian Empire [now Russia]
Production Designer Producer TV Movie production designer costume designer Michael Krantz Sophie Carbonell   17 June 1968 Michael Krantz 'FilmMaker' (USA), 1994, Vol. 2, Iss. 4, pg. 19-20, by: Jaq Greenspan, 'Drawn To Life' M.Z. Horvitz Six times (in 1998, 2000, 2004, 2006 and 2008), he won an Emmy for directing Oscar telecasts while he was working. He was working because each time, he was directing the very Emmy Award telecast that honored him with the statuettes. He accepted all his awards on camera from the control booth, thanking people in between shouting commands to the production crew. Lou Horvitz Male
TV Movie Editor Person actor director Jake West  Josep Castillo Escalona birth notes gender death date aka name birth date death notes 1972 Jake West UK Male 14 February 1921 Josep Castillo Escalona 30 April 2011 Sentmenat, Barcelona, Spain Jose Castillo Escalona Barcelona, Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain Male
TV Movie Editor Person actor director  Peter Jones Jack Bailey birth notes gender death date name trivia birth date death notes magazine cover photo pictorial Emmy award-winning filmmaker Peter Jones began his career as a broadcast journalist. A graduate of Stanford University (BA in American Studies, 1978) with a Master's Degree in Journalism from Northwestern University (1981), Jones served as Washington correspondent for KOTV (CBS) in Tulsa, Oklahoma; a news and feature reporter for KVUE (ABC) in Austin, Texas; an anchor for WSLS (NBC) in Roanoke, Virginia; and an assignment editor for KCBS-TV in Los Angeles. Jones won numerous honors, including several Outstanding Achievement Awards from United Press International and The Associated Press.  In 1987, he formed Peter Jones Productions, originally specializing in documentaries related to the history of the Hollywood film industry. Since then, his Los Angeles-based company has produced more than 120 hours of programming on a variety of subjects.  For several years, he produced, wrote and hosted the short-form series, Only In Hollywood, which aired on Showtime, The Movie Channel, The Disney Channel, TNT, AMC and Encore. In 1992, the segments premiered in broadcast syndication as a half-hour magazine-style series. From 1990-96, he produced, directed, wrote and hosted the short-form series, AMC in Hollywood with Peter Jones.  In 1994, Peter Jones Productions became a contracted producer for the A&E series, Biography. During a 10-year association in which his company produced 85 profiles, Jones became well known for securing previously unattainable rights without relinquishing editorial control, including those for such subjects as Sam Phillips, Brian Wilson, Charlie Chaplin, Theodor Geisel (aka Dr. Seuss), Georgia O'Keeffe and Alfred Stieglitz. Jones wrote and directed a 2-hour special on Judy Garland that won a 1997 Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Informational Series, the first for the network. His 2-hour special, Ozzie and Harriet: Adventures of America's Favorite Family, became the highest-rated documentary in the network's history, earning a 1999 Primetime Emmy Award nomination for Outstanding Non-Fiction Series. In 2001, his film, Goldwyn, premiered on the critically acclaimed PBS series, American Masters. In 2002 he received the Producer of the Year Award from the Producers Guild of America for Biography.  In 2003, Jones conceived, produced and directed Sunset Junction, a feature-length verite documentary about a Beverly Hills hairdresser who becomes an unlikely father figure to gang members and the neglected children of illegal immigrants. The film had its world premiere at The Los Angeles International Film Festival (AFI FEST) in November 2003.  In 2006, Stardust: The Bette Davis Story has its U.S. premiere on Turner Classic Movies, garnering Jones and his team the best reviews in the company's history, an Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing for Nonfiction Programming, and an Emmy nomination for Outstanding Nonfiction Special.  His latest project, Inventing LA: The Chandlers and Their Times, a documentary on the single-family reign of four publishers of the Los Angeles Times newspaper, premiered as a national prime time special on PBS in October 2009, a first for a documentary on Los Angeles. The film won the prestigious Peabody Award. Peter Jones Graduated from Stanford University with degree in American History, Literature and Politics and later earned a Master's Degree in Broadcast Journalism from Northwestern University. Male Executive Producer-90-min documentary 'Hitmakers: The Teens Who Stole Pop Music' (2001), premiered May 3, 2001 at Museum of TV and Radio documentary festival in NYC. 15 September 1907 Jack Bailey 1 February 1980 Santa Monica, California, USA (pneumonia) He was awarded 2 Stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for Radio at 1708 Vine Street and for Television at 6411 Hollywood Boulevard in Hollywood, California. TV Movie Editor Person actor director  Steve Zahn Alicia Ulrich name 'Premiere' (USA), February 1997, Vol. 10, Iss. 6, pg. 35, by: Oliver Jones 'Robyn Peterman' (qv) (16 July 1994 - present); 2 children Graduated from Cooper High School, New Hope, Minnesota. [2007 quote] I've had more people come up to me about _Saving Silverman (2001)_ (qv) than anything else. That and _That Thing You Do! (1996)_ (qv) but 'Saving Silverman' is the one I get most often. And I love that. It's just funny that it didn't do that well in theaters. It did all right, but none of us were big stars at the time. 'Jason Biggs (I)' (qv) was probably bigger than any of us. That's another one that kind of baffles me. So many people have seen it. I got this big Western coming out. I have another crazy comedy that I really like, _Strange Wilderness (2008)_ (qv). It's just fucking dumb, and I can't wait to see how people react, because I just know that I'll have people approach me and say 'Strange Wilderness, man. That's my favorite movie'. I'll love that. Next trained at American Repertory Theatre in Cambridge, MA; then moved to New York City where he won a role touring for 13 months in national company of 'Tommy Tune' (qv)-directed version of 'Bye Bye Birdie'. Composer Work Person producer Jimmy Holcomb Thom Oliphant   Jimmy Holcomb James Terry Holcomb Jr. Thom has spent a decade as a producer, executive producer, and show runner for major network and cable series. He began his career as a music video director. He has worked with who's who list of music superstars from BB King to Faith Hill, Bruce Springsteen to Shania Twain and the Dixie Chicks to Metallica. As a director, he has won awards for excellence, like the Country Music Association Video of the Year, a Clio, a Canadian Country Music Association Award, multiple Addys, and several Billboard Awards. After over 200 music videos and 100 commercial campaigns, he segued into TV. He has worked on big formats and music competition series (CMT's Can You Duet and Fox's Next Great American Band) and lately he has turned his focus has been on telling stories (CMT's Posse). Thom Oliphant

Work Editor Person actor producer Hal Holbrook Jimmy Holcomb   'TV Guide' (USA), 21 April 2008, Vol. 56, Iss. 16, pg. 46, by: Ileane Rudolph, 'Q&A Hal Holbrook' 'Dixie Carter (I)' (qv) (27 May 1984 - 10 April 2010) (her death) Portrayed 'Abraham Lincoln (I)' (qv) in _'Toast of the Town' (1948)_ (qv), _'Lincoln' (1974)_ (qv), _'North and South' (1985)_ (qv) and _'North and South, Book II' (1986)_ (qv). 'Playboy' (USA), November 1980, Vol. 27, Iss. 11, pg. 181, by: Arthur Knight, 'Sex In Cinema 1980' Most everybody today that's young is operating under the insane idea that what we've got going on is the best that there is. But it's not. Current entertainment is cheap, shoddy, infantile, adolescent, not grown-up. We're fed imagery that's really pornographic, by people with an infantile idea of sexuality. It's a sad and depressing thing. TV Pilot 1976 called The Oath: 33 Hours in the Life of God. This was not picked up by the networks and starred Hal Holbrook as Dr. Simon Abbott, Carol Rossen as his wife Alison, Hume Cronyn as Dr. Jaffe, Louise Latham as Nurse Levitt, John Devil as Dr. Watt, Edgar Daniels as Mark Davers, and Michael O'Keefe as Freddie. The premise was the story of a surgeon, his personal life, his health problems and his belief in perfection. Holbrook Jr., Harold Rowe 17 February 1925 (2006) Host of an infomercial for 'Fisher Investments'. Hal Holbrook is an Emmy- and Tony-Award winning actor who is one of the great craftsman of stage and screen. He is best known for his performance as 'Mark Twain' (qv), for which he won a Tony and the first of his ten Emmy Award nominations. Aside from the stage, Holbrook made his reputation primarily on television, and was memorable as 'Abraham Lincoln (I)' (qv), as Senator Hays Stowe on _'The Bold Ones: The Senator' (1970)_ (qv) and as Capt. 'Lloyd Bucher' (qv) on _Pueblo (1973) (TV)_ (qv). All of these roles brought him Emmy Awards, with _Pueblo (1973) (TV)_ (qv) bringing him two, as Best Lead Actor in a Drama and Actor of the Year - Special. On January 22, 2008, he became the oldest male performer ever nominated for a an Academy Award, for his supporting turn in _Into the Wild (2007)_ (qv)  He was born Harold Rowe Holbrook, Jr. on February 17, 1925 in Cleveland, Ohio. His mother was the former Eileen Davenport, a vaudeville dancer. Raised primarily in South Weymouth, Mass., Holbrook attended the Culver Academies. During World War II, Holbrook served in the Army in Newfoundland. After the war, he attended Denison University, graduating in 1948. While at Denison, Holbrook's senior honors project concerned Mark Twain. He'd later develop 'Mark Twain Tonight', the one-man show in which he impersonates the great American writer 'Mark Twain' (qv), a.k.a. Samuel Clemens.  Holbrook learned his craft on the boards and by appearing in the TV soap opera _'The Brighter Day' (1954)_ (qv). He first played 'Mark Twain' (qv) as a solo act in 1954, at Lock Haven State Teachers College in Pennsylvania. The show was a success that created a buzz. After seeing the performance, 'Ed Sullivan (I)' (qv), the host of TV's premier variety show, featured him on _'Toast of the Town' (1948)_ (qv) on February 12, 1956. This lead to an international tour sponsored by the U.S. Department of State, which included appearances in Iron Curtain countries. Holbrook brought the show to Off-Broadway in 1959. He even played 'Mark Twain' (qv) for President 'Dwight D. Eisenhower' (qv).  The 1966 'Mark Twain Tonight' Broadway production brought Holbrook even more acclaim, and the Tony Award. The show was taped and Holbrook won an Emmy nomination. He reprised the show on Broadway in 1977 and in 2005. By that time, he had played Samuel Clemens on stage over 2,000 times.  Among Holbrook's more famous roles was 'The Major' in the original Broadway production of 'Arthur Miller (I)' (qv)'s 'Incident at Vichy', as 'Martin Sheen' (qv)'s significant other in the controversial and acclaimed TV movie _That Certain Summer (1972) (TV)_ (qv), the first TV movie to sympathetically portray homosexuality, and as 'Abraham Lincoln (I)' (qv) in a TV special based on 'Carl Sandburg' (qv)'s acclaimed biography of the 16th President. He also is known for his portrayal of the enigmatic 'Deep Throat' in _All the President's Men (1976)_ (qv), one of the major cinema events of the mid-'70s. In the 1990s, he had a regular supporting role in the TV series _'Evening Shade' (1990)_ (qv), playing 'Burt Reynolds''s father-in-law. Hal Holbrook Harold Rowe Holbrook Jr. 6' 1' Cleveland, Ohio, USA Male Jimmy Holcomb James Terry Holcomb Jr.

Work Editor Person actor producer Billy Gilman Jimmy Holcomb   24 May 1988 Billy Gilman 'Teen People' (USA), May 2001, pg. 100, by: Jeremy Helligar, '25 Hottest Stars Under 25' He has a dog and a cat. 'Country' (USA), 23 January 2001 William Wendell Gilman III 5' 7' I think 'Everything and More' is a more mature version of 'One Voice.' The music is fun and includes all aspects of the country genre (including bluegrass, pop, country rock, and traditional ballads) and every song is about a new aspect in my life. One song is about the trying times that I went through with my voice change and my fear that I may never sing again. Another song, 'I'm Not Me Anymore,' is about how I've grown and changed - it's my favorite. This time, I had a say in what I wanted to record and I'm so proud of this project because it's a reflection of who I am today as a young adult. I think the lyrics of each and every song create a picture - just as if you were at the movies. I really hope everyone enjoys my personal 'photo' album! Hope Valley, Rhode Island, USA Male Album - 2001 - Dare To Dream III, William Wendell Gilman Jimmy Holcomb James Terry Holcomb Jr.
Work Editor Person actor producer Jimmy Holcomb Benton Jennings   Jimmy Holcomb James Terry Holcomb Jr. 'Liz' (1986 - present) Began acting at age seven, portraying his boyhood hero 'Robin Hood' in a school play. Thirty years later, he got to reprise the character in a professional theatrical production, plus choreographing the fight sequences.  A third generation Texan, he fulfilled another boyhood dream -- that of performing in an Alamo movie...and not just one, but two Alamo movies.  He earned a BFA in theatre arts from TCU (Texas Christian University) with additional studies in cinematography. Studies also include London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art, The Film Actors Lab in Dallas, 'DeVera Marcus' (qv)' Improv Class in L.A., & numerous L.A. voice-over coaches.  Benton has performed in over 100 stage productions and national tours including 25 years with 2 partners in an award winning sketch comedy act -- 'The Gunfighters' -- with over 6000 performances nationally, quite literally everywhere from being introduced onstage by 'Tony Randall (I)' (qv) at Madison Square Garden to performing alongside 'Clayton Moore (I)' (qv) of _'The Lone Ranger' (1949)_ (qv) fame at a festival in Texas.  With a natural and nurtured knack for embodying the roles he plays, Benton has portrayed a vast swath of characters ranging from psycho killers, FBI agents, good ol' boy farmers, upscale butlers and maitre'ds, cranky patients, caring physicians, Shakespearean kings, high school janitors, news anchors, senators, paraplegic British officers and even Hitler. (He has the dubious distinction of having played Hitler five times. First on NBC'S _'Passions' (1999)_ (qv), 'David Zucker (I)' (qv)'s feature film _An American Carol (2008)_ (qv), again in the indie feature _Poolboy: Drowning Out the Fury (2011)_ (qv), on _'Jimmy Kimmel Live!' (2003)_ (qv) in the 'Captain Mexico' parody sketch, ep 9.163 26 July 2011), and February 2012 in a professional photo essay which depicts a time traveling assassin shooting Hitler.  Benton also has worked as an historical consultant, historical military technical advisor and fight director. Benton Jennings 'The Los Angeles Times' (USA), 6 October 2008, by: Gary Goldstein, 'Review: 'An American Carol'' Son of 'William Bryan Jennings' (qv), who appeared in _Manos: The Hands of Fate (1966)_ (qv). Male TowDown music video: 'Dirty South', concept as homage to 'Dukes of Hazard', role of the Sheriff. Directed by Jeff Byrd.

Series Producer Costume Designer actor actress Sonya Eddy Greg Vaughan   17 June 1967 Sonya Eddy, a native of Concord, California, graduated from UC Davis. During her intense studies she began her acting career in the West Coast premiere of 'Zora, Is My Name!' (written by the award-winning actress Ruby Dee). Sonya performed several roles in 'Zora' including Big Sweet - a bawdy blues singer (Ruby Dee's personal favorite). Sonya continued forth to perform the role of the Courtesan in 'Comedy of Errors' as well as performances in productions of 'The Crucible', 'Pericles', and the Witch in 'Into The Woods'. Ms. Eddy won an Arty Award for her powerful portrayal of Bloody Mary in 'South Pacific'.  Sonya's professional acting career in Los Angeles has spanned over a dozen years. Her roles include recurrings on 'ER', 'Joan of Arcadia', 'Seinfeld', 'The Drew Carey Show' and others. Having appeared in the Hallmark Movie of the Week 'The Reading Room' opposite James Earl Jones, Ms. Eddy was also a series regular on Martin Short's 'Primetime Glick' and has also appeared professionally in 'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof' with John Goodman and Brenda Fricker at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles. Most recently, Ms. Eddy can be seen in her recurring role on 'General Hospital' as Epiphany Johnson - a no-nonsense head nurse. She will also bring Epiphany to SOAPnet's first serialized drama for primetime 'General Hospital: Night Shift', which premieres in July, 2007. Ms. Eddy can also be seen as a guest star on 'CSI: Crime Scene Investigation'.  Sonya's many guest appearances in other primetime shows include 'In Case of Emergency', 'Everybody Hates Chris', 'Daybreak', 'Malcolm In the Middle','Reba',and many others. Her guest star performances include 'Strong Medicine', 'Still Standing', and 'The Hughleys'.  In addition to her career successes, Ms. Eddy has recently become the only actor to have been cast twice on 'ER'. Her work can also be seen in over a dozen National commercials yearly.  Not to be omitted, her versatility as an all around performer can be seen in her most recent feature film roles in 'Coach Carter' starring Samuel L. Jackson, 'Bad News Bears' with Billy Bob Thornton, 'Barbershop', 'Daddy Daycare', 'Matchstick Men', and 'Surviving Christmas'. Recently, Sonya completed filming 'Year of the Dog' with Molly Shannon and Peter Sarsgaard.  Among Sonya's many special skills and talents she is also an accomplished Improv\Sketch artist, vocalist (2nd Soprano to 1st Tenor) and voice-over artist. Sonya Eddy Her home town is Concord, California. Sonya Jean Eddy 5' 4' Concord, California, USA Female Eddy, Sonya Jean 15 June 1973 'Touriya Haoud' (qv) (4 June 2006 - present); 3 children James Gregory Vaughan, Jr., was born in Dallas, Texas, on June 15, 1973, and was raised in both the big city of Dallas and the small German town of Fredericksburg, Texas, from his preschool years through his early teens, graduating from Mesquite High in 1991. Vaughan was involved in sports, student government, and a few school talent productions. At 16, before graduating high school, he was discovered in a community back-to-school fashion show, and was immediately signed up by a local modeling agent.  With the opportunity to travel the world, he bypassed college and ventured to Milan, Italy, just months after high school graduation. Upon his arrival, he landed prestigious campaigns for the legendary designers 'Giorgio Armani' (qv) and 'Gianni Versace' (qv), further ensuring his newfound success by adding Banana Republic, 'Tommy Hilfiger' (qv), and 'Ralph Lauren' all before the age of 21.  Relocating from city to city, a life requiring only a suitcase, came to an end through his mother's influence. She encouraged him to follow his true passion: acting. Vaughan's acting career began with abundant commercial work, preparing him for what he now claims has become his life's work over the past 10 years.  In 1996, Vaughan made his television series debut as Josh Walker in the popular 'Aaron Spelling' (qv) series _'Malibu Shores' (1996)_ (qv), which soon spun off into _'Beverly Hills, 90210' (1990)_ (qv), where Vaughan played Cliff Yeager (1996-1997). Trying his hand at a few small independent films, he was cast in the popular cult films _Poison Ivy_ and _The Last Seduction (1994)_ (qv), followed by _No Small Ways (1997)_ (qv), which led him back home to Austin, Texas. Upon returning to Los Angeles, he began filming _Children of the Corn V: Fields of Terror (1998) (V)_ (qv).  Vaughan spent his time between projects in a number of guest-starring television appearances in series that included _'Buffy the Vampire Slayer' (1997)_ (qv), _'Any Day Now' (1998)_ (qv), _'Sabrina, the Teenage Witch' (1996)_ (qv) and _'Nash Bridges' (1996)_ (qv) before shooting a controversial 'dramody' pilot, _Student Affairs (1999) (TV)_ (qv), for Imagine Television.  Spelling Entertainment soon created a role for Vaughan as a series regular, boy-next-door Dan Gordon, on _'Charmed' (1998)_ (qv) (1999-2000). After the series ended, Vaughan quickly landed the role of Milo Mosley in _'Glory Days' (2002)_ (qv), the highly anticipated 'Kevin Williamson (I)' (qv) series. After its short television run, Vaughan began his foray into daytime drama as Diego on CBS's #1 _'The Young and the Restless' (1973)_ (qv). With rave reviews and notoriety, a Daytime Best Newcomer nomination followed, with People Magazine naming Greg Vaughan as 'One of the Sexiest Men Alive' in 2002. Finding little spare time, he still managed to appear in guest roles on both _'Will & Grace' (1998)_ (qv) and _'Still Standing' (2002)_ (qv) before jumping from one daytime drama to another. Vaughan's opportunity to grab the highly acclaimed role of Lucky Spencer on _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) seems to have simply happened before anyone knew it. Greg Vaughan Briefly dated co-star 'Alyssa Milano' (qv). Gregg Vaughan 6' 0' Dallas, Texas, USA Male TV commercial for Preferred Stock cologne (1999) Jr., James Gregory Vaughan
Series Producer Costume Designer actor actress Rick Springfield Sonya Eddy   'Washington Post' (USA), 2 May 1982, pg. MP4, by: Betty Debnam, 'Meet Singer-Actor Rick Springfield' 'Barbara Porter' (27 October 1984 - present); 2 children He was in the early group version of wickety wak.wickety wak - later Australia's premier showband in the 1980s and 90s. I've always been something of a whore with my acting, but never my music. 2000: TV commercial for AT&T phones. Springthorpe, Richard Lewis 23 August 1949 Rick (June 2003) Starred in the Las Vegas extravaganza, 'EFX-Alive' at the MGM Grand from January 2001 until the show closed on December 31, 2002. He is now working on a new album, titled 'Shock/Denial/Anger/Acceptance' and has been touring the United States. Rick Springfield. _Late, Late at Night: A Memoir._ New York: Touchstone, 2010. ISBN 439191158 'Rick Springfield' (qv) was born the son of a Lt. Colonel in the British Army and spent his childhood on various army bases in Australia and Britain. As a teenager, he fronted many music bands-such as the 'Jordy Boys', 'Wakedy Wak' and 'Zoot'. The latter was his most successful paving his way for his future success as a musician. However, that success was still a long time coming. While he waited for that big break he signed a contract with Universal television which cast him in bit parts in shows such as the _'The Six Million Dollar Man' (1974)_ (qv) and _'The Rockford Files' (1974)_ (qv). As well, he also had a recurring role on the soap _'The Young and the Restless' (1973)_ (qv). In the early 1980's, his luck changed as he signed to RCA Records and was then cast as 'Dr. Noah Drake' on the soap _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv). While he had released six albums in the 1970s, his 1980 break-through album 'Working Class Dog' gave him the #1 single 'Jessie's Girl'. From the music and TV exposure, he became a teen idol. He ruled the airwaves for a couple of years, ended his stint on _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) and attempted a a motion picture career, which fizzled. Rick Springfield 'Hartford Courant' (USA), 4 April 1982, pg. Series Producer Costume Designer actor actress  Kimberly McCullough Josh Wingate gender name mini biography article 5 March 1978 Kimber Kimberly McCullough 'Woman's World' (USA), 7 February 2006, Vol. 27, Iss. 6, pg. 16-17, by: Jillian Boyle, 'Lose 8 lbs in 14 days!' 'Woman's World' (USA), 7 February 2006, Vol. 27, Iss. 6 Kimberly Anne McCullough 5' 2' (When asked who on her cast she'd take with her car shopping) I'd take Maurice Benard (Sonny), because he seems to scare people even though he's the sweetest man ever. He's kind of like a big brother to me. He could come in and act like a mobster and scare them into giving me a good buy. Bellflower, California, USA Female Played Cosette in the Broadway version of Les Miserables as a young child Born in Colorado, Wingate was raised in Massachusetts. At the age of 15, he stepped on a stage for the first time and knew he was home. Wingate worked steadily in local and regional theater productions and starred in _'Bay State' (1991)_ (qv), the longest-running college soap opera, before relocating to Los Angeles.  In a few short years, Wingate has steadily earned a notable resume, including memorable guest-starring roles on primetime series including, the Peabody Award-winning FX series _'Justified' (2010)_ (qv), ABC's _'Castle' (2009)_ (qv), CBS' _'CSI: NY' (2004)_ (qv), and Showtime's _'Dexter' (2006)_ (qv).  Wingate's impressive recurring role as Carter, an inmate who sexually assaults a fellow prisoner (played by 'Chad Duell' (qv)) on ABC's _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv), garnered him a 2011 Soap Opera Spirit Award nomination. The groundbreaking storyline marked the first time daytime television had ever addressed the taboo issue of male survivors of sexual violence.  On the big screen, Wingate has appeared opposite 'Paul Bettany' (qv) in 'Scott Charles Stewart (I)' (qv)'s _Priest (2011)_ (qv). Wingate just wrapped 'Marc Forster' (qv)'s _World War Z (2013)_ (qv) (starring 'Brad Pitt' (qv)) as well as the indie feature Inverse, his first lead role in a feature film.  A skilled martial arts expert, Wingate continues to train regularly. He is privileged to lend his time and talent to causes ranging from youth mentoring to health and wellness. Josh Wingate 'ABC Soaps In Depth' (USA), 26 July 2010, Vol. 14, Iss. 30, pg. 98-99, by: Rosemary Rossi, 'That Touch of Evil' Male

Series Producer Costume Designer actor actress Sonya Eddy Dan Olivo   17 June 1967 Sonya Eddy, a native of Concord, California, graduated from UC Davis. During her intense studies she began her acting career in the West Coast premiere of 'Zora, Is My Name!' (written by the award-winning actress Ruby Dee). Sonya performed several roles in 'Zora' including Big Sweet - a bawdy blues singer (Ruby Dee's personal favorite). Sonya continued forth to perform the role of the Courtesan in 'Comedy of Errors' as well as performances in productions of 'The Crucible', 'Pericles', and the Witch in 'Into The Woods'. Ms. Eddy won an Arty Award for her powerful portrayal of Bloody Mary in 'South Pacific'.  Sonya's professional acting career in Los Angeles has spanned over a dozen years. Her roles include recurrings on 'ER', 'Joan of Arcadia', 'Seinfeld', 'The Drew Carey Show' and others. Having appeared in the Hallmark Movie of the Week 'The Reading Room' opposite James Earl Jones, Ms. Eddy was also a series regular on Martin Short's 'Primetime Glick' and has also appeared professionally in 'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof' with John Goodman and Brenda Fricker at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles. Most recently, Ms. Eddy can be seen in her recurring role on 'General Hospital' as Epiphany Johnson - a no-nonsense head nurse. She will also bring Epiphany to SOAPnet's first serialized drama for primetime 'General Hospital: Night Shift', which premieres in July, 2007. Ms. Eddy can also be seen as a guest star on 'CSI: Crime Scene Investigation'.  Sonya's many guest appearances in other primetime shows include 'In Case of Emergency', 'Everybody Hates Chris', 'Daybreak', 'Malcolm In the Middle','Reba',and many others. Her guest star performances include 'Strong Medicine', 'Still Standing', and 'The Hughleys'.  In addition to her career successes, Ms. Eddy has recently become the only actor to have been cast twice on 'ER'. Her work can also be seen in over a dozen National commercials yearly.  Not to be omitted, her versatility as an all around performer can be seen in her most recent feature film roles in 'Coach Carter' starring Samuel L. Jackson, 'Bad News Bears' with Billy Bob Thornton, 'Barbershop', 'Daddy Daycare', 'Matchstick Men', and 'Surviving Christmas'. Recently, Sonya completed filming 'Year of the Dog' with Molly Shannon and Peter Sarsgaard.  Among Sonya's many special skills and talents she is also an accomplished Improv\Sketch artist, vocalist (2nd Soprano to 1st Tenor) and voice-over artist. Sonya Eddy Her home town is Concord, California. Sonya Jean Eddy 5' 4' Concord, California, USA Female Eddy, Sonya Jean 5 March 1975 Dan Olivo is an actor and singer. He began his career performing in various plays with his parents Rocco and Maria Olivo who in 1972 founded The Italian Theatre of Arts in Los Angeles. Since then, Dan has work as an actor in film, television, theatre and radio. A side from acting, Dan at the age of 13 began studying jazz saxophone and singing. Once in High School he joined the prestigious Eagle Rock High School Jazz Band which gained national recognition as one of the best jazz programs in the country winning numerous festivals and competitions. As a part of the program Dan was fortunate enough to travel and perform all over the world to such locations including Hawaii, Germany, and Holland and in 1992 Washington D.C. where they performed at The Inauguration of President Bill Clinton.  Dan recently appeared as Harry the Horse in Frank Loesser's 'Guys & Dolls' at the Downey Civic Light Opera. Dan can also be seen in the upcoming film 'Reservations' directed by Aloura M. Charles. He has also appeared on television as Nick on FOX's 'Malcolm in the Middle' and on ABC's 'General Hospital'. Dan Olivo 'U-Entertainment' (USA), 10 October 2006, by: John Farrell, ''Guys and Dolls' Odds On Favorite' 6' Los Angeles, California, USA Male

Sonya Jean Eddy 5' 4' Concord, California, USA Female Eddy, Sonya Jean William Tempel was born in the Midwest, grew up on the east coast and has the best qualities of both. A tireless, yet easy going work ethic and an effortless ability to drop into the moment. He has studied with Dr. Lawrence Tretler, Richard Barron and Ms. Salome Jens....the attention to craft instilled by these professionals shows through in crisp, layered performances that are a joy to experience. A true up-and-comer, a talent sure to be noticed. William Tempel Is an honorably discharged Veteran of the Us Army and Us Army reserves serving as a squad leader trained in Forward Observation and Combat Engineering, and is a graduate of the US Army Field Artillery School holding a top secret security clearance. Sonya Jean Eddy 5' 4' Concord, California, USA Female Eddy, Sonya Jean 'Paula Smith (I)' (qv) (11 August 1990 - present); 4 children Enjoys Martial Arts and Boxing. 'I was told directors wouldn't hire me. They'd think I'd go crazy on the set. What's more important - directors or producers who might not cast me becuase they're ignorant, or helping people? So that's what I've been doing.' - speaking publicly about his bipolar disorder. Morales, Mauricio Jose Mo (November 2004) Recently signed on for 4 more years with General Hospital, so he will be there at least till 2008 Daytime Emmy Award winning Actor Maurice Benard joined the cast of General Hospital in the role of Sonny Corinthos in August 1993. He briefly left the show for a year-long hiatus in December 1998. For his portrayal, Mr. Benard received the Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in 2003. He was also nominated in 1996, 1997, 2004, 2006 and 2011.  Mr. Benard's multi-cultural upbringing began in San Francisco, where he was born to parents from Nicaragua and San Salvador. Uninspired by the traditional education route, he gleaned an education in the open job market after high school. He began modeling in his early twenties. Following that, Mr. Benard took up acting in numerous theatrical productions in the Bay area.  After auditioning for a role on the ABC drama All My Children, Mr. Benard was cast as Nico Kelly. Two years later, he struck out to find new challenges and moved to Los Angeles, where he was cast as the lead in the much-publicized TV movie, Lucy and Desi: Before the Laughter. He later added a pivotal role in the feature film Ruby to several other prominent film and television credits.  Mr. Benard has been a popular voice in the battle against bipolar disorder. He has been very open about his personal battle with the illness, appearing on television programs such as The View, Entertainment Tonight, and Oprah. He has been featured in People and LA Life Magazines. He also began working with the National Mental Health Association (NMHA) on the 'Bipolar Disorder: Do You Know It?' campaign to help educate Americans about the importance of recognizing the signs and symptoms of bipolar disorder. Maurice Benard 'Soap Opera Digest' (USA), 19 September 2000 Mauricio Jose Morales 5' 9' Martinez, California, USA Male

Video Game Producer Genre editor genre    Joel Cox birth notes gender aka name trivia birth name mini biography birth date 2 April 1942 Joel Cox was born c. 1941 and his film career began at a very early age - appearing before the cameras, in fact - as a baby in the film 'Random Harvest'. Some twenty years later he began work as a mail-room boy with Warner Brothers, the company with whom he has worked ever since, and in 1969 moved into the cutting-room, as an uncredited assistant editor on 'Woodstock' and 'The Wild Bunch'. He was a credited assistant on 'The Outlaw Josey Wales', working for the first time with Clint Eastwood. A durable collaboration followed with Cox cutting all films made by Eastwood since. Joel Cox He credits 'Ferris Webster' (qv) and 'Walter Thompson (I)' (qv) as being his greatest mentors, followed by 'Sam O'Steen' (qv). Joel Edward Cox Los Angeles, California, USA Male Cox, Joel Edward

Movie Episode Editor editor references  Peter Zinner   24 July 1919 'Christa Zinner' (? - 13 November 2007) (his death) Peter Zinner 'The Independent' (UK), 19 November 2007, Iss. 6582, pg. 36 - 37, by: Tony Sloman, 'Obituary: Peter Zinner 'Oscar-winning film editor'' 13 November 2007 Santa Monica, California, USA (complications from non-Hodgkin's lymphoma) Had an appearance as Admiral Yuri Ilyich Padorin in Hunt for Red October. He was actually hired as editor, but due to stylistic differences with the director John McTiernan, he agreed to be replaced but agreed to take this small part. Vienna, Austria Male
Movie Episode Editor editor references William Reynolds    14 June 1910 New York-born William Reynolds was a self-effacing editor with a distinguished sixty-year career in the motion picture industry, noted for his unobtrusive, seamless work on movies of every genre, from romantic melodramas to gangster films. A graduate of Princeton University, he started in the business, moving props as part of the 20th Century Fox swing gang. Displaying a keen interest in the art of editing, he was taken under the wing of the experienced 'Robert L. Simpson' (qv), whom he accompanied to Paramount as assistant in 1935. After just two years, Reynolds was promoted to full editor, his most prestigious assignment being _Algiers (1938)_ (qv). In 1942, he moved across to 20th Century Fox, but wartime service put a temporary halt to his career. However, he did manage to sustain continuity by editing U.S. Army training films.  From 1946, Reynolds was part of a top-notch editing team assembled by 'Darryl F. Zanuck' (qv), himself a former editor and famous for his hands-on approach to post-production. During the remainder of his tenure at Fox, Reynolds cut some of the studio's best films, including the excellent sci-fi classic _The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951)_ (qv); and glossy romances and musicals like _Three Coins in the Fountain (1954)_ (qv) and _Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing (1955)_ (qv). Reynolds was a frequent collaborator and preferred editor for directors like 'Robert Wise (I)' (qv) and 'Joshua Logan (I)' (qv). He did some of his most acclaimed work after free-lancing for three years, back at Fox, on _The Sound of Music (1965)_ (qv) -- winning an Oscar and caustically commenting, 'when in doubt, cut to Julie Andrews' (NY Times, July 22 1997)). Free-lancing again from 1970, he edited the first half of _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv) ('Francis Ford Coppola' (qv) assigned the second half to 'Peter Zinner' (qv)) and _The Sting (1973)_ (qv) (which Reynolds regarded as one of his most demanding assignments). However, towards the end of his career, he was also involved in several significant commercial failures: _Heaven's Gate (1980)_ (qv) -- on which he also acted as executive producer, _Pirates (1986)_ (qv) and _Ishtar (1987)_ (qv). In 1977, Reynolds was named by his peers in a Film Comment poll as one of the three best-ever film editors. William Reynolds 16 July 1997 South Pasadena, California, USA (cancer) William H. Reynolds Elmira, New York, USA Male In 1961, he and Stanley Daugherty co-produced an unsold pilot for a adventure series set in the Pacific Northwest called 'Loggers' which starred Slim Pickens and Bing Russell.
Movie Episode Editor editor references  William Reynolds   14 June 1910 New York-born William Reynolds was a self-effacing editor with a distinguished sixty-year career in the motion picture industry, noted for his unobtrusive, seamless work on movies of every genre, from romantic melodramas to gangster films. A graduate of Princeton University, he started in the business, moving props as part of the 20th Century Fox swing gang. Displaying a keen interest in the art of editing, he was taken under the wing of the experienced 'Robert L. Simpson' (qv), whom he accompanied to Paramount as assistant in 1935. After just two years, Reynolds was promoted to full editor, his most prestigious assignment being _Algiers (1938)_ (qv). In 1942, he moved across to 20th Century Fox, but wartime service put a temporary halt to his career. However, he did manage to sustain continuity by editing U.S. Army training films.  From 1946, Reynolds was part of a top-notch editing team assembled by 'Darryl F. Zanuck' (qv), himself a former editor and famous for his hands-on approach to post-production. During the remainder of his tenure at Fox, Reynolds cut some of the studio's best films, including the excellent sci-fi classic _The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951)_ (qv); and glossy romances and musicals like _Three Coins in the Fountain (1954)_ (qv) and _Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing (1955)_ (qv). Reynolds was a frequent collaborator and preferred editor for directors like 'Robert Wise (I)' (qv) and 'Joshua Logan (I)' (qv). He did some of his most acclaimed work after free-lancing for three years, back at Fox, on _The Sound of Music (1965)_ (qv) -- winning an Oscar and caustically commenting, 'when in doubt, cut to Julie Andrews' (NY Times, July 22 1997)). Free-lancing again from 1970, he edited the first half of _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv) ('Francis Ford Coppola' (qv) assigned the second half to 'Peter Zinner' (qv)) and _The Sting (1973)_ (qv) (which Reynolds regarded as one of his most demanding assignments). However, towards the end of his career, he was also involved in several significant commercial failures: _Heaven's Gate (1980)_ (qv) -- on which he also acted as executive producer, _Pirates (1986)_ (qv) and _Ishtar (1987)_ (qv). In 1977, Reynolds was named by his peers in a Film Comment poll as one of the three best-ever film editors. William Reynolds 16 July 1997 South Pasadena, California, USA (cancer) William H. Reynolds Elmira, New York, USA Male In 1961, he and Stanley Daugherty co-produced an unsold pilot for a adventure series set in the Pacific Northwest called 'Loggers' which starred Slim Pickens and Bing Russell.

Video Game Company Person distributors composer Warner Home Video [US]  Frank Fitzpatrick gender aka name trivia mini biography Warner Home Video [US] As a critically acclaimed composer and music supervisor, Frank Fitzpatrick has created the soundtracks for over two dozen feature films (Scary Movie 3, Queen of the Damned, Friday, In Too Deep, Nuns On the Run) and scores and themes for several television shows including the renown Larry Sanders Show. Recent original works include scores for two animated films (Disney's Proud Family Movie and Revolution's Lil' Pimp), featured songs for the Scary Movie 4, Big Mama's House II, Modigliani and Proud Family Movie soundtracks and the underscore and theme song for Disney's Channel's highest rating premier and top-selling soundtrack Jump In! Listed in Variety as one of the 'Top Music Supervisors of the Decade', Fitzpatrick has contributed to the sale of over six million soundtrack albums, including the multi-platinum original Friday.  Fitzpatrick has also written and produced songs for Gold & Platinum artists including Jill Scott, Fat Joe, Dave Hollister, K-Ci & JoJo, Brownstone, Lina, Carl Anderson, Ice Cube, Akil (of Jurassic 5), Jazz (of Dru Hill) and The London Symphony. In addition to his film soundtracks, Frank's current releases include Siren: a Classical Crossover duet project for Blue Note/EMI Records (co-produced with Peter Asher), Jump to the Rhythm: the single for Hollywood Record's latest teen star Jordan Pruitt and opening song for the High School Musical tour, and Angeli: the theme for the Victoria's Secret ad campaign. He is currently working on his own jazz album and the sophomore CD for Sasha Lazard.  As an emerging filmmaker, his expertise is in music-driven projects and multi-platform entertainment. His first short film, Jungle Jazz: Public Enemy #1, won the prestigious Silver Bear Award for Best Short Film at the Berlin International Film Festival. The film also received top prizes at festivals in Brazil and Australia and has played to over 15 countries with critical acclaim. Continuing his award-winning Jungle Cinema series, Fitzpatrick recently completed the animated short film The Rebel Angel. The Rebel Angel is an anime-inspired adventure, featuring original recordings with the National Symphony of Venezuela, Trance-Opera Diva Sasha Lazard, DJ Spooky, Delirium, DJ Styles (Delinquent Habits) and Grammy Award Winner Andy Vargas (Santana). Two of the songs from the film have already made their mark on the Billboard Dance Charts.  Fitzpatrick has committed himself to giving back to the community and raising social consciousness through music and entertainment. Some of his current initiatives include arts education (he is donating the proceeds from his upcoming jazz album) and AIDS awareness for teens (he wrote and produced the title song for the film Reflections). Reflections, directed by Gina Prince-Blythewood (Love and Basketball), will air on BET and in high schools across America as part of an AIDS education and outreach program.  Prior to his record & film career, Detroit-born Fitzpatrick produced live shows for the likes of Miles Davis, Ella Fitzgerald, Sarah Vaughn, Ray Charles and Prince, produced jazz and arts educational programs, performed in bands and hosted his own radio show. Frank Fitzpatrick 'Jungle Jazz: Public Enemy #1' written and directed by Frank Fitzpatrick won the Silver Bear award from the Berlin International Film Festival as well as audience awards in Sydney and San Paulo. Hidden Faces Male
Video Game Company Person distributors composer Gativideo [AR] James Newton Howard   Gativideo [AR] 9 June 1951 'Rosanna Arquette' (qv) (13 September 1986 - 2 October 1987) (divorced) James Newton Howard attended the University of Southern California's music school, but dropped out to tour with 'Elton John' (qv), and eventually compose music for film and television. He started with _Head Office (1985)_ (qv) in 1985. He has been nominated for eight Academy Awards. He currently is a songwriter, record producer, conductor, keyboardist, and film composer. James Newton Howard Has said that his single most favorite composer is probably 'Ludwig van Beethoven'. Never conducts his own music James Howard Newton I wish I had some great words of advice. The only advice I have ever been able to give anybody is to focus on writing music, and if you're writing a movie score particularly, don't worry about the picture. Just write great music and the rest will take care of itself. Los Angeles, California, USA Male Wrote original music for the theatrical trailer of _Batman Begins (2005)_ (qv).
Video Game Company Person distributors composer  Bernard Herrmann Cinema International Corporation (CIC) [FI] name 'Lucy Anderson' (August 1949 - 1964) (divorced) North Hollywood, Los Angeles, California, USA (heart attack) Composed the original opening theme for The Twilight Zone. Near the end of the first season, it was replaced by the more familiar theme composed by Marius Constant. Your views are as narrow as your tie. Unused score: _Torn Curtain (1966)_ (qv) _Music for the Movies: Bernard Herrmann (1992)_ (qv) 29 June 1911 Benny Steven C. Smith. _A Heart at Fire's Center: The Life and Music of Bernard Herrmann._ Berkeley, CA: University of California Press, 1991. The man behind the low woodwinds that open _Citizen Kane (1941)_ (qv), the shrieking violins of _Psycho (1960)_ (qv), and the plaintive saxophone of _Taxi Driver (1976)_ (qv) was one of the most original and distinctive composers ever to work in film. He started early, winning a composition prize at the age of 13 and founding his own orchestra at the age of 20. After writing scores for 'Orson Welles' (qv)'s radio shows in the 1930s (including the notorious 1938 'The War of the Worlds' broadcast), he was the obvious choice to score Welles's film debut, _Citizen Kane (1941)_ (qv), and, subsequently, _The Magnificent Ambersons (1942)_ (qv), although he removed his name from the latter after additional music was added without his (or Welles's) consent when the film was mutilated by a panic-stricken studio. Herrmann was a prolific film composer, producing some of his most memorable work for 'Alfred Hitchcock (I)' (qv), for whom he wrote nine scores. A notorious perfectionist and demanding (he once said that most directors didn't have a clue about music, and he blithely ignored their instructions--like Hitchcock's suggestion that _Psycho (1960)_ (qv) have a jazz score and no music in the shower scene). He ended his partnership with Hitchcock after the latter rejected his score for _Torn Curtain (1966)_ (qv) on studio advice. He was also an early experimenter in the sounds used in film scores, most famously _The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951)_ (qv), scored for two theremins, pianos, and a horn section; and was a consultant on the electronic sounds created by 'Oskar Sala' (qv) on the mixtrautonium for _The Birds (1963)_ (qv). His last score was for 'Martin Scorsese' (qv)'s _Taxi Driver (1976)_ (qv) and died just hours after recording it. He also wrote an opera, 'Wuthering Heights', and a cantata, 'Moby Dick'. Bernard Herrmann 'International Herald Tribune' (USA), 28 March 2001, Iss. 36721, pg. 7, by: David Stevens, 'Movies, With Orchestra' _Hitchcock (2012)_ (qv) Mr. Bernard Herrmann 5' 8' New York City, New York, USA Male Cinema International Corporation (CIC) [FI]

Video Game Company Person distributors composer Yleisradio (YLE) [FI] Brad Fiedel   Yleisradio (YLE) [FI] 10 March 1951 'Ann Dusenberry' (qv) (? - present) Extremely talented, prolific and versatile composer Brad Fiedel was born on March 10, 1951 in New York City. His mother was a dancer and his father was a composer and musician. Brad started out as a keyboardist for 'Hall & Oates' (qv). Fiedel first began composing music for movies in the mid-70s for such low-budget pictures as _The Astrologer (1975/I)_ (qv), _Deadly Hero (1975)_ (qv) and the raunchy _Jaws (1975)_ (qv) porno parody _Gums (1976)_ (qv). Although best known for his strong, lively and driving scores for action movies and thrillers, Brad has displayed considerable range and skill with his equally fine scores for dramas (_Immediate Family (1989)_ (qv) and _The Accused (1988)_ (qv)), comedies (_Straight Talk (1992)_ (qv) and _Fraternity Vacation (1985)_ (qv)) and numerous made-for-TV features. Fiedel is widely regarded as a vital and creative pioneer for his expert and innovative use of electronic instruments and synthesizers in his music. Brad achieved his greatest success with the incredibly powerful and hard-charging metallic score for _The Terminator (1984)_ (qv) -- he was deservedly nominated for a Saturn Award for Best Music for his outstanding and unforgettable work -- and its sequel _Terminator 2: Judgment Day (1991)_ (qv). He collaborated with 'Terminator' director 'James Cameron (I)' (qv) a third time on the blockbuster smash _True Lies (1994)_ (qv). In addition, Fiedel supplied the chillingly effective scores for the horror pictures _Just Before Dawn (1981)_ (qv), _Eyes of Fire (1983)_ (qv), _Fright Night (1985)_ (qv), the Made-for-TV _The Midnight Hour (1985) (TV)_ (qv) and _The Serpent and the Rainbow (1988)_ (qv). He's also written and/or performed songs that are featured on several film soundtracks. Alas, Brad Fiedel retired from composing scores for both theatrical features and made-for-TV movies, alike, in the late 90s. He's married to actress 'Ann Dusenberry' (qv). Brad Fiedel His most famous piece is the _The Terminator (1984)_ (qv) theme tune. Brad Ira Fiedel New York City, New York, USA Male (1980) Composed music for tag of 'Lightstorm Entertainment', 'James Cameron (I)' (qv)'s production company. Fiedel, Brad Ira
