Series Producer Cinematographer Video Movie actress producer Sonya Eddy   Jill Farren-Phelps birth notes gender aka name trivia birth name mini biography birth date spouse 17 June 1967 Sonya Eddy, a native of Concord, California, graduated from UC Davis. During her intense studies she began her acting career in the West Coast premiere of 'Zora, Is My Name!' (written by the award-winning actress Ruby Dee). Sonya performed several roles in 'Zora' including Big Sweet - a bawdy blues singer (Ruby Dee's personal favorite). Sonya continued forth to perform the role of the Courtesan in 'Comedy of Errors' as well as performances in productions of 'The Crucible', 'Pericles', and the Witch in 'Into The Woods'. Ms. Eddy won an Arty Award for her powerful portrayal of Bloody Mary in 'South Pacific'.  Sonya's professional acting career in Los Angeles has spanned over a dozen years. Her roles include recurrings on 'ER', 'Joan of Arcadia', 'Seinfeld', 'The Drew Carey Show' and others. Having appeared in the Hallmark Movie of the Week 'The Reading Room' opposite James Earl Jones, Ms. Eddy was also a series regular on Martin Short's 'Primetime Glick' and has also appeared professionally in 'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof' with John Goodman and Brenda Fricker at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles. Most recently, Ms. Eddy can be seen in her recurring role on 'General Hospital' as Epiphany Johnson - a no-nonsense head nurse. She will also bring Epiphany to SOAPnet's first serialized drama for primetime 'General Hospital: Night Shift', which premieres in July, 2007. Ms. Eddy can also be seen as a guest star on 'CSI: Crime Scene Investigation'.  Sonya's many guest appearances in other primetime shows include 'In Case of Emergency', 'Everybody Hates Chris', 'Daybreak', 'Malcolm In the Middle','Reba',and many others. Her guest star performances include 'Strong Medicine', 'Still Standing', and 'The Hughleys'.  In addition to her career successes, Ms. Eddy has recently become the only actor to have been cast twice on 'ER'. Her work can also be seen in over a dozen National commercials yearly.  Not to be omitted, her versatility as an all around performer can be seen in her most recent feature film roles in 'Coach Carter' starring Samuel L. Jackson, 'Bad News Bears' with Billy Bob Thornton, 'Barbershop', 'Daddy Daycare', 'Matchstick Men', and 'Surviving Christmas'. Recently, Sonya completed filming 'Year of the Dog' with Molly Shannon and Peter Sarsgaard.  Among Sonya's many special skills and talents she is also an accomplished Improv\Sketch artist, vocalist (2nd Soprano to 1st Tenor) and voice-over artist. Sonya Eddy Her home town is Concord, California. Sonya Jean Eddy 5' 4' Concord, California, USA Female Eddy, Sonya Jean 7 July 1952 'Robert Phelps (I)' (qv) (? - present); 1 child Phelps studied at Carnegie Mellon University, where she received a BFA in directing. She stage-managed at New Jersey's McCarter Theater before becoming a production assistant for various New York stage productions, including shows directed by 'Mike Nichols (I)' (qv) and 'Bob Fosse' (qv). She began her television career in 1974 as a production assistant on _'The Guiding Light' (1952)_ (qv). From 1977-84 Phelps became an Emmy Award-winning music director on the ABC Daytime drama _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv). In 1984 she joined _'Santa Barbara' (1984)_ (qv) where she ultimately rose to the position of executive producer. During her tenure the show garnered three consecutive Emmy Awards for Outstanding Drama Series. From 1991-95 Phelps returned to her first stomping grounds, taking the helm of the longest-running Daytime soap _'The Guiding Light' (1952)_ (qv). Then, she served as executive producer of _'Another World' (1964)_ (qv) where she split viewers opinions but along with the creation of a dynamic new opening and innovative new sets she managed to achieve a sharp ratings increase. Afterwards Phelps returned to ABC Daytime serving as executive producer of _'One Life to Live' (1968)_ (qv) from December 1997 through December 2000 before switching to _'General Hospital' (1963)_ (qv) in the same capacity. So far the show received numerous Emmy awards under her tenure. Jill Farren-Phelps Mother of Courtney Phelps. Jill Farren Phelps New York City, New York, USA Female Farren, Jill
Series Producer Cinematographer Video Movie actress producer Sonya Eddy  Charles Pratt Jr.   17 June 1967 Sonya Eddy, a native of Concord, California, graduated from UC Davis. During her intense studies she began her acting career in the West Coast premiere of 'Zora, Is My Name!' (written by the award-winning actress Ruby Dee). Sonya performed several roles in 'Zora' including Big Sweet - a bawdy blues singer (Ruby Dee's personal favorite). Sonya continued forth to perform the role of the Courtesan in 'Comedy of Errors' as well as performances in productions of 'The Crucible', 'Pericles', and the Witch in 'Into The Woods'. Ms. Eddy won an Arty Award for her powerful portrayal of Bloody Mary in 'South Pacific'.  Sonya's professional acting career in Los Angeles has spanned over a dozen years. Her roles include recurrings on 'ER', 'Joan of Arcadia', 'Seinfeld', 'The Drew Carey Show' and others. Having appeared in the Hallmark Movie of the Week 'The Reading Room' opposite James Earl Jones, Ms. Eddy was also a series regular on Martin Short's 'Primetime Glick' and has also appeared professionally in 'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof' with John Goodman and Brenda Fricker at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles. Most recently, Ms. Eddy can be seen in her recurring role on 'General Hospital' as Epiphany Johnson - a no-nonsense head nurse. She will also bring Epiphany to SOAPnet's first serialized drama for primetime 'General Hospital: Night Shift', which premieres in July, 2007. Ms. Eddy can also be seen as a guest star on 'CSI: Crime Scene Investigation'.  Sonya's many guest appearances in other primetime shows include 'In Case of Emergency', 'Everybody Hates Chris', 'Daybreak', 'Malcolm In the Middle','Reba',and many others. Her guest star performances include 'Strong Medicine', 'Still Standing', and 'The Hughleys'.  In addition to her career successes, Ms. Eddy has recently become the only actor to have been cast twice on 'ER'. Her work can also be seen in over a dozen National commercials yearly.  Not to be omitted, her versatility as an all around performer can be seen in her most recent feature film roles in 'Coach Carter' starring Samuel L. Jackson, 'Bad News Bears' with Billy Bob Thornton, 'Barbershop', 'Daddy Daycare', 'Matchstick Men', and 'Surviving Christmas'. Recently, Sonya completed filming 'Year of the Dog' with Molly Shannon and Peter Sarsgaard.  Among Sonya's many special skills and talents she is also an accomplished Improv\Sketch artist, vocalist (2nd Soprano to 1st Tenor) and voice-over artist. Sonya Eddy Her home town is Concord, California. Sonya Jean Eddy 5' 4' Concord, California, USA Female Eddy, Sonya Jean Charles Pratt Jr. Father of 'Chelsea Pratt' (qv). Charles A. Pratt Jr. Male

Movie Language Person production designer language Steve Bass    Multi-Emmy Award winner Steve Bass has designed many of the most prestigious live and televised shows produced, including the Oscars, Grammys, Emmys and Tony Awards. His talents were tapped for the Opening and Closing Ceremonies of the Atlanta Olympics, Salt Lake Olympics Medals Plaza, The Democratic Convention, Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus, and the Inaugural Celebration at the Lincoln Memorial for President Obama.  Live show design includes mega hits from Disney: the Lion King Celebration and a theatrical production of The Little Mermaid which to date has been seen by over 25 million guests, as well as the national tour of Disney's Symphonic Fantasy and Sesame Street Live. Recent live productions include DreamWorks Madagascar Live!, Disney's Mad T Party: an innovative experiential nightclub, and the award-winning Starlight Parade for Universal Studios Japan.  Steve has a long-standing history designing for iconic entertainment programs such as Great Performances, Nickelodeon's Kids Choice, Christmas in Washington, TV Land, and Entertainment Tonight, as well as corporate events for auto giants Lexus and Toyota. Steve Bass

I'd watch the Academy Awards and it was such a magical event. I really wanted to be part of that world, like everyone does. Movie Language Person language cinematographer Robert Draper    'Fangoria Horror Spectacular' (USA), 1991, Iss. 4, pg. 10-13, by: Mark Cerulli, 'Lighting the Crypt' With more than 35 years experience in Film and Television, Rob has worked on everything from Regional TV News to Hollywood Feature Films.  Known as a technical innovator and creative risk taker in the industry he has pioneered many new techniques and worked on development of motion picture products for SONY, Panasonic, Fuji Film, Arri and Zeiss. Rob was also the first to run a full scale Hi Definition shoot in Hollywood on the then 'new gen' camera's.  Rob set the style for what has become known as Reality TV in a groundbreaking series he shot for Universal called 'The Street'...after which the New York Times declared 'the show practically creates a new visual language'. Rob also worked on some of the first Music Videos used to promote feature Films and developed a visual style for using promotional music videos for retailing in a 5 minute Hollywood extravaganza for Coca Cola.  Rob's photography on the Sundance Audience award winner, The Spitfire Grill, drew accolades worldwide.  Rob draws inspiration from the classic painters and his skilled and delicate use of light and shade as integral elements of composition sets his work apart. Over the past 20 years he has inspired thousand of cinematographers worldwide as a dynamic instructor at workshops, and as a consultant, on the art of film lighting  More recently he has been on the cutting edge of digital technology on the web with his groundbreaking IPTV channel Singlemalt TV. Launched in 2006 it immediately drew attention and a long relationship with major media players in UK.  Rob has worked worldwide on TV movies,Feature Films,Mini Series,TV series documentaries, TV Commercials and Music Videos. He has worked for every major Hollywood studio and US TV Network claiming multiple Awards in both Australia and the United States. Robert Draper 'Imagine News' (USA), June 2002, by: 'Eric Harper (I)' (qv), 'Rob Draper: New England Cinematography on the Cutting Edge' 'Imagine News' (USA), June 2002 Male

Movie Language Person language cinematographer James Glennon    29 August 1942 'Charmaine Witus' (1977 - 19 October 2006) (his death); 4 children American cinematographer and something of a Renaissance man. The son of famed cinematographer 'Bert Glennon' (qv), James Glennon and his brothers learned photography at their father's feet. (Their mother was script supervisor 'Mary Coleman (II)' (qv).) James Glennon began work in the Warner Bros. mail room, where he often was assigned to make deliveries to studio head 'Jack L. Warner' (qv) because the other mail clerks were afraid of Warner. Warner advised Glennon to buy a motion picture camera and rent it out, offering his own services for free. Glennon did so, and thus initiated his career as a cinematographer with _Jaws of Death (1977)_ (qv). He continued to work as a camera operator on other cinematographers' films, including _The Conversation (1974)_ (qv), _Ordinary People (1980)_ (qv), and _Altered States (1980)_ (qv), before coming to notice as cinematographer on the groundbreaking _El Norte (1983)_ (qv). He worked steadily thereafter. He filmed _My Wicked, Wicked Ways: The Legend of Errol Flynn (1985) (TV)_ (qv), the story of the actor his own father had photographed in four films. He partnered with director 'Alexander Payne (I)' (qv) on three films: _Citizen Ruth (1996)_ (qv), _Election (1999)_ (qv), and _About Schmidt (2002)_ (qv). He won an Emmy Award in 2005 for an episode of _'Deadwood' (2004)_ (qv), the Western series for which he was principal cinematographer for its entire run. He had widely varied interests. He served repeatedly as a judge in the Nicholl Fellowship in Screenwriting of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences. He operated Malibu Water Resources, a water aeration program, and he farmed clams in the Pacific Northwest. He was extraordinarily beloved of his crews and casts for his eternal optimism and unstinting praise and encouragement. He died unexpectedly on October 19, 2006, from a blood clot resulting from surgery for prostate cancer. James Glennon 19 October 2006 Los Angeles, California, USA (blood clot following surgery for prostate cancer) Had been a member of the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC) since 1994. James Michael Glennon Los Angeles, California, USA Male Glennon, James Michael
Movie Language Person language cinematographer Randall P. Dark    In 1986, Randall Dark was given the opportunity to view High Definition for the first time and knew it was the future of images. A few short years later, he founded HD Vision in New York City. The company later moved its headquarters to Dallas, then to Los Angeles. Its mandate was to specialize in the growth of High Definition, launching Dark into the position of a technological and creative visionary. An undisputed pioneer in the emerging industry, today, Randall is the creative and marketing force behind Randall Dark Productions, Inc. He received one of the International Electronic Cinema Festival's top honors: The Pioneer Award, bestowed in recognition of extraordinary contributions to the success of High Definition. He is a member of the Television Arts and Sciences Academy and is one of a select few members of the Consumer Electronics Association's Academy of Digital Pioneers, a group recognized for their efforts implementing Digital Television in the United States.  Recognized globally as an expert in emerging technologies, Randall has spoken to audiences at events including: MIPCOM, Tokyo International Film Festival, CASBAA Hong Kong, Banff World Television Festival, National Association of Broadcaster's Convention, International Electronic Cinema Festival, Infocomm, Consumer Electronic Show, HDExpo, World Television Forum, creaTVty Zurich, Canadian Association of Broadcasters Convention, Hollywood Post Alliance, New York State Bar Association, Bear Stearns Media Conference, NATPE and Playback Forum (Toronto) where he served as the Keynote Speaker.  Dark and his companies have been involved in over 2000 HD projects including feature films, documentaries, commercials, music videos, corporate presentations, product launches and live events.  In 2007, the Maxell Corporation presented Dark its Independent Filmmaker Award for Achievement made during the making of 'Closing Escrow'. HD Programs directed by Dark have also received awards from CEA, Telly, IECF, Communicator, Aurora, Axiem, WorldFest Houston International Film Festival, Videographer, The American Corporate Video Awards and Cinema Chicago. Randall P. Dark 'TV Technology' (USA), 26 July 2010, by: John Merli, 'A 3D Ode to the Smokies'

Video Game Actress Writer writer costume designer Carol Oditz  Vince Vaughn gender other works trivia nick names spouse article quotes interviews aka name trade mark birth name where now mini biography birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial 15 August 1946 Carol Oditz Was interviewed by Terry Gross for NPR's FRESH AIR. New York City, New York, USA 'DreamWatch' (UK), July 1997, Iss. 35, pg. 61, by: Marc Shapiro, 'Snap happy' 'Kyla Weber' (2 January 2010 - present); 1 child [2008] Topped Forbes list of actors who give movie studios the best return on their investment, with his films earning $14.75 Dollars for every $1 Dollar he is paid. 'Premiere' (USA), October 1998, Vol. 11, Iss. 14, pg. 76-77, by: Andrew MacPherson My father's name is Vernon, and my mother liked the initials double V, so she named my sisters Victoria and Valerie. That's cool- except when the dogs start getting V names. Provides audio commentary with co-star 'Jon Favreau' (qv) on the DVD for _Made (2001)_ (qv). Vaughn, Vincent Anthony 28 March 1970 Mr Sunshine (July 2005) Filming _The Break-Up (2006)_ (qv) in Chicago with 'Jennifer Aniston' (qv). Vincent Anthony Vaughn was born on March 28, 1970, in Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA and raised in Lake Forest, Illinois, USA. His parents were 'Vernon Vaughn' (qv), a salesman, and 'Sharon Vaughn (II)' (qv), a real-estate agent and stockbroker. They later divorced in 1991. He also has two older sisters named 'Victoria Vaughn (I)' (qv) and 'Valeri Vaughn' (qv). Vince was interested in theater early on and grabbed a spot in a Chevy commercial. Figuring he was set, he packed his bags and headed for Hollywood only to become a struggling actor losing role after role. He managed to hit a few spots on television, but his real goal was to make it to the big screen. He made his first credited role in the film _Rudy (1993)_ (qv) where he met his friend 'Jon Favreau' (qv), who was writing a script detailing his life as an out-of-work actor. Vince was written into _Swingers (1996)_ (qv) by Jon to play the character of 'Trent'. He signed on just as a favor to his buddy, not realizing it would be a career changing role. Though not a commercial success, it was a critical success in which 'Steven Spielberg' (qv) saw him and cast him in the big budget sequel _The Lost World: Jurassic Park (1997)_ (qv). This role gave Vince the exposure he needed to become a movie star and, for the first time, choose the roles he wanted to take. _A Cool, Dry Place (1998)_ (qv) put him as a loving father, _Return to Paradise (1998)_ (qv) cast him as a man having to make a life or death decision to save a friend, and _Clay Pigeons (1998)_ (qv) cast him as an interesting serial killer. Since then his roles have been primarily in comedies such as _Old School (2003)_ (qv), _Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story (2004)_ (qv), _Wedding Crashers (2005)_ (qv), and _Couples Retreat (2009)_ (qv). Vince Vaughn 'Parade' (USA), 13 January 2008, pg. 9-10, by: Jeanne Wolf, 'I Work Hard, I Play Hard' Sardonic sense of Humour 'Parade' (USA), 13 January 2008 Vincent Vaughn 6' 5' Male
Video Game Actress Writer writer costume designer David Morrell Tom Bronson   24 April 1943 David Morrell was born in 1943, shortly after his father was killed in action. His mother could not both raise him and have a job, so David was sent to an orphange. He went to Pennsylvania State University from 1966-70, where he was inspired by his teacher, writer William Tenn. In 1972 he wrote _First Blood (1982)_ (qv), which later became the legendary movie introducing John Rambo played by 'Sylvester Stallone' (qv) in 1982. He was a professor of American literature at the University of Iowa and taught from 1970 to 1986, where he resigned. In 1987 he lost his 15 year old son Matthew because of bone cancer. He left Iowa and today he lives with his wife and daughter in Santa Fe, New Mexico. He has written several novels and First Blood is probably the most famous. David Morrell 'Knave' (UK), 1986, Vol. 18, Iss. 6, pg. 60-64, by: William Alland, 'The Man Who Made Rambo' David Morrell actually wrote _First Blood (1982)_ (qv) at the same time he was writing his dissertation on American literature, and submitted both at the same time. When his agent called to tell him of the sale, Morrell actually thought he was talking about his dissertation being accepted. The first scripts [for _Rambo III (1988)_ (qv)) I saw were excellent, particular the character of a fortyish female French physician who takes care of Afghan children injured during the war. The story had an epical RAMBO OF ARABIA feel. But for budgetary and other reasons, the scripts got simpler until the released film felt like a cartoon. One of the subtexts I added was that the Soviet War with Afghanistan was a version of America's involvement in Vietnam, with similar fracturing effects to each country's veterans and culture. Kitchener, Ontario, Canada Male The Fraternity of the Stone (1985) Tom Bronson Thomas M. Bronson

Video Game Producer TV Movie Writer actress writer Ian Fleming  Samantha Bond birth notes gender other works name trivia birth date spouse height quotes 'Anne Geraldine Charteris' (24 March 1952 - 12 August 1964) (his death); 1 child Canterbury, Kent, England, UK (heart attack) His wife, Anne Geraldine Charteris, was the granddaughter of the 9th Earl of Wemyss, and had been previously married to Shane O'Neill, 3rd Lord O'Neill (she was his widow) and then to Esmond Cecil Harmsworth, 2nd Viscount Rothermere, whom she divorced to marry Ian. Anne and Ian had one son, Casper Robert Fleming, born 12th of August 1952. I wanted the simplest, dullest, plainest-sounding name I could find, James Bond was much better than something more interesting like 'Peregrine Maltravers.' Exotic things would happen to and around him but he would be a neutral figure - an anonymous blunt instrument wielded by a Government Department. (1965) Novel (published posthumously): 'The Man With The Golden Gun' (filmed as _The Man with the Golden Gun (1974)_ (qv)) _'Explorations' (1956) {Ian Fleming: The Brain Behind Bond}_ (qv) 28 May 1908 'John Pearson (III)' (qv). _The Life of Ian Fleming._ London, England: Jonathon Cape Ltd., 1966. Born into a wealthy and influential English family, Ian Fleming spent his early years attending top British schools such as Eton and Sandhurst military academy. He took to writing while schooling in Kitzbuhel, Austria, and upon failing the entrance requirements for Foreign Service joined the news agency Reuters as a journalist -- winning the respect of his peers for his coverage of a 'show trial' in Russia of several Royal Engineers on espionage charges. Fleming briefly worked in the financial sector for the family bank, but just prior to the Second World War, was recruited into British Naval Intelligence where he excelled, shortly achieving the rank of Commander. When the war ended, Fleming retired to Jamaica where he built a house called 'Goldeneye,' took up writing full-time and created the character that would make him famous -- British Secret Service agent James Bond, in a novel called 'Casino Royale.' Fleming spent the rest of his life writing and traveling the world, but as his Bond character reached new heights of popularity on movie screens, Fleming was in ailing health. He died of a heart attack (his second) in England in August 1964 at the age of 56. Ian Fleming 'The New York Times' (USA), 19 May 2008, Vol. 157, Iss. 54,315, pg. E1 & E6, by: John F. Burns, 'Remembering Fleming, Ian Fleming' 12 August 1964 _Goldeneye (1989) (TV)_ (qv) Cigarette (in holder) perched between fingers of his right hand 'The Times Magazine' (UK), 5 April 2008 Ian Lancaster Fleming 6' Mayfair, London, England, UK Male 27 November 1961 'Alexander Hanson' (qv) (? - present); 2 children Samantha Bond Sister of 'Abigail Bond' (qv) 5' 6 1/2' 'As for 'Daniel Craig (I)' (qv) as Bond, I think it is an absolutely brilliant choice. He is butch, male, attractive and a bloody good actor. He was by far the most plausible choice' [on _Casino Royale (2006)_ (qv)]. Composer Series Producer actress  Lexi Ainsworth Kimberly McCullough birth notes gender other works aka name trivia nick names birth date article magazine cover photo height quotes 28 October 1992 Born Alexandra Ainsworth in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma to a dentist father and a school teacher mother, Lexi began dancing on stage by age 6 with the local ballet company. This lead to her appearance in the professional theater production of The Wizard of Oz where she performed as a Lullabye League munchkin. After other musical theater performances she won the lead role of Scout in the Actors Equity production of To Kill a Mockingbird. But it was after attending a film camp in New York that she developed an interest in film and television acting . Furthering this pursuit she attended an acting boot camp in Los Angeles where she caught the attention of an agency who sent her out on her first national commercial audition which she subsequently shot for Barbie. After other commercials and industrials she acquired the lead role of Caroline in the AFI short film Caroline Crossing and Grace Budd, the child lead in the independent film The Gray Man. She has also co-stared in the NBC television series Medical Investigation with Kelly Williams and guest-stared then recurred as Tille on WB's Gilmore girls. Most recently she won the role of Molly in Universal's Feature film Wild Child where she plays Emma Roberts little sister. She was admitted to the Screen Actors Guild in 2005. Lexi Ainsworth Alexandra Danielle Ainsworth 5' 1' Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, USA Female Ainsworth, Alexandra Danielle 5 March 1978 Kimber Kimberly McCullough 'Woman's World' (USA), 7 February 2006, Vol. 27, Iss. 6, pg. 16-17, by: Jillian Boyle, 'Lose 8 lbs in 14 days!' Attended NYU's Tisch School for the Arts in 1996-1997. 'Woman's World' (USA), 7 February 2006, Vol. 27, Iss. 6 Kimberly Anne McCullough 5' 2' (When asked who on her cast she'd take with her car shopping) I'd take Maurice Benard (Sonny), because he seems to scare people even though he's the sweetest man ever. He's kind of like a big brother to me. He could come in and act like a mobster and scare them into giving me a good buy. Bellflower, California, USA Female Played Cosette in the Broadway version of Les Miserables as a young child
Composer Series Producer actress Sonya Eddy Christie Lynn Smith   17 June 1967 Sonya Eddy, a native of Concord, California, graduated from UC Davis. During her intense studies she began her acting career in the West Coast premiere of 'Zora, Is My Name!' (written by the award-winning actress Ruby Dee). Sonya performed several roles in 'Zora' including Big Sweet - a bawdy blues singer (Ruby Dee's personal favorite). Sonya continued forth to perform the role of the Courtesan in 'Comedy of Errors' as well as performances in productions of 'The Crucible', 'Pericles', and the Witch in 'Into The Woods'. Ms. Eddy won an Arty Award for her powerful portrayal of Bloody Mary in 'South Pacific'.  Sonya's professional acting career in Los Angeles has spanned over a dozen years. Her roles include recurrings on 'ER', 'Joan of Arcadia', 'Seinfeld', 'The Drew Carey Show' and others. Having appeared in the Hallmark Movie of the Week 'The Reading Room' opposite James Earl Jones, Ms. Eddy was also a series regular on Martin Short's 'Primetime Glick' and has also appeared professionally in 'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof' with John Goodman and Brenda Fricker at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles. Most recently, Ms. Eddy can be seen in her recurring role on 'General Hospital' as Epiphany Johnson - a no-nonsense head nurse. She will also bring Epiphany to SOAPnet's first serialized drama for primetime 'General Hospital: Night Shift', which premieres in July, 2007. Ms. Eddy can also be seen as a guest star on 'CSI: Crime Scene Investigation'.  Sonya's many guest appearances in other primetime shows include 'In Case of Emergency', 'Everybody Hates Chris', 'Daybreak', 'Malcolm In the Middle','Reba',and many others. Her guest star performances include 'Strong Medicine', 'Still Standing', and 'The Hughleys'.  In addition to her career successes, Ms. Eddy has recently become the only actor to have been cast twice on 'ER'. Her work can also be seen in over a dozen National commercials yearly.  Not to be omitted, her versatility as an all around performer can be seen in her most recent feature film roles in 'Coach Carter' starring Samuel L. Jackson, 'Bad News Bears' with Billy Bob Thornton, 'Barbershop', 'Daddy Daycare', 'Matchstick Men', and 'Surviving Christmas'. Recently, Sonya completed filming 'Year of the Dog' with Molly Shannon and Peter Sarsgaard.  Among Sonya's many special skills and talents she is also an accomplished Improv\Sketch artist, vocalist (2nd Soprano to 1st Tenor) and voice-over artist. Sonya Eddy Her home town is Concord, California. Sonya Jean Eddy 5' 4' Concord, California, USA Female Eddy, Sonya Jean 'John Fortson' (qv) (27 June 1998 - present); 1 child ORALL2715 Christie Lynn Smith Gave birth to her daughter Abby Ryder Fortson on March 14, 2008 at 12:19pm. She weighed 7lbs 8oz and 20 1/4 inches long. Christie Smith 5' 5' Female
Composer Series Producer actress Sonya Eddy Nancy Lee Grahn   17 June 1967 Sonya Eddy, a native of Concord, California, graduated from UC Davis. During her intense studies she began her acting career in the West Coast premiere of 'Zora, Is My Name!' (written by the award-winning actress Ruby Dee). Sonya performed several roles in 'Zora' including Big Sweet - a bawdy blues singer (Ruby Dee's personal favorite). Sonya continued forth to perform the role of the Courtesan in 'Comedy of Errors' as well as performances in productions of 'The Crucible', 'Pericles', and the Witch in 'Into The Woods'. Ms. Eddy won an Arty Award for her powerful portrayal of Bloody Mary in 'South Pacific'.  Sonya's professional acting career in Los Angeles has spanned over a dozen years. Her roles include recurrings on 'ER', 'Joan of Arcadia', 'Seinfeld', 'The Drew Carey Show' and others. Having appeared in the Hallmark Movie of the Week 'The Reading Room' opposite James Earl Jones, Ms. Eddy was also a series regular on Martin Short's 'Primetime Glick' and has also appeared professionally in 'Cat on a Hot Tin Roof' with John Goodman and Brenda Fricker at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles. Most recently, Ms. Eddy can be seen in her recurring role on 'General Hospital' as Epiphany Johnson - a no-nonsense head nurse. She will also bring Epiphany to SOAPnet's first serialized drama for primetime 'General Hospital: Night Shift', which premieres in July, 2007. Ms. Eddy can also be seen as a guest star on 'CSI: Crime Scene Investigation'.  Sonya's many guest appearances in other primetime shows include 'In Case of Emergency', 'Everybody Hates Chris', 'Daybreak', 'Malcolm In the Middle','Reba',and many others. Her guest star performances include 'Strong Medicine', 'Still Standing', and 'The Hughleys'.  In addition to her career successes, Ms. Eddy has recently become the only actor to have been cast twice on 'ER'. Her work can also be seen in over a dozen National commercials yearly.  Not to be omitted, her versatility as an all around performer can be seen in her most recent feature film roles in 'Coach Carter' starring Samuel L. Jackson, 'Bad News Bears' with Billy Bob Thornton, 'Barbershop', 'Daddy Daycare', 'Matchstick Men', and 'Surviving Christmas'. Recently, Sonya completed filming 'Year of the Dog' with Molly Shannon and Peter Sarsgaard.  Among Sonya's many special skills and talents she is also an accomplished Improv\Sketch artist, vocalist (2nd Soprano to 1st Tenor) and voice-over artist. Sonya Eddy Her home town is Concord, California. Her family moved to Honolulu, Hawaii, when she was four. Her parents were professional actors who performed small parts on _'Hawaii Five-O' (1968)_ (qv) and _'Magnum, P.I.' (1980)_ (qv). But when you're working 80-hour weeks and your weekends are still devoted to work in some way - whether it's an interview or getting your roots done at a beauty salon - you're just not your normal self. (1997) TV commercial for Always. Herbst, Rebecca Ann Liberty 12 May 1977 Liberty Rebecca Herbst, also known as Becky, has been acting since she was 5 years old. She originally wanted to be a figure skater and skated with the likes of Michelle and Karen Kwan. She continued skating until she was 16 and then decided to continue with acting instead. Becky has appeared in many different TV shows and movies. She married former 'General Hospital' co-star, 'Michael Saucedo' (qv) (ex 'Juan') and they are expecting their first baby, a boy in November 2001. They were wed on June 1st, 2001 in Maui and are currently living in Malibu Beach, California. [on 'Meryl Streep' (qv)] The danger I'm talking about here is that she tends to sound boring because she's so perfect. Credited as actor, in Barbara Streisand's The Broadway Album, on the song 'Putting it Together'. _'The Directors' (1999) {The Films of Sydney Pollack (#2.4)}_ (qv) Pollack, Sydney Irwin 1 July 1934 Janet Meyer. _Sydney Pollack: A Critical Filmography._ Jefferson, NC: McFarland & Co., Inc., 1998. ISBN 0786404868 Sydney Pollack was an Academy Award-winning director, producer, actor, writer and public figure, who directed and produced over 40 films.  He was born on July 1, 1934, in Lafayette, Indiana, USA, to a family of Russian-Jewish immigrants. His mother, Rebecca Miller, was a homemaker. His father, David Pollack, was a professional boxer turned pharmacist. His parents divorced when he was young. His mother, an alcoholic, died at age 37, when Sydney Pollack was 16. He spent his formative years in Indiana, graduating from his HS in 1952, then moved to the New York City.  From 1952-1954 young Pollack studied acting with 'Sanford Meisner' (qv) at The Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre in New York. He served two years in the army, and then returned to the Neighborhood Playhouse and taught acting. In 1958, Pollack married his former student Claire Griswold. They had three children. Their son, Steven Pollack, died in a plane crash on November 26, 1993, in Santa Monica, California. Their daughter, Rebecca Pollack, served as vice president of film production at United Artists during the 1990s. Their youngest daughter, Rachel Pollack, was born in 1969.  Pollack began his acting career on stage, then made his name as television director in the early 1960s. He made his big screen acting debut in _War Hunt (1962)_ (qv), where he met fellow actor 'Robert Redford (I)' (qv), and the two co-stars established a life-long friendship. Pollack called on his good friend Redford to play opposite 'Natalie Wood (I)' (qv) in _This Property Is Condemned (1966)_ (qv). Pollack and Redford worked together on six more films over the years. His biggest success came with _Out of Africa (1985)_ (qv), starring 'Robert Redford (I)' (qv) and 'Meryl Streep' (qv). The movie earned eleven Academy Award nominations in all and seven wins, including Pollack's two Oscars: one for Best Direction and one for Best Picture.  Pollack showed his best as a comedy director and actor in _Tootsie (1982)_ (qv), where he brought feminist issues to public awareness using his remarkable wit and wisdom, and created a highly entertaining film, which was nominated for ten Academy Awards. Pollack's directing revealed 'Dustin Hoffman' (qv)'s range and nuanced acting in gender switching from a dominant boyfriend to a nurse in drag, a brilliant collaboration of director and actor that broadened public perception about sex roles. Pollack also made success in producing such films as _The Talented Mr. Ripley (1999)_ (qv), _The Quiet American (2002)_ (qv) and _Cold Mountain (2003)_ (qv). Pollack returned to the director's chair in 2004, when he directed _The Interpreter (2005)_ (qv), the first film ever shot on location at the United Nations Headquarters and within the General Assembly in New York City.  In 2000, Sydney Pollack was honored with the John Huston Award from the Directors Guild of America as a 'defender of artists' rights.' He died from cancer on May 26, 2008, at his home in the Los Angeles suburb of Pacific Palisades, California. Sydney Pollack 'Baltimore Sun' (USA), 28 May 2008, by: Michael Sragow, 'Sydney Pollack: an Actor's Director' 26 May 2008 Frequently casts 'Robert Redford (I)' (qv) Sidney Pollock 6' Lafayette, Indiana, USA Male
Series Production Designer Work director referenced in Lloyd Kaufman    'Amarcord' (Italy), 1996, Vol. 2, Iss. 5, pg. 54-57, by: Igor Molino Padovan, 'Poche cazzate... Rossellini e il migliore' 'Patricia Kaufman' (qv) (13 July 1974 - present); 3 children Is the President of Troma Films, one of the longest running independent film companies. In our racist, sexist society, Christmas is the eight hours when we stop killing each other and gratuitous overeating is encouraged so that the starving and other people in the world can die! Lloyd Kaufman and James Gunn. _All I Need to Know about Filmmaking I Learned from the Toxic Avenger._ New York: Boulevard Books, 1999. ISBN 0425163571 ORALL1601 Lloyd Kaufman 'Maxim' (USA), October 2012, pg. 35, by: Lloyd Laufman, 'Land Your Dream Job' The plots of his films center around radiation and science gone wrong 'Penny Blood' (USA), 2007, Iss. 8 Stanley Lloyd Kaufman Jr. New York City, New York, USA Male
Series Production Designer Work director referenced in Sydney Pollack    'G?teborgs-Posten' (Sweden), 7 November 1999, pg. 62, 'Pollack ?r en jordn?ra stj?rna', by: Kristina Torell 'Claire Griswold' (qv) (22 September 1958 - 26 May 2008) (his death); 3 children Pacific Palisades, Los Angeles, California, USA (stomach cancer) In 2000, co-founder, with 'Anthony Minghella' (qv), of 'Mirage Enterprises' to produce films. [on 'Meryl Streep' (qv)] The danger I'm talking about here is that she tends to sound boring because she's so perfect. Credited as actor, in Barbara Streisand's The Broadway Album, on the song 'Putting it Together'. _'The Directors' (1999) {The Films of Sydney Pollack (#2.4)}_ (qv) Pollack, Sydney Irwin 1 July 1934 Janet Meyer. _Sydney Pollack: A Critical Filmography._ Jefferson, NC: McFarland & Co., Inc., 1998. Movie Episode Writer references composer  Nino Rota   3 December 1911 Born in Milan in 1911 into a family of musicians, Nino Rota was first a student of Orefice and Pizzetti. Then, still a child, he moved to Rome where he completed his studies at the Conservatory of Santa Cecilia in 1929 with Alfredo Casella. In the meantime, he had become an 'enfant prodige', famous both as a composer and as an orchestra conductor. His first oratorio, 'L'infanzia di San Giovanni Battista,' was performed in Milan and Paris as early as 1923 and his lyrical comedy, 'Il Principe Porcaro,' was composed in 1926. From 1930 to 1932, Nino Rota lived in the USA. He won a scholarship to the Curtis Institute of Philadelphia where he attended classes in composition taught by Rosario Scalero and classes in orchestra taught by 'Fritz Reiner' (qv). He returned to Italy and earned a degree in literature from the University of Milan. In 1937, he began a teaching career that led to the directorship of the Bari Conservatory, a title he held from 1950 until his death in 1979. After his 'childhood' compositions, Nino Rota wrote the following operas: Ariodante (Parma 1942), Torquemada (1943), Il cappello di paglia di Firenze (Palermo 1955), I due timidi (RAI 1950, London 1953), La notte di un neurastenico (Premio Italia 1959, La Scala 1960), Lo scoiattolo in gamba (Venezia 1959), Aladino e la lampada magica (Naples 1968), La visita meravigliosa (Palermo 1970), Napoli milionaria (Spoleto Festival 1977). He also wrote the following ballets: La rappresentazione di Adamo ed Eva (Perugia 1957), La Strada (La Scala 1965), Aci e Galatea (Rome 1971), Le Moli?re imaginaire (Paris and Brussels 1976) and Amor di poeta (Brussels 1978) for Maurice B?jart. In addition, there are countless works for orchestra that have been performed since before World War II and are still performed by orchestras in every part of the world. His work in film dates back to the early forties. His filmography includes the names of virtually all of the noted directors of his time. First among these is 'Federico Fellini' (qv). He wrote all of the movie scores for Fellini's films from _Lo sceicco bianco (1952)_ (qv) in 1952 to _Prova d'orchestra (1978)_ (qv) in 1978. Other directors include 'Renato Castellani' (qv), 'Luchino Visconti' (qv), 'Franco Zeffirelli' (qv), 'Mario Monicelli' (qv), 'Francis Ford Coppola' (qv) (Oscar for best original score for _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv)), 'King Vidor' (qv), 'Ren? Cl?ment' (qv), 'Edward Dmytryk' (qv), and 'Eduardo de Filippo'. He also composed the music for many theatre productions by Visconti, Zefirelli, and de Filippo. In February of 1995, the Nino Rota Foundation was established at Fondazione Cini of Venice, Italy. Cini specializes in the works of 20th century Italian composers and includes the estate of Casella. Nino Rota 'Difono' (Greece), January 2000, Iss. 52, pg. 105-109, by: Yorgos Notaras, '20 hronia apo to thanato tou Nino Rota' 10 April 1979 Rome, Lazio, Italy (coronary thrombosis) Giovanni Rota Rinaldi Milan, Lombardy, Italy Male _Un amico magico: il maestro Nino Rota (1999)_ (qv) Rinaldi, Giovanni Rota
Movie Episode Writer references composer   Nino Rota birth notes gender death date aka biographical movies name birth name mini biography birth date death notes article 3 December 1911 Born in Milan in 1911 into a family of musicians, Nino Rota was first a student of Orefice and Pizzetti. Then, still a child, he moved to Rome where he completed his studies at the Conservatory of Santa Cecilia in 1929 with Alfredo Casella. In the meantime, he had become an 'enfant prodige', famous both as a composer and as an orchestra conductor. His first oratorio, 'L'infanzia di San Giovanni Battista,' was performed in Milan and Paris as early as 1923 and his lyrical comedy, 'Il Principe Porcaro,' was composed in 1926. From 1930 to 1932, Nino Rota lived in the USA. He won a scholarship to the Curtis Institute of Philadelphia where he attended classes in composition taught by Rosario Scalero and classes in orchestra taught by 'Fritz Reiner' (qv). He returned to Italy and earned a degree in literature from the University of Milan. In 1937, he began a teaching career that led to the directorship of the Bari Conservatory, a title he held from 1950 until his death in 1979. After his 'childhood' compositions, Nino Rota wrote the following operas: Ariodante (Parma 1942), Torquemada (1943), Il cappello di paglia di Firenze (Palermo 1955), I due timidi (RAI 1950, London 1953), La notte di un neurastenico (Premio Italia 1959, La Scala 1960), Lo scoiattolo in gamba (Venezia 1959), Aladino e la lampada magica (Naples 1968), La visita meravigliosa (Palermo 1970), Napoli milionaria (Spoleto Festival 1977). He also wrote the following ballets: La rappresentazione di Adamo ed Eva (Perugia 1957), La Strada (La Scala 1965), Aci e Galatea (Rome 1971), Le Moli?re imaginaire (Paris and Brussels 1976) and Amor di poeta (Brussels 1978) for Maurice B?jart. In addition, there are countless works for orchestra that have been performed since before World War II and are still performed by orchestras in every part of the world. His work in film dates back to the early forties. His filmography includes the names of virtually all of the noted directors of his time. First among these is 'Federico Fellini' (qv). He wrote all of the movie scores for Fellini's films from _Lo sceicco bianco (1952)_ (qv) in 1952 to _Prova d'orchestra (1978)_ (qv) in 1978. Other directors include 'Renato Castellani' (qv), 'Luchino Visconti' (qv), 'Franco Zeffirelli' (qv), 'Mario Monicelli' (qv), 'Francis Ford Coppola' (qv) (Oscar for best original score for _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv)), 'King Vidor' (qv), 'Ren? Cl?ment' (qv), 'Edward Dmytryk' (qv), and 'Eduardo de Filippo'. He also composed the music for many theatre productions by Visconti, Zefirelli, and de Filippo. Series Producer Person writer cinematographer Ken Fournelle  Paul Chaplin birth notes gender aka name birth name birth date Ken Fournelle 1 May 19?? Paul Chaplin Paul Schersten Illinois, USA Male Schersten, Paul
Series Producer Person writer cinematographer Robert Clouse  David Eggby birth notes gender aka name trivia nick names birth date 6 March 1928 A hard-working director throughout his long and varied career, Robert Clouse is known best for his two most successful films: _Enter the Dragon (1973)_ (qv) and _Game of Death (1978_. Clouse was a director who worked mainly in the visuals of cinema, owing to the fact that he was completely deaf, he employed assistant directors who could verify that actors had delivered their lines correctly. After being hired by Warner Bros. and Golden Harvest to direct _Enter the Dragon (1973)_ (qv), Clouse was escalated into the realm of profitable directors. But, unlike others in this category, doors in Hollywood were not entirely open to him. Clouse was, in 1974, hired to direct _Black Belt Jones (1974)_ (qv) for Warner Brothers Pictures. The film proved to be a moderate success, but was seen more as a vehicle for _Enter the Dragon (1973)_ (qv) prot?g? 'Jim Kelly'. In 1978, Clouse returned to Hong Kong where he was hired by Golden Harvest's 'Raymond Chow' (qv) to direct a comeback movie for Martial Artist 'Bruce Lee', despite the fact that Lee had died five years earlier. Clouse was given the incomplete footage from Bruce Lee's original version of Game of Death, but decided that only a small amount of this footage should be used (mainly because the original film's plot had been re-created countless times in Hong Kong cinema since Lee's death). With the help of Lee companions such as 'Samo Hung' and 'Bob Wall', Clouse shot several 'Bruce Lee' lookalikes and stand-ins as well as cutting back to footage from other Lee movies and, of course, the original Game of Death takes.  Despite attempts, Clouse was unable to match the success of his two 'Bruce Lee' films later in his career. Robert Clouse, the director of the film that many call the perfect Martial Arts movie _Enter the Dragon (1973)_ (qv), died on February 4, 1997. Robert Clouse 4 February 1997 Ashland, Oregon, USA (kidney failure) _Dragon: The Bruce Lee Story (1993)_ (qv) Was a still photographer prior to directing films and TV shows. Robert Byron Clouse Wisconsin, USA Male Book: 'Bruce Lee: The Biography.' Burbank, CA: Unique Books, 1988. Clouse, Robert Byron 1950 Googy David Eggby Cinematographer on two projects titled 'Kansas': a crime feature film, released to movie houses everywhere in 1988 and a drama made for television shot in 1994. David Egby London, England, UK Male
Series Producer Person writer cinematographer W.T. Morgan  John Monsour aka name W.T. Morgan Male John Monsour Karem John Monsour
Series Producer Person writer cinematographer Elaine May  Owen Roizman birth notes gender name trivia mini biography birth date spouse article quotes 21 April 1932 Judith Coleman. _The Compass._ University of Chicago Press, 'Marvin May' (? - ?); 1 daughter 'Jeannie Berlin' (qv) Elaine May 'Film Comment' (USA), March 2006, Vol. 42, Iss. 2, pg. 46-48, 50-53, by: Chuck Stephens, 'Chronicle of a Disappearance' Her play, 'Hot Line', was nominated for a 1983 'Joseph Jefferson (I)' (qv) Award for 'New Work' at the Goodman Theatre in Chicago, Illinois. Elaine Berlin Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA Female (2002) Stage: Wrote 'Adult Entertainment', opened off-Broadway, directed by 'Stanley Donen' (qv). Berlin, Elaine 22 September 1936 'Mona Lindholm' (6 December 1964 - present); 1 child Ace cinematographer Owen Roizman was born September 22, 1936, in Brooklyn, New York. His father Sol was a cinematographer for Fox Movietone News and his uncle 'Morrie Roizman' (qv) was a film editor. Owen studied math and physics at Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania. He began his career shooting TV commercials, and made his feature debut as a director of photography with the obscure and little seen 1970 movie _Stop (1970)_ (qv). Owen brought a strong and compelling sense of raw, gritty, documentary-style realism to 'William Friedkin' (qv)'s harsh and hard-hitting police action thriller classic _The French Connection (1971)_ (qv). Roizman received a well-deserved Academy Award nomination for his outstanding visual contributions to this picture; he went on to garner four additional Oscar nominations, for _The Exorcist (1973)_ (qv), _Tootsie (1982)_ (qv), _Network (1976)_ (qv) and _Wyatt Earp (1994)_ (qv). Owen gave a similar rough and grainy look to the edgy urban thrillers _The Taking of Pelham One Two Three (1974)_ (qv) and _Straight Time (1978)_ (qv). His other films encompass an impressively diverse array of different genres which include horror ('The Exorcist'), science fiction (_The Stepford Wives (1975)_ (qv)), comedy (_The Heartbreak Kid (1972)_ (qv) 'Tootsie'), musicals (_Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band (1978)_ (qv)), drama (_True Confessions (1981)_ (qv), _Absence of Malice (1981)_ (qv)) and even Westerns (_The Return of a Man Called Horse (1976)_ (qv), 'Wyatt Earp'). His last feature to date was _French Kiss (1995)_ (qv). In the early 1980s Owen took a hiatus from shooting films and formed the commercial production company Roizman and Associates. He has directed and/or photographed hundreds of TV commercials. In 1997 he was the recipient of a Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Society of Cinematographers. Owen Roizman 'American Cinematographer' (USA), February 1997, Vol. 78, Iss. 2, pg. 40-47, by: David E. Williams, 'Chasing Greatness: The ASC fetes Owen Roizman for his diverse career of groundbreaking work with the 1997 Lifetime Achievement Award.' Member of the Board of Governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (Cinematographers Branch) [2002-] When I was nominated for an Oscar for _The French Connection (1971)_ (qv), I couldn't believe it. I thought I was fooling everyone. You know, I still feel that way. In fact, when I was nominated for the fifth time for _Wyatt Earp (1994)_ (qv), the first thing my wife said was, 'Well, you fooled them again'. Brooklyn, New York City, New York, USA Male
Series Producer Person writer cinematographer Peter Salim  William Link birth notes gender other works aka name trivia birth date spouse interviews 10 May 1939 Peter Salim 19 February 1994 Los Angeles California, USA (heart attack) Had been a member of the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC) since 1992. Video Game Producer TV Movie Director composer writer Ian Fleming   Tim Jones birth notes aka name birth date spouse height 'Anne Geraldine Charteris' (24 March 1952 - 12 August 1964) (his death); 1 child Canterbury, Kent, England, UK (heart attack) His wife, Anne Geraldine Charteris, was the granddaughter of the 9th Earl of Wemyss, and had been previously married to Shane O'Neill, 3rd Lord O'Neill (she was his widow) and then to Esmond Cecil Harmsworth, 2nd Viscount Rothermere, whom she divorced to marry Ian. Anne and Ian had one son, Casper Robert Fleming, born 12th of August 1952. I wanted the simplest, dullest, plainest-sounding name I could find, James Bond was much better than something more interesting like 'Peregrine Maltravers.' Exotic things would happen to and around him but he would be a neutral figure - an anonymous blunt instrument wielded by a Government Department. (1965) Novel (published posthumously): 'The Man With The Golden Gun' (filmed as _The Man with the Golden Gun (1974)_ (qv)) _'Explorations' (1956) {Ian Fleming: The Brain Behind Bond}_ (qv) 28 May 1908 'John Pearson (III)' (qv). _The Life of Ian Fleming._ London, England: Jonathon Cape Ltd., 1966. Born into a wealthy and influential English family, Ian Fleming spent his early years attending top British schools such as Eton and Sandhurst military academy. He took to writing while schooling in Kitzbuhel, Austria, and upon failing the entrance requirements for Foreign Service joined the news agency Reuters as a journalist -- winning the respect of his peers for his coverage of a 'show trial' in Russia of several Royal Engineers on espionage charges. Fleming briefly worked in the financial sector for the family bank, but just prior to the Second World War, was recruited into British Naval Intelligence where he excelled, shortly achieving the rank of Commander. When the war ended, Fleming retired to Jamaica where he built a house called 'Goldeneye,' took up writing full-time and created the character that would make him famous -- British Secret Service agent James Bond, in a novel called 'Casino Royale.' Fleming spent the rest of his life writing and traveling the world, but as his Bond character reached new heights of popularity on movie screens, Fleming was in ailing health. He died of a heart attack (his second) in England in August 1964 at the age of 56. Ian Fleming 'The New York Times' (USA), 19 May 2008, Vol. 157, Iss. 54,315, pg. E1 & E6, by: John F. Burns, 'Remembering Fleming, Ian Fleming' 12 August 1964 _Goldeneye (1989) (TV)_ (qv) Cigarette (in holder) perched between fingers of his right hand 'The Times Magazine' (UK), 5 April 2008 Ian Lancaster Fleming 6' Mayfair, London, England, UK Male 1971 'Evelyn Jones' (1996 - present); 2 children Tim Jones Timothy Jones 6' 4' Mission Viejo, California, USA

She held stock in a company called ImClone and had a close relationship with the firm's CEO. She sold all her stock holdings shortly before the firm suffered a severe financial setback and its stock price plummeted so low as to make the stock virtually worthless. The government, and her stockbroker's assistant, said it was because she got inside information from her CEO friend. Stewart said it was a coincidence and her broker had orders to sell the stock when it fell to a certain price. The investigation is continuing. Christopher M. A proud Southern California native, Chad began his career early with the help of producer aunt, Patricia Friedman. Son of Kentucky born contractor Stephen Doreck and Chicago born homemaker Catherine Doreck, Chad is brother to Holly Doreck and former actor Stephen Doreck Jr. He graduated from the prestigious Orange County High School of the Arts where he majored in Musical Theater and briefly attended USC. He studies acting at The Gloria Gifford Conservatory for the Arts and singing with Evelyn Halus. Asside from pursuing a career in acting, Chad is also working on a career as a singer, having written, produced, and sung on his first funk music CD in 2005. Producer  Lennox Lewis gender other works trivia spouse quotes interviews birth notes aka name birth name where now mini biography birth date height pictorial 'Playboy' (USA), April 2002, Vol. 49, Iss. 4, pg. 63-68+147-149, by: Kevin Cook, 'Playboy Interview: Lennox Lewis' 'Violet Chang' (15 July 2005 - present); 2 children First child, son Landon, born in June 2004. 'Playboy' (USA), November 1993, Vol. 40, Iss. 11, pg. 116-117, by: Hollis Wayne, 'Robe Warrior' I always ask myself why old heavyweights come back, but I plan to stay out of the ring. I've got a new life now, a new future, there's a lot more to Lennox Lewis than just being a boxer. I am very sure about my decision. TV and internet commercials for Red Stripe beer. (2004) Lewis, Lennox Claudius 2 September 1965 (February 2004) Announced his retirement from boxing stating he 'had nothing left to prove.' After a long amateur career that included a gold medal winning performance in the 1988 Seoul Olympics that came in the form of a KO of 'Riddick Bowe' (who also went on to win the world heavyweight crown), former undisputed world heavyweight boxing champion Lennox Lewis turned professional in 1989. His 2 round win over Canadian boxer Donnovan Ruddock in Oct of 1992 gained him recognition as a threat among the tough heavyweight ranks. Lewis, a citizen of England and Canada, was slated for a shot at the winner of 'Evander Holyfield' (qv) vs Riddick Bowe. Bowe, a victim of a brutal knockout suffered at the hands of Lewis in the amateur ranks, refused to live up to his end of the bargain by not giving Lewis a well-deserved title shot and infamously tossed the WBC title in a garbage bin. This act prompted the WBC commission to strip Bowe and crown Lewis as the new WBC champion. Lennox Lewis went on to defend the crown for several fights until he was defeated by Oliver McCall in 2 rounds in Sept of 1994. Lewis, with the help of new trainer 'Emanuel Steward' (qv), came back and began tearing his way through the ranks of the heavyweight division. Lewis was again denied a title shot when champion 'Mike Tyson (I)' (qv) relinquished his WBC title to fight 'Evander Holyfield' (qv) rather than risk his titles against Lewis. Lewis recaptured the vacant WBC title by beating his conquerer Oliver McCall in a rematch. Lewis, after defeating every top contender thrown his way, was given his shot at 'Evander Holyfield' (qv) in a championship unification fight on March 13, 1999. Lewis dominated the fight but due to controversial judging, the bout was declared a draw. Lewis defeated 'Evander Holyfield' (qv) in a rematch on Nov 13, 1999 to become undisputed world champion. Due to promoter 'Don King (I)' (qv)'s underhanded tactics, the WBA belt was stripped from Lewis in court. Lewis went on to beat every mandatory challenger while keeping his crown. While avidly issuing challenges to reluctant contender 'Mike Tyson (I)' (qv), Lewis went to Johannesburg in South Africa at the invitation of 'Nelson Mandela' (qv). Lewis would defend his titles against supposed low-risk opponent Hasim Rahman. Due to Lewis' failure to prepare for the fight by dropping excessive weight rapidly, arriving in Johannesburg 2 weeks before the fight which, according to expert opinion, was too late to acclimatize to the thin air since Johannesburg was 5,000 feet above sea level, Lewis suffered one of the biggest upsets in boxing history. However, Lewis has had his rematch with Hashim Rahman and won the title back, and he also fought 'Mike Tyson (I)' (qv) and beaten him 'easily' in 8 rounds. Lennox Lewis Lennox Claudius Lewis 6' 5' London, England, UK Male

(2010) TV commercial for Comcast XFINITY Pugh, Zachary Levi 29 September 1980 Zach The middle child between two sisters, Zachary Levi was born September 29, 1980 in Lake Charles, Louisiana. He grew up all over the country before his family put down roots in Ventura County, California. At the early age of six, Zachary began acting, singing and dancing in school and local theater productions.  After graduating from Buena High School, he headed to Los Angeles to pursue his dream of acting. Zachary began acting in theater, performing roles in such regional productions like Grease, The Outsiders, Oliver, The Wizard of Oz and Big River. It was his portrayal of Jesus in Ojai's Godspell that brought him to the attention of Hollywood.  Most recently he completed a supporting role in the television movie _Big Shot: Confessions of a Campus Bookie (2002) (TV)_ (qv) with 'David Krumholtz (I)' (qv), 'Tory Kittles (I)' (qv), 'Jennifer Morrison (II)' (qv) and 'Nicholas Turturro' (qv).  He then began acting as Kipp Steadman in the TV series _'Less Than Perfect' (2002)_ (qv) with 'Sara Rue' (qv), 'Andrea Parker (I)' (qv), 'Eric Roberts (I)' (qv), 'Andy Dick (I)' (qv) and 'Sherri Shepherd' (qv).  He recently was seen in the television movie _See Jane Date (2003) (TV)_ (qv) on the WB with 'Charisma Carpenter' (qv), 'Holly Marie Combs' (qv), 'Linda Dano' (qv) and 'Rachelle Lefevre' (qv). In his spare time, Zachary enjoys skateboarding, snowboarding, skydiving and participating in various other sports. He lives in Los Angeles. Company Work Person production company producer  Thom Oliphant Cloudland Filmworks [US] name Thom has spent a decade as a producer, executive producer, and show runner for major network and cable series. He began his career as a music video director. He has worked with who's who list of music superstars from BB King to Faith Hill, Bruce Springsteen to Shania Twain and the Dixie Chicks to Metallica. As a director, he has won awards for excellence, like the Country Music Association Video of the Year, a Clio, a Canadian Country Music Association Award, multiple Addys, and several Billboard Awards. After over 200 music videos and 100 commercial campaigns, he segued into TV. He has worked on big formats and music competition series (CMT's Can You Duet and Fox's Next Great American Band) and lately he has turned his focus has been on telling stories (CMT's Posse). Thom Oliphant Cloudland Filmworks [US]

Company Work Person production company producer Bob Hope  Hope Enterprises [US] name 'Playboy' (USA), December 1973, Vol. 20, Iss. 12, pg. 97-110, by: William Murray, 'Playboy Interview:Bob Hope' 'Dolores Hope' (qv) (19 February 1934 - 27 July 2003) (his death); 4 children Toluca Lake, California, USA (pneumonia) He was awarded 4 Stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for Motion Pictures at 6541 Hollywood Boulevard; for Radio at 6141 Hollywood Boulevard; for Live Theatre at 7021 Hollywood Boulevard; and for Television at 6758 Hollywood Boulevard in Hollywood, California. 'Look' (USA), 13 March 1951 [on 'Vincent Price (I)' (qv)] He always loved a good joke. Moreover, he was kind enough to laugh at jokes that weren't so good. (1973) Album: 'Holidays' (Spear Records 4700), consisted of holiday-themed monologues from previous specials _'Biography' (1987) {Bob Hope: America's Entertainer}_ (qv) Hope, Leslie Townes 29 May 1903 Old Ski Nose Bob Hope with Linda Hope. _Bob Hope: My Life in Jokes._ New York: Hyperion Books, 2003. ISBN 1-4013-0095-2 Comedian, born in London and moved to Bristol before emigrating with his parents to the US in 1908. After some years on the stage as a dancer and comedian, he made his first film appearance in _The Big Broadcast of 1938 (1938)_ (qv) singing 'Thanks for the Memory,' which became his signature tune. In partnership with 'Bing Crosby' (qv) and 'Dorothy Lamour' (qv), he appeared in the highly successful 'Road to ...' comedies (1940-1952), and in many others until the early 1970s. During World War II and the Korean and Vietnam wars he spent much time entertaining the troops in the field. For these activities and for his continued contributions to the industry he was given a special Academy Award on five occasions. (1936). Stage Play: Ziegfeld Follies of 1936 [return engagement]. Music by 'Vernon Duke' (qv). Lyrics by 'Ira Gershwin' (qv). Based on material by David Freeman. Musical Director: John McManus. Produced by 'Billie Burke' (qv) Ziegfeld. De Cordova, Frederick Timmins 27 October 1910 Fred Frederick de Cordova. _Johnny Came Lately ._ New York: 1998. Educated at Northwestern University, Frederick De Cordova began his show business career on the stage, and came to Hollywood in the mid-'40s as a dialogue director. He graduated to director in 1945. He spent much of his career at Universal Pictures, where he turned out medium-budget westerns, comedies and musicals. In the mid-'50s he turned his main focus to television, directing and producing _'The George Burns and Gracie Allen Show' (1950)_ (qv), _'The Jack Benny Program' (1950)_ (qv) and _'December Bride' (1954)_ (qv). Although he directed an occasional feature, he was much more successful on TV, and in 1971 became executive producer of the long-running late-night talk show _'The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson' (1962)_ (qv). Frederick De Cordova 15 September 2001 _Talk to Me (2007)_ (qv) Frederick Timmins De Cordova New York City, New York, USA Male

Movie Country Person production designer country Andy Walmsley    Andy Walmsley
Movie Country Person production designer country     
Movie Country Person production designer country Steve Bass    Multi-Emmy Award winner Steve Bass has designed many of the most prestigious live and televised shows produced, including the Oscars, Grammys, Emmys and Tony Awards. His talents were tapped for the Opening and Closing Ceremonies of the Atlanta Olympics, Salt Lake Olympics Medals Plaza, The Democratic Convention, Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus, and the Inaugural Celebration at the Lincoln Memorial for President Obama.  Live show design includes mega hits from Disney: the Lion King Celebration and a theatrical production of The Little Mermaid which to date has been seen by over 25 million guests, as well as the national tour of Disney's Symphonic Fantasy and Sesame Street Live. Recent live productions include DreamWorks Madagascar Live!, Disney's Mad T Party: an innovative experiential nightclub, and the award-winning Starlight Parade for Universal Studios Japan.  Steve has a long-standing history designing for iconic entertainment programs such as Great Performances, Nickelodeon's Kids Choice, Christmas in Washington, TV Land, and Entertainment Tonight, as well as corporate events for auto giants Lexus and Toyota. Steve Bass

Movie Country Person production designer country   Roy Christopher gender other works biographical movies name trivia quotes Roy Christopher Attended California State University, Fresno. I grew up as a farm boy in Fresno, which is an agricultural town plunked in the middle of California--thousands of miles mentally from Hollywood. I'd watch the Academy Awards and it was such a magical event. I really wanted to be part of that world, like everyone does. Movie Production Designer Person editor cinematographer Jim Yockey Brent Carpenter   Jim Yockey Brent directed a wide range of productions over the last several years including the darkly humorous _'Greg the Bunny' (2002)_ (qv), _'Caroline in the City' (1995)_ (qv), 'The Hollywood Bowl Hall of Fame', _'America's Greatest Pets' (1998)_ (qv), _'Union Square' (1997)_ (qv) and 'How To Lose Friends and Irritate People'. Brent also directed a special '50th Birthday Film' for Billy Crystal's birthday party, starring Rob Reiner, Martin Short and Christopher Guest among many others.  Brent was Emmy and Grammy nominated in 1998 as co-producer on the Robert Altman film _'Great Performances' (1970) {Robert Altman's Jazz '34 (#25.13)}_ (qv). He also oversaw the editing of this jazz spectacular, featuring a number of current jazz greats portraying jazz stars of the 1930s. In addition he produced and directed the short films 'Extras', _Chantmania: The Benzedrine Monks of Santo Damonica (1994) (V)_ (qv), _The Fan (1995) (V)_ (qv) starring Judy Tenuta and 'Exceeding Expectations' with Harry Anderson. Brent was a featured director on 'The Dog & Pony Show' broadcast. He worked as sketch director on the 'Stephanie Miller Show', and he served as co-producer on Harry Anderson's CBS special 'Tricks Of His Trade'. Brent served as co-producer and editor on the first season of _'The Larry Sanders Show' (1992)_ (qv) helping to create the backstage look that served the show so well. He was one of a number of producers and the editor on the CBS comedy _'Dave's World' (1993)_ (qv), and has long been involved in the world of comedy. He also served in that capacity on the critically acclaimed HBO series _'Sessions' (1991)_ (qv) created by 'Billy Crystal' (qv).  Brent is also heavily involved in the world of music, directing and producing music videos for a number of alternative country and folk acts, including Dale Watson and Chuck E. Weiss.  Brent started in television as a news photographer in Phoenix and Minneapolis. Before becoming involved with television, he was a roustabout in the Tulsa oil fields and cooked hamburgers. He prefers television. Brent Carpenter Male

Movie Production Designer Person editor cinematographer Robert Draper  Mark W. Rosenbaum aka name 'Fangoria Horror Spectacular' (USA), 1991, Iss. 4, pg. 10-13, by: Mark Cerulli, 'Lighting the Crypt' With more than 35 years experience in Film and Television, Rob has worked on everything from Regional TV News to Hollywood Feature Films.  Known as a technical innovator and creative risk taker in the industry he has pioneered many new techniques and worked on development of motion picture products for SONY, Panasonic, Fuji Film, Arri and Zeiss. Rob was also the first to run a full scale Hi Definition shoot in Hollywood on the then 'new gen' camera's.  Rob set the style for what has become known as Reality TV in a groundbreaking series he shot for Universal called 'The Street'...after which the New York Times declared 'the show practically creates a new visual language'. Rob also worked on some of the first Music Videos used to promote feature Films and developed a visual style for using promotional music videos for retailing in a 5 minute Hollywood extravaganza for Coca Cola.  Rob's photography on the Sundance Audience award winner, The Spitfire Grill, drew accolades worldwide.  Rob draws inspiration from the classic painters and his skilled and delicate use of light and shade as integral elements of composition sets his work apart. Over the past 20 years he has inspired thousand of cinematographers worldwide as a dynamic instructor at workshops, and as a consultant, on the art of film lighting  More recently he has been on the cutting edge of digital technology on the web with his groundbreaking IPTV channel Singlemalt TV. Launched in 2006 it immediately drew attention and a long relationship with major media players in UK.  Rob has worked worldwide on TV movies,Feature Films,Mini Series,TV series documentaries, TV Commercials and Music Videos. He has worked for every major Hollywood studio and US TV Network claiming multiple Awards in both Australia and the United States. Robert Draper 'Imagine News' (USA), June 2002, by: 'Eric Harper (I)' (qv), 'Rob Draper: New England Cinematography on the Cutting Edge' 'Imagine News' (USA), June 2002 Male Mark W. Rosenbaum Mark Rosenbaum

Language Work Person producer language   Thom Oliphant name mini biography Thom has spent a decade as a producer, executive producer, and show runner for major network and cable series. He began his career as a music video director. He has worked with who's who list of music superstars from BB King to Faith Hill, Bruce Springsteen to Shania Twain and the Dixie Chicks to Metallica. As a director, he has won awards for excellence, like the Country Music Association Video of the Year, a Clio, a Canadian Country Music Association Award, multiple Addys, and several Billboard Awards. After over 200 music videos and 100 commercial campaigns, he segued into TV. He has worked on big formats and music competition series (CMT's Can You Duet and Fox's Next Great American Band) and lately he has turned his focus has been on telling stories (CMT's Posse). Thom Oliphant

I'm a writer who just happens to draw Writes and draws the widely syndicated cartoon strip 'Life in Hell' (1978-present). Groening, Matthew Abram 15 February 1954 Growing up in Portland, Oregon, Matt Groening did not particularly like school, which is what originally turned him towards drawing. In the mid-1980s, he moved to Los Angeles and started drawing a comic strip named 'Life in Hell', which eventually became published in the newspaper where he worked. In 1988, 'James L. Brooks' (qv), looking for a filler in the television show, _'The Tracey Ullman Show' (1987)_ (qv), turned towards a framed 'Life in Hell' strip on his wall and contacted Groening. The animated shorts that Groening created were _'The Simpsons' (1989)_ (qv). Matt Groening 'Simpsons Illustrated' (USA), Summer 1993, Vol. 1, Iss. 9, pg. 24-30, by: Jamie Angell, 'Explaining Groening: One-on-one with the sultan of fun' His characters' middle name often begins with the letter 'J', e.g. Homer J(ay) Simpson, Bart J(ojo) Simpsons, Philip J. Series Actor Person actor writer Mike Colasuonno Jay Leno   Mike Colasuonno 'Entrevue' (France), April 1999, Iss. 81, pg. 87, by: Pierre Blois, 'La star tele' 'Mavis Leno' (qv) (30 November 1980 - present) Raised in Andover, Massachusetts. 'Playboy' (USA), December 1986, Vol. 33, Iss. 12, pg. 86-87, by: Mario Casilli, 'Tango Americano' Some sad news: President Bush's lapdog passed away. Gee, I didn't even know Tony Blair was sick. (1987) TV commercial: Doritos Cool Ranch flavored tortilla chips Leno, James Douglas Muir 28 April 1950 (2007) Release of the book, 'Eddie Krumble is the Clapper' by Dito Montiel. Bill Carfter. _The War for Late Night: When Leno Went Early and Television Went Crazy._ 2010. Jay Leno began his career in night clubs, where he worked 300 nights a year before hitting it big in 1992 with his own late-night talk show, _'The Tonight Show with Jay Leno' (1992)_ (qv). By that time he had appeared on television, acted in a few films (_American Hot Wax (1978)_ (qv)) but hit paydirt with his late-night television appearances (he made a record number of visits to _'Late Night with David Letterman' (1982)_ (qv)); for several years, he served as 'Johnny Carson (I)' (qv)'s permanent guest host on _'The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson' (1962)_ (qv). A big, sweet guy with a very good comedy routine, he vied with 'David Letterman' (qv) to inherit Carson's seat when Johnny retired in 1992. His victory was well-publicized, but empty, though he did gain a measure of revenge when his show beat Letterman's for the Emmy in 1995. Though he consistently lost in the ratings to Letterman except on special occasions, like 'Hugh Grant (I)' (qv)'s first TV appearance after his encounter with 'Divine Brown (I)' (qv), he surged ahead in 1996, as CBS plunged further into oblivion. Jay Leno 'TV Guide' (USA), 18 July 2004, Vol. 52, Iss. 29, pg. 23, by: Diane Clehane, Ron LaFranco, Cathy Piedmont, 'Hey, Big Spenders!' _Dawn of the Dead (2004)_ (qv) His large chin 'Rolling Stone' (USA), 2 November 1989 James Douglas Muir Leno 5' 11' New Rochelle, New York, USA Male

Series Actor Person actor writer Johnny Cash  Morgan Neville birth notes other works name birth date 'Penthouse' (USA), August 1975, Vol. 6, Iss. 72, pg. 64-66, by: Larry Linderman 'Vivian Liberto' (7 August 1954 - August 1966) (divorced); 4 children Nashville, Tennessee, USA (complications from diabetes) He was awarded a Star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for Recording at 6320 Hollywood Boulevard in Hollywood, California. 'Bart Smit' (Netherlands), 11 June 2012 How well I have learned that there is no fence to sit on between heaven and hell. There is a deep, wide gulf, a chasm, and in that chasm is no place for any man. CD: 'Unchained' _Johnny Cash: The Anthology (2000) (V)_ (qv) Cash, J. R. 26 February 1932 Man In Black (2007) Release of her book, 'I Walked the Line: My Life with Johnny' by his first wife, Vivian Cash, with 'Anne Sharpsteen' (qv). Vivian died in 2005. John L. Smith. _Another Song to Sing: The Recorded Repertoire of Johnny Cash._ Lanham, MD: Scarecrow Press, 1999. ISBN 0810836297 Johnny Cash was born February 26, 1932, in Kingsland, Arkansas. He made his first single, 'Hey Porter', for Sun Records in 1955. In 1958 he moved to Columbia Records. He had long periods of drug abuse during the 1960s, but later that decade he successfully fought his addiction with the help of singer 'June Carter Cash' (qv), whom he married in 1968. In 1971 he appeared in the western _A Gunfight (1971)_ (qv) with 'Kirk Douglas (I)' (qv). Cash made a few films but quite a few appearances on television, both in series and made-for-TV films, and was especially effective as a rural Southern sheriff in the 1930s determined to bring to justice a wealthy landowner who committed murder because he believed he was above the law, in _Murder in Coweta County (1983) (TV)_ (qv), a drama based on a true story. In 1975 Cash wrote his autobiography, 'Man In Black', which is now out of print. In the late 1980s he moved from Columbia Records to Mercury, then in the next decade moved again to American Recordings.  Amonst his biggest hit records was 'I Walk the Line', 'Ring of Fire' and 'A Boy Named Sue'.  After several years of ill health, he died of complications from diabetes on 12 September 2003, only a few months after the death of his beloved wife. Johnny Cash 'AD Rotterdams Dagblad' (Netherlands), April 2012, 'Het Evangelie volgens Cash' 12 September 2003 _I Still Miss Someone (1999)_ (qv) Many of his songs are about outlaws or tough men who have had hard lives 'AD Rotterdams Dagblad' (Netherlands), April 2012 J. R. Series Actor Person actor writer Gregg Rogell  Jimmy Brogan birth notes gender name trivia birth date magazine cover photo height portrayed in 18 February 1967 Gregg Rogell Long Island, New York, USA Male 18 September 1948 Jimmy Brogan _The Late Shift (1996) (TV)_ (qv) Jimmy Brogan served as a writer for the opening monologue on 'The Tonight Show with Jay Leno'. Jimmy would sit to one side of the audience while Jay told his jokes. On occasion, Jimmy and Jay would make a bet to see if a certain joke worked or not. If Jimmy won, Jay would walk down the stage, and pay Jimmy. If Jay won, Jimmy would come to the stage and pay off the bet. All this was done while the camera was running.
