Series Actor Person actor writer Waylon Jennings  Morgan Neville birth notes other works name birth date 'Maxine Lawrence' (1956 - ?) (divorced); 3 children Chandler, Arizona, USA (diabetes-related illness) Named Male Vocalist of the Year by the Country Music Association in 1975. [1984, in an interview in the CMA's 'Close Up' magazine] I did more drugs than anybody you ever saw in your life. Album: 'Nashville Rebel' _Waylon: Renegade. Outlaw. Legend. (2002) (V)_ (qv) Jennings, Waylon Arnold 15 June 1937 Hoss Waylon Jennings. _Waylon._ Warner Publications Jennings, a singer, songwriter and guitarist, recorded 60 albums and had 16 No. 1 country singles in a career that spanned five decades. He was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in October 2001. With pal 'Willie Nelson' (qv), Jennings performed duets like 'Mammas Don't Let Your Babies Grow Up to Be Cowboys', 'Luckenbach' and 'Good Hearted Woman'. Those 1970s songs nurtured a progressive sound and restless spirit embraced later by 'Travis Tritt' (qv), 'Charlie Daniels (I)' (qv), 'Steve Earle (I)' (qv) and others. His resonant, authoritative voice also was used to narrate the popular TV show _'The Dukes of Hazzard' (1979)_ (qv). He sang its theme song, which was a million seller. 'I aimed the narration at children and it made it work,' he said in a 1987 AP interview. He traditionally wore a black cowboy hat and ebony attire that accented his black beard and mustache. Often reclusive when not on stage, he played earthy music with a spirited, hard edge. Combined, Jennings had a well-defined image that matched well with his history of battling record producers to do music his way. About his independence, he said: 'There's always one more way to do something-- your way.' Some of his album titles nourished his brash persona: 'Lonesome, On'ry and Mean,' 'I've Always Been Crazy,' 'Nashville Rebel,' 'Ladies Love Outlaws' and 'Wanted: The Outlaws.' He often refused to attend music awards shows on grounds performers should not compete against each other. Despite those sentiments, Jennings won two Grammy awards and four Country Music Association awards. He did not attend his induction into the Country Music Hall of Fame last year. In 1959, his career was nearly cut short by tragedy. He was scheduled to fly on the light plane that crashed and killed 'Buddy Holly' (qv), 'Ritchie Valens' and 'The Big Bopper' (qv). Jennings gave up his seat on the plane to 'The Big Bopper' (qv), who was ill and wanted to fly rather than travel by bus with those left behind. He and Holly were teen-age friends in Lubbock, Texas, and Jennings was in Holly's band. 'Mainly what I learned from Buddy was an attitude,' Jennings said. 'He loved music, and he taught me that it shouldn't have any barriers to it.' Born in Littlefield, Texas, Jennings became a radio disc jockey at 14 and formed his own band not long afterward. By the early 1960s Jennings was playing regularly at a nightclub in Phoenix. In 1963, he was signed by 'Herb Alpert''s A&M Records, then was signed by RCA in Nashville shortly thereafter by 'Chet Atkins (I)' (qv). Once in Nashville, he and Cash became friends and roommates. His hit records began in the mid-1960s and his heyday was the mid-1970s. About his outlaw image, he said: 'It was a good marketing tool. In a way, I am that way. You start messing with my music, I get mean. As long was you are honest and up front with me, I will be the same with you. But I still do things my way.' Waylon Jennings 'The Washington Post' (USA), 15 February 2002, pg. C1+C4, by: Richard Harrington, 'Appreciation: The Renegade Who Rocked Nashville' 13 February 2002 _'Screen Two' (1985) {Words of Love (#5.4)}_ (qv) Waylon Arnold Jennings 6' 0 1/2' Littlefield, Texas, USA Male 10 October 1967 Morgan Neville Los Angeles, California, USA Produced, directed 90-min documentary 'Hitmakers: The Teens Who Stole Pop Music' (2001), premiered May 3, 2001 at Museum of TV and Radio documentary festival in New York City.

Video Game Episode Producer Director editor composer Arthur Schmidt   Tim Jones birth notes aka name birth date spouse height 17 June 1937 Arthur Schmidt Arthur Robert Schmidt Los Angeles, California, USA Male Schmidt, Arthur Robert 1971 'Evelyn Jones' (1996 - present); 2 children Tim Jones Timothy Jones 6' 4' Mission Viejo, California, USA
Video Game Episode Producer Director editor composer Arthur Schmidt  Trevor Rabin   17 June 1937 Arthur Schmidt Arthur Robert Schmidt Los Angeles, California, USA Male Schmidt, Arthur Robert 13 January 1954 'Shelley Rabin' (1979 - present); 1 child Trevor Rabin was born in South Africa in 1954. He began playing guitar at the age of 12 after having had piano lessons since he was a toddler. In 1972 he formed the band Rabbit becoming the most successful rock act ever to emerge from South Africa. Rabin left Rabbit to pursue a solo career in London and released three solo albums.  Rabin moved to Los Angeles in 1982. Here he became a member of the newly reformed progressive art/rock group Yes for the groundbreaking 90125 album as a guitarist, keyboardist, singer, songwriter, producer and recording engineer. He penned the majority of the songs on 90125 as well as Big Generator and Talk, before leaving Yes in 1994 to pursue a career as a film composer.  Rabin has scored three dozen films which include Con Air, Homegrown, Armageddon, Enemy of the State, Jack Frost, Deep Blue Sea, Gone in 60 Seconds, Remember the Titans, The 6th Day, The Banger Sisters, Kangaroo Jack, Bad Boys 2, The Great Raid, Exorcist: The Beginning, National Treasure, Coach Carter, Snakes On A Plane, The Guardian, and Flyboys.  Along with many Grammy nominations and one win, Mr. Rabin also has received nine BMI film score awards, and has received a lifetime achievement award from the Temecula Film Festival. Trevor Rabin Wrote the number one hit Owner of a Lonely Heart. Trevor Charles Rabin I love being in a band. I love that collaborative spirit, although some would suggest that I don't get involved in the collaborative spirit, but it's not true. Johannesburg, South Africa Male

Video Game Episode Producer Director editor composer Arthur Schmidt Michael Stearns    17 June 1937 Arthur Schmidt Arthur Robert Schmidt Los Angeles, California, USA Male Schmidt, Arthur Robert Michael Stearns is one of the finest musicians and synthesizer wizards to work in the so-called, poorly defined new age music genre (his specialty is ambient music, which was pioneered by 'Brian Eno' (qv)), and his music is absolutely a positive asset to any film soundtrack and a credit to the producers of films featuring his work.  Having begun his musical career as a rock musician in Los Angeles, California, in the early 1970s, and influenced by progressive rock artists such as Pink Floyd, Stearns started up his own record label in 1977, Continuum Montage, to produce his own works and others', and market them at new age outlets around the United States such as bookstores and record stores, recording the amazing sounds he produced with profundity on his mighty Serge synthesizer. His first work of note was his lush thematic opus 'Ancient Leaves' (1977), and many more followed on inexpensive but digitally mastered high-output cassette tapes until the advent of CDs in the early 1980s.  By far the most compelling and brilliant of his early musical works is the masterful, awe-inspiring opus 'Planetary Unfolding' (1981), which is the soundtrack for a nonexistent stream-of-consciousness imaginary movie voyage through space. One hears echoes of science fiction classics such as 'Louis Barron (I)' (qv)'s and 'Bebe Barron' (qv)'s marvelous tonalities heard on the score of _Forbidden Planet (1956)_ (qv) and 'Bernard Herrmann (I)' (qv)'s dramatic invasion thesis, _The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951)_ (qv), interwoven as vibratory patterns in his works like this showing a subtle influence into his creative genius. Stearns broke new ground as an avant-garde performance artist as well with his expansive, futuristic album 'Lyra Sound Constellation' (1983), which used George Landry's musical instrument of the title as his vehicle for new musical expressions.  In 1984, Stearns signed with a new record label, Sonic Atmospheres, quietly closed down his indie label, and released his first major film soundtrack for Ron Fricke's IMAX presentation _Chronos (1985)_ (qv). Since these auspicious beginnings, Stearns has distinguished himself among his peers such as Tangerine Dream, 'Vangelis' (qv) and 'Kitar? (I)' (qv) for continually pushing the envelope and expanding the public consciousness to show what music is and can be, to the infinity of the universe. Michael Stearns Female

Video Game Episode Producer Director editor composer Arthur Schmidt  Brad Fiedel   17 June 1937 Arthur Schmidt Arthur Robert Schmidt Los Angeles, California, USA Male Schmidt, Arthur Robert 10 March 1951 'Ann Dusenberry' (qv) (? - present) Extremely talented, prolific and versatile composer Brad Fiedel was born on March 10, 1951 in New York City. His mother was a dancer and his father was a composer and musician. Brad started out as a keyboardist for 'Hall & Oates' (qv). Fiedel first began composing music for movies in the mid-70s for such low-budget pictures as _The Astrologer (1975/I)_ (qv), _Deadly Hero (1975)_ (qv) and the raunchy _Jaws (1975)_ (qv) porno parody _Gums (1976)_ (qv). Although best known for his strong, lively and driving scores for action movies and thrillers, Brad has displayed considerable range and skill with his equally fine scores for dramas (_Immediate Family (1989)_ (qv) and _The Accused (1988)_ (qv)), comedies (_Straight Talk (1992)_ (qv) and _Fraternity Vacation (1985)_ (qv)) and numerous made-for-TV features. Fiedel is widely regarded as a vital and creative pioneer for his expert and innovative use of electronic instruments and synthesizers in his music. Brad achieved his greatest success with the incredibly powerful and hard-charging metallic score for _The Terminator (1984)_ (qv) -- he was deservedly nominated for a Saturn Award for Best Music for his outstanding and unforgettable work -- and its sequel _Terminator 2: Judgment Day (1991)_ (qv). He collaborated with 'Terminator' director 'James Cameron (I)' (qv) a third time on the blockbuster smash _True Lies (1994)_ (qv). In addition, Fiedel supplied the chillingly effective scores for the horror pictures _Just Before Dawn (1981)_ (qv), _Eyes of Fire (1983)_ (qv), _Fright Night (1985)_ (qv), the Made-for-TV _The Midnight Hour (1985) (TV)_ (qv) and _The Serpent and the Rainbow (1988)_ (qv). He's also written and/or performed songs that are featured on several film soundtracks. Alas, Brad Fiedel retired from composing scores for both theatrical features and made-for-TV movies, alike, in the late 90s. He's married to actress 'Ann Dusenberry' (qv). Brad Fiedel His most famous piece is the _The Terminator (1984)_ (qv) theme tune. Brad Ira Fiedel New York City, New York, USA Male (1980) Composed music for tag of 'Lightstorm Entertainment', 'James Cameron (I)' (qv)'s production company. Fiedel, Brad Ira

Episode Production Designer Character null actress Dana Ivey    12 August 1941 (May 2005) Currently serving on the National Council of the Actors' Equity Association. Dana Ivey was born in Atlanta, Georgia. She decided at age six that she wanted to act, and throughout school she pursued it. She majored in theatre at Rollins College in Florida. She received a grant to study drama in England at the London Academy of Music and Art. She has received critical acclaim on the stage, winning many honors, such as a Tony Nomination, an Outer Critics award, a Drama Desk Award. She has appeared on such television shows as _'Law & Order' (1990)_ (qv) and _'Frasier' (1993)_ (qv). She currently lives in New York City. Dana Ivey Nominated for the 2005 Tony Award (New York City) for Supporting or Features Actress in a Drama for 'The Rivals'. Series Person writer  Michael Barrie Steve Young name trivia mini biography spouse Michael Barrie Mike Barrie Male 'Samantha' (1989 - present); 2 children Steve Young is a multi-talented, award-winning writer who refuses let himself be limited by any medium or arena. In film, he wrote and directed the scathing, but on the money satire, 'My Dinner With Ovitz.' On TV his credits include ABC's 'Boy Meets World', CBS's 'Cybill,' HBO Family's 'Crashbox', the WB's 'Family Affair' or Disney's 'The Smart Guy', for which he was recently acknowledged for his 'creation of entertainment that also enriches life,' with the Prism Award and a Humanitas nomination. He's authored the inspiring book 'Great Failures Of The Extremely Successful' (Tallfellow Press, Fall 2002) where he was able to get the greats of many different fields to share their remarkable stories of adversity. Of 'Great Failures...', Jack Canfield, co-creator of 'Chicken Soup For The Soul' said, 'When you finish reading this amazing book, you will never let failure or fear of failure stand in your way again.' Steve has more than shown his grasp of creating stories and characters that both entertain and enlighten (without it being jammed down our children's throats) in his children's picture book series, 'What If There Were No...?' (Smallfellow, 2003) and his first novel, 'The 130 Tales of Winchell Mink' (Harper Collins, 2003). This former stand-up comedian's social and political satire has been recognized as some of the funniest, yet still poignant, with his stories regularly gracing the Oped pages of major newspapers across the country and his tongue-in-cheek punditing seen on CNN and Fox News. As contributing editor at the Writer Guild Of America's 'Written By' magazine, Steve's reputation has given him serious entrance to the best writers and producers in the industry while also allowing him one more outlet to lampoon the entertainment business he so cares about. With boundless energy and enthusiasm, we can expect to see the name of Steve Young appearing on an ever-growing amount of books lining the shelves of countless bookstores. And if anyone catches Steve putting his name on these books would you please report it to your local authorities. He must be stopped! Steve Young Harvard Graduate.

Series Person writer  Michael Barrie Spike Feresten birth notes gender aka name trivia birth name mini biography birth date spouse article Michael Barrie Mike Barrie Male 3 September 1964 'Erika' (? - present) Spike Feresten was raised in West Bridgewater, MA, where he attended public school and got his first job as a bag boy at the local supermarket. With a dream to be the next Jimi Hendrix, Feresten attended Berklee College of Music in Boston.  One night, disillusioned with his career choice, Feresten thought he might feel better if he dropped four-foot fluorescent light bulbs out the window of his dorm room - just to watch them shatter on the sidewalk eight stories below. He got caught and was evicted. Soon after, Feresten saw David Letterman performing the exact same stunt on his late-night talk show, and a real light bulb went on: If network television encouraged this sort of behavior, he might have a future after all. Thus, a career in TV comedy was born.  Feresten came up through the ranks of television, working first as an intern at NBC in New York. His career took on a Hollywood fable quality when his job as the receptionist for 'Saturday Night Live' led him to pass jokes he had written to 'Weekend Update's' Dennis Miller. Eventually, Feresten's full-time job at SNL led to a staff-writing position in 1990 at 'Late Night with David Letterman,' where he wrote for five years and earned five Emmy nominations.  In 1995, Feresten left the late-night realm to join the writing staff of the groundbreaking sitcom 'Seinfeld,' where he wrote for three seasons, becoming supervising producer in 1998. During his 'Seinfeld' tenure, Feresten garnered an additional three Emmy nominations, including one for his famed 'Soup Nazi' episode, which remains part of the pop-culture vernacular.  In 2006 FOX selected Feresten to host his own Late Night series, Talkshow with Spike Feresten which Feresten also executive produced and co-wrote. Several of the show's many viral videos made HULU's all-time most viewed list beating out Family Guy and Tina Fey's Sarah Palin sketches.  In addition to 'Seinfeld' and 'Letterman,' Feresten has written and developed other television comedy, penning episodes of The Simpsons, 'Space Ghost Coast to Coast' and 'The Jamie Kennedy Experiment.' Continuing to work with Jerry Seinfeld, Feresten co-wrote the screenplay for the animated feature 'Beemovie,' and the 2012 Acura NSX Superbowl Commercial. Spike Feresten 'The New York Times' (USA), 20 December 2008, Vol. 158, Iss. 54,530, pg. C1 & C6, by: Bill Carter, 'Another Late-Night Contender Emerges' His wife Erika is expecting their first child together, a son, in February 2008. Michael Donovan Feresten Jr West Bridgewater, Massachusetts, USA Male Jr, Michael Donovan Feresten

After graduating from college, he moved to Atlanta, Georgia where he began his acting career. Walter Hendrix III has also written, directed, and produced several projects as well and has plans to produce several more over the upcoming years. Editor Person Video Movie actor cinematographer David Boyd  Jeremy Jordan birth notes gender other works aka name trivia mini biography nick names birth date spouse 'Barbara Crampton' (qv) (1 October 1988 - 1990) (divorced) David Boyd First husband of 'Barbara Crampton' (qv). David R. Boyd 20 November 1984 JJ 'Ashley Spencer (I)' (qv) (8 September 2012 - present) Jeremy was born and raised in Corpus Christi, Texas. His grandma directed a youth program at a local community theatre in Chorpus Christi. In school he was always in choir, one year he did a choir concert at the community theatre and it lead to acting roles. It wasn't until he did a production of The Fantasticks that he became serious about acting. He received a BFA from Ithaca College in 2007 and moved to NYC.  Shortly after moving to NYC he booked the National Tour for Whistle Down The Wind. However, he wanted to stay in NYC so he turned it down. He did a few readings and regional productions. In 2009, he booked his first Broadway show, Rock of Ages. He was a swing understudying several roles, including the lead. In December of 2009, he decided to leave Rock of Ages to play Tony in West Side Story on Wednesday evenings and Sunday matinees.  Upon leaving West Side Story, Jeremy traveled to Sarasota, Florida to play Clyde Barrow, opposite Laura Osnes, in Bonnie & Clyde. After a successful month run, he then headed to Atlanta, Georgia to film his first feature film, Joyful Noise. Todd Graff, who wrote and directed the film, happened to be at Jeremy's very first performance at Rock of Ages and cast him in the movie. His character is Randy Garrity, the rebellious grandson of G.G. Sparrow (played by Dolly Parton).  He returned to NY after being away for a few months, he was a part of some compilation concerts and readings. In the Fall of 2011, Jeremy got to fulfill a childhood dream when he was cast as Jack Kelly in Disney's world premiere production of Newsies. While Jeremy was enjoying playing Jack Kelly at night, during the day he was rehearsing for Bonnie & Clyde which would come to Broadway shortly after Newsies finished its run.  In November of 2011, Jeremy got to originate his first leading role on Broadway in Bonnie & Clyde; once again he got to play Clyde Barrow. Sadly, the production would close after only 69 performances (and Jeremy didn't miss a single performance).  Shortly after Bonnie & Clyde's closing, Jeremy announced he would be returning to Newsies to play Jack Kelly at the Nederlander theatre. Just four months into the run, Jeremy would be pulling double duty once again -- filming season 2 of NBC's hit TV show, Smash while still playing Jack Kelly in Newsies.  Jeremy left Newsies to film Smash full-time. His final performance was September 4, 2012. Season 2 of Smash will start airing on February 5, 2013 on NBC.  Jeremy is married to fellow Broadway actress Ashley Spencer. Jeremy Jordan Close friends with 'Bonnie and Clyde Musical' costar 'Laura Osnes' (qv). JJ Corpus Christi, Texas, USA Male (15 March 2012-4 September 2012) Originated the role of Jack Kelly in the Broadway musical 'Newsies' at the Nederlander Theatre.

Editor Person Video Movie actor cinematographer David Boyd  John T. Ford gender aka name mini biography 'Barbara Crampton' (qv) (1 October 1988 - 1990) (divorced) David Boyd First husband of 'Barbara Crampton' (qv). David R. Boyd John or J.T. as his friend's call him was born in the small town of Union City, Tennessee, which located in the far North West corner of the state near the geological phenomenon, known as Reelfoot Lake. He was first bit by the acting bug at the age of 20, when a scene from the movie 'U.S. Marshalls' was to be filmed at Reelfoot Lake. Due to some miscommunication an opportunity to be a stand-in was lost. He would not get another opportunity to enter the entertainment business till late 2010 at the age of 36. He was laid off from a factory and was waiting to start school when he saw an ad on craigslist for court room extras in the crime reenactment show 'Sins and Secrets'. He submitted his picture and stats and was asked by production to come and fill seats for no pay. He showed up at the federal court house and asked where the show was being filmed and no one knew anything about it. Thinking he was being tricked or scammed in some way he left. Shortly after leaving he e-mailed the trickster congratulating them on the success of their little joke. They immediately emailed him back and implored him to please come back, that someone was supposed to have met him down stairs and they were very sorry for the mix-up. Once back on location he found where the show was being filmed at and instead of a jury member or seat filler in the audience, he was asked if he would mind playing the assistant defense attorney and then was asked to stay later and be the attorney in the defendant's interrogation scene. Needless to say, he had been officially bit by the bug again and has worked sporadically on more reenactments and as an extra on a few popular television shows Like 'The Vampire Diaries', 'Teen Wolf', and Necessary Roughness' and a few movies, as well as speaking roles in some independent films, all while attending school for a degree in computer networking. He is very grateful for his success so far and say's none of it would have been possible without the support of beautiful wife Arrah Ford. John T. Ford J.T. Ford Male
Editor Person Video Movie actor cinematographer David Boyd  Hajji Golightly gender name 'Barbara Crampton' (qv) (1 October 1988 - 1990) (divorced) David Boyd First husband of 'Barbara Crampton' (qv). David R. Boyd Hajji Golightly Male
Editor Person Video Movie actor cinematographer David Boyd  Trey Best gender other works name mini biography height 'Barbara Crampton' (qv) (1 October 1988 - 1990) (divorced) David Boyd First husband of 'Barbara Crampton' (qv). David R. Boyd At a very early age, Trey displayed unusual abilities and talent. At age 3, banging on mom's pots and pans went beyond kids play.  In Trey's first preschool performance, he was the director of his choir, which required an elevated platform for the choir members to see him.  Eventually, Trey became a regular lead singer of the church's children's choir. He sang for family, school and community events and put on productions in the basement of his parents home with music, dance and numerous wardrobe changes. Trey would create costumes out of old clothing, costumes and anything his parents would supply. With amazement family and friends sat attentively as he entertained them.  Trey's first paid gig was playing drums for a kid's choir at age 6 and won his first drum competition as well. He began to dance with a hip hop step and dance company for teens. Although he was only 7, Trey did not miss a beat in learning routines and dance techniques. A young musician, singer and dancer led to pursuing acting.  Trey Best is a 14 year old actor, recording artist, dancer, musician, choreographer, Songwriter and Producer. He's the owner of Giant Baby Music publishing company. Trey Best 5' 1' Male TV commercial for Cartoon Network

Series Movie Editor Person actor production designer The Muppets Jerry Dunn    The Muppets Jim Henson's Muppets Male (March 2012) A video called 'Muppets vs. Goldman Sachs' on FunnyorDie.com with some of 'The Muppets' (qv), 'Kyle MacLachlan' (qv) and 'Neal McDonough' (qv) spoofing public claims by an ex-employee of Goldman Sachs that Goldman Sachs refers to its' clients as Muppets. Series Movie Editor Person actor production designer The Muppets Steve Bass    The Muppets Jim Henson's Muppets Male (March 2012) A video called 'Muppets vs. Goldman Sachs' on FunnyorDie.com with some of 'The Muppets' (qv), 'Kyle MacLachlan' (qv) and 'Neal McDonough' (qv) spoofing public claims by an ex-employee of Goldman Sachs that Goldman Sachs refers to its' clients as Muppets. The video also featured 'Stephen Glickman' (qv), 'Richard Riehle' (qv), 'John Mawson (II)' (qv), 'Darri Ingolfsson' (qv), 'Luke Barnett (II)' (qv), and 'Adam Lustick' (qv). Multi-Emmy Award winner Steve Bass has designed many of the most prestigious live and televised shows produced, including the Oscars, Grammys, Emmys and Tony Awards. His talents were tapped for the Opening and Closing Ceremonies of the Atlanta Olympics, Salt Lake Olympics Medals Plaza, The Democratic Convention, Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus, and the Inaugural Celebration at the Lincoln Memorial for President Obama.  Live show design includes mega hits from Disney: the Lion King Celebration and a theatrical production of The Little Mermaid which to date has been seen by over 25 million guests, as well as the national tour of Disney's Symphonic Fantasy and Sesame Street Live. Recent live productions include DreamWorks Madagascar Live!, Disney's Mad T Party: an innovative experiential nightclub, and the award-winning Starlight Parade for Universal Studios Japan.  Steve has a long-standing history designing for iconic entertainment programs such as Great Performances, Nickelodeon's Kids Choice, Christmas in Washington, TV Land, and Entertainment Tonight, as well as corporate events for auto giants Lexus and Toyota. Steve Bass
Series Movie Editor Person actor production designer The Muppets Andy Walmsley    The Muppets Jim Henson's Muppets Male (March 2012) A video called 'Muppets vs. Goldman Sachs' on FunnyorDie.com with some of 'The Muppets' (qv), 'Kyle MacLachlan' (qv) and 'Neal McDonough' (qv) spoofing public claims by an ex-employee of Goldman Sachs that Goldman Sachs refers to its' clients as Muppets. The video also featured 'Stephen Glickman' (qv), 'Richard Riehle' (qv), 'John Mawson (II)' (qv), 'Darri Ingolfsson' (qv), 'Luke Barnett (II)' (qv), and 'Adam Lustick' (qv). Andy Walmsley

TV Movie Actor Person writer costume designer  Toby Huss Carolee Fisher name 9 December 1966 Toby Huss A great 'Frank Sinatra' (qv) impersonator. 6' Marshalltown, Iowa, USA Male Played 'Patrick Schliesman' in the short independent film 'The Adventures of Roo' (1984) while a theater student at the University of Iowa. The writer/director of that film, film historian Scott Allen Nollen, is the authorized biographer of Boris Karloff and co-wrote 'Kreating Karloff,' which just won Best Experimental Film at the 2007 Honolulu Film Festival. Carolee Fisher
TV Movie Actor Person writer costume designer  Carolee Fisher Martin Short gender other works trivia nick names spouse article quotes interviews aka name trade mark birth name where now birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial Carolee Fisher 'Movieline' (USA), June 1996, Vol. VII, Iss. 9, pg. 81, ''what's your favorite scene in your favorite video?'' 'Nancy Dolman' (qv) (December 1980 - 21 August 2010) (her death); 3 children He was 'Mel Brooks (I)' (qv)' first choice to star opposite 'Nathan Lane (I)' (qv) as Leo Bloom in his Broadway version of 'The Producers'. In 2000 Short was hosting his short-lived talk show, _'The Martin Short Show' (1999)_ (qv), and Brooks and Lane appeared as guests on the same episode--during which, sitting between Lane and Short, Brooks pulled out the contract for 'The Producers', wanting them both to sign it right there. This was met with gales of surprised and flattered laughter from the two actors. Having professional obligations on the West Coast due to the talk show, as well as family obligations (he had three children enrolled in school in the Los Angeles area at the time) Short had to decline, and was visibly guilty as he told Brooks he couldn't sign at that moment and would consider the offer later. Lane helped the situation by doing the same. While Lane later accepted, Short declined and 'Matthew Broderick (I)' (qv) took his place (earning a Tony Award nomination). Short wound up enjoying a successful run opposite 'Jason Alexander (I)' (qv) in the Los Angeles production of 'The Producers' in 2003. 'Playboy' (USA), April 1986, Vol. 33, Iss. 4, pg. 208, by: Michaelin McDermott, 'Grapevine: These Folks Aren't Bob, Carol, Ted or Alice' [asked why he remains in show business] Two words, sweetie: balloon mortgage. And the need to be loved. (1974) Stage: Appeared in 'Fortune and Men's Eyes'. Short, Martin Hayter 26 March 1950 Shorty (March 2003) Rehearsing to play Leo Bloom in The Producers at Pantages Theatre in LA beginning May 2. Martin Short 'New York Times' (USA), 14 April 2002, pg. Arts 34, by: Hal Hinson, 'A Tempest in a Talk Show: Jiminy Glick's Wild Ride' His Jiminy Glick character - an eccentric, obese celebrity interviewer 'Parade' (USA), 23 January 2000 Jiminy Glick 5' 7 1/2' Male

Composer Character Person actress  Heather Thomas Dolly Parton gender other works biographical movies trivia nick names spouse article quotes interviews portrayed in birth notes books aka name trade mark birth name where now mini biography birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial 'Harry M. Brittenham' (qv) (10 October 1992 - present); 1 child Best known by the public for her starring role as Jody Banks on _'The Fall Guy' (1981)_ (qv). 'Playboy' (USA), January 1987, Vol. 34, Iss. 1, pg. 71-72, by: Photographer Greg Gorman, 'Playboy Gallery' In our society, you know, there are people who are broken and your poster hangs in jail, as your poster hangs in jail, as your poster hangs in wards, so, I had a lot of stalkers. Thomas, Heather Anne 8 September 1957 (July 2008) Release of her book, 'Trophies'. Heather Thomas 'TV Guide' (USA), 13 July 1985, Vol. 33, Iss. 28, pg. 26-30, by: Heather Thomas, 'Diary Of A Fall Girl' 'TV Guide' (USA), 13 July 1985, Vol. 33, Iss. 28 Heather Anne Thomas 5' 5 1/2' Greenwich, Connecticut, USA Female 'A&U: Art and Understanding' (USA), July 2003, Vol. 12, Iss. 7, pg. 16-17, by: Plant, B. Andrew, 'Dolly Parton: Red, Hot & Bluegrass' 'Carl Dean' (qv) (30 May 1966 - present) During the 40th Annual Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle Awards in 2009, Parton won for Best Musical Score for '9 To 5: The Musical' which played the Ahmanson Theatre in Los Angeles during in the fall of 2008. 'People Weekly' (USA), 9 February 1998, Vol. 49, Iss. 5, pg. 98, 'Brush With Fame - Roddy McDowall' (alluding to her famous bust) If I build another park, it will probably be in Silicon Valley. (2003) Music video: 'I'm Gone' _'E! True Hollywood Story' (1996) {Dolly Parton}_ (qv) Parton, Dolly Rebecca 19 January 1946 The Smoky Mountain Songbird (2006) Currently writing the score for the Broadway version of _Nine to Five (1980)_ (qv) as well as a children's book currently titled 'I Am A Rainbow'. As of October/November 2006, Parton is playing limited concerts at various venues in the USA and Canada and is currently working on a new country music CD currently titled 'Country Is As Country Does'. The new CD and children's book are expected to be released in 2007. Connie Berman (foreword by Dolly Parton). _The Official Dolly Parton Scrapbook._ New York: Grosset & Dunlap, 1978. ISBN 0- 44816176-1 Dolly Rebecca Parton was born on January 19, 1946, one of 12 children of Robert Lee Parton, a tobacco farmer, and Avie Lee Parton (n?e Owens). Dolly grew up on a run-down farm in Locust Ridge, Tennessee. At 12, she was appearing on Knoxville TV and, at 13, she was already recording on a small label and appearing at the Grand Ole Opry. After graduating from high school in Sevier County, Tennessee, in 1964, she moved to Nashville to launch her career as a country singer. She fell in love with 'Carl Dean' (qv), who ran an asphalt-paving business; they got married on May 30, 1966 (and they are still together). The next year, Dolly's singing caught the attention of 'Porter Wagoner' (qv). He hired Dolly to appear on his program, _'The Porter Wagoner Show' (1961)_ (qv). Dolly stayed with the show for 7 years, their duets became famous, and she appeared with his group at the Grand Ole Opry; she also toured and sold records. By the time her hit 'Joshua' reached #1 in 1970, her fame had overshadowed Porter's, and she struck out on her own, though still recording duets with him. She left him for good to become a solo artist in 1974. Dolly gained immense popularity as a singer/songwriter. Dolly won numerous Country Music Association awards (1968, 1970, 1971, 1975, 1976). This petite (5'0') beauty was a natural for television and, by the mid-1970s, Dolly was appearing frequently on TV specials and talk shows. Dolly then got her own show, aptly titled _'Dolly' (1976)_ (qv). In 1977, Dolly got her first Grammy award: Best Female Country Vocal Performance, for her song 'Here You Come Again'. Dolly's movie debut was in _Nine to Five (1980)_ (qv), where she got an Oscar nomination for writing the title tune, and also Grammy awards 2 and 3, Best Country Song, and Best Female Country Vocal Performance for the song 'Nine to Five'. Dolly got more fame for appearing in _The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas (1982)_ (qv), and in _Rhinestone (1984)_ (qv) with the song 'Tennessee Homesick Blues'. She is the head of Dolly Parton Enterprises, a $100 million media empire, and, in 1986, she founded Dollywood, a theme park in Pigeon Forge, Tennessee, celebrating her Smokey Mountain upbringing. She appeared as herself in the _'Dolly' (1987)_ (qv) TV series. In 1988, she won another Grammy award: Best Country Performance Duo or Group with Vocals, for 'Trio'. Dolly was in the acclaimed picture _Steel Magnolias (1989)_ (qv) with 'Julia Roberts (I)' (qv), and went on to appear in 15 movies and TV-movies for the 1990s, and of course garnered more Country Music Association awards. In 2000, Dolly received her 5th Grammy award: Best Country Collaboration with Vocals. She also released a Bluegrass Album. Dolly is known for beautiful songs such as 'Coat of Many Colors' and 'Jolene' and 'I Will Always Love You'. Dolly said in an interview, 'My music is what took me everywhere I've been and everywhere I will go. It's my greatest love. I can't abandon it. I'll always keep making records'. Dolly Parton 'Wide Open Magazine' (UK), 9 June 2006, Iss. 2, by: Staff Writer, 'Jill Jackson of Country Duo 'Jackson and Cassidy' on Why She Loves Dolly Parton' _'Blue Collar TV' (2004)_ (qv) Always uses butterflies as her logos, since she feels they represent beauty and freedom. 'TV Quick' (Spain), 6 July 1991 Dolly Rebecca Parton 4' 11' Sevierville, Tennessee, USA Female
Composer Character Person actress  Wendi McLendon-Covey Dolly Parton gender other works biographical movies trivia nick names spouse article quotes interviews portrayed in birth notes books aka name trade mark birth name where now mini biography birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial 10 October 1969 'Long Beach Press Telegram' (USA), 21 June 2007, pg. Section 'U', p.6-7, by: Phillip Zonkel, 'Dancer to Deputy' 'Greg Covey' (10 August 1996 - present) Wendi McLendon-Covey Has been called the 'Queen of Improv' by TV Guide for her work on two unscripted shows: Reno 911, and Lovespring International. Wendy Anne McLendon 5' 8' As a performer, you can't just sit around waiting for the phone to ring. You have to write and develop projects for yourself, because casting people aren't always going to see you the way you want to be seen. Write a one-person show, shoot a short film, do plays, whatever - activity breeds activity. No one's interested in a stay-at-home actress. Bellflower, California, USA Female She was an Interviewee on VH1's Big in '04 McLendon, Wendy Anne 'A&U: Art and Understanding' (USA), July 2003, Vol. 12, Iss. 7, pg. 16-17, by: Plant, B. As of October/November 2006, Parton is playing limited concerts at various venues in the USA and Canada and is currently working on a new country music CD currently titled 'Country Is As Country Does'. Composer Character Person actress  Cindy Margolis Dolly Parton gender other works biographical movies trivia nick names spouse article quotes interviews portrayed in birth notes books aka name trade mark birth name where now mini biography birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial 'Playboy' (USA), March 2000, Vol. 47, Iss. 3, pg. 122-123+138-142, by: David Rensin, 'Playboy's 20Q: Cindy Margolis' 'Guy Starkman' (6 September 1998 - 2009) (divorced); 3 children 1999, Voted in the Guiness book of world records as the Most Downloaded woman ever. Margolis held the title until 2000 when her record was surpassed by 'Danni Ashe' (qv). 'Playboy' (USA), December 2006, Vol. 53, Iss. 12, pg. 160-169, by: Stephen Wayda, 'Desperately Seeking Cindy' [when asked as to how many men she slept with] I've been with more than you can count on one hand, but less than you can count on two. But I will say, looking back, if I could do it all over again, I would have been the biggest slut. I wish I could tell you I was in double or triple digits. Print ads: 'Vidal Sassoon' (qv) hair-care products. Margolis, Cynthia Dawn 1 October 1965 (2008) Release of her book, 'Having a Baby When the Old-Fashion Way Isn't Working'. Born in Los Angeles, California, blonde bombshell Cindy Margolis is not only known as the 'Queen of the Internet' but also as a talk show host, model and actress. It all started when Cindy was working on a project for a college business course she was taking. She took her project idea of greeting cards further and launched her own greeting card line, with her as the cover model for the cards. Agents started to ask about this greeting card cover girl. The company was a huge success. Cindy began to model and appeared in ads for Reebok, 'Vidal Sassoon' (qv), Coors, Hanes and Sunkist. Cindy then moved on to television appearances on shows such as _'Married with Children' (1987)_ (qv), _'Murphy Brown' (1988)_ (qv), _'Baywatch' (1989)_ (qv), _'Baywatch Nights' (1995)_ (qv), _In the Dark (1996)_ (qv) and _'Head Over Heels' (1997)_ (qv). Her first foray into television was as a 'Barker Beauty', a hostess on the game show, _'The Price Is Right' (1984)_ (qv). Her popularity on the Internet started when she appeared on _'Extra' (1994)_ (qv) in 1995. Since then, she has been named Yahoo Internet Life magazine's 'Queen of the Internet' from 1996-1999. She has been downloaded worldwide over 58 million times and has been inducted into The Guinness Book of World Records 2000 Millennium Issue, for having been downloaded 70,000 times in a period of 24 hours. For her reign in the cyber world, Cindy will be featured in the New Ripley's Believe It or Not museums. She married her first husband, Guy Starkman, who owns Jerry's Famous Deli, after having met him on a blind date. Cindy Margolis 'Max' (Greece), January 2000, Iss. 118, pg. 26, by: Grigoris Samourkassoglou, 'I Cindy Crawford ton 90s' 'Muscular Development' (USA), July 2000 Cynthia Dawn Margolis 5' 7 1/2' Los Angeles, California, USA Female 'A&U: Art and Understanding' (USA), July 2003, Vol. 12, Iss. 7, pg. 16-17, by: Plant, B. Andrew, 'Dolly Parton: Red, Hot & Bluegrass' 'Carl Dean' (qv) (30 May 1966 - present) During the 40th Annual Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle Awards in 2009, Parton won for Best Musical Score for '9 To 5: The Musical' which played the Ahmanson Theatre in Los Angeles during in the fall of 2008. 'People Weekly' (USA), 9 February 1998, Vol. 49, Iss. 5, pg. 98, 'Brush With Fame - Roddy McDowall' (alluding to her famous bust) If I build another park, it will probably be in Silicon Valley. Dolly is known for beautiful songs such as 'Coat of Many Colors' and 'Jolene' and 'I Will Always Love You'. Dolly said in an interview, 'My music is what took me everywhere I've been and everywhere I will go. It's my greatest love. I can't abandon it. I'll always keep making records'. (2003) Music video: 'I'm Gone' _'E! True Hollywood Story' (1996) {Dolly Parton}_ (qv) Parton, Dolly Rebecca 19 January 1946 The Smoky Mountain Songbird (2006) Currently writing the score for the Broadway version of _Nine to Five (1980)_ (qv) as well as a children's book currently titled 'I Am A Rainbow'. As of October/November 2006, Parton is playing limited concerts at various venues in the USA and Canada and is currently working on a new country music CD currently titled 'Country Is As Country Does'. The new CD and children's book are expected to be released in 2007. Connie Berman (foreword by Dolly Parton). _The Official Dolly Parton Scrapbook._ New York: Grosset & Dunlap, 1978. ISBN 0- 44816176-1 Dolly Rebecca Parton was born on January 19, 1946, one of 12 children of Robert Lee Parton, a tobacco farmer, and Avie Lee Parton (n?e Owens). Dolly grew up on a run-down farm in Locust Ridge, Tennessee. At 12, she was appearing on Knoxville TV and, at 13, she was already recording on a small label and appearing at the Grand Ole Opry. After graduating from high school in Sevier County, Tennessee, in 1964, she moved to Nashville to launch her career as a country singer. She fell in love with 'Carl Dean' (qv), who ran an asphalt-paving business; they got married on May 30, 1966 (and they are still together). The next year, Dolly's singing caught the attention of 'Porter Wagoner' (qv). He hired Dolly to appear on his program, _'The Porter Wagoner Show' (1961)_ (qv). Dolly stayed with the show for 7 years, their duets became famous, and she appeared with his group at the Grand Ole Opry; she also toured and sold records. By the time her hit 'Joshua' reached #1 in 1970, her fame had overshadowed Porter's, and she struck out on her own, though still recording duets with him. She left him for good to become a solo artist in 1974. Dolly gained immense popularity as a singer/songwriter. Dolly won numerous Country Music Association awards (1968, 1970, 1971, 1975, 1976). This petite (5'0') beauty was a natural for television and, by the mid-1970s, Dolly was appearing frequently on TV specials and talk shows. Dolly then got her own show, aptly titled _'Dolly' (1976)_ (qv). In 1977, Dolly got her first Grammy award: Best Female Country Vocal Performance, for her song 'Here You Come Again'. Dolly's movie debut was in _Nine to Five (1980)_ (qv), where she got an Oscar nomination for writing the title tune, and also Grammy awards 2 and 3, Best Country Song, and Best Female Country Vocal Performance for the song 'Nine to Five'. Dolly got more fame for appearing in _The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas (1982)_ (qv), and in _Rhinestone (1984)_ (qv) with the song 'Tennessee Homesick Blues'. She is the head of Dolly Parton Enterprises, a $100 million media empire, and, in 1986, she founded Dollywood, a theme park in Pigeon Forge, Tennessee, celebrating her Smokey Mountain upbringing. She appeared as herself in the _'Dolly' (1987)_ (qv) TV series. In 1988, she won another Grammy award: Best Country Performance Duo or Group with Vocals, for 'Trio'. Dolly was in the acclaimed picture _Steel Magnolias (1989)_ (qv) with 'Julia Roberts (I)' (qv), and went on to appear in 15 movies and TV-movies for the 1990s, and of course garnered more Country Music Association awards. In 2000, Dolly received her 5th Grammy award: Best Country Collaboration with Vocals. She also released a Bluegrass Album. Dolly is known for beautiful songs such as 'Coat of Many Colors' and 'Jolene' and 'I Will Always Love You'. Dolly said in an interview, 'My music is what took me everywhere I've been and everywhere I will go. It's my greatest love. I can't abandon it. I'll always keep making records'. Dolly Parton 'Wide Open Magazine' (UK), 9 June 2006, Iss. 2, by: Staff Writer, 'Jill Jackson of Country Duo 'Jackson and Cassidy' on Why She Loves Dolly Parton' _'Blue Collar TV' (2004)_ (qv) Always uses butterflies as her logos, since she feels they represent beauty and freedom. 'TV Quick' (Spain), 6 July 1991 Dolly Rebecca Parton 4' 11' Sevierville, Tennessee, USA Female 'Empire' (UK), 1997, Iss. 91, pg. 54-55, by: John Naughton, 'Making Up For Lost Time...' 'David Shaw' (3 February 2006 - present) Made her Broadway debut in The Phoenix Theatre's production of Congrieve's 'Love for Love.' She was the understudy to the star 'Mary Ure' (qv), and went on for a Saturday evening performance after Miss Ure was let go after that Saturday matin?e. 'Cinema' (Hungary), February 2001, Iss. 111, pg. 49, 'Sz?p Cs?f' [on her Oscar-nominated role as Albert Nobbs] Albert is a survivor and I think she chose an invisible job. An invisible person chose an invisible job. In nineteenth-century Victorian times, servants weren't supposed to to look at anybody in the eye. They don't see you, they don't talk to you, you don't talk to them. (2002) Stage: Plays Blanche DuBois in 'A Streetcar Named Desire' by 'Tennessee Williams' (qv), (Royal National Theater/Lyttelton, London, England). 19 March 1947 Glennie (November 2002) Appearing in London at the Royal National Theatre in 'Streetcar Named Desire' Ron Newcomer. _The Films of Glenn Close._ Secaucus, New Jersey: Citadel Press, 1999. ISBN 0806517212 Six time Academy Award nominee Glenn Close was born and was raised in Greenwich, Connecticut. She was often seen on Broadway until 1982 when she was cast in her award winning role as Jenny Fields in _The World According to Garp (1982)_ (qv) alongside 'Robin Williams (I)' (qv). For this role, a breakthrough in film for Close, she later went on to receive an Academy Award Nomination for Best Supporting Actress. The following year she was cast in the hit comedy _The Big Chill (1983)_ (qv) for which she received a second Oscar Nomination, once again for Supporting Actress in the role of Sarah Cooper. In her third film, Close portrayed Iris Gaines a former lover of baseball player Roy Hobbs portrayed by 'Robert Redford (I)' (qv), in one of the greatest sports films of all time, _The Natural (1984)_ (qv). For a third and final time, Close was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress. Close went on to star in films like _The Stone Boy (1984)_ (qv), _Maxie (1985)_ (qv) and _Jagged Edge (1985)_ (qv). In 1987 Close was cast in the box office hit _Fatal Attraction (1987)_ (qv) for which she portrayed deranged stalker Alex Forrest alongside costars 'Michael Douglas (I)' (qv) and 'Anne Archer' (qv). For this role she was nominated for the Academy Award and Golden Globe for Best Actress. The following year Close stared in the Oscar Winning Drama _Dangerous Liaisons (1988)_ (qv) for which she portrayed one of the most classic roles of all time as Marquise Isabelle de Merteuil, starring alongside 'John Malkovich' and 'Michelle Pfeiffer' (qv). For this role she was nominated once again for the Academy Award and BAFTA Film Award for Best Actress. Close was favorite to win the coveted statue but lost to 'Jodie Foster' (qv) for _The Accused (1988)_ (qv). Close had her claim to fame in the 1980s. Close currently stars on the hit Drama series _'Damages' (2007)_ (qv) for which she has won a Golden Globe Award and two Emmy Awards. In her career Close has been Oscar nominated five times, won three Tonys, an Obie, three Emmys, two Golden Globes and a Screen Actors Guild Award. Glenn Close 'TV Guia' (Portugal), 1997, Iss. 947, pg. 110-111, by: Joao Antunes Often portrays scheming women 'TV Guide' (USA), 6 August 2007, Vol. 55, Iss. 32 Glennie 5' 5' Greenwich, Connecticut, USA Female

As of October/November 2006, Parton is playing limited concerts at various venues in the USA and Canada and is currently working on a new country music CD currently titled 'Country Is As Country Does'. The new CD and children's book are expected to be released in 2007. Connie Berman (foreword by Dolly Parton). _The Official Dolly Parton Scrapbook._ New York: Grosset & Dunlap, 1978. ISBN 0- 44816176-1 Dolly Rebecca Parton was born on January 19, 1946, one of 12 children of Robert Lee Parton, a tobacco farmer, and Avie Lee Parton (n?e Owens). Dolly grew up on a run-down farm in Locust Ridge, Tennessee. At 12, she was appearing on Knoxville TV and, at 13, she was already recording on a small label and appearing at the Grand Ole Opry. After graduating from high school in Sevier County, Tennessee, in 1964, she moved to Nashville to launch her career as a country singer. She fell in love with 'Carl Dean' (qv), who ran an asphalt-paving business; they got married on May 30, 1966 (and they are still together). The next year, Dolly's singing caught the attention of 'Porter Wagoner' (qv). He hired Dolly to appear on his program, _'The Porter Wagoner Show' (1961)_ (qv). Dolly stayed with the show for 7 years, their duets became famous, and she appeared with his group at the Grand Ole Opry; she also toured and sold records. By the time her hit 'Joshua' reached #1 in 1970, her fame had overshadowed Porter's, and she struck out on her own, though still recording duets with him. She left him for good to become a solo artist in 1974. Dolly gained immense popularity as a singer/songwriter. Dolly won numerous Country Music Association awards (1968, 1970, 1971, 1975, 1976). This petite (5'0') beauty was a natural for television and, by the mid-1970s, Dolly was appearing frequently on TV specials and talk shows. Dolly then got her own show, aptly titled _'Dolly' (1976)_ (qv). In 1977, Dolly got her first Grammy award: Best Female Country Vocal Performance, for her song 'Here You Come Again'. Dolly's movie debut was in _Nine to Five (1980)_ (qv), where she got an Oscar nomination for writing the title tune, and also Grammy awards 2 and 3, Best Country Song, and Best Female Country Vocal Performance for the song 'Nine to Five'. Dolly got more fame for appearing in _The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas (1982)_ (qv), and in _Rhinestone (1984)_ (qv) with the song 'Tennessee Homesick Blues'. She is the head of Dolly Parton Enterprises, a $100 million media empire, and, in 1986, she founded Dollywood, a theme park in Pigeon Forge, Tennessee, celebrating her Smokey Mountain upbringing. She appeared as herself in the _'Dolly' (1987)_ (qv) TV series. In 1988, she won another Grammy award: Best Country Performance Duo or Group with Vocals, for 'Trio'. Dolly was in the acclaimed picture _Steel Magnolias (1989)_ (qv) with 'Julia Roberts (I)' (qv), and went on to appear in 15 movies and TV-movies for the 1990s, and of course garnered more Country Music Association awards. In 2000, Dolly received her 5th Grammy award: Best Country Collaboration with Vocals. She also released a Bluegrass Album. Dolly is known for beautiful songs such as 'Coat of Many Colors' and 'Jolene' and 'I Will Always Love You'. Dolly said in an interview, 'My music is what took me everywhere I've been and everywhere I will go. It's my greatest love. I can't abandon it. I'll always keep making records'. Composer Character Person actress  Brooke Shields Dolly Parton gender other works biographical movies trivia nick names spouse article quotes interviews portrayed in birth notes books aka name trade mark birth name where now mini biography birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial 'People' (USA), 9 May 2010, pg. 44, by: Ulrica Wihlborg, 'Talking kids and movies with Brooke Shields' 'Chris Henchy' (qv) (4 April 2001 - present); 2 children Did an audition for the role of Vivian in _Pretty Woman (1990)_ (qv), but the role went to 'Julia Roberts (I)' (qv) (and Roberts became a major star with this movie). 'Vanity Fair' (USA), March 2010, pg. 224, by: Howard Schatz, 'In Character Starring Brooke Shields' Being nice to everybody, saying hello to everyone in the room, signing every autograph; it was instilled in me at a very young age that this was what I was suppose to do. But I don't think it helps at all. I see more people who are rude or arrogant being rewarded - but, this way, I can put my head on the pillow at night. I can look at my child and know that, to my daughter, I'm the best example I can possibly be. (2005) (2000) TV commercial: Ivory soap _Headliners & Legends: Brooke Shields (2001) (TV)_ (qv) 31 May 1965 Brookie (November 2004) Appearing on-stage in 'Wonderful Town' at the 'Al Hirschfeld' (qv) Theater in New York City. Brooke Shields. _Down Came the Rain : My Journey Through Postpartum Depression._ New York: Hyperion, 2005. ISBN 1401301894 'Want to know what gets between me and my Calvins? Nothing'. If you had not heard of Brooke Shields before, this tagline from her 'Calvin Klein (I)' (qv) Jeans ad had to grab your attention. Not that she had not had a previously noteworthy resume. She was born on May 31, 1965 in New York City and, at age 12, she starred as a child prostitute in _Pretty Baby (1978)_ (qv). Could this movie even be made today? It was considered risky and controversial in 1978. It was followed by another blockbuster, the romance adventure drama _The Blue Lagoon (1980)_ (qv). Brooke has proved herself to be so much more than her early films. Her broad range of work as an adult would be quite an achievement for anyone, especially given how difficult transitioning from child actor to adult often is.  She has never stopped working, whether it be a 'Bob Hope (I)' (qv) Christmas special, her own sitcom _'Suddenly Susan' (1996)_ (qv) or as an author. She also managed to work on a degree from Princeton University. She has received a number of awards during her career, most notably The People's Choice award for 1981 through 1984 in the category of Favorite Young Performer. In 1997, she was honored again with The People's Choice award for Favorite Female Performer in a New Television Series in 1997 for her work in _'Suddenly Susan' (1996)_ (qv). In her personal life, she was married in 1997 to tennis player 'Andre Agassi' (qv) and was devastated when they divorced two years later. She married for the second time in 2001 to 'Chris Henchy' (qv). She has been open about using fertility treatments to become pregnant with their daughter, Rowan, born in 2003.  When suffering debilitating depression after the birth of her daughter, she made the decision to put her feelings down on paper. Her book, 'Down Came the Rain: My Journey Through Postpartum Depression', takes a hard, honest look at what she and many other women experience after childbirth. She still lives in New York City, and is still sought after for work in movies, television, and on stage. Pretty nice list of achievements for the once 'Calvin Klein (I)' (qv) jeans girl. Andrew, 'Dolly Parton: Red, Hot & Bluegrass' 'Carl Dean' (qv) (30 May 1966 - present) During the 40th Annual Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle Awards in 2009, Parton won for Best Musical Score for '9 To 5: The Musical' which played the Ahmanson Theatre in Los Angeles during in the fall of 2008. 'People Weekly' (USA), 9 February 1998, Vol. 49, Iss. 5, pg. 98, 'Brush With Fame - Roddy McDowall' (alluding to her famous bust) If I build another park, it will probably be in Silicon Valley. (2003) Music video: 'I'm Gone' _'E! True Hollywood Story' (1996) {Dolly Parton}_ (qv) Parton, Dolly Rebecca 19 January 1946 The Smoky Mountain Songbird (2006) Currently writing the score for the Broadway version of _Nine to Five (1980)_ (qv) as well as a children's book currently titled 'I Am A Rainbow'. As of October/November 2006, Parton is playing limited concerts at various venues in the USA and Canada and is currently working on a new country music CD currently titled 'Country Is As Country Does'. The new CD and children's book are expected to be released in 2007. Connie Berman (foreword by Dolly Parton). _The Official Dolly Parton Scrapbook._ New York: Grosset & Dunlap, 1978. ISBN 0- 44816176-1 Dolly Rebecca Parton was born on January 19, 1946, one of 12 children of Robert Lee Parton, a tobacco farmer, and Avie Lee Parton (n?e Owens). Dolly grew up on a run-down farm in Locust Ridge, Tennessee. At 12, she was appearing on Knoxville TV and, at 13, she was already recording on a small label and appearing at the Grand Ole Opry. After graduating from high school in Sevier County, Tennessee, in 1964, she moved to Nashville to launch her career as a country singer. She fell in love with 'Carl Dean' (qv), who ran an asphalt-paving business; they got married on May 30, 1966 (and they are still together). The next year, Dolly's singing caught the attention of 'Porter Wagoner' (qv). He hired Dolly to appear on his program, _'The Porter Wagoner Show' (1961)_ (qv). Dolly stayed with the show for 7 years, their duets became famous, and she appeared with his group at the Grand Ole Opry; she also toured and sold records. By the time her hit 'Joshua' reached #1 in 1970, her fame had overshadowed Porter's, and she struck out on her own, though still recording duets with him. She left him for good to become a solo artist in 1974. Dolly gained immense popularity as a singer/songwriter. Dolly won numerous Country Music Association awards (1968, 1970, 1971, 1975, 1976). This petite (5'0') beauty was a natural for television and, by the mid-1970s, Dolly was appearing frequently on TV specials and talk shows. Dolly then got her own show, aptly titled _'Dolly' (1976)_ (qv). In 1977, Dolly got her first Grammy award: Best Female Country Vocal Performance, for her song 'Here You Come Again'. Dolly's movie debut was in _Nine to Five (1980)_ (qv), where she got an Oscar nomination for writing the title tune, and also Grammy awards 2 and 3, Best Country Song, and Best Female Country Vocal Performance for the song 'Nine to Five'. Dolly got more fame for appearing in _The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas (1982)_ (qv), and in _Rhinestone (1984)_ (qv) with the song 'Tennessee Homesick Blues'. She is the head of Dolly Parton Enterprises, a $100 million media empire, and, in 1986, she founded Dollywood, a theme park in Pigeon Forge, Tennessee, celebrating her Smokey Mountain upbringing. She appeared as herself in the _'Dolly' (1987)_ (qv) TV series. In 1988, she won another Grammy award: Best Country Performance Duo or Group with Vocals, for 'Trio'. Dolly was in the acclaimed picture _Steel Magnolias (1989)_ (qv) with 'Julia Roberts (I)' (qv), and went on to appear in 15 movies and TV-movies for the 1990s, and of course garnered more Country Music Association awards. In 2000, Dolly received her 5th Grammy award: Best Country Collaboration with Vocals. She also released a Bluegrass Album. Dolly is known for beautiful songs such as 'Coat of Many Colors' and 'Jolene' and 'I Will Always Love You'. Dolly said in an interview, 'My music is what took me everywhere I've been and everywhere I will go. It's my greatest love. I can't abandon it. I'll always keep making records'. Dolly Parton 'Wide Open Magazine' (UK), 9 June 2006, Iss. 2, by: Staff Writer, 'Jill Jackson of Country Duo 'Jackson and Cassidy' on Why She Loves Dolly Parton' _'Blue Collar TV' (2004)_ (qv) Always uses butterflies as her logos, since she feels they represent beauty and freedom. 'TV Quick' (Spain), 6 July 1991 Dolly Rebecca Parton 4' 11' Sevierville, Tennessee, USA Female 'Newsweek' (USA), 10 January 2005, Vol. 165, Iss. 2, pg. 62, by: Nicki Gostin, 'Q&A Brigitte Nielsen' 'Kasper Winding' (qv) (1983 - October 1984) (divorced); 1 child She left her first husband and child in Denmark to find fame in America (1985). 'Playboy' (USA), September 1985, Vol. 32, Iss. 9, pg. 78-83, by: Richard Fegley & Marco Emili, 'Rating Neilsen' 'I like to have men look at me from the bottom to the top.' (referring to her height: 6'1') Album: 'I Am The One...Nobody Else' (1991). _'E! True Hollywood Story' (1996) {Brigitte Nielsen}_ (qv) Nielsen, Gitte 15 July 1963 The Great Dane (June 2003) In England, where she participates in the game-show _'Stars in Their Eyes' (1990)_ (qv). Gitte Nielsen. _Du har kun ?t liv._ Copenhagen: Lindhardt og Ringhof, 2009. ISBN 9788711439036 Actress, model, presenter, and singer Brigitte Nielsen was born in R?dovre, a little place near Copenhagen in Denmark. At the end of high school when she was 16, Gitte (her given name) left her family to begin her modeling career. She worked for top fashion designers like 'Giorgio Armani' (qv), 'Gianni Versace' (qv) and 'Gianfranco Ferr?' (qv) and divided her time between New York, Paris, Milan and Berlin. In 1983, she married Danish musician 'Kasper Winding' (qv) and the year after her first son Julian was born but, in the same period, acted in _Red Sonja (1985)_ (qv) and left her husband and son for an acting career. The film with 'Arnold Schwarzenegger' (qv) was successful and, in 1985, she also acted in _Rocky IV (1985)_ (qv) with her future husband, 'Sylvester Stallone' (qv). Stallone met Nielsen in the summer of 1985 during _Red Sonja (1985)_ (qv)'s promo and, after six months, they married in Malibu. After 19 months, another film together _Cobra (1986)_ (qv) and many scandals, Gitte and Sly divorced. In 1987, Brigitte acted in _Beverly Hills Cop II (1987)_ (qv) and went to Italy where she worked in a big Italian TV show called _'Festival' (1987)_ (qv), recorded a dance album, 'Every Body Tells A Story', and a pop music single, 'Body Next To Body' with Austrian singer Falco.  In January 1988, she met football player 'Mark Gastineau' (qv) in an LA gym and soon she was in love with him. In December 1989, her second son, Killian, was born but the relationship with Gastineau finished. In 1990, Nielsen married the photographer/director 'Sebastian Copeland' (qv) ('Orlando Bloom' (qv)'s cousin) in Las Vegas and recorded another album called 'I'm the One...Nobody Else'. In 1992, when her third marriage was finished, Brigitte met Swiss/Italian 'Raoul Meyer' (qv) and married him in December 1993. The same year, her third son, Douglas Aaron, was born and Gitte also acted in some films such as: _The Double 0 Kid (1992) (V)_ (qv) with 'Seth Green' (qv) and 'Wallace Shawn' (qv), _Fantaghir? 2 (1992) (TV)_ (qv), and in the erotic thriller _Chained Heat II (1993)_ (qv). Meanwhile, she also worked in European television and, in 1995, her last son, Raoul Jr. Ayrton (in memory of her friend 'Ayrton Senna' (qv)) was born.  Since them, Brigitte left her 4th husband and lives in Milan, Italy and in the USA. She continues to act in many films such as: _Codename: Silencer (1995)_ (qv), _Snowboard Academy (1996)_ (qv), _Hostile Environment (2000)_ (qv) and _Doomsdayer (2000)_ (qv). She has also recorded some dance music singles: 'No More Turning Back' and 'You're No Lady'. In 2004, she participated in two reality show, the Italian _'La talpa' (2004)_ (qv) (Celebrity Mole) and the American _'The Surreal Life' (2003)_ (qv) and _'Strange Love' (2005)_ (qv). Brigitte Nielsen 'Oui' (USA), February 1988, Vol. 19, Iss. 2, pg. 22-27+81, by: George Carpozzi, Jr., 'Rambo: Prisoner of Love' Platinum blonde hair 'Playboy' (Germany), December 1987 Brigitte Neilsen 6' 1' R?dovre, Denmark Female

Album: 'Portfolio' (1977) Mendoza, Grace 19 May 1948 The Queen of Gay Discos (May 2007) She appeared on the Danish TV show Go' Aften Danmark (Good Evening Denmark), helping her old friend 'Sven-Ole Thorsen' (qv) promote a new book of his. Jones, a Jamaican-born perfomer, is better known as a model and singer. Her androgynous appearance, and outrageous musical act employing live lions and leopards, has made her a cult favorite, and propelled her into several acting roles. ISBN 0- 44816176-1 Dolly Rebecca Parton was born on January 19, 1946, one of 12 children of Robert Lee Parton, a tobacco farmer, and Avie Lee Parton (n?e Owens). Dolly grew up on a run-down farm in Locust Ridge, Tennessee. At 12, she was appearing on Knoxville TV and, at 13, she was already recording on a small label and appearing at the Grand Ole Opry. After graduating from high school in Sevier County, Tennessee, in 1964, she moved to Nashville to launch her career as a country singer. She fell in love with 'Carl Dean' (qv), who ran an asphalt-paving business; they got married on May 30, 1966 (and they are still together). The next year, Dolly's singing caught the attention of 'Porter Wagoner' (qv). He hired Dolly to appear on his program, _'The Porter Wagoner Show' (1961)_ (qv). Dolly stayed with the show for 7 years, their duets became famous, and she appeared with his group at the Grand Ole Opry; she also toured and sold records. By the time her hit 'Joshua' reached #1 in 1970, her fame had overshadowed Porter's, and she struck out on her own, though still recording duets with him. She left him for good to become a solo artist in 1974. Dolly gained immense popularity as a singer/songwriter. Dolly won numerous Country Music Association awards (1968, 1970, 1971, 1975, 1976). This petite (5'0') beauty was a natural for television and, by the mid-1970s, Dolly was appearing frequently on TV specials and talk shows. Dolly then got her own show, aptly titled _'Dolly' (1976)_ (qv). In 1977, Dolly got her first Grammy award: Best Female Country Vocal Performance, for her song 'Here You Come Again'. Dolly's movie debut was in _Nine to Five (1980)_ (qv), where she got an Oscar nomination for writing the title tune, and also Grammy awards 2 and 3, Best Country Song, and Best Female Country Vocal Performance for the song 'Nine to Five'. Dolly got more fame for appearing in _The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas (1982)_ (qv), and in _Rhinestone (1984)_ (qv) with the song 'Tennessee Homesick Blues'. She is the head of Dolly Parton Enterprises, a $100 million media empire, and, in 1986, she founded Dollywood, a theme park in Pigeon Forge, Tennessee, celebrating her Smokey Mountain upbringing. She appeared as herself in the _'Dolly' (1987)_ (qv) TV series. In 1988, she won another Grammy award: Best Country Performance Duo or Group with Vocals, for 'Trio'. Dolly was in the acclaimed picture _Steel Magnolias (1989)_ (qv) with 'Julia Roberts (I)' (qv), and went on to appear in 15 movies and TV-movies for the 1990s, and of course garnered more Country Music Association awards. In 2000, Dolly received her 5th Grammy award: Best Country Collaboration with Vocals. She also released a Bluegrass Album. Dolly is known for beautiful songs such as 'Coat of Many Colors' and 'Jolene' and 'I Will Always Love You'. Dolly said in an interview, 'My music is what took me everywhere I've been and everywhere I will go. It's my greatest love. I can't abandon it. I'll always keep making records'. Dolly grew up on a run-down farm in Locust Ridge, Tennessee. At 12, she was appearing on Knoxville TV and, at 13, she was already recording on a small label and appearing at the Grand Ole Opry. After graduating from high school in Sevier County, Tennessee, in 1964, she moved to Nashville to launch her career as a country singer. She fell in love with 'Carl Dean' (qv), who ran an asphalt-paving business; they got married on May 30, 1966 (and they are still together). The next year, Dolly's singing caught the attention of 'Porter Wagoner' (qv). He hired Dolly to appear on his program, _'The Porter Wagoner Show' (1961)_ (qv). Dolly stayed with the show for 7 years, their duets became famous, and she appeared with his group at the Grand Ole Opry; she also toured and sold records. By the time her hit 'Joshua' reached #1 in 1970, her fame had overshadowed Porter's, and she struck out on her own, though still recording duets with him. She left him for good to become a solo artist in 1974. Dolly gained immense popularity as a singer/songwriter. Dolly won numerous Country Music Association awards (1968, 1970, 1971, 1975, 1976). This petite (5'0') beauty was a natural for television and, by the mid-1970s, Dolly was appearing frequently on TV specials and talk shows. She is the head of Dolly Parton Enterprises, a $100 million media empire, and, in 1986, she founded Dollywood, a theme park in Pigeon Forge, Tennessee, celebrating her Smokey Mountain upbringing. She appeared as herself in the _'Dolly' (1987)_ (qv) TV series. In 1988, she won another Grammy award: Best Country Performance Duo or Group with Vocals, for 'Trio'. Dolly was in the acclaimed picture _Steel Magnolias (1989)_ (qv) with 'Julia Roberts (I)' (qv), and went on to appear in 15 movies and TV-movies for the 1990s, and of course garnered more Country Music Association awards. Dolly is known for beautiful songs such as 'Coat of Many Colors' and 'Jolene' and 'I Will Always Love You'. Dolly said in an interview, 'My music is what took me everywhere I've been and everywhere I will go. It's my greatest love. I can't abandon it. I'll always keep making records'. Series Production Designer Genre genre writer   Joe Eszterhas gender other works trivia spouse article quotes interviews birth notes books aka name trade mark birth name where now birth date 'Playboy' (USA), April 1998, Vol. 45, Iss. 4, pg. 55-64+157-160, by: Michael Fleming, 'The Playboy Interview' 'Naomi Baka' (30 July 1994 - present); 4 children 'Jen? Mate' (qv) sponsored his family's immigration from Europe. I wrote _Basic Instinct (1992)_ (qv) in a blind frenzy while listening almost non-stop to the Rolling Stones. I didn't outline the script and I didn't know my ending until I was almost two-thirds finished. It exploded out of my head - I kept hearing lines of dialogue and had to hurry to keep up with the voices I was hearing. I woke up at four in the morning and wrote lines of dialogue down. I wrote it in two shifts each day - from nine in the morning till one in the afternoon and from three in the afternoon to eight o'clock at night. From the time I began writing till the day my agent sold it at auction: thirteen days. Book, 'F.I.S.T.,' the novelization of his script for _F.I.S.T (1978)_ (qv). Eszterh?s, J?zsef 23 November 1944 (February 2004) Wrote and published his memoirs called 'Hollywood Animal'. Joe Eszterhas. _Hollywood Animal._ New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 2004. ISBN 0375413553 Joe Eszterhas 'The Washington Post' (USA), 8 February 2004, Vol. 127, Iss. 65, pg. Series Production Designer Genre genre writer  Navid Khonsari   Raised in Iran and Canada, Khonsari was first introduced to filmmaking through his grandfather's super 8mm films. He developed an appreciation for storytelling from his grandmother, who would recite stories (both fictional and historical) from memory. Khonsari fell in love with video games after playing Pitfall on Atari.  He graduated from the University of British Columbia, and also studied at the Vancouver Film School. His first short film was entitled 'Arcade Angels', which focused on video game burnouts who robbed a video rental store and then opened an arcade. He wrote and produced The Contract, his first film with Billy Dee Williams. Khonsari broke out on to the gaming scene with Grand Theft Auto III and Max Payne.  He met his wife Vassiliki, while working on Pindemonium. They own and operate iNK Stories, a studio based out of New York and Toronto. Navid Khonsari Male

Series Production Designer Genre genre writer  Lazlow Jones   Graduated from Harvard University at the age of 21, acted as student body vice president during his 4 years in Harvard. Credited for writing and voicing parody advertisements on the Grand Theft Auto games series by Rockstar Games. Producer of parody shows 'The Lazlow Show' named after himself. Later became a real talk show. Lazlow Jones Lazlow Male Currently does 'The Lazlow Show' on Opie & Anthony's XM channel, The Virus 202.

Video Game Movie Production Designer Writer actor production designer  Bruce Bellamy David Leitch   Bruce Bellamy Only the incompetent ever need panic. David Leitch Dave Leitch 5' 11' Male
Video Game Movie Production Designer Writer actor production designer Jack Martin Smith  David Leitch   2 January 1911 Jack Martin Smith graduated with a degree in architecture from the University of Southern California. He joined MGM as a sketch artist and designer in 1938 (among others, creating drawings for the Emerald City in _The Wizard of Oz (1939)_ (qv)) and the following year was promoted to full art director. He worked for the studio until 1954, chiefly associated with creating the lavish, mythical backgrounds for the big budget musicals produced by the 'Arthur Freed' (qv) unit, foremost among them _Meet Me in St. Louis (1944)_ (qv), _Ziegfeld Follies (1945)_ (qv) and _Easter Parade (1948)_ (qv).  In 1954, Smith joined 20th Century Fox, collaborating with 'Lyle R. Wheeler' (qv) on creating the sumptuous look of _An Affair to Remember (1957)_ (qv) and _Peyton Place (1957)_ (qv). He eventually succeeded Wheeler as supervising art director, putting his stamp on some of the most spectacular blockbusters of the era, including _Cleopatra (1963)_ (qv) and _Hello, Dolly! (1969)_ (qv). From the early 60's, he also worked extensively in television. In addition to his work in Hollywood, Smith was an accomplished painter of seascapes and river scenes. Jack Martin Smith Santa Barbara, California, USA Jack M. Smith Los Angeles, California, USA David Leitch Dave Leitch 5' 11' Male

Steven Mirkovich Male 3 April 1965 'Bikini' (USA), February 1998, Iss. 29, pg. 14-15, by: Walter Cessna, 'Angie, Baby' Angela Eileen Featherstone is a Canadian actress. She is best known for playing Linda, Adam Sandler's ex-girlfriend, in The Wedding Singer. Angela Featherstone was a model in the 1980's. She has been an actress since 1992 in films and television. While acting Featherstone created sitcoms she sold to Sony, DreamWorks and NBC television in the 90's. She has written non fiction for Time, Jane and Flare magazines and in July 2011 she had her curatorial debut at the Robert Berman Gallery. She lives in Los Angeles, CA. Crew Member TV Movie Actress editor actress Steve Mirkovich  Rachel Ticotin gender trivia spouse quotes interviews birth notes aka name where now mini biography birth date height pictorial Steve Mirkovich Father of Tim Mirkovich. Steven Mirkovich Male 'Starlog' (USA), September 1990, Iss. 158, by: Will Murray, 'Rebel Rouser' 'David Caruso (I)' (qv) (1983 - 1989) (divorced); 1 daughter She trained as a ballet dancer before she began acting. 'Celebrity Sleuth' (USA), 1993, Vol. 6, Iss. 4, pg. 40-41, by: staff, 'Lethal Women: Rachel Ticotin, 'Total Recall'' I'm more interested in my life than I am in my career. I don't want to not work. I do enjoy working, but not to the point where that's the only thing I focus on. 1 November 1958 (March 2008) Appearing on Broadway as Lady Macduff in Macbeth with 'Patrick Stewart (I)' (qv). One tough cookie who can definitely hold her own next to the boys on film and TV, lovely, dark-haired Rachel Ticotin has stepped up to the plate many times in strong-armed femme roles, playing everything from cops and bodyguards to military corporals. Born and raised in the Bronx, she learned the fine art of discipline at a young age with ballet training at age 8. She made her first stage appearance at age 10 as a Siamese princess in a production of 'The King and I' at NYC's City Center Theatre. At age twelve she joined the Ballet Hispanico of New York and went on to work with such famed choreographers as 'Alvin Ailey' (qv), 'Geoffrey Holder' (qv) and 'Anna Sokolow' (qv). She made her film debut at age 20 in a bit role as a gypsy dancer in the _King of the Gypsies (1978)_ (qv) starring 'Eric Roberts (I)' (qv). She gained valuable experience in off-Broadway shows and on the other side of the camera as a production assistant for such films as _The Wanderers (1979)_ (qv), _Dressed to Kill (1980)_ (qv) and _Raging Bull (1980)_ (qv).  Rachel earned her big break after being handed the top female role opposite 'Paul Newman (I)' (qv) and 'Edward Asner' (qv) in the brutal police film _Fort Apache the Bronx (1981)_ (qv). Television became a viable forum with the TV pilot _For Love and Honor (1983) (TV)_ (qv) as Corporal Grace Pavlik. The pilot introduced her to up-and-coming actor 'David Caruso (I)' (qv). They married later that year. Rachel went on to appear in the short-lived series version of _'For Love and Honor' (1983)_ (qv) without Caruso. Other television projects included assertive roles in _Prison Stories: Women on the Inside (1991) (TV)_ (qv), _Aftershock: Earthquake in New York (1999) (TV)_ (qv) and _Warden of Red Rock (2001) (TV)_ (qv). On the big screen she played tough in _Critical Condition (1987)_ (qv), _Where the Day Takes You (1991)_ (qv), and _Falling Down (1993)_ (qv).  Her best known role is probably the 'Arnold Schwarzenegger' (qv) sci-fi blockbuster _Total Recall (1990)_ (qv) in which the athletic Rachel has a memorable fisticuffs scene with 'Sharon Stone (I)' (qv). In 1997, Rachel earned an ALMA award for her role as a prison guard in _Con Air (1997)_ (qv). Divorced from Caruso after six years in 1989, she later met actor 'Peter Strauss (I)' (qv) on the set of the TV movie _Thicker Than Blood: The Larry McLinden Story (1994) (TV)_ (qv). They married in 1998. In series drama she joined the cast of _'Ohara' (1987)_ (qv) as a U.S. attorney and played detective in the police drama _'Crime & Punishment' (1993)_ (qv).  Although she has yet to hit the very top rungs of stardom, Rachel is a proven talent. Alluring as well as enduring, her latest work in the popular films _Something's Gotta Give (2003)_ (qv) starring 'Jack Nicholson (I)' (qv) and Oscar-nominated 'Diane Keaton' (qv), _Man on Fire (2004)_ (qv) with 'Denzel Washington' (qv) and the recent _The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)_ (qv), not to mention the critically acclaimed bi-cultural series _'American Family' (2002)_ (qv), is proof of the pudding. Rachel Ticotin Rachel Ticoti 5' 7' Bronx, New York, USA Female
