Video Game Series Character Person actor references  Paul Benjamin    1938 Born and raised for a time in Pelion, South Carolina, African-American actor Paul Benjamin is the youngest of twelve children born to a Baptist preacher, the Reverend Fair Benjamin, and his wife Rosa. Paul lost his mother while still a baby and his father as a child. He moved to Columbia, South Carolina, where he was taken in by one of his older brothers, David, and his wife and family. Suppressing his teenage desires of becoming an actor due to social pressures, he attended C.A. Johnson High and, upon graduation, enrolled at Benedict College for about a year before deciding to move to New York City and pursue his dream. Studying at the 'Herbert Berghof' (qv) Studio, he finally made his professional stage debut in the late 60s at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. His theater career quickly picked up steam with such classical and contemporary plays as 'Hamlet' (1967), 'Cities in Bezique (1969), 'The Owl Answers' (1969), 'No Place to Be Somebody' (1969), 'The Year Boston Won the Pennant' (1969), 'Camino Royal' 1970, 'Operation Sidewinder' (1970), Boesman and Lena (1970), 'The Black Terror' (1971), 'Assassination 1865' (1971), 'The Cherry Orchard' (1973) and 'The Old Glory' (1976).  Benjamin made his film debut inauspiciously as a bartender in _Midnight Cowboy (1969)_ (qv), which highlighted New York's seamier side. Following small roles in _The Anderson Tapes (1971)_ (qv) and _Born to Win (1971)_ (qv), he earned a top featured role and strong notices playing a robber-turned-killer in _Across 110th Street (1972)_ (qv) co-starring 'Anthony Quinn (I)' (qv) and 'Yaphet Kotto' (qv), which again took place on the gritty New York streets. He then gave incisive, strong-armed portrayals as part of a gang in _The Deadly Trackers (1973)_ (qv) and as a lieutenant alongside 'Tony Lo Bianco' (qv) and 'Hal Linden' (qv) in the above-average TV-movie _Mr. Inside/Mr. Outside (1973) (TV)_ (qv). His film and TV career, which peaked in the 1970s, included the 'blaxploitation' scene -- he appeared with 'Mary Alice (I)' (qv) as the parents of the titular character in _The Education of Sonny Carson (1974)_ (qv) and as a senator in the 'Pam Grier' (qv) vehicle _Friday Foster (1975)_ (qv).  Throughout the decades he has worked with prestigious actors in prestigious projects yet never attained the public attention he merited. Neverthless he added solid authenticity to the musical bio _Leadbelly (1976)_ (qv); 'Clint Eastwood' (qv)'s _Escape from Alcatraz (1979)_ (qv); the 'Richard Pryor' (qv) comedy-drama _Some Kind of Hero (1982)_ (qv); 'Barbra Streisand' (qv)'s courtroom vehicle _Nuts (1987)_ (qv); 'Spike Lee' (qv)'s lacerating, one-two punch on urban black life in _Do the Right Thing (1989)_ (qv); the Temptations-like story of _The Five Heartbeats (1991)_ (qv); and the excellent, fact-based drama in _Rosewood (1997)_ (qv) with racism at its core. On the mini-movie circuit he appeared in good company as 'LeVar Burton' (qv)'s father in the baseball story _One in a Million: The Ron LeFlore Story (1977) (TV)_ (qv), and was a noticeable factor in _Gideon's Trumpet (1980) (TV)_ (qv) starring 'Henry Fonda' (qv); 'Maya Angelou' (qv)'s _I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings (1979) (TV)_ (qv); the hard-hitting _'The Atlanta Child Murders' (1985)_ (qv)_ (TV) and, perhaps most notably, the chain-gang story _The Man Who Broke 1,000 Chains (1987) (TV)_ (qv) in which he portrayed Big Sam.  Paul the actor has added to his success as an award-winning playwright as well and, broaching age 70, continues to write as well as perform. His play 'Carrier', in which he appeared with 'Roscoe Lee Browne' (qv) and 'Paula Kelly (I)' (qv), received special citations for its writing and performances. Paul Benjamin Mayor Tom Bradley presented Paul with a Commendation from the City of Los Angeles for Paul's play, 'Carrier,' for which 'Paula Kelly (I)' (qv) won the 1982 NAACP Image Awards for Best Actress. She, along with Paul and actor/poet Roscoe Lee Browne, received Certificates of Recognition from Sen. Diane Watson for their performances in the same play. 6' 1 1/2' Pelion, South Carolina, USA Male

Video Game Series Character Person actor references    Ewan Bailey birth notes gender aka name trivia mini biography birth date spouse height 1966 'Ruth' (1997 - present); 1 child Ewan Bailey was born in 1966 in Brighton, Sussex,as Ewan Thomson, the son of Dr. Bruce Thomson, a noted Rugby Union player who represented Scotland at international level. He attended Brighton College and read Modern History at Keble College, Oxford, before studying drama at the Central School of Speech and Drama in London. In 2001 he was one of the actor presenters of the BBC radio satirical show 'The Sunday Format', mocking Sunday newspaper contents, and has provided the narration for numerous television documentaries on Channel 4 and the Discovery Channel. He is also the founder of Rubbaball, a small comedy theater company. Ewan Bailey Graduated from Oxford University with a degree in Modern History. Has a Black Belt (Second Dan) in Shotokan Karate. Ewan Bailley 191 cm Brighton, Sussex, England, UK Male

Episode Director Person production designer director Peter Jamison Penelope Spheeris   27 August 1944 Peter Jamison 15 October 2010 Venice, California, USA (complications from heart disease) Peter Michael Jamison Oregon, USA 2 December 1945 'Robert Biggs (I)' (qv) (7 July 1977 - 14 December 1984) (divorced) Penelope Spheeris 'Creem' (USA), September 1988, Vol. 19, Iss. 11, pg. 55, by: Vicki Arkoff, ''Screenbeat: Comfortably Dumb'' _What We Do Is Secret (2007)_ (qv) She studied psychobiology (studying how the brain reacts to external forces) and film in college, eventually attending the film program at UCLA. After college, she produced short and feature length films directed by comic 'Albert Brooks (I)' (qv), some of which were shown during the first season of _'Saturday Night Live' (1975)_ (qv). P. Spheeris My whole career up until _Wayne's World (1992)_ (qv) didn't produce any monetary funds. When I directed Wayne's World, I made close to $150,000 - the biggest payday I had to date. My percentage points from Wayne's World enabled me to pay off all of the debts from my previous works, but I only came up even in the end. New Orleans, Louisiana, USA Female Print ads for Directors Guild of America (2001)
Episode Director Person production designer director Bobby Roth    1950 Bobby Roth grew up in Los Angeles, a block from where he lives today. He studied Philosophy and Creative Writing at UC Berkeley, then got a BA in Cinema at USC in 1972, and an MFA in Motion Picture Production from UCLA in 1975. For his entire career he has alternated between independent filmmaking and commercial television. In the early eighties he had an overall deal to write, produce and direct for Universal, where he created the series 'The Insiders' for ABC.  His independent films have now been exhibited in over one hundred film festivals worldwide, five of which have premiered at Sundance where Bobby has also been a judge.  He was a founding member of the Independent Feature Project and also a founding member of the DGA's Independent Feature Committee where he was its first Co-Chairman. Bobby Roth Father of 'Nick Roth (I)' (qv). Robert J. Roth Female Roth, Robert Jay
Episode Director Person production designer director Steve Bass  Glenn Weiss gender aka name birth name Multi-Emmy Award winner Steve Bass has designed many of the most prestigious live and televised shows produced, including the Oscars, Grammys, Emmys and Tony Awards. His talents were tapped for the Opening and Closing Ceremonies of the Atlanta Olympics, Salt Lake Olympics Medals Plaza, The Democratic Convention, Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus, and the Inaugural Celebration at the Lincoln Memorial for President Obama.  Live show design includes mega hits from Disney: the Lion King Celebration and a theatrical production of The Little Mermaid which to date has been seen by over 25 million guests, as well as the national tour of Disney's Symphonic Fantasy and Sesame Street Live. Recent live productions include DreamWorks Madagascar Live!, Disney's Mad T Party: an innovative experiential nightclub, and the award-winning Starlight Parade for Universal Studios Japan.  Steve has a long-standing history designing for iconic entertainment programs such as Great Performances, Nickelodeon's Kids Choice, Christmas in Washington, TV Land, and Entertainment Tonight, as well as corporate events for auto giants Lexus and Toyota. Steve Bass Glenn Weiss Glenn P. Weiss Male Weiss, Glenn P.

Episode Director Person production designer director Andy Walmsley Adam Shankman   Andy Walmsley 27 November 1964 'Out' (USA), February 2002, pg. 17-19, by: Chris Gardner, 'Taking Direction' Adam Shankman 'The Chicago Tribune' (USA), 4 March 2005, by: Mike Szymanski, 'Director Shankman Finds his 'Pacifier'' While a guest on NPR's 'Fresh Air With Terry Gross' in July 2007, Shankman revealed to Gross that he did not start dancing until he was 18, which is very late for someone who intends to become a professional dancer. Furthermore, once he decided to become a dancer, he auditioned for college dance programs all over the country, including NYU, North Carolina, and Julliard (the most prestigious and selective dance program in the United States), and he got into all of them without ever once having taken a dance class. Characters being sent to do community service Adam M. Shankman [In response to Kevin Naff's (editor of The Washington Blade) proposed boycott of film 'Hairspray' (2007) by gays, which claimed star John Travolta had 'no business' playing an iconic gay character] 'I am stunned this has gotten that far. He (Naff) has made the dumbest claims on the entire planet. Everybody involved in 'Hairspray' - all the creators are gay. So John has no problem with people being gay - me, the writers, composer, John Waters - all gay. John's personal beliefs never walked onto my set. I never heard the word 'Scientology.'' Los Angeles, California, USA Male Shankman, Adam Michael
Episode Director Person production designer director Jeff Margolis  Roy Christopher gender other works biographical movies name trivia quotes Jeff Margolis Male Roy Christopher Attended California State University, Fresno. I grew up as a farm boy in Fresno, which is an agricultural town plunked in the middle of California--thousands of miles mentally from Hollywood. I'd watch the Academy Awards and it was such a magical event. I really wanted to be part of that world, like everyone does. Person  Mark Wahlberg gender other works trivia nick names spouse article quotes interviews birth notes books aka name trade mark birth name mini biography birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial 'The Advocate' (USA), 25 January 1994, Iss. 646/647, pg. 61-74, by: Judy Wieder, 'His Turn' 'Rhea Durham' (qv) (1 August 2009 - present); 4 children Has stated that he struggled with weight gain his whole life. 'Cinema' (Hungary), November 1998, Iss. 84, pg. 81, 'Az a kis plusz' Marty and I were constantly in this struggle. I had problems with Marty. He was 'I'm 'Martin Scorsese' (qv)... da-dee-da.' He was pushing me in different ways. But it wasn't just Marty. The whole time I was in the character so I was mad at everybody. It was Leo, Matt and Jack. Fuck Jack too. We were able to laugh about it afterwards and we have a great relationship now and we're going to do other stuff in the future. (2000) Music video for Black Label Society: 'Counterfeit God' as the stand-in bass player Wahlberg, Mark Robert Michael 5 June 1971 Marky Mark Mark Wahlberg, with Lynn Goldsmith. _Marky Mark._ New York: HarperCollins, 1992. American actor Mark Wahlberg is one of a handful of respected entertainers who successfully made the transition from teen pop idol to respected actor. A Best Supporting Actor Oscar nominee for _The Departed (2006)_ (qv) who went on to receive positive critical reviews for his performance in _The Fighter (2010)_ (qv), Wahlberg also is a solid comedy actor, proven by his starring role in _Ted (2012)_ (qv).  Born Mark Robert Michael Wahlberg on June 5, 1971 in Dorchester neighborhood of Boston, Massachusetts, Wahlberg is the youngest of nine children. Wahlberg became involved in drugs at a young age and, following a string of pretty crimes, was convicted of assault against two men in 1988. He was sentenced to two years in state prison at Boston's Deer Island House of Correction, but served 45 days. Wahlberg cites his jail time as being his motivation to improve his life. Around this time, his older brother 'Donnie Wahlberg' (qv) had become an overnight teen idol as a member of the 1980's boy band New Kids on the Block.  Donnie used his connections in the music business to help his little brother secure a recording contract, and soon the world was introduced to Marky Mark and the Funky Bunch, with Wahlberg as a bad-boy rapper who danced in his boxers. This led to a modeling contract with Calvin Klein, widespread fame and a 1992 biography that he dedicated to his penis. As that last detail hints, Wahlberg tended to get in trouble with his mouth, which was feverishly reported upon in the tabloids. But it was his appearance on a British talk show with rapper Shabba Ranks that effectively ended Wahlberg's career as a hip-hop star: When Ranks made blatantly homophobic statements that Wahlberg did nothing to refute, he soon found himself accused of bigotry. His second album was a flop, and soon after Wahlberg abandoned his rap career.  Using his real name, Wahlberg made his big screen debut in 'Penny Marshall (I)' (qv)'s _Renaissance Man (1994)_ (qv). This was followed by a performance in _The Basketball Diaries (1995)_ (qv) that earned him positive critical notice, and a deeply disturbing role in _Fear (1996)_ (qv) as a violent, obsessed stalker.  The major turning point in Wahlberg's career came with the role of troubled porn star Dirk Diggler in 'Paul Thomas Anderson' (qv)'s _Boogie Nights (1997)_ (qv). Since then, Wahlberg has chosen roles that demonstrate a wide range of dramatic ability, starring in critically acclaimed dramas such as _Three Kings (1999)_ (qv) and _The Perfect Storm (2000)_ (qv), popcorn flicks like _Planet of the Apes (2001)_ (qv) and _Contraband (2012)_ (qv), and even indies such as _I Heart Huckabees (2004)_ (qv).  Wahlberg also is the executive producer of such television series as _'Boardwalk Empire' (2010)_ (qv), _'In Treatment' (2008)_ (qv) and the highly successful comedy _'Entourage' (2004)_ (qv), which was partly based on his experiences in Hollywood.  Wahlberg and his wife 'Rhea Durham' (qv) have four children. Mark Wahlberg 'TimeOut' (), July 2001, Iss. 293, pg. 32, by: Miwa Hirai, 'Planet of the Apes' Often plays tough, no-nonsense characters 'Premiere' (USA), May 1998, Vol. II, Iss. 9 Monk D 5' 8' Dorchester, Boston, Massachusetts, USA Male

Person  Toni Basil birth notes gender other works aka name trivia birth name mini biography birth date article pictorial 22 September 1943 Toni Basil began her career as a dancer and assistant choreographer, working on such shows as _'Hullabaloo' (1965)_ (qv) choreographed by David Winters. Later, she choreographed the hit film _American Graffiti (1973)_ (qv) and also began appearing in films, including the now-classic _Easy Rider (1969)_ (qv). After several films, she launched her music career with her first album, 'Word of Mouth', in 1981, which was released both as a record and a video, quite an innovation at the time. Culled from that album was a innocent little ditty called 'Mickey', which soon became a massive hit all over the world, first in Britain. The song topped the American music charts in December 1982, and the video (directed by Basil, as were all of her others) still receives airplay, today. In 1984, Toni Basil's self-titled follow-up album was released, which included the American Top 40 hit 'Over My Head'. Although she found future chart success elusive, Basil remained busy appearing in such films as _Rockula (1990)_ (qv) and has appeared in a guest shot on _'Baywatch' (1989)_ (qv) in the late 1990s. Her choreographer talents have also been utilized lately by superstars 'Bette Midler' (qv) and 'David Bowie' (qv) and, in 1998, she choreographed a successful ad for 'The Gap'. Toni Basil 'Entertainment Weekly' (USA), 1 November 1996, Iss. 351, pg. 84, by: Dave Karger, 'What Ever Happened To...Toni Basil' Was head cheerleader at Las Vegas High School and wears her actual varsity uniform from those days in the 'Mickey' video. 'Celebrity Sleuth' (USA), 1992, Vol. 6, Iss. 1, pg. 50-51, by: staff, 'Contro-Verses: Mickey' Tony Basil Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA Female Music video: Directed 'Talking Heads' (qv) video 'Once in a Lifetime'. Person  Dickie Moore birth notes books gender other works aka name trivia birth name mini biography birth date spouse quotes 12 September 1925 Dickie Moore (as Dick Moore). _Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star._ New York: Harper & Row, 1984. 'Jane Powell (I)' (qv) (21 May 1988 - present) Dickie Moore made his acting and screen debut at the age of 18 months in the 1927 'John Barrymore (I)' (qv) film _The Beloved Rogue (1927)_ (qv) as a baby, and by the time he had turned 10 he was a popular child star and had appeared in 52 films. He continued as a child star for many more years, and became the answer to the trivia question, 'Who was the first actor to kiss 'Shirley Temple' (qv) on screen?' when that honor was bestowed upon him in 1942's _Miss Annie Rooney (1942)_ (qv). As with many child actors, once Dickie got older the roles began to dry up. He made his last film in 1950, but was still in the public eye with the 1949 to 1955 TV series _'Captain Video and His Video Rangers' (1949)_ (qv). He then retired from acting for a new career in publicity. He currently produces industrial shows. Dickie Moore In 1957 he accepted the newly designed post of public relations director of Actors Equity. In 1964 he left to form his own public relations firm, Dick Moore Associates. Dickey Moore I think performers have a real need to be made aware of the fact that their gifts and talents have a residual use. I'm always interested in anybody's story where they have managed to beat the odds and come out doing something they want to do, and still be able to utilize their backgrounds. It's worked for me. Los Angeles, California, USA Male (1999) Release of his book, 'Opportunities in Acting Careers'. The foreword was by 'Roddy McDowall' (qv). Jr., John Richard Moore

Video Game TV Movie Actress Cinematographer actress crew member Kelly McGillis Alpha Barry    'Parade Magazine' (USA), November 1997, pg. 22, by: James Brady, 'In Step With: Kelly McGillis' 'Boyd Black' (14 April 1979 - 1981) (divorced) Wanted to play the role of 'Kathryn Murphy', the district attorney in _The Accused (1988)_ (qv), because she and her roommate were assaulted and raped by two men in their apartment in 1982. 'Celebrity Sleuth' (USA), 1991, Vol. 5, Iss. 1, pg. 58-59, by: staff, 'Not To Be Myth'd: Kelly McGillis' For a long time I thought I could deal with my anger and hostility on my own. But I couldn't. I denied that it had affected me, and yet I was so frantic on the inside with other people: I needed to be constantly reassured. It wasn't until I started seeing myself self-destructing that I realized I needed help. To realize how angry I was and to ask for help -- those were the stepping stones. There's a part of me that wants to be stoic and very strong. I had to realize that the attack wasn't directed at me, as Kelly. It was random. I was at the wrong place at the wrong time. That was the first step toward getting rid of all those hostile feelings I had about it. Still, when you're a victim of a violent crime -- when somebody has taken control over your life, if only for a moment -- I don't think you ever fully recover. - Speaking about her reactions to being raped. Appeared in production of John Webber's play 'The Duchess of Malfi' at the Shakespeare Theatre, Washington, DC. (2002) McGillis, Kelly Ann 9 July 1957 (March 2004) Performing on stage as 'Mrs. Robinson' in the national touring company of the play 'The Graduate.' Kelly McGillis was born in Newport Beach, California, to Joan, a homemaker, and Donald McGillis, a general practitioner of medicine. She decided to drop out of high school to pursue a career as an actress and eventually attended Juilliard in Manhattan and Pacific Conservatory of Performing Art in Santa Monica, CA.  She held a variety of jobs while pursuing her career, such as waitressing, and snagged a few stage roles before landing a supporting part in the Academy Award-nominated _Reuben, Reuben (1983)_ (qv). This led to a lot of TV work and a lead role opposite 'Harrison Ford (I)' (qv) in the highly acclaimed thriller _Witness (1985)_ (qv). This box office hit, directed by 'Peter Weir (I)' (qv), got her noticed around Hollywood and producers took note of her. One of them was 'Jerry Bruckheimer' (qv), who cast her as Charlie Blackwood in the mega-hit _Top Gun (1986)_ (qv) which became the highest-grossing film of the year and gave her some major name recognition.  Ironically, that breakthrough role didn't help her career in terms of high-profile work. She played prosecutor Kathryn Murphy in _The Accused (1988)_ (qv) with 'Jodie Foster' (qv) who won an Academy Award for her role, but unfortunately for McGillis she was overlooked for any major nomination. Never interested in being box-office gold, she remained loyal to the theater, even after being established as a major star during the mid to late 1980s, taking such various stage roles in such 'William Shakespeare (I)' (qv) plays as 'The Merchant of Venice', 'Don Juan', 'Twelfth Night', 'The Merry Wives of Windsor', 'Mourning Becomes Electra' and 'A Midsummer Night's Dream'. In 1994 she scored the title role in the Broadway production of 'Hedda Gabler' but unfortunately it only played for 33 performances before closing.  She had two daughters in the early 1990s, and worked more sporadically on TV and film so she could spend time with her family and owned her business, a restaurant in Florida. She worked on _Winter People (1989)_ (qv), _Cat Chaser (1989)_ (qv), _The Babe (1992)_ (qv), _North (1994)_ (qv), _At First Sight (1999)_ (qv) and _The Monkey's Mask (2000)_ (qv) as well as a string of made-for-TV films.  She has completed a national stage tour of 'The Graduate', playing the infamous Mrs. Robinson, and continues to act as she begins study on Addiction Studies and raising her children in Pennsylvania. Kelly McGillis 'Prevue' (USA), June 1990, Vol. 2, Iss. 39, pg. 48-49, by: Lowell Goldman, 'Chasing Kelly McGillis' 'Kino' (Germany), December 1986 Kelly Ann McGillis 5' 10' Newport Beach, California, USA Female Alpha Barry

Video Game TV Movie Actress Cinematographer actress crew member Alpha Barry   Christine Hewett birth notes gender death date name mini biography birth date death notes Alpha Barry 11 August 1943 A tall, fair-haired model since the late sixties, Christine Hewitt appeared in the cantina sequence of _Star Wars (1977)_ (qv) together with another 'Space Girl', Angela Staines. Although the casting call asked for blonde girls, both of them were fitted with black beehive style wigs for the occasion. Even though she was on screen for less than 5 seconds in the finished film, her character received a name and a back-story through Star Wars games and merchandising, and is listed as such on this database. Nowadays, Christine Hewitt still works as a 'mature model' in commercials and in uncredited roles in films such as _Four Weddings and a Funeral (1994)_ (qv) and _Bridget Jones's Diary (2001)_ (qv). Christine Hewett 19 September 2007 England, UK (cancer) London, England, UK Female

Video Game TV Movie Actress Cinematographer actress crew member Alpha Barry Lois Chiles    Alpha Barry 'Richard Gilder' (qv) (2005 - present) Her younger brother, with whom she was extremely close, tragically died of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in 1978. She made a choice to take a three-year hiatus from acting as a result just as her career had reached its peak. Her film career never fully recovered after she came back. She originally was offered the top Bondian love interest that 'Barbara Bach (I)' (qv) portrayed in _The Spy Who Loved Me (1977)_ (qv) by director 'Lewis Gilbert (II)' (qv) but turned it because of her initial self-imposed hiatus. The director, however, convinced her to play Holly Goodhead in _Moonraker (1979)_ (qv) before she left the screen. Series Character Editor actor writer Bert Lahr   'Mildred Schroeder' (11 February 1940 - 4 December 1967) (his death); 2 children New York City, New York, USA (hemorrhage and pneumonia) Actor 'Tommy Bond (I)' (qv) who was also 'Butch' in the 'Little Rascals' and 'Jimmy Olsen' in the original _Atom Man vs. Superman (1950)_ (qv) serials, was a regular on Lahr's radio show in the 1930's, and played his son. Hollywood is the only community in the world where the entire population is suffering from 'rumourtism.' ORALL1721 Lahrheim, Irving 13 August 1895 'John Lahr' (qv). _Notes on a Cowardly Lion: The Biography of Bert Lahr._ New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1969. ISBN 0394438728 Fittingly known to be a 'Leo' for his horoscope, Bert Lahr is always remembered as the Cowardly Lion in (and the farmer 'Zeke') _The Wizard of Oz (1939)_ (qv). But during his acting career, he has been known for being in burlesque, vaudeville, and Broadway.  Dropped out of high school at the age of fifteen for a juvenile vaudeville act, Lahr worked his way up to the top billing of the Columbia Burlesque Circuit. When in Broadway, Lahr usually plays a comic actor in plays which he starred in such as the classic routine The Song of the Woodman, which he would later perform in _Merry Go Round of 1938 (1937)_ (qv).  Aside from _The Wizard of Oz (1939)_ (qv), Lahr's movie career never caught on because his gestures and reactions were too broad. Lahr died in 1967. Bert Lahr 4 December 1967 _Life with Judy Garland: Me and My Shadows (2001) (TV)_ (qv) 'Life' (USA), 13 May 1957 Irving Lahrheim 5' 9' New York City, New York, USA Male

Series Character Editor actor writer  Vince Vaughn gender other works trivia nick names spouse article quotes interviews aka name trade mark birth name where now mini biography birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial 'DreamWatch' (UK), July 1997, Iss. 35, pg. 61, by: Marc Shapiro, 'Snap happy' 'Kyla Weber' (2 January 2010 - present); 1 child [2008] Topped Forbes list of actors who give movie studios the best return on their investment, with his films earning $14.75 Dollars for every $1 Dollar he is paid. 'Premiere' (USA), October 1998, Vol. 11, Iss. 14, pg. 76-77, by: Andrew MacPherson My father's name is Vernon, and my mother liked the initials double V, so she named my sisters Victoria and Valerie. That's cool- except when the dogs start getting V names. Provides audio commentary with co-star 'Jon Favreau' (qv) on the DVD for _Made (2001)_ (qv). Vaughn, Vincent Anthony 28 March 1970 Mr Sunshine (July 2005) Filming _The Break-Up (2006)_ (qv) in Chicago with 'Jennifer Aniston' (qv). Vincent Anthony Vaughn was born on March 28, 1970, in Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA and raised in Lake Forest, Illinois, USA. His parents were 'Vernon Vaughn' (qv), a salesman, and 'Sharon Vaughn (II)' (qv), a real-estate agent and stockbroker. They later divorced in 1991. He also has two older sisters named 'Victoria Vaughn (I)' (qv) and 'Valeri Vaughn' (qv). Vince was interested in theater early on and grabbed a spot in a Chevy commercial. Figuring he was set, he packed his bags and headed for Hollywood only to become a struggling actor losing role after role. He managed to hit a few spots on television, but his real goal was to make it to the big screen. He made his first credited role in the film _Rudy (1993)_ (qv) where he met his friend 'Jon Favreau' (qv), who was writing a script detailing his life as an out-of-work actor. Vince was written into _Swingers (1996)_ (qv) by Jon to play the character of 'Trent'. He signed on just as a favor to his buddy, not realizing it would be a career changing role. Though not a commercial success, it was a critical success in which 'Steven Spielberg' (qv) saw him and cast him in the big budget sequel _The Lost World: Jurassic Park (1997)_ (qv). This role gave Vince the exposure he needed to become a movie star and, for the first time, choose the roles he wanted to take. _A Cool, Dry Place (1998)_ (qv) put him as a loving father, _Return to Paradise (1998)_ (qv) cast him as a man having to make a life or death decision to save a friend, and _Clay Pigeons (1998)_ (qv) cast him as an interesting serial killer. Since then his roles have been primarily in comedies such as _Old School (2003)_ (qv), _Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story (2004)_ (qv), _Wedding Crashers (2005)_ (qv), and _Couples Retreat (2009)_ (qv). Vince Vaughn 'Parade' (USA), 13 January 2008, pg. 9-10, by: Jeanne Wolf, 'I Work Hard, I Play Hard' Sardonic sense of Humour 'Parade' (USA), 13 January 2008 Vincent Vaughn 6' 5' Male
Series Character Editor actor writer  John Zurhellen   John Zurhellen Male

Series Character Editor actor writer   Spike Lee gender other works biographical movies trivia spouse article quotes interviews portrayed in birth notes books aka name trade mark birth name where now mini biography birth date magazine cover photo height pictorial 'Cineaste' (USA), 2001, Vol. XXVI, Iss. 2, pg. 4-9, by: Gary Crowdus and Dan Georgakas, 'Thinking About the Power of Images: An Interview with Spike Lee' 'Tonya Lewis Lee' (qv) (2 October 1993 - present); 2 children His grandmother, 'Zimmie Shelton' (qv), helped fund his first full-length feature film, _She's Gotta Have It (1986)_ (qv). 'Playboy' (USA), January 2004, Vol. 51, Iss. 1, pg. 96, by: Spike Lee, 'Lights, Camera, Fantasy!' [Speaking out after the death of comedian 'Richard Pryor' (qv)]: 'He was an innovator and a trailblazer. It's a great loss'. (2004) TV commercial: Directed commercial for Telecom _Spike Lee's '25th Hour': The Evolution of an American Filmmaker (2003) (V)_ (qv) Lee, Shelton Jackson 20 March 1957 (January 2010) Preparing to make a follow-up film to 'When the Levees Broke' Spike Lee, as told to Kaleem Aftab. _Spike Lee: That's My Story and I'm Sticking to It._ New York: W.W. Norton, 2005. ISBN 0393061531 Spike Lee was born Shelton Jackson Lee on March 20, 1957, in Atlanta, Georgia. At a very young age, he moved from pre-civil rights Georgia, to Brooklyn, New York. Lee came from artistic, education-grounded background; his father was a jazz musician, and his mother, a schoolteacher. He attended school in Morehouse College in Atlanta and developed his film making skills at Clark Atlanta University. After graduating from Morehouse, Lee attended the Tisch School of Arts graduate film program. He made a controversial short, _The Answer (1980)_ (qv), a reworking of 'D.W. Griffith (I)' (qv)'s The Birth of a Nation (1915)_ - a ten-minute film. Lee went on to produce a 45-minute film _Joe's Bed-Stuy Barbershop: We Cut Heads (1983)_ (qv), which won a student Academy Award.  In 1986, Spike Lee made the film, _She's Gotta Have It (1986)_ (qv), a comedy about sexual relationships. The movie was made for $175,000, and earned $7 million at the box office, which launched his career and allowed him to found his own production company, 40 Acres & a Mule Filmworks. His next movie was _School Daze (1988)_ (qv), which was set in a historically black school, focused mostly on the conflict between the school and the Fraternities, of which he was a strong critic, portraying them as materialistic, irresponsible, and uncaring. With his _School Daze (1988)_ (qv) profits, Lee went on to make his landmark film, _Do the Right Thing (1989)_ (qv), a movie based specifically his own neighborhood in Brooklyn, New York. The movie portrayed the racial tensions that emerge in the Bed-Stuy neighborhood on one very hot day. The movie garnered Oscar nominations for Best Original Screenplay, for 'Danny Aiello' (qv) for supporting actor, and sparked a debate on racial relations.  Lee went on to produce the jazz biopic _Mo' Better Blues (1990)_ (qv), the first of many Spike Lee films to feature 'Denzel Washington' (qv), including the biography of _Malcolm X (1992)_ (qv), in which 'Denzel Washington' (qv) portrayed the civil rights leader. The movie was a success, and garnering an Oscar nomination for Washington. The pair would work together again on, _He Got Game (1998)_ (qv), an excursion into the collegiate world showing the darker side of recruiting college athletes, as well as the 2006 film _Inside Man (2006)_ (qv).  Spike Lee's role as a documentarian has expanded over the years, highlighted by his part in _Lumi?re et compagnie (1995)_ (qv), the Oscar-nominated _4 Little Girls (1997)_ (qv), to his Peabody Award-winning biographical adaptation of Black Panther leader in _A Huey P. Newton Story (2001) (TV)_ (qv), through his 2005 Emmy Award-winning examination of post-Katrina New Orleans in _'When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts' (2006)_ (qv) and its follow-up five years later in _'If God Is Willing and da Creek Don't Rise' (2010)_ (qv).  Through his production company 40 Acres & A Mule Filmworks, Lee continues to create and direct both independent films and projects for major studios, as well as working on story development, creating an internship program for aspiring filmmakers, releasing music, and community outreach and support.  He is married to 'Tonya Lewis Lee' (qv), and they have two sons, Satchel and Jackson. Spike Lee 'Entertainment Weekly' (USA), 18 August 2006, Vol. 1, Iss. 891, pg. 37-38, by: Drumming, Neil, ''Spotlight'' _'Clerks' (2000)_ (qv) Baseball: Every one of his narrative feature films makes reference to baseball teams and players. 'Shift' (Canada), September 2000 Shelton J. Lee 5' 6' Atlanta, Georgia, USA Male

Female 18 September 1948 Jimmy Brogan _The Late Shift (1996) (TV)_ (qv) Jimmy Brogan served as a writer for the opening monologue on 'The Tonight Show with Jay Leno'. Jimmy would sit to one side of the audience while Jay told his jokes. On occasion, Jimmy and Jay would make a bet to see if a certain joke worked or not. If Jimmy won, Jay would walk down the stage, and pay Jimmy. If Jay won, Jimmy would come to the stage and pay off the bet. All this was done while the camera was running. 'Los Angeles Times Magazine' (USA), 22 February 1998 6' 1 1/2' Boston, Massachusetts, USA Male

Series Producer Country actress country Arlene Golonka    23 January 1936 'Michael Longo' (1963 - 1967) (divorced) A native Chicagoan, veteran character actress Arlene Golonka was born Arline Golonka. She seemed destined for acting from the start, having been named after silver screen actress 'Arline Judge' (qv), and her childhood was dominated by singing and acting classes. She headed to New York at the age of 19 and began a career on Broadway and in films made in New York City, generally playing bubble-headed or eccentric blondes, often prostitutes.  She relocated to Los Angeles in the late 60s. There, while continuing to play small roles on the big screen, she established one of the strongest resumes in television of any character actress, appearing in dozens of programs over the following three decades, often repeatedly on the same program and sometimes playing different characters.  Her TV appearances included such legendary programs as _'Mary Tyler Moore' (1970)_ (qv), _'All in the Family' (1971)_ (qv) and _'M*A*S*H' (1972)_ (qv). Her best-known recurring performance as the same character is probably 'Millie' on _'Mayberry R.F.D.' (1968)_ (qv).  Golonka has largely retired from television work but continues to take roles in feature films occasionally. Arlene Golonka The word 'golonka' is Polish for 'pigs' foot' or 'hamhock'. Chicago, Illinois, USA Female Comedy album, 'You Don't Have To Be Jewish', 1965 (character voices)

Language TV Movie Person actor language   Steve Zahn gender trivia spouse article quotes interviews birth notes aka name birth name mini biography birth date height 'Premiere' (USA), February 1997, Vol. 10, Iss. 6, pg. 35, by: Oliver Jones 'Robyn Peterman' (qv) (16 July 1994 - present); 2 children Graduated from Cooper High School, New Hope, Minnesota. [2007 quote] I've had more people come up to me about _Saving Silverman (2001)_ (qv) than anything else. That and _That Thing You Do! (1996)_ (qv) but 'Saving Silverman' is the one I get most often. And I love that. It's just funny that it didn't do that well in theaters. It did all right, but none of us were big stars at the time. 'Jason Biggs (I)' (qv) was probably bigger than any of us. That's another one that kind of baffles me. So many people have seen it. I got this big Western coming out. I have another crazy comedy that I really like, _Strange Wilderness (2008)_ (qv). It's just fucking dumb, and I can't wait to see how people react, because I just know that I'll have people approach me and say 'Strange Wilderness, man. That's my favorite movie'. I'll love that. Zahn, Steven James 13 November 1967 Career kicked off in his native Minnesota when he crashed the audition of a local stage production of 'Biloxi Blues' and won the lead role. Next trained at American Repertory Theatre in Cambridge, MA; then moved to New York City where he won a role touring for 13 months in national company of 'Tommy Tune' (qv)-directed version of 'Bye Bye Birdie'. Back in New York, he played opposite 'Ethan Hawke' (qv) in 'Sophistry' at Playwright's Horizon, where 'Ben Stiller' (qv) noticed him and cast him and Hawke in _Reality Bites (1994)_ (qv). III, Randolph Severn Parker 19 October 1969 (February 2005) Began working on beginning of season 9 of _'South Park' (1997)_ (qv) Trey was born in Conifer, Colorado, on October 19, 1969 to 'Randy Parker (I)' (qv) ,a geologist, and Sharon Parker, an insurance broker. He has an older sister, Shelley Parker. He met 'Matt Stone (I)' (qv) (co-creator of _'South Park' (1997)_ (qv)) while attending the University of Colorado in Boulder, where he had a double major of music and Japanese. While at UCB he wrote, directed and starred in _Alferd Packer: The Musical (1993)_ (qv) (aka 'Cannibal: The Musical!') based on a true episode in Colorado's history. After graduation from UCB (rumors that he didn't due to skipping classes to work on the movie are false), he and Stone were asked by then-FoxLab executive 'Brian Graden' (qv) to create an animated Christmas card for his friends and family. The now infamous short, titled _The Spirit of Christmas (1995)_ (qv), led to _'South Park' (1997)_ (qv). Series Producer Country production country writer Ian Fleming    'Anne Geraldine Charteris' (24 March 1952 - 12 August 1964) (his death); 1 child Canterbury, Kent, England, UK (heart attack) His wife, Anne Geraldine Charteris, was the granddaughter of the 9th Earl of Wemyss, and had been previously married to Shane O'Neill, 3rd Lord O'Neill (she was his widow) and then to Esmond Cecil Harmsworth, 2nd Viscount Rothermere, whom she divorced to marry Ian. Anne and Ian had one son, Casper Robert Fleming, born 12th of August 1952. I wanted the simplest, dullest, plainest-sounding name I could find, James Bond was much better than something more interesting like 'Peregrine Maltravers.' Exotic things would happen to and around him but he would be a neutral figure - an anonymous blunt instrument wielded by a Government Department. (1965) Novel (published posthumously): 'The Man With The Golden Gun' (filmed as _The Man with the Golden Gun (1974)_ (qv)) _'Explorations' (1956) {Ian Fleming: The Brain Behind Bond}_ (qv) 28 May 1908 'John Pearson (III)' (qv). _The Life of Ian Fleming._ London, England: Jonathon Cape Ltd., 1966. Born into a wealthy and influential English family, Ian Fleming spent his early years attending top British schools such as Eton and Sandhurst military academy. He took to writing while schooling in Kitzbuhel, Austria, and upon failing the entrance requirements for Foreign Service joined the news agency Reuters as a journalist -- winning the respect of his peers for his coverage of a 'show trial' in Russia of several Royal Engineers on espionage charges. Fleming briefly worked in the financial sector for the family bank, but just prior to the Second World War, was recruited into British Naval Intelligence where he excelled, shortly achieving the rank of Commander. When the war ended, Fleming retired to Jamaica where he built a house called 'Goldeneye,' took up writing full-time and created the character that would make him famous -- British Secret Service agent James Bond, in a novel called 'Casino Royale.' Fleming spent the rest of his life writing and traveling the world, but as his Bond character reached new heights of popularity on movie screens, Fleming was in ailing health. He died of a heart attack (his second) in England in August 1964 at the age of 56. Ian Fleming 'The New York Times' (USA), 19 May 2008, Vol. 157, Iss. 54,315, pg. E1 & E6, by: John F. Burns, 'Remembering Fleming, Ian Fleming' 12 August 1964 _Goldeneye (1989) (TV)_ (qv) Cigarette (in holder) perched between fingers of his right hand 'The Times Magazine' (UK), 5 April 2008 Ian Lancaster Fleming 6' Mayfair, London, England, UK Male
Series Producer Country production country writer  Peter Fonda   'Gallery' (USA), March 1975, Vol. 3, Iss. 2, by: Steven Y. Mori, 'Peter Fonda: Easy Rider Meets the Marx Brothers' 'Susan Brewer' (qv) (8 October 1961 - 15 April 1974) (divorced); 2 children Accidentally shot himself in the stomach when he was 10. Video Game Movie Production Designer Writer actor director  Steven Soderbergh David Leitch   'Humo' (Belgium), 6 November 2001, Iss. 3192, pg. 128, 'De zwarte periode' 'Jules Asner' (qv) (10 May 2003 - present) At one point, was interested in directing _Fantastic Four (2005)_ (qv). [on if he feels he understands what audiences want] No. I've tried to get better about weighing what I think the accessibility of an idea is against the cost of executing it. I've tried to be smarter about that, because if you're not smart about that, you're going to be unemployed. But I'm still mystified about what works for people. And I'm not talking about my movies, I'm talking in general. I'm mystified by the stuff that doesn't work. I'm mystified by what's going on in the critical side, too. Stuff I like is getting trashed and stuff that is being praised I think is terrible. I don't really feel in sync with what's happening, but at the same time, what I think keeps me afloat is that I try not to be, and don't want to be, very indulgent. I try to make the films as lean as possible, and to not spend a lot of time crawling up my own ass creatively. Directed stage play, 'Geniuses', for Swine Palace Productions, Baton Rouge, LA. (1996) Soderbergh, Steven A. 14 January 1963 Steven Soderbergh was born on January 14, 1963, in Atlanta, Georgia, USA, the second of six children and, while still at a very young age, his family moved to Baton Rouge, Louisiana, where his father, 'Peter Soderbergh' (qv), was a professor and the dean of the College of Education at Louisiana State University. While still in high school, around the age of 15, Soderbergh enrolled in the university's film animation class and began making short 16-millimeter films with second-hand equipment, one of which was the short film 'Janitor'. After graduating high school, he went to Hollywood, where he worked as a freelance editor. His time there was brief and, shortly after, he returned home and continued making short films and writing scripts.  His first major break was in 1986 when the rock group 'Yes' (qv) assigned him to shoot a full-length concert film for the band, which eventually earned him a Grammy nomination for the video, _Yes: 9012 Live (1985) (V)_ (qv). Following this achievement, Soderbergh filmed _Winston (1987)_ (qv), the short-subject film that he would later expand into _Sex, Lies, and Videotape (1989)_ (qv), a film that earned him the Cannes Film Festival's Palme d'Or Award, the Independent Spirit Award for Best Director, and an Oscar nomination for Best Original Screenplay. Over the next six years, he was married to actress 'Betsy Brantley' (qv) and had a daughter named Sarah Soderbergh, who was born in 1990.  Also during this time, he made such films as _Kafka (1991)_ (qv), _King of the Hill (1993)_ (qv), _Underneath (1995)_ (qv) and _Gray's Anatomy (1996)_ (qv), which many believed to be disappointments. In 1998, Soderbergh made _Out of Sight (1998)_ (qv), his most critically and commercially successful film since _Sex, Lies, and Videotape (1989)_ (qv). Then, in 2000, Soderbergh directed two major motion pictures that are now his most successful films to date: _Erin Brockovich (2000)_ (qv) and _Traffic (2000)_ (qv). These films were both nominated for Best Picture Oscars at the 2001 Academy Awards and gave him the first twin director Oscar nomination in almost 60 years and the first ever win. He won the Oscar for Best Director for _Traffic (2000)_ (qv) at the 2001 Oscars. Steven Soderbergh 'The New York Times' (USA), 23 May 2008, Vol. 157, Iss. 54,319, pg. E1 & E8, by: A.O. Scott, 'Soderbergh and Che, Provocateurs' Frequently uses jump-cuts 'M Le Magazine du Monde' (France), 11 August 2012, Iss. 47 Steve Soderbergh 6' Atlanta, Georgia, USA Male David Leitch Dave Leitch 5' 11' Male

I thought painting, acting, directing and photography was all part of being an artist. I have made my money that way. And I have had some fun. It's not been a bad life. Episode Movie Character Director null writer  Mario Puzo   'Playboy' (USA), July 1991, Vol. 38, Iss. 7, pg. 18, by: Joan Goodman, 'Guest Shot: Mario Puzo' 'Erika Lina Broske' (1946 - 9 November 1978) (her death); 5 children Bay Shore, Long Island, New York, USA (heart failure) Was writing a story outline for a fourth 'Godfather' film before he died. The best way to launch an Italian restaurant is to have it raided because the Mafia eats there. Everybody knows they eat well. Novel: 'The Family' Puzo, Mario Gianluigi 15 October 1920 Mario Puzo was born October 15, 1920, in 'Hell's Kitchen' on Manhattan's (NY) West Side and, following military service in World War II, attended New York's New School for Social Research and Columbia University. His best-known novel, 'The Godfather,' was preceded by two critically acclaimed novels, 'The Dark Arena' and 'The Fortunate Pilgrim.' In 1978, he published 'Fools Die,' followed by 'The Sicilian' (1984) and 'The Fourth K' (1991). Mario Puzo has also written several screenplays, including _Earthquake (1974)_ (qv), _Superman (1978)_ (qv), and all three 'Godfather' movies, for which he received two Academy Awards. Mario's latest novel, 1996's 'The Last Don,' was made into a CBS television miniseries in May 1997, starring 'Danny Aiello' (qv), 'Kirstie Alley' (qv) and 'Joe Mantegna' (qv). In 1997, Part II was aired. Also in 1997, Mario's 'The Fortunate Pilgrim' was re-released by Random House. Mario passed away July 2, 1999, at his home in Bay Shore, Long Island. His last novel, 'Omerta,' will be published July, 2000. He is survived by his companion of 20 years, Carol Gino, and five children. Mario Puzo 'Di?rio de Not?cias' (Portugal), 4 July 1999, pg. 58, by: Abel Coelho de Morais, 'Morreu o autor de ?O Padrinho?' 2 July 1999 'Time' (USA), 28 August 1978 Mario Gianluigi Puzo New York City, New York, USA Male

His best-known novel, 'The Godfather,' was preceded by two critically acclaimed novels, 'The Dark Arena' and 'The Fortunate Pilgrim.' In 1978, he published 'Fools Die,' followed by 'The Sicilian' (1984) and 'The Fourth K' (1991). Episode Movie Character Director null writer  Francis Ford Coppola   'The Independent Arts & Books' (UK), 11 June 2010, Iss. 7383, pg. 10 - 11, by: Kaleem Aftab, 'It's all about the family business' 'Eleanor Coppola' (qv) (2 February 1963 - present); 3 children 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) said that he based the 'Han Solo' character from the Star Wars trilogy on Coppola. 'New York Times Magazine' (USA), 19 May 2002, pg. 26+28, by: Frank Bruni, 'In the Name of the Father' On 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv): Most directors have one masterpiece by which they are known, or possibly two. Kurosawa has at least eight or nine. Print ad for Robert Mondavi Wines. (2000) 7 April 1939 (September 2005) Visiting Istanbul for vacation. Rodney F. Hill. _Francis Ford Coppola: Interviews._ 2004. He was born in 1939 in Detroit, USA, but he grew up in a New York suburb in a creative, supportive Italian-American family. His father, 'Carmine Coppola' (qv), was a composer and musician. His mother, 'Italia Coppola' (qv), had been an actress. Francis Ford Coppola graduated with a degree in drama from Hofstra University, and did graduate work at UCLA in filmmaking. He was training as assistant with filmmaker 'Roger Corman' (qv), working in such capacities as sound-man, dialogue director, associate producer and, eventually, director of _Dementia 13 (1963)_ (qv), Coppola's first feature film. During the next four years, Coppola was involved in a variety of script collaborations, including writing an adaptation of 'This Property is Condemned' by 'Tennessee Williams' (qv) (with 'Fred Coe' (qv) and 'Edith Sommer' (qv)), and screenplays for _Paris br?le-t-il? (1966)_ (qv) and _Patton (1970)_ (qv), the film for which Coppola won a Best Original Screenplay Academy Award. In 1966, Coppola's 2nd film brought him critical acclaim and a Master of Fine Arts degree. In 1969, Coppola and 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) established American Zoetrope, an independent film production company based in San Francisco. The company's first project was _THX 1138 (1971)_ (qv), produced by Coppola and directed by Lucas. Coppola also produced the second film that Lucas directed, _American Graffiti (1973)_ (qv), in 1973. This movie got five Academy Award nominations, including one for Best Picture. In 1971, Coppola's film _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv) became one of the highest-grossing movies in history and brought him an Oscar for writing the screenplay with 'Mario Puzo' (qv) The film was a Best Picture Academy Award-winner, and also brought Coppola a Best Director Oscar nomination. Following his work on the screenplay for _The Great Gatsby (1974)_ (qv), Coppola's next film was _The Conversation (1974)_ (qv), which was honored with the Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and brought Coppola Best Picture and Best Original Screenplay Oscar nominations. Also released that year, _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), rivaled the success of _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), and won six Academy Awards, bringing Coppola Oscars as a producer, director and writer. Coppola then began work on his most ambitious film, _Apocalypse Now (1979)_ (qv), a Vietnam War epic that was inspired by 'Joseph Conrad (I)' (qv)'s _Heart of Darkness (1993) (TV)_ (qv). Released in 1979, the acclaimed film won a Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and two Academy Awards. Also that year, Coppola executive produced the hit _The Black Stallion (1979)_ (qv). With 'George Lucas (I)' (qv), Coppola executive produced _Kagemusha (1980)_ (qv), directed by 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv), and _Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)_ (qv), directed by 'Paul Schrader (I)' (qv) and based on the life and writings of 'Yukio Mishima' (qv). Coppola also executive produced such films as _The Escape Artist (1982)_ (qv), _Hammett (1982)_ (qv) _The Black Stallion Returns (1983)_ (qv), _Barfly (1987)_ (qv), _Wind (1992)_ (qv), _The Secret Garden (1993)_ (qv), etc.  He helped to make a star of his nephew, 'Nicolas Cage' (qv). Personal tragedy hit in 1986 when his son Gio died in a boating accident. Francis Ford Coppola is one of America's most erratic, energetic and controversial filmmakers. Francis Ford Coppola 'Cinema' (Greece), March 1998, Iss. 88, pg. 45, by: Yorgos Krassakopoulos, 'Skinothetis kai alla polla...' _Brando Unauthorized (2011)_ (qv) Often works with cinematographer 'Gordon Willis (I)' (qv) and producers 'Fred Roos' (qv) and 'Gray Frederickson' (qv). 'The Independent Arts & Books Review' (UK), 16 November 2007 Thomas Colchart 5' 11 1/2' Detroit, Michigan, USA Male

Country Person Video Movie country cinematographer Theodore Ashton    Theodore Ashton Ted Ashton
Country Person Video Movie country cinematographer Randall P. Dark    In 1986, Randall Dark was given the opportunity to view High Definition for the first time and knew it was the future of images. A few short years later, he founded HD Vision in New York City. The company later moved its headquarters to Dallas, then to Los Angeles. Its mandate was to specialize in the growth of High Definition, launching Dark into the position of a technological and creative visionary. An undisputed pioneer in the emerging industry, today, Randall is the creative and marketing force behind Randall Dark Productions, Inc. He received one of the International Electronic Cinema Festival's top honors: The Pioneer Award, bestowed in recognition of extraordinary contributions to the success of High Definition. He is a member of the Television Arts and Sciences Academy and is one of a select few members of the Consumer Electronics Association's Academy of Digital Pioneers, a group recognized for their efforts implementing Digital Television in the United States.  Recognized globally as an expert in emerging technologies, Randall has spoken to audiences at events including: MIPCOM, Tokyo International Film Festival, CASBAA Hong Kong, Banff World Television Festival, National Association of Broadcaster's Convention, International Electronic Cinema Festival, Infocomm, Consumer Electronic Show, HDExpo, World Television Forum, creaTVty Zurich, Canadian Association of Broadcasters Convention, Hollywood Post Alliance, New York State Bar Association, Bear Stearns Media Conference, NATPE and Playback Forum (Toronto) where he served as the Keynote Speaker.  Dark and his companies have been involved in over 2000 HD projects including feature films, documentaries, commercials, music videos, corporate presentations, product launches and live events.  In 2007, the Maxell Corporation presented Dark its Independent Filmmaker Award for Achievement made during the making of 'Closing Escrow'. HD Programs directed by Dark have also received awards from CEA, Telly, IECF, Communicator, Aurora, Axiem, WorldFest Houston International Film Festival, Videographer, The American Corporate Video Awards and Cinema Chicago. Randall P. Dark 'TV Technology' (USA), 26 July 2010, by: John Merli, 'A 3D Ode to the Smokies'

Country Person Video Movie country cinematographer   Mark A. Catalena aka name Mark A. Catalena Mark Catalena
Country Person Video Movie country cinematographer  Larry McConkey   Larry McConkey Larry McKonkey
Country Person Video Movie country cinematographer James Glennon    29 August 1942 'Charmaine Witus' (1977 - 19 October 2006) (his death); 4 children American cinematographer and something of a Renaissance man. The son of famed cinematographer 'Bert Glennon' (qv), James Glennon and his brothers learned photography at their father's feet. (Their mother was script supervisor 'Mary Coleman (II)' (qv).) James Glennon began work in the Warner Bros. mail room, where he often was assigned to make deliveries to studio head 'Jack L. Warner' (qv) because the other mail clerks were afraid of Warner. Warner advised Glennon to buy a motion picture camera and rent it out, offering his own services for free. Glennon did so, and thus initiated his career as a cinematographer with _Jaws of Death (1977)_ (qv). He continued to work as a camera operator on other cinematographers' films, including _The Conversation (1974)_ (qv), _Ordinary People (1980)_ (qv), and _Altered States (1980)_ (qv), before coming to notice as cinematographer on the groundbreaking _El Norte (1983)_ (qv). He worked steadily thereafter. He filmed _My Wicked, Wicked Ways: The Legend of Errol Flynn (1985) (TV)_ (qv), the story of the actor his own father had photographed in four films. He partnered with director 'Alexander Payne (I)' (qv) on three films: _Citizen Ruth (1996)_ (qv), _Election (1999)_ (qv), and _About Schmidt (2002)_ (qv). He won an Emmy Award in 2005 for an episode of _'Deadwood' (2004)_ (qv), the Western series for which he was principal cinematographer for its entire run. He had widely varied interests. He served repeatedly as a judge in the Nicholl Fellowship in Screenwriting of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences. He operated Malibu Water Resources, a water aeration program, and he farmed clams in the Pacific Northwest. He was extraordinarily beloved of his crews and casts for his eternal optimism and unstinting praise and encouragement. He died unexpectedly on October 19, 2006, from a blood clot resulting from surgery for prostate cancer. James Glennon 19 October 2006 Los Angeles, California, USA (blood clot following surgery for prostate cancer) Had been a member of the American Society of Cinematographers (ASC) since 1994. James Michael Glennon Los Angeles, California, USA Male Glennon, James Michael
Country Person Video Movie country cinematographer David Boyd    'Barbara Crampton' (qv) (1 October 1988 - 1990) (divorced) David Boyd First husband of 'Barbara Crampton' (qv). David R. Boyd
Country Person Video Movie country cinematographer Robert Draper    'Fangoria Horror Spectacular' (USA), 1991, Iss. 4, pg. 10-13, by: Mark Cerulli, 'Lighting the Crypt' With more than 35 years experience in Film and Television, Rob has worked on everything from Regional TV News to Hollywood Feature Films.  Known as a technical innovator and creative risk taker in the industry he has pioneered many new techniques and worked on development of motion picture products for SONY, Panasonic, Fuji Film, Arri and Zeiss. Rob was also the first to run a full scale Hi Definition shoot in Hollywood on the then 'new gen' camera's.  Rob set the style for what has become known as Reality TV in a groundbreaking series he shot for Universal called 'The Street'...after which the New York Times declared 'the show practically creates a new visual language'. Rob also worked on some of the first Music Videos used to promote feature Films and developed a visual style for using promotional music videos for retailing in a 5 minute Hollywood extravaganza for Coca Cola.  Rob's photography on the Sundance Audience award winner, The Spitfire Grill, drew accolades worldwide.  Rob draws inspiration from the classic painters and his skilled and delicate use of light and shade as integral elements of composition sets his work apart. Over the past 20 years he has inspired thousand of cinematographers worldwide as a dynamic instructor at workshops, and as a consultant, on the art of film lighting  More recently he has been on the cutting edge of digital technology on the web with his groundbreaking IPTV channel Singlemalt TV. Launched in 2006 it immediately drew attention and a long relationship with major media players in UK.  Rob has worked worldwide on TV movies,Feature Films,Mini Series,TV series documentaries, TV Commercials and Music Videos. He has worked for every major Hollywood studio and US TV Network claiming multiple Awards in both Australia and the United States. Robert Draper 'Imagine News' (USA), June 2002, by: 'Eric Harper (I)' (qv), 'Rob Draper: New England Cinematography on the Cutting Edge' 'Imagine News' (USA), June 2002 Male

Composer  Joel Goldsmith birth notes gender death date name trivia mini biography birth date death notes 19 November 1957 One of six children of the legendary composer 'Jerry Goldsmith' (qv), and the oldest son, Joel Goldsmith's own career in film scoring began in 1978, when he collaborated with 'Richard Band' (qv) on the score for _Laserblast (1978)_ (qv). Joel Goldsmith next worked as sound mixer for another Band project, _The Day Time Ended (1979)_ (qv) before receiving his first solo scoring assignment, _Olivia (1983)_ (qv), for cult German director 'Ulli Lommel' (qv). The stylish synthesizer score Goldsmith provided was succeeded by dozens more for film and TV, including _The Man with Two Brains (1983)_ (qv) and _Man's Best Friend (1993)_ (qv). His electronic expertise came in handy when he co-produced father Jerry's first all-electronic score, _Runaway (1984)_ (qv), and helped in the same capacity for Jerry's theme from _Hoosiers (1986)_ (qv). Joel also scored episodes of the TV series _'H.E.L.P.' (1990)_ (qv), for which Jerry wrote the original theme; and Joel composed some 20 minutes of additional music (with credit) for his father's 1996 assignment _Star Trek: First Contact (1996)_ (qv).  Joel Goldsmith composed his first symphonic score, for 'Roland Emmerich' (qv)'s _Moon 44 (1990)_ (qv), in 1990. Surprisingly, this sweeping score did not lead to more similar assignments; but, in recent years, Joel Goldsmith's profile has been boosted in recent years with assignments such as TV's _Vampirella (1996) (V)_ (qv) and the 1997 cult hit _Kull the Conqueror (1997)_ (qv), another big, bold symphonic score which helped nab him the assignment _Shadow of Doubt (1998)_ (qv). Most recently, he has been the chief composer for the TV shows _'Stargate SG-1' (1997)_ (qv) and _'Stargate: Atlantis' (2004)_ (qv). While Joel's style is recognizably similar to his father's (he seems to have a particular love for Jerry's _The Wind and the Lion (1975)_ (qv)), it is recognizably distinct, which observers of the film music scene believe can only continue to ripen. Joel Goldsmith 29 April 2012 Hidden Hills, California, USA (cancer) Son of 'Jerry Goldsmith' (qv) Los Angeles, California, USA Male

Composer  Tim Truman name mini biography Tim Truman  The musical life of Tim Truman started with the world of percussion. He immersed himself in rhythm winning awards all through his early school years topping it off with the 'Best Musician in California' at the Hollywood Bowl. His college studies began to change as it was not enough for the exploratory musician. He shifted his focus to original musical composition. He was accepted into the coveted USC composition department. From there he began scoring prime-time network television. George Lucas and Francis Ford Coppola selected Tim Truman to complete the score to the 70 mm 3D Disneyland feature 'Captain EO' Starring Michael Jackson. Michael Mann hand picked Tim to replace Jan Hammer on his hit show 'Miami Vice' scoring the entire fifth season. The Michael Mann directed movie 'LA Takedown' was next gathering strong reviews. Tim then composed the original Main Title theme to 'Melrose Place' going on to score over 120+ episodes of that world wide hit. Oliver Stone asked Tim to score the controversial film 'South Central' with a full orchestra for Warner Brothers. The television and features continued with an EMMY nomination for the Main Title Theme to 'Central Park West'. The entire debut season of 'Charmed' was in Tim's hands as well. Tim has been honored with several ASCAP, Gold and Platinum album and video awards. Tim Truman won an EMMY as a co-producer on 'The Killer Whale People' with Nancy Wilson (Heart). He then Executive produced 'One World' with Olivia Newton John garnering five EMMY nominations. SHOWTIME brought in Tim to score all 35 hour episodes of 'Jeremiah' created by J. Michael Strazensky (Babylon 5). The pull to tell compelling stories, rather then just support them musically, has become central in the evolving career of Tim Truman. The fifteen million dollar original feature 'Touch of Grace' is preparing to film in 2013 with Tim at the helm. Always a believer in truth Tim is bringing to the screen a powerful story about a single mother protecting her only child, Grace, as her own mental state is deteriorating. 'Touch of Grace' is humorous, filled with humanity, tragedy, but with ultimate redemption. With thousands of productions guiding his focus, an unwavering eye for truth, Tim Truman continues to expand the possibilities of tomorrow. Tim Truman

Composer  Hans Zimmer gender other works trivia spouse article quotes interviews birth notes aka name trade mark birth name mini biography birth date 'Empire' (UK), 1995, Iss. 77, pg. 58, by: Caroline Westbrook 'Vicki Carolin' (19 March 1982 - 7 April 1992) (divorced); 1 child December 2003 - Hans' longtime business partner, 'Jay Rifkin' (qv), filed a $10 million suit against him for conspiring to take business for himself. Due to this lawsuit Media Ventures changed its name to Remote Control. I have all these computers and keyboards and synthesizers, and I rattle away. For instance, with The Lion King I wrote over four hours' worth of tunes, and they were really pretty --but totally meaningless. So in the end I came up with material I liked. We worked on The Lion King for four years, but I wasn't toying until the last three-and-a-half weeks properly. On Crimson Tide, on the other hand, I just went in and within seconds I knew what I wanted. He produced the song 'History Of The World (Part 1)' by British punk band The Damned for their fourth LP 'The Black Album'. TV Movie Country Person actor country  Steve Zahn   'Premiere' (USA), February 1997, Vol. 10, Iss. 6, pg. 35, by: Oliver Jones 'Robyn Peterman' (qv) (16 July 1994 - present); 2 children Graduated from Cooper High School, New Hope, Minnesota. [2007 quote] I've had more people come up to me about _Saving Silverman (2001)_ (qv) than anything else. That and _That Thing You Do! (1996)_ (qv) but 'Saving Silverman' is the one I get most often. And I love that. It's just funny that it didn't do that well in theaters. It did all right, but none of us were big stars at the time. 'Jason Biggs (I)' (qv) was probably bigger than any of us. That's another one that kind of baffles me. So many people have seen it. I got this big Western coming out. I have another crazy comedy that I really like, _Strange Wilderness (2008)_ (qv). It's just fucking dumb, and I can't wait to see how people react, because I just know that I'll have people approach me and say 'Strange Wilderness, man. That's my favorite movie'. I'll love that. Zahn, Steven James 13 November 1967 Career kicked off in his native Minnesota when he crashed the audition of a local stage production of 'Biloxi Blues' and won the lead role. Next trained at American Repertory Theatre in Cambridge, MA; then moved to New York City where he won a role touring for 13 months in national company of 'Tommy Tune' (qv)-directed version of 'Bye Bye Birdie'. TV Movie Country Person actor country Trey Parker    'Reason' (USA), December 2006, Vol. 38, Iss. 7, pg. 58-66, by: Nick Gillespie and Jesse Walker, 'South Park Libertarians: Trey Parker and Matt Stone on Liberals, Conservatives, Censorship, and Religion' 'Emma Sugiyama' (January 2006 - 2008) (divorced) Has a black belt in tae kwan do. (On _'That's My Bush!' (2001)_ (qv)): 'A lot of people didn't get it. I didn't get it myself'. (2011) Co-director with Casey Nicholaw of the Tony Award-nominated musical 'The Book of Mormon,' for which he also wrote the book and composed the score in collaboration with Matt Stone. III, Randolph Severn Parker 19 October 1969 (February 2005) Began working on beginning of season 9 of _'South Park' (1997)_ (qv) Trey was born in Conifer, Colorado, on October 19, 1969 to 'Randy Parker (I)' (qv) ,a geologist, and Sharon Parker, an insurance broker. He has an older sister, Shelley Parker. He met 'Matt Stone (I)' (qv) (co-creator of _'South Park' (1997)_ (qv)) while attending the University of Colorado in Boulder, where he had a double major of music and Japanese. While at UCB he wrote, directed and starred in _Alferd Packer: The Musical (1993)_ (qv) (aka 'Cannibal: The Musical!') based on a true episode in Colorado's history. After graduation from UCB (rumors that he didn't due to skipping classes to work on the movie are false), he and Stone were asked by then-FoxLab executive 'Brian Graden' (qv) to create an animated Christmas card for his friends and family. The now infamous short, titled _The Spirit of Christmas (1995)_ (qv), led to _'South Park' (1997)_ (qv). Trey Parker 'Playboy' (USA), October 1998, Vol. 45, Iss. 10, pg. 87+148, by: Steve Pond, 'Porno For Tyros' Often works alongside Matt Stone Randolph Severn Parker III 6' 1' Conifer, Colorado, USA Male

TV Movie Country Person actor country The Muppets    The Muppets Jim Henson's Muppets Male (March 2012) A video called 'Muppets vs. Goldman Sachs' on FunnyorDie.com with some of 'The Muppets' (qv), 'Kyle MacLachlan' (qv) and 'Neal McDonough' (qv) spoofing public claims by an ex-employee of Goldman Sachs that Goldman Sachs refers to its' clients as Muppets. The video also featured 'Stephen Glickman' (qv), 'Richard Riehle' (qv), 'John Mawson (II)' (qv), 'Darri Ingolfsson' (qv), 'Luke Barnett (II)' (qv), and 'Adam Lustick' (qv).

Video Game Movie Producer Director actress editor   Samantha Bond Joel Cox birth notes gender aka name trivia birth name mini biography birth date 27 November 1961 'Alexander Hanson' (qv) (? - present); 2 children Samantha Bond Sister of 'Abigail Bond' (qv) 5' 6 1/2' 'As for 'Daniel Craig (I)' (qv) as Bond, I think it is an absolutely brilliant choice. He is butch, male, attractive and a bloody good actor. He was by far the most plausible choice' [on _Casino Royale (2006)_ (qv)]. London, England, UK Female (August 1988) She acted in 'William Shakespeare (I)' (qv)'s play, 'Much Ado About Nothing', in a Renaissance Theatre Company production during the Renaissance Shakespeare Festival at the Phoenix Theatre in London, England with 'Kenneth Branagh' (qv), Samantha Bond, 'Richard Easton (II)' (qv), 'Edward Jewesbury' (qv), 'David Lloyd Meredith' (qv), 'Dearbhla Molloy' (qv), 'David Parfitt' (qv), 'Shaun Prendergast' (qv), 'Sophie Thompson (I)' (qv), 'Jay Villiers' (qv) and 'Jimmy Yuill' (qv) in the cast. 'Judi Dench' (qv) was the director. 2 April 1942 Joel Cox was born c. 1941 and his film career began at a very early age - appearing before the cameras, in fact - as a baby in the film 'Random Harvest'. Some twenty years later he began work as a mail-room boy with Warner Brothers, the company with whom he has worked ever since, and in 1969 moved into the cutting-room, as an uncredited assistant editor on 'Woodstock' and 'The Wild Bunch'. He was a credited assistant on 'The Outlaw Josey Wales', working for the first time with Clint Eastwood. A durable collaboration followed with Cox cutting all films made by Eastwood since. Joel Cox He credits 'Ferris Webster' (qv) and 'Walter Thompson (I)' (qv) as being his greatest mentors, followed by 'Sam O'Steen' (qv). Joel Edward Cox Los Angeles, California, USA Male Cox, Joel Edward

Crew Member Movie Episode references director Francis Ford Coppola    'The Independent Arts & Books' (UK), 11 June 2010, Iss. 7383, pg. 10 - 11, by: Kaleem Aftab, 'It's all about the family business' 'Eleanor Coppola' (qv) (2 February 1963 - present); 3 children 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) said that he based the 'Han Solo' character from the Star Wars trilogy on Coppola. 'New York Times Magazine' (USA), 19 May 2002, pg. 26+28, by: Frank Bruni, 'In the Name of the Father' On 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv): Most directors have one masterpiece by which they are known, or possibly two. Kurosawa has at least eight or nine. Print ad for Robert Mondavi Wines. (2000) 7 April 1939 (September 2005) Visiting Istanbul for vacation. Rodney F. Hill. _Francis Ford Coppola: Interviews._ 2004. He was born in 1939 in Detroit, USA, but he grew up in a New York suburb in a creative, supportive Italian-American family. His father, 'Carmine Coppola' (qv), was a composer and musician. His mother, 'Italia Coppola' (qv), had been an actress. Francis Ford Coppola graduated with a degree in drama from Hofstra University, and did graduate work at UCLA in filmmaking. He was training as assistant with filmmaker 'Roger Corman' (qv), working in such capacities as sound-man, dialogue director, associate producer and, eventually, director of _Dementia 13 (1963)_ (qv), Coppola's first feature film. During the next four years, Coppola was involved in a variety of script collaborations, including writing an adaptation of 'This Property is Condemned' by 'Tennessee Williams' (qv) (with 'Fred Coe' (qv) and 'Edith Sommer' (qv)), and screenplays for _Paris br?le-t-il? (1966)_ (qv) and _Patton (1970)_ (qv), the film for which Coppola won a Best Original Screenplay Academy Award. In 1966, Coppola's 2nd film brought him critical acclaim and a Master of Fine Arts degree. In 1969, Coppola and 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) established American Zoetrope, an independent film production company based in San Francisco. The company's first project was _THX 1138 (1971)_ (qv), produced by Coppola and directed by Lucas. Coppola also produced the second film that Lucas directed, _American Graffiti (1973)_ (qv), in 1973. This movie got five Academy Award nominations, including one for Best Picture. In 1971, Coppola's film _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv) became one of the highest-grossing movies in history and brought him an Oscar for writing the screenplay with 'Mario Puzo' (qv) The film was a Best Picture Academy Award-winner, and also brought Coppola a Best Director Oscar nomination. Following his work on the screenplay for _The Great Gatsby (1974)_ (qv), Coppola's next film was _The Conversation (1974)_ (qv), which was honored with the Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and brought Coppola Best Picture and Best Original Screenplay Oscar nominations. Also released that year, _The Godfather: Part II (1974)_ (qv), rivaled the success of _The Godfather (1972)_ (qv), and won six Academy Awards, bringing Coppola Oscars as a producer, director and writer. Coppola then began work on his most ambitious film, _Apocalypse Now (1979)_ (qv), a Vietnam War epic that was inspired by 'Joseph Conrad (I)' (qv)'s _Heart of Darkness (1993) (TV)_ (qv). Released in 1979, the acclaimed film won a Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and two Academy Awards. Also that year, Coppola executive produced the hit _The Black Stallion (1979)_ (qv). With 'George Lucas (I)' (qv), Coppola executive produced _Kagemusha (1980)_ (qv), directed by 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv), and _Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)_ (qv), directed by 'Paul Schrader (I)' (qv) and based on the life and writings of 'Yukio Mishima' (qv). Coppola also executive produced such films as _The Escape Artist (1982)_ (qv), _Hammett (1982)_ (qv) _The Black Stallion Returns (1983)_ (qv), _Barfly (1987)_ (qv), _Wind (1992)_ (qv), _The Secret Garden (1993)_ (qv), etc.  He helped to make a star of his nephew, 'Nicolas Cage' (qv). Personal tragedy hit in 1986 when his son Gio died in a boating accident. Francis Ford Coppola is one of America's most erratic, energetic and controversial filmmakers. Francis Ford Coppola 'Cinema' (Greece), March 1998, Iss. 88, pg. 45, by: Yorgos Krassakopoulos, 'Skinothetis kai alla polla...' _Brando Unauthorized (2011)_ (qv) Often works with cinematographer 'Gordon Willis (I)' (qv) and producers 'Fred Roos' (qv) and 'Gray Frederickson' (qv). 'The Independent Arts & Books Review' (UK), 16 November 2007 Thomas Colchart 5' 11 1/2' Detroit, Michigan, USA Male
Crew Member Movie Episode references director  Francis Ford Coppola   'The Independent Arts & Books' (UK), 11 June 2010, Iss. 7383, pg. 10 - 11, by: Kaleem Aftab, 'It's all about the family business' 'Eleanor Coppola' (qv) (2 February 1963 - present); 3 children 'George Lucas (I)' (qv) said that he based the 'Han Solo' character from the Star Wars trilogy on Coppola. Released in 1979, the acclaimed film won a Golden Palm Award at the Cannes Film Festival, and two Academy Awards. Also that year, Coppola executive produced the hit _The Black Stallion (1979)_ (qv). With 'George Lucas (I)' (qv), Coppola executive produced _Kagemusha (1980)_ (qv), directed by 'Akira Kurosawa' (qv), and _Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)_ (qv), directed by 'Paul Schrader (I)' (qv) and based on the life and writings of 'Yukio Mishima' (qv). Coppola also executive produced such films as _The Escape Artist (1982)_ (qv), _Hammett (1982)_ (qv) _The Black Stallion Returns (1983)_ (qv), _Barfly (1987)_ (qv), _Wind (1992)_ (qv), _The Secret Garden (1993)_ (qv), etc.  He helped to make a star of his nephew, 'Nicolas Cage' (qv). Personal tragedy hit in 1986 when his son Gio died in a boating accident. Francis Ford Coppola is one of America's most erratic, energetic and controversial filmmakers.
